reviews.review: Eclectic and aristocratic place. Recoleta is one of the most traditional tours of Buenos Aires. You will find a beautiful church over 150 years, the traditional cemetery, museums, parks and a great gastronomic offer

Style and refinement. Have you ever considered to visit a cementery? Believe it or not, it's and enjoyable walk where you can see strange funerary monuments and listen to unexpected stories about the people buried there. There's also a cultural centre with interesting exhibitions, coffee shops, a crafts fair and much more.

Over Hyped. We were really excited about staying in this area- We stayed at an amazing hotel but quickly found that we missed Palermo, where we had stayed the previous three nights. Recoleta is boring comparatively. The shopping is not as good, the restaurants serve all the same food and it is really more of a one day thing instead of stretching it over a few like we did. The indoor mall was nothing special and the cemetery was not nearly as cool as the ones I've seen in Prague, Vienna and New Orleans.
Nice place to go,. See museums, fashion, design mall, Eva Peron's grave in the cemetery, and very trendy nice neighborhood.

A lot of history but not for wveryone. Wandering aimlessly through Recoleta's city of the dead, I quickly started to wonder why we'd come here.Marked as one of Buenos Aires top attractions, the Recoleta's is packed with history (very little of which will reveal itself to you without a knowledgeable guide). Navigating your way round is not straightforward (if you are seeking out certain tombs you'll need to know beforehand which direction to head).This is one of Buenos Aires' peculiarities for tourists in a city that is not overburdened with landmarks. Nevertheless, it is somewhere that should be left to the dead and their families for all but the most informed and inquisitive of visitors.
Marvelous place. Very interesting stories to heart about if you get a tour with a guide! Unforgetable experiance from the place!

Exquisite neighborhood. Recoleta Mall is indoor and immediately across from the famous Recoleta cemetery. Many restaurants and bars line the streets on all sides around the cemetery. Weekends the area is alive with people enjoying the food and music. The food selection will suit all palates. Fun place and especially safe. Buenos Aires comes alive in the evenings and weekends. The 'portenos' (people of BA) love to live life. Awesome atmosphere. Be willing to walk and explore to become part of this culture.
Interesting area.. The cemetery is interesting to visit, there is a market most weekends and lots of pavement cafes to enjoy lunch in the warm sunshine.Well worth a couple of hours to visit.
Nice neighborhood. Recoleta is a very nice and safe neighborhood where you can find the most famous cemetery in Buenos Aires. Definitely worth the visit.

Where to stay in BA. Can't comment on other locales in BA but was very happy we landed here. Did all the usual intertnet searches and made the leap and stayed in Recoleta area. Safe , close to tourist sites, good shopping and excellent dining, Enhanced our enjoyment of our visit.
Wonderful, diverse neighborhood. We visited with both a van tour and a walking tour for different perspectives. Both were extremely interesting
Lovely place to wander.... Spent many afternoons with coffee or gelato wandering the side streets of recoleta. Very nice.. some beautiful antique shops!

Very very posh suburb. Smart, up market locals wandering around with their dogs window shopping in chic boutique's many 'dog Wallers's with 10-12 dogs on leashes, plus elderly rich ladies with small chic shopping bags.

The manhattan of BsAs, a great home base for tourists. Recoleta is a great place for a hotel or Airbnb because it's central to many of the best attractions of the city. Plaza de mayo/casa rosada, the cemetario, the obelisk, teatro colón and many museums are all within walking distance. There also loads of buses and Linea D on the Subte runs up and down Santa Fe. For all the benefits, it's a bit stodgy. To find the cool, head to Palermo.

A great place to spend time when in Buenos Aires. I had a few hours to kill before flying home. I spent time walking around BA and a good portion of this in the Recoleta area. It is a lovely area, full of history and definitely one that a visitor to BA must visit to feel some of the history of the area.

Used to be much better. Lot of businesses have closed and those that are left are hungry for tourist dollars and will play all sorts of games to attract your attention. Still a handful of good restaurants and bars but a significant decline from how it used to be 10+ years ago... The cemetery is worth a visit.

The place to stay . Beautiful area, safe, near everything or a quick cab ride away. Delightful dining and sightseeing nearby. Friendly people throughout the area in shops and restaurants. Highly recommend this neighborhood.

Shabby chic . The area is interesting to wander around although more shabby than chic Pavement is broken up in most places so care not to trip Cemetery is main attraction but just past it is a wonderful old church and down the hill a short stroll to the art gallery which we enjoyed a lot . DONT buy post-cards as there is nowhere to post them - also there is a local stamp scam where they get you to buy expensive DHL stamps and there is no place to post them We were told Argentina does not have a functional postal service!

Impressive cemetery in beautiful quarter. Recoleta is a beautiful quarter to walk through and be amazed about the beautiful houses. Nice to see the students earning some money by walking with a group of sometimes more than 10 dogs. The highlight however is the cemetery with small houses in which the family members are buried. Evita's tomb is a must but not very special.

Great place to wander around. This is a very nice area to walk around. Parks, restaurants and cafes, up market shops and buildings. Felt very safe also. Make sure you visit the cemetery, and the little church next to it

I understand that there are people buried here who are not Eva Peron. Gorgeous mausolea. Every mausoleum in there would be the highlight of any other cemetery - and this place is packed with them!
Beautiful, engaging, tranquil.
I'd have stayed all day if my companion hadn't started to whine.
Bring your camera.

Highlight of BA. One of the highlights in Buenos Aires.
Very interresting place to visite. Good to get a map, cementery is not so big but you get lost easily.
Note: Evitas grave is not so visible.

Rich area of BA. You can see how the upper class lived a few short years ago. Magnificent architecture on display as well as many restaurants and businesses. A few parks and statues as well as art galleries and museums. A must see part of BA.
Unusual Cemetry. Has to be seen because of all the masoleums. They are grand. Also Eva Peron is buried here. We had to buy a map to find her masoleum and it was worth it.

Barrio. . This area is predominantly for the more well off, not the most well off. We found the area safe and easy to navigate. Wide streets, good signs and heaps of shops of all description. Most expensive around the cemetery. Local market on the weekend which was huge and many people picnicking on the grass. Tourist info stall near the cemetery which was helpful. Lots of arty places nearby. Recommended.

Walk among the rich. This is one of the most rich neighbourhoods of Buenos Aires and a must when in the city. Most of the buildings in the area are European and Vatican styled constructions which are either owned by rich families or embassies of various countriea such as France, Brazil etc. Each building is unique and a pleausre to observe. It also houses the biggest hotel in Buenos Aires.

A city for the dead. I loved this place, it had a sense of quiet and reverence. You can look up famous people by name and find their tombs. I like Father Fahy's tomb and of course Eva Peron. Good to look up the history of Buenos Aires' leaders before you go. Some tombs are very extravagant other are plain but all are beautiful in their own way.
Nice!. nice area and much to see there. many good cafes and restaurants. a must is the Hippie Market on the weekends

Nice little street market. There where a few street performers playing interesting music and a good number of stalls selling a variety of goods. When you travel you frequently see the same "stuff" over and over again. However here there are different items for sale, unquie crafts and items. It is a good way to watch the time go by.
Beautiful Neighborhood. Upscale neighborhood with hotels, restaurants, and shops. The neighborhood is adjacent to the Recoleta Cemetery where the wealthy and famous of Argentine society are buried.

Paris of South America. We were totally captivated by this area of Buenos Aires - it really does have something of the sense of Paris - with its wonderful examples of French architecture. This area has some great coffee, shopping and Galleries - Recoleta Cemetery, Cultural centre, dont miss the wonderful Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes, walking distance to other sights or a short taxi ride to San Telmo or Palermo. So central and definitely an excellent base.

High life in Buenos Aires. After visiting Recoleta you understand why Buenos Aires is named Paris of Latin America. Wonderful streets with splendid buildings serving as luxury residence, embassy or top class hotels and shops. And, even if there is a kind of similarity with Paris, you still feel that you are in Buenos Aires and understand why this city is so amazing! Don't leave it without visiting Recoleta!
Beautiful!. Looks and feels like Paris, but with the great Argentinan flare! The people here are lovely and helpful!

Lovely cemetery . Who is who in Argentine Society and history is buried here. Unless you read up I recommend on it take a guide who stand at the entry and who will walk you around and take you to the highlights, we once had a guide who showed us all the Masonic inspired cenotaphs. Evita is buried here.

The Beverly Hills of Buenos Aires. This place is so Classy, with luxurious homes and hotels. Upscale shops like those on Rodeo Drive or Fifth Ave. I stayed at the beautiful Palacio Duhau Park Hyatt and I did not want my visit to end.

Feels like Paris, but ITS BUENOS AIRES !. Taking a walk along the beautiful streets of LA RECOLETA is a living experience of the glorious past ( and present ! ) of my favorite town... just take your time to picture those splendid facades, houses built after Budapest and Paris, sip a cup of the best coffee, enjoy great restaurants and just seat to see time go by ! Thats Buenos Aires, einfach Buenos Aires !
The best place to rest forever. Nice cemetery, great place to wander and photograph, some of the best mausoleums are in this place, lots of important figures are resting here, among them, Eva Peron
Great. Loved this neighborhhod, very safe and full of things to do during the day and the night as well great time spent here

Beverly Hills of Argentina. The Recoleta area of Buenos Aires is a beautiful and interesting place to spend some time. You can visit the tomb of Evita Perron or still the lovely streets and parks. There is good shopping and great architecture. We stayed in this area where you feel safe walking around day or evening and there is lots to see

Interesting architecture . We spent an afternoon walking around Recoleta. There are some lovely shops and equally interesting architecture. Yu can understand why some refer to Buenos Aires as the Paris of the south.

Argentinian Immigrants Traditional way of living!. Without doubts the most elegant area to live and to shop in the capital ! Full of small fine caffeés and beautiful shops, there is a large number of embassys in this area aswell as the French Society Club, the Headquarters of the European Union and large number of argentinian assiciantions. VERY nice but expensive area to live ;)

a beautiful place. The mall, plaza, the Hard Rock coffee, craft fair, the cemetery ... all together in a delightful neighborhood to walk and enjoy every one of its attractions. At lunchtime many bars and restaurants offer menus and drinks for everyone. A beautiful place!!!!
Beuatiful Buenos Aires neighborhood. Recoleta is a beautiful upscale and vibrant neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Wonderful steak restaurants and night life.

Great neighborhood. Beautiful neighborhood. Especially worth visiting the flea market on the weekends. Selling great home made arts and crafts and other interesting items. Next door is the cemetery of the rich and famous where families are buried in above ground crypts. A bit unnerving seeing all the coffins. Burial site of Evita (Eva Peron).
Great neighborhood for your base in BA. Great neighborhood with shops, restaurants and entertainment. Cemetery is definetely worth a visit as is the craft fair on the weekend.

Lived there for 2 months. Loved the cafes, the small town atmosphere, the warmth of the people who lived there, the friendliness of the servers at the cafes who worked there, the safety of the area, the very good restaurants.
It is my favourite place in BA!

A worthy visit. Umming and Arghing whether or not to visit a cemetery.. Generally not my vibe..However, we were walking to Palermo Soho, and thought we'd drop on by..Wow...Amazed at the lengths people will go to to shrine themselves..Hundreds of fancy mausoleums line narrow alleyways, some restored some breaking apart...some filled with entire families others just with themselves.. If you have an hour to spare go for a wander..
lot of shops... love the area. lot of shops with good quality. to walk around and see the amazing architecture.......

worth a visit. visited as part of the day tour of Buenos Aires. It was worth a visit. In addition to the most visited tomb of Evita, there were other interesting tombs of notable generals and those from large and notable families in the golden days of Argentina.

Beautiful area. This is a lovely area to explore. Nice streets. Nice eateries. Shopping areas and parks etc. definitely need to dedicate a day or two to exploring the Recoleta area. Beware of the pigeons though, they are very confident!
Gracious. A lovely old part of town with gracious buildings and squares. A good and safe place to walk around on a Sunday morning

Recoleta. Is one of the most visited places by tourists, you can gon with Toiristic Bus also, and there you will find the beautiful Park and also the Historical Bar/rest La Biela buit more than 100 tears ago.
Place is near all kind of activities as museums, restaurants, shopping malls, Church of Cementery and recoletás Historical Cementery

Old and artistic!. The cemetery was artistic and beautiful! I felt a bit spooky but the visit was worth. The cemetry is adjecent to an old, old cathedral which is so beautiful! A lot of love to those monks and priests who came to this land and tried to give God's words to local people in 16, 17 century ♡~
Morning tour . Great tour! Lots of walking. Lots of places to see and take pictures. And lots of great stories. About past and present
Great neighbourhood. I rented a flat in Recoleta and I don't regret it. It's well located, very safe even at night. There is everything you need in Recoleta.

"LIved" in Recoleta for 1 month and LOVED it. This is a terrific area of BA and we rented a place for a month, while working and exploring the city. It's close to many parks, activities and you have every type of shop, food, products at your finger tips just a walk away. IT was a true pleasure to stay here.
Beautiful neighborhood. Recoleta is a beautiful neighborhood to walk around. It offers a very different flavor from Palermo, and the architecture is great.

Nice Neighborhood. We decided to visit on our last day in BA, and we were very glad to do so. Although the neighborhood is nice and safe, I expected more from the architecture. Taking the metro was very easy, as the yellow line takes you very close to the cemetery.

Wonderful area to visit. main reason to visit here was to see the cemetery which is quite incredible, with hardly one mausoleum being the same as another. There are many hotels in this area also and good restaurants.

Wonderful visit with a private tour guide, Simon. We were going to tour on our own but met a private tour guide at the entrance and had a wonderful, fact filled tour. We spent over an hour seeing some amazing mausoleums and statues. We would have missed so many details without Simon's keen knowledge of the cemetery. Fantastic!

Lovely neighborhood for walking. It's a wonderful neighborhood to take in all the sights as well as dine and shop. We just loved the Cemetary, Museo Bella Artes and wandering through all the streets. We even walked to the pedestrian street, Florida, from here.

A must see. Great area to visit. Go for a walk anytime of day. Enjoy a visit to the Alvear Palace Hotel or the Four Seasons Duhau. I highly recommend a guided tour to the cemetery, yes, I am not kidding. Beautiful sculptures, lots of history.

Classy area of BA. Beautiful classy part of the city with the some of the gay bars based here. The famous Evita cemetery is here along with the high society like roads - often compared to a petit Paris.

Cream of the crop of Buenos Aires’ neighborhoods.. What is realy worth seeing is a Recoleta Cementary. Lots of tombs, resting places of famous argetinian families. If you are in the mood for culture you can enjoy Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. You can also just relax in green parks (near Plaza Francia) and spend nice time in the evening in small bars.
Historic Recoleta. Recoleta is an area of historical and architectural interest where the rich upper class live ... Amazing buildings, rich in history ... Stunning shop fronts.

Petit Paris in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is well known for being the high society neighbourhood in Buenos Aires and for its vibrant nightlife.But you'll enjoy walking around in daytime too.Apart from the obvious attractions, like the cemetery with a real who's who of Argentina's past and the great museums (don't miss the Fine Arts one, with a small but important collection and always attractive exhibitions), Recoleta shows an array of French-style buildings worth the detour.Start by the French embassy itself, an icon of the city, just around a small beautiful square surrounded by other beautiful buildings like the Brazilian embassy, the Jockey Club (where you can have lunch if you were a tie and jacket) and an array of little Paris houses and buildings.Walk down Arroyo Street, with its S-shaped shadowy look, full of art galleries, every one with a small treasury hidden in a corner. It end towards one of the most beautifull unknown architecture treasuries of Buenos Aires: the Estrugamou Palace, an amazing rental building of the early 20th century. If you're lucky, on of its tenants will invite you to visit inside. Don't miss the chance.To the north you have the quintessentially Parisian avenue: Alvear, showing how the high class of earlier Buenos Aires liked to show tiself and its power: the Vatican embassy, the Building of the Academies, the Culture Ministry were all family owned houses.A special word for the hotels built on old palacettes: the Hyatt at the Duhau's (don't miss the unexepect hilly gardens inside), the Four Seasons at the Alzaga Unzue's and the Sofitel at the Bencich's.You can visit Recoleta or you can live it. Choose the later.
The best of BA. This part of the city is in my opinion the jewel in the crayon. Easy to vase yourself here as taxis come often. The tree lined streets are full of boutiques and cafes.

One of the cutest places of the city!. It's a must if you're visiting BA. You can visit the cementery, in which you can see monuments of lots of important people. There are beautiful restaurants and parks.

Lovely neighborhood dominated by a historical cemetery. The cemetery houses so many different architectural styles that it's worth the visit despite the glaring morbidity. It's a tourist attraction by now, but some solemnity does well while visiting. Out of the cemetery, people make strangely long lines to eat at Pani, right by the mall. The mall itself offers a nice break from exploring the region. Resuming the exploration, you can follow Avenida Alvear and appreciate the charming old mansions that surround it until you reach 9 de Julio.
Must go place. Very nice. Have to walk aroud to feel the atmosphere. Just take a cab and as for the place. Walk, eat, drink and try to bond with the argentinians, they are nice people.

Bairro limpo, bonito e seguro. / A clean, pretty and safe neighborhood. A Recoleta é ótima para ficar, mas recomendo procurar apartamentos para alugar, que são mais baratos que os hotéis e muito bons. Tem tudo o que é preciso, e é um dos bairros mais recomendados de Buenos Aires. Mas é um bairro caro para comer.Recoleta is great to stay but recommend looking apartments for rent, which are cheaper than hotels and very good. It has everything you need , and is one of the most recommended neighborhoods of Buenos Aires. But it's an expensive neighborhood to have breakfast and lunches.

A great visit. Beautiful place to relax, go for some "mates" with friends and enjoy a sunny day! You may also like visiting "centro cultural recoleta" or the "B.A Design" where there are different shops! Recoleta Mall is very close, it has villare cinemas and it's surrounded by many bars and restaurants! Hope this helps! I would say it's a MUST DO! ENJOY!!!!

Love it here. I always stay in Recoleta when I come to Buenos Aires. There's a really cool vibe, the streets are always very ALIVE. There's lots to do and see around here and if you like shopping, check out the stores in Santa Fe Avenue.
beautiful cemenetry. beautiful cementery. i was a bot disappointed with evita's burial space, but still worth a visit as the whole neighborhood is amazing.

Beautiful Neighborhood. Historic favorite of the Argentinian aristocrats. Many used their fortunes to display a rich architectural legacy. Although many of the French styled châteaux have been demolished, a walk down Alvear Avenue will take you past the Palacio Duhau (former property of the Duhau family), the Nunciature of the Vatican (the Fernández Anchorena Palace), the French Embassy (former Ortiz Basualdo Palace), the Brazilian Embassy (former Pereda Palace), the Jockey Club, and the luxurious Alvear Palace Hotel. It is interesting to see how half of the planned Alvear Palace Hotel was not completed and instead transformed into apartments. You can see the difference if you look at the windows. Amazing history is also in the Recoleta cemetery which is the size of a city block filled with leafy avenues and narrow, marble walled streets and alleys. It is filled with the last resting places of the many notable Argentinians such as presidents, Nobel prize winners and a granddaughter of Napoleon. Evan Peron, the First Lady, can be visited at site 88. Ironically she was buried by her sisters in the family tomb with the father who did not play a role in her life after a long journey and controversy on where her final resting place should be. For more information about the area, go on a free two hour walking tour with Buenos Aires Free Tours. Jimena was a great guide. The tour starts at 5 PM from the San Martin Statue and winds from Retiro to Recoleta.

Most walkable neighborhood. Like being in Europe. Enjoy every block. The Northern limit is the wonderful (!) Recoleta Cemetery (where Evita Peron is buried) and just below it you'll find dozens of cafes with lots of ambiance . Note the tree-lined streets, the chic boutiques, the architecture.

History - Culture and Fun. Recoleta is a neighbourhood around the cementery where the aristocratic families of Buenos AIres and Las Pampas are buried. However, is not only that. Buildings with style, little cafes and restaurants as well as the feria on the week-ends. It is a good walking for a cool afternoon or summer evening.

Elegant and full of stories. Try and find a local guide to introduce you to the many stories behind the palaces and monuments of this fascinating area which shows one of the many different facets of the "Great Lady", Buenos Aires

Friends afternoon. Recoleta is an amazing place to spend the afternoon and late evening.It is a bit dangerous, so i do not advised to be around alone.Has greats coffee shops, bars, pubs. Fancy and very elegants.Worth to walk around !

Very interesting. This is one of the most fascinating places that I have ever seen. I guess the people here never heard of the phrase "you can't take it with you". They tried to take it with them by building opulent grave sites and the visitors have an interesting place to explore. I think that a guided tour is a must so that you can a true feeling of the meaning of this place and the history of the people who are buried here. Evita is not the only interesting person who is here. This is a graveyard with some very interesting architecture. You could wander here for hours. There is no entrance fee.

Great. Recoleta is a great place to visit during the weekend. It is all history and young Argentinians at the same time. The people selling popular art are pleasant and authentic . It was a pleasure to see young people having a good time just hanging out...no drugs, no violence but just enjoying the nice sun and company.I highly recommend it!!!
French barrio in BS AS. I spent 2 months in Recoleta, I lived here. And I really liked it pretty safe and elegant, you have everything, clubs, bars,cinema, shops. Love it. it s very central
Wonderful Area of BA to Visit. This area of BA has a lot of older sophistication and charm. Take a stroll around and have a coffee at a cafe.
Recoleta is a great place to live. I loved Recoleta, it is a super safe place to live. I love the fact that you have cafés in the street like in Paris

Out of this world !. Visiting this stunning cemetery is a must if you come to Buenos Aires. Mandatory of course is to site Eva Peron's (Evita) nee Duarte final resting place of this icon, but all the stunning mausoleums which surround you will leave you breathless as one is more impressive than the next. It is an other-worldly experience which does have extremes as some of the grave sites are derelict with coffins exposed and families long gone, but accompanying one of the many tour guides makes sense in the rich history of this most prestigious cemetery in Argentina where plots are now rumoured to be in the millions $.. if you can secure one.

Nice place to spend an afternoon. I will under separate cover write up the review for the restaurant I went to in Recoleta. I will focus here on the general activities that you can experience in the Recoleta area. The top tourist attraction is the Cemetery where Eva Peron is buried, of course not everyone is into cemeteries which is understandable, but if you enjoy history, art and architecture, you will love this cemetery because it has it all and is unlike any other cemetery I've ever seen and I've seen many from Arlington National Cemetery, to New Orleans and many in between. There are also shopping centers, restaurants and very nice homes and buildings in the general area, some of the nicest in Buenos Aires. You can spend a complete morning and have lunch or complete afternoon and have dinner. The area is quite, clean and pretty safe, as always in any big city, don't flaunt expensive jewelry, don't take out your wallet or money in public and the bigger your group the better (4 is great) and most of all, just be aware, keep your eyes open and you will be fine.

Lovely area in an amazing city . Recoleta is a lovely neighborhood. It offered upscale shopping along with a sprinkle of nice restaurants and parks. It's quiet and elegant. Nearby world class museums and attractions it's a great place to be if you are in Buenos Aires.

Such an active space!. I was really impressed by the cultural richness and greenery of this area - there are lots of free or inexpensive activities to do and some extremely satisfying walks to go on. The architecture of some of the buildings are just gorgeous.

This is a family MUST SEE in Buenos Aires. We could have spent a day in the cemetery. The history, architecture and beauty were breathtaking. Our son, age 10, enjoyed it as well. Take a guide to really get the inside stories and to appreciate all that you will see.
Nice mixed business and residential area. The region has many restaurants, hotels and shops. It also makes me feel a bit at home, once there are several residential buildings.

Great neighborhood . I have been there for 3 times already and always want to come back. Recoleta is a safe and beautiful neighborhood. And also is quite close to all other places, such as Downtown, Puerto Madero..
The cemetery is must to visit, it is about the art, the culture they have for the graves.

CLASSIC OF BUENOS AIRES ... It is the classical visit you have to made while in the capital of Argentina, eupopean architecture, have a look at the Alvear Hotel and the Palacio Duhau and its beautifull garden...

Perfect location for seeing the city. We rented an AirBnB in this neighborhood for our trip to BA. Perfect spot for getting around the city with our ex-pat son. He is fluent in Spanish, so it was a huge help to us in negotiating buses, taxis and restaurants. It was wonderful to experience the city the way the natives live and shop.

Very close to everything, and very safe with lots to do.. There are many options in the Recoleta. It is very close to many attractions such as the PinkHouse, the Recoleta Cemetary and catherdral, and many parks. There is a huge variety of shops and restaurants.
Tour. Very good guide...informative...entertaining. Guide was a musician so his passion was evident. The ticket seller put us in an English tour without our having to ask.

Good for a walk/ stay/ live!. Best residential area in Bsas!
Nice coffee places, little shops, parks and of course Parrillas!
Would definitely live here!

The neighborhood more charming of Buenos Aires. Nowadays Buenos Aires has many charming places like Palermo Soho or Palermo Hollywood but the Recoleta is still the most charming neighborhood .
A walk around Alvear Street is a great deal. It is plenty of nice buildings and you can know the famous Alvear Hotel or, walking to the Patio Bulrich Mall in the same street .

Great neighborhood . All you want in BaSa is here no error coming down to this place best restaurants and dance clubs and pubs I would live here easily but earn yin Usd dollar not in pesos hahahahahaha
Economy is bad down here with inflation on the 40 % range

Beautiful and peaceful place. This area of Buenos Aires was the elite district and there are many fine buildings, shops, restaurants and fine hotels. When you are there you can visit Recoleta Cemetary and view the amazing toumbs of the rich and famous including the tomb of Eva Peron. On Saturday there is a market in the park with some amazing stalls showing local art, leather goods and many other handmade items. There are food stalls and music shows in the park. This is a place that I would recommend one visit whilst in Buenos Aires.
Nice spot.. A great area to view the shops, famous graveyard where Evitas grave is. Lots of shops and markets all around the park! Well worth stopping by.
Best mix. The best in food, history, night life, landscapes and shoping the city has to offer. And very friendly to foreigners.

Photographers dream. We spent a day at Recoleta. Used uber to get there as it is super cheap in BA. Firstly spent 2 hours at the cemetery - amazing place . Took some beautiful photos. Easy area to walk around. Different Architecture to admire. Cool graffiti everywhere you look. Great day out more.
Biz/leisure trip. Went for the cultural visit, plenty to see and experience, especially on weekends. Went for the tango/dinner show, the meal and performance was worth every cent!

Always a pleasure to wander thru. Recoleta embodies the best of Buenos Aires culture and lifestyle. It could be correctly called a brand as the name conjures up with local and informed visitors that it is the heart of the cities upper-class neighbours from at least the past 100yrs. Some of the cities must important restaurants, art galleries, hotels ( Alvear Palace ), and apartment buildings like the Estrugamou Building are all located here. Not only this, it is very safe to live in.
Great!. Great neighborhood to walk around, beautiful buildings and stores. There also many restaurants including a Buenos Aires Hard Rock Cafe.
Amazing. This is a must do and see if in BA, the history, the stories, the pubs a great way to spend the afternoon.
Aus. Great place lots of history in a central location with lots of other historical buildings surrounding .. easily worth the short walk must see !
Must be visited!. Take an afternoon to walk around this neighborhood and finish it by sitting down at a Pub. Worthy! Hard Rock Cafe is situated in this place as well.
Beautiful neighbourhood. Spend a relaxing day strolling around Recoleta. There is the most beautiful architecture, fabulous museums, great weekend markets, lots of restaurants and Recoleta cemetery.
Nice neighborhood . Nice neighborhood with the famous cemetery. Hidden gem of family oriented restaurants that are easy on the wallet with tasty local foods. Many top museums are located here.
Beautiful! High standard of living area in Buenos Aires. This Cosmo area is reminiscent of NYC - Nicely done with Top level Hotels, shops, lots of traffic, and lots of people.

Beautiful area of town. The Recoleta area is beautiful with many places to visit. This area of town is the affluent area and much of the area reminded me of Europe. There is a famous cemetery to visit there where Eva Peron is laid to rest. If possible have a guide when touring.

Fantastic dining, shopping. Recolata is an inviting and exciting part of the city with 5-star hotels,beautiful park areas and the City's famous Opera House serving as great destinations. The cemetery is an impressive walk through history and features Evita's final resting place. Tour guides are helpful.
Neat and upscale neighborhood . Has tons of convenient places to go for a meal. Also is within walking distance to many touristy areas. Loved the European vibe of the area.

Go to the Cemetry!. It may sound morbid but this was one of our favourite things we did in Buenos Aires.
The Cemetry was amazing to walk round, and the most expensive real estate in buenos aires 30,000 USD per square metre. I've never seen anything like it and doubt I ever will again.
Free entry as well!

The cemetary is a hauntingly beautiful mansions for the dead. We walked through the cemetary. The English tours were suspended when we visited, but we still enjoyed the experience walking around on our own. We were surprised by how rundown some of the mausoleums were - broken glass, doors ajar, ceilings caved in - but I suppose that's what happens over the course of a few hundred years. It's a hauntingly beautiful neighborhood of mansions for the dead; architecturally interesting and worth a visit. The Duarte family site, where Eva Duarte Peron is interred, is off to the far left side of the entrance..

A great neighborhood to visit. This is a nice area to visit. There is the Recoleta Cemetery, where Evita Peron is buried. Also a nice church (see pic). You will also find Buenos Aires Design, which is a sort of mall that specializes in design furniture, and building materials. Also, restaurants and the Hard Rock Cafe.

Great for dinning out. The mall itself has nothing to boost about. But the restaurants at the front is awesome. Lot to choose from. Also the movie place there is nice and seem to be the only one that mostly play english movies. We like the Fridays restaurant that is right in front. Also once you are done shopping you can walk that whole strip at night for bars and also people selling on the streets. It's also right across from the famous recolleta cemetery so you can do that during the day and have dinner at night in the same area. Also walking from there is the recolleta park and my kids had fun just running and playing with other people's dogs. And sometimes at the park they have live music right on the lawn. Great place to spend a whole day
Safe and sound . We stayed at the Poetry Building and walked everywhere. We always felt regardless of the time of day or night.
Beautiful neighborhood. (May 2015) Just walking these streets is to be immersed in all that is Buenos Aires - push yourself to feel like a porteño, you won't be disappointed!

Wow! Worth the visit. . I was unsure what to expect here but everyone said I had to go if in Buenos Aires. The respect for the deceased was incredible. The elaborate crypt/mausoleums were unlike anything I've ever seen before. It's hard to explain. You can spend as much or little time as you want. I'd give yourself at least 1-2 hrs. The Church Nextdoor is worth a visit as well as the small fee for the side museum.

Gotta go. If you are in BA city this neighbourhood should be part of your visit. Specially on Sundays for its full of street markets and music and food. You can enjoy the culture of Buenos Aires as well as some tango show in public. It's a place full of turists

Beverly Hills of Buenos Aires. This is ground zero for high society Buenos Aires. Many established restaurants and Patio Bullrich the main designer shopping mall. Stunning architecture and flanked by Four Seasons Hotel on one end with the stunning Embassy Row behind it. Some of the few remaining original private Villas of the early 1900's are found in this area including the spectacular French Embassy building. Lunch time at 2 of the areas most established restaurants Fervor and Sotto Voce are 2 of our favorites and great people watching from old society Buenos Aires grand dames to local businessmen and families. Easy walkable streets full of shops, coffee shops and more.
The cemetery. This is such an Amazing place and so different. You must go. It's like something you've never seen before and not at all maudlin or creepy.

Elegant and far from the maddening crowd.. The old quarter of Recoleta takes its name from the site of a convent and adjacent cemetery. Nothing, except for the church of Our lady of Pilar, remains. The cemetery however, for its peculiar architecture, is worth a visit where you may run into the tumbs of historic character like Evita or a few notable families or presidents of the country.The "design" District is quite fashionable as well as the terrace and the City Cultural Center with many temporary art exhibits. Walking around with elegant boutiques, hotels like Alvear Palace -the bar is reccomended- as well as de Bougogne restaurant or the traditional Cafe and bar "La Biela" just around the block are high in the least of attractions not to be missed. For a more relaxed and decontracted atmosphere just take a cab and go to Palermo. But that is another story.

Perfect walk-tour for you and your family!. Recoleta is a great área where you can find: - "Teatro Ateneo" (biggest library in Buenos Aires: Av. Santa Fe 1860. It's free and open btw 10 - 19). - Cementerio de la Recoleta (where the most important elite politicans are. Ahh and evita jajaja. Address: Junin 1760. It's free and open btw 8 - 18). Near the Cementerio you can find a lot of bars. I recommend: - Buller Bar (hand-made beer). (It is in front of the Cementry). (Pte. Ortiz 1827)- Camping BA (Av. Pueyrredón 2501 - It is inside Buenos Aires Design)You can also find some other places to visit:- Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes- La Flor ("The Flower")- Palais de GlaceGreat places you MUST GO:- Fervor (Address: Posadas 1519. A little bit expensive but BEST meat restaurant ever)- Mi barrio Hamburguesería (Address: Guido 1936.)- Pani (Address: Vicente Lopez 2056. Amazing place for tea-time. Expensive)- Le Ble (Address: Vicente Lopez 1793. Another nice place for tea-time and brunch).- La Querencia (Address: Uriburu 1488. THIS IS A PLACE NOT EXPENSIVE WHERE YOU WILL FIND ARGENTINAN FOOD).

BA Feb 2016. 3 days stopover on way to Ushuaia. Recoletta, downtown area, Palermo, San Telmo, La Boca, and lots of walking. Eating "on the street", talking to locals. Safety only an issue once when we were stranded in La Boca, so would recommend caution around that area

Upper East Side of Buenos Aires. Strolling on the shady streets in front of high-end shops, it really did feel a bit like the upper East Side of NYC. I found the star attraction, the Recoleta Cemetery, a bit creepy, but I loved the handi-craft market on Saturday (and other days too) at the adjacent Plaza Frances. There are hundreds of artists' booths, but the jugglers, dancers, food vendors and lounging student musicians provided the real entertainment. Nuestra Senora del Pilar Church was small but highly ornate and the small museum there was well worth the visit. I went to the church museum for the view over the cemetery (over the rooftops of the crypts), but found that the exhibits and the alabaster window "glass" in the cloisters were actually more interesting.
Family trip. Bring comfortable shoes, the entire city is a Manhattan walk-way... with the Paris coffee, *cafés, where you can stop any time for a fresh juice or coffee.
Stunning suburb, worth the visit. A true history of Buenos Aries on the street. Stunning architecture, simply beautiful. A must see, lovely Cafes as well.
Wow!. What an amazing place to visit. It is beautiful and very interesting historically and quite macabre.
Stunning. An incredible neighborhood. With a beautiful architecture, it is a perfect place to spend an afternoon, either by foot or cycling.
Beautiful. Stayed at this area in Buenos Aires, Argentina for a month. Very nice area, highly recommend to anyone looking for good night life!

Best area to stay in Buenos Aires. It was wonderful, after a day of exploring, to come back each night to Recoleta. By the end of our trip, we just wandered around here. Stayed in an apartment on Quintana through VRBO and loved our location with the shops, restaurants and bakeries. The open air markets on the weekends with musicians and artists in the park was a favorite.
Overrated. Again an area overrated, Buenos Aires has nothing really authentic but if you are around Recoleta I recommend you to get lost in its streets and you might find ineresting bars

Astounding Cemetry. Wandered through the Recoleta Cemetery where I was able to see down to the underground tombs, some so deep that unable to see how far down they went, The tombs in the main were very large and very ornate. Felt overwhelmed when standing before The Duarte family Tome where Evita Peron is laid to rest,
A wet wander. Arrived here on our only day of rain.Nice for a wander looking at dates tombs some a bit eerry.Found Eva Perons last resting place!

Shopping but beware. Keep your valuables in your safe at the hotel. Don't walk around Buenos Aires with any valuables. No watches especially. The street is full of peddlers. They sell anything and everything. But if you get past the hassle. The shops are good. There are no high end stores but a good assortment of local shops. The architecture is gorgeous. You could see that this city was extravagant in it's prime.

An era gone by. This neighbourhood is primarily famous for the cemetery and has an old world charm around it still, when you walk around. It has become a little touristy and crowded with people mostly flocking for this one tourist spot, but if you go at a lesser crowded time, you really get a sense f the palce.
Overcrowded. Actually it is graveyard, but because of Evita it is a tourist spot. The restaurants,.. neraby are typically touristic. Had a quick coffe at Starbucks.

City of the dead. This city of the dead is an experience which is very Buenos Aires. Many famous deceased, including Eva Peron, reside here, but its the feeling of walking through what is literally a "city of the dead" which is so extraordinary.

Fantastic Area of BA. So much to see just walking the blocks - great museums, a real treasure with the Museo de Beaux Artes - quite an impressive collection of Impressionist paintings and famous Argentine painters. Do not miss the Recoleta Cemetary - I could have spent 5 hours walking each corridor, the history is amazing. Does help to have a map. Many parks in Recoleta and fancy hotels.
Graves . Is great to look at but one tombstone is as good as the other. Surrounding town is vibrant and busy which is great if you find a people watching spot
Nice!. Spend a sunny afternoon at Recoleta. You'll no regret. Beautiful neighborhood, many greenery, parks, the cemetery.

Recoleta. A visit therw this neighborhood is a must when visiting Buenos Aries. It's the rich and expensive area of Buenos Aries. A walk around to view all the beautiful architecture is free, so why not enjoy all the beauty this neighborhood has to offer.

Interesting monuments . This was quite an interesting cemetery. Instead of tombstones, there are only mausoleums -- hundreds of them. It's a fascinating walk through them all and looking at styles and inscriptions.

Difficult to Conceptualize Until You See It. I went without a tour, but did use my phone to research some tidbits. This is a great place to visit, and I wouldn't hesitate to return a second time.It's a large place - enough to occupy you from anywhere from thirty minutes to several hours, depending upon how much "background" info you seek. A tour would've been nice, and they have regularly-schedule Spanish ones. If I went again, I'd try to arrange an English one (even if it was a download on my phone or something). However, if you don't have a tour and just want to take it in, that won't be disappointing, it just will mean a shorter trip.Of course, there's the final resting place of Evita Peron (Duarte). While this is interesting both from the historic perspective and the fact that the tomb always has an abundance of fresh flowers and tributes, from a tomb-gazing perspective there are more interesting ones.What's hard to realize, until you're there, is how elaborate and (dare I say it) ostentatious some of these are? Meters-high sculptures. 100% marble. Sitting/genuflection rooms. Elaborate setups, carvings, and tributes. I had been told, but it didn't really register until I was there.You can get disoriented pretty easily while in there, but it's small enough that this wasn't alarming. There are tons of stray cats that seemed friendly-ish, but I avoided because I didn't want to antagonize one and maybe get bit.This was a good way to spend a couple of hours.

Glad we stayed in this area. There is so much to do, so much to see. Plenty of great restaurants and lots of shops. The outdoor market is a cheaper shopping and fun to just walk through, less pushy shop keepers as well.
Interesting cementery. Cementery a bit spooky but interesting. Walkable distance from city centre. Clean, beautiful neighbourhood with numerous cafes.
Beautiful suburb with tons of character and things to do.. So much to explore in Recoleta, we loved the local cafe's, the cemetery, and great local artisanal market.

The main focus is always going to be the cemetery. The area is quite nice, there are some nice buildings around.
It is good for a walk and you can see that there are a lot of local people living in the area, which is a nice change from the tourist groups.

Nice neighbourhood. Clearly a 'nicer' area than other parts of the city and it's noticeable by the better paving on the footpaths. Beautiful apartments and the streets are cleaner, better shops etc. Make sure you go the the cemetery, it's amazing albeit slightly creepy.
Look up down and ALL around!. Take a walk and Enjoy the architecture!! Easy to wander the streets to get a feel of "how it was"...

Recoleta Cemetary. What an experience to stroll through such a cemetery. It’s quite something you don’t see every day. Absolute must if you be there. And get a guide for explanation. otherwise you get lost.
Only Interesting. Being in Buenos Aires I guess one must visit Eva Peron and I guess it is a reflection of life of a by gone era. A visit does not take long.

Must See. This is well worth going to see. We're Eva Peron is interred I. The family vault, there is a map at the enterance showing where it is situated, without which you have no chance of finding it, the whole cemetery is very interesting with the many mausoleums to the great and good. A good day out.

Beatiful Neighborhood. If you don't have so much time to spend in Buenos Aires, you should go to Recoleta.. You can't miss it!!
A beatiful neighborhood, a great place to walk!! It's so beatiful!
Love Recoleta! Great restaurants, bars, art teathers!

Beautiful architecture. Lovely area of Buenos Aires. The Recoleta cemetery, with its ornate and elaborate structures, was breathtaking. Hire a tour guide right as you arrive at the cemetery to really get all of the history and stories of how Eva Peron's body was eventually returned to Argentina and laid to rest at this lovely place. Worth your time to see this place.

Great area to wander around just looking in Windows. . I have now stayed in Recoleta a few times and every time I find something more to see. There are so many beautiful shops and everything is kept very neat and tidy for the public. There is also markets to visit giving the area both ends of the spectrum if top end shoes and clothes aren't your thing. Markets are generally weekends though. This is just one of many neighbourhoods that are great to visit in this fantastic city. Just keep exploring.
Great bars, restaurants and parks. Recoleta is one of the most famous neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. There you can find great bars, restaurants and parks

Recoletta. Nice safe area to stay in, close to lots of cafes and several bars. Interestingly in the centre of it is a massive cemetery. Generally don't spend a lot of time wandering around these places but this one is particularly interesting and has some fantastic statues and of course Eva Peron or Evita is in turd there in her family mausoleum under the name of Eva Duarde. A little hard to find unless you check out in the office before you go through and look up the index and then it's pretty straightforward to find it. Don't cry for me Argentina just passed the entrance to the cemetery there is an old building which has been converted into restaurants bars on the ground floor and on the basement level there are a lot of homeware shops of good quality. Come to think of it you don't really go shopping for homewares when you're on holiday but it's interesting. The area is it to Riffic central location to move around BA . Easy to get taxis and they are inexpensive and knowledgeable drivers, In other words they don't take your the long way round
Shop till you drop. Lovely neighborhood with lots of boutiques. Good sight seeing and a mall if you want something from a big brand store. Restaurants are good and it's safe! I would come back!

What an amazing place to get buried. A cemetery full of beautiful mausoleums of the rich and famous, including Eva Peron. (Evita). The architecture of the graves is amazing and the scale of others grand. Take a tour with BA Freewalks, 3pm every day, it costs 150 pesos, approx $15 nzd, you'll get way more out of it.

Very nice area of town. Many restaurants and things to do. This area is very nice and safe.It is close to many attractions and top restaurants.We stayed here and walked to fairs, dinner, the cemetery and a mall to exchange money.

A safe residential type neighbourhood with lots of tall buildings and local restaurants and stores. We stayed in an apartment (through VRBO) in Recoleta. It was in an older French style 6 story building - similar to many in the area. There are different parts of Recoleta. Some look more run down and others have upscale lobbies and nice balconies. Depending on the street you can have simple cafes / bakeries / ice cream stores and small hair salons. Other streets (like Alvear) have higher end shops (towards the Retiro neighbourhood). Recoleta is the closest neighbourhood to the Cemetery. We also liked the Sunday

Nice neighborhood to vist. This is an area with lots of history, shops, art galleries, and restaurants. The large cemetery (where Eva Peron is buried) is in this area. It's a nice area to spend an afternoon.

Charming and old history . Here you will find your art boutiques, galleries, old mansions and little streets cafes as well as your high end stored like Cartier etc.It safe and relaxing walking the ought the Multiple little streets of the recoleta except when you find your occasional dog poop.

Beautiful part of the city. This is the wealthy part of the city with fancy shops, great restaurants and a very cool cemetary where Eva Peron is buried. If you want to experience the entire city don't miss this neighborhood.

Impressive monuments and lots of history.. We spent more time than usual here. Most tourists go see Evita Duarte Peron's mausoleum and quickly exit the cemetery. Take your time and check out some of the others. Some monuments are much grander than Evita's and if you Google the name, you may find out some very interesting history. Look through the windows, some are very ornate on the inside.
Do Not Miss This. The Ricoleta Cemetery was one of the highlights of my visit to Buenos Aires. A virtual "city" of incredibly ornate mausoleums including Eva Peron's final resting place. A must see!

One of the World's Great Cemetaries. This has been the final resting place for Argentina's elite for centuries -- Presidents, military generals, artists, aristocracy and Eva Duarte Peron. The mausoleums and tombs are simply fabulous -- many Polorid moments. The cemetery is enormous, maybe 13 or 14 acres. The architectural styles are numerous and fascinating and of course you cannot leave without visiting Eva Peron's vault.
Stunning neighborhood. Be sure to stroll Avenidas Alvear and Arroyo as you appreciate all of the French influence in the architecture of this historic neighborhood.

Free to the Public. It helped that we had a guide who could give us history of some of the families and explanation of the mausoleum's. She also took us to see Eva Peron's family mausoleum. If you don't have a guide, you can purchase a map of the cemetery to do it on your own.

Love Architecture. If you love looking at 19th century buildings and walking this is an interesting afternoon walk. There are beautiful buildings with fascinating histories, great area to stop and grab a coffee as well.

Lovely neighborhood to wander about. Stayed in this part of town for a week in mid-May and really enjoyed it. Charming touches pervade and it doesn't lack for amenities and location to other parts of the City.

City hustle and bustle. This area feels like the city center. A great many restaurants, shops, sights and connections by subway or bus to everywhere. More shoe shops than you can shake a stick at in Santa Fé. Do not miss the world-class cementery!
Loved it!. Really unusual place but definitely worth a visit! It's massive and you can easily spend a couple of hours getting lost among the tombs.

I love this neighborhood . From drop dead gorgeous parks , free fabulous museums , wide beautiful avenues , world class shopping and dining and the setting for the most prolific cemeteries I ever visited , Recoleta is by far one of my favorite barrios to hang out in.

Lovely neighborhood, central but pricey. A nice place to stay if you aren't watching the pennies. Worth an afternoon or evening strolling the lovely hotels and shops. The restaurants in this part of town cater to the high class residents and tourists staying in this part of town. The outer neighborhoods give a better flavor of the pulse of the city. If you are only staying in BA for a few days this is a nice safe , convenient location.

Great Place to Stay and Explore. Great High End area. Good place for a first time visitor and easy to explore the cemetery etc. Only approx $10 NZD by taxi to most places. Get Sol from Sol-of-ba.com to do a local tour for you. I am a travel agent and she was an awesome guide to have!

Great architecture and a nice buzz about the place. Try the deco cafes. You almost think you are in Madrid, but this is BA with its own unique style and colour. Nice shops and boulevards to soak-up the afternoon sun.
Amazing mansions. Some of the best buildings are in this area of the city. Old mansions still kept in great condition have now been turned into embassies and hotels
A place to visit. I highly recommend visiting this place. It has plenty of good restaurants and cafes. Places to visit are the cemetery, church, museum and melba.

Best neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Top neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Very nice and very safe. Kayla and I felt very safe here. I liked the fact that you have access to lots of attractions and there is always something to do.

The perfect location for exploring. We chose to stay in Recoleta as opposed to Palermo due to its proximity to the central city. No regrets-you can walk anywhere from here. The cemetery is close, Palermo is within walking distance and so are the attractions in the city. There are many good restaurants and shopping areas. It felt like a neighbourhood and seemed less touristy than some other areas.
Our favourite neighbourhood. Stroll around and enjoy the multiple stores and the lovely vibe in the street - cemetery is great also and lovely cafes and restaurants. The best place to stay

Best part is buenas aires. Unlike the rest of Buenas Aires you can walk around Recoleta without having to have your eyes fixed to the ground to avoid dog poo.This is the B.A I expected to see.Went to the feria artisanal last Sunday and the craft was the best I've seen in B.A.Recoleta cemetery was truly unbelievable ,a fortune spent on crypts of the aristocracy while most of B.A languishes in stark poverty.Most of the old mansions are now embassies.
Very nice.. Very nice upscale part of town. Cafe's shopping etc. As nice a place as I have ever seen. Reminds me of Madrid meets NYC
Pretty. A very upmarket part of the city, includes the famous graveyard where Evita, among others, is buried. Very pleasant to walk around

Outside dining in a great location. We stumbled into this wonderful iconic retro restaurant superbly located with outside seating under a magnificent huge sprawling gum tree. Used mainly by locals as a place the place has a glamorous 1950s auto racing theme, the original owner appears to have had or was involved in a racing team.

Beautiful part of BA. Recoleta is a beautiful part of Buenos Aires. It is lovely to walk around go to the cemetery which is very interesting to see, it is full of history and culture, one can see where Evita resting place is. It has an array of lovely cafes and bars, great to relax have a coffee and watch the day go by. The architecture is cool so European French style, it is a must see when in BA, so much to say about the place, best to go there and see it and experience what it is all about!

Nice to stroll and spend time on a cafe . Fancy neighborhood with elegant people up and down the streets. Feels Parisian when you sit by the walk on a cafe or brasserie to sip some wine and espresso while watching the movement.

Lots to do and I felt relatively safe.. Many attractions and very interesting stores, restaurants and other attractions here. Also, Sunday's seem to be a good day for local markets to enjoy. A guide is much needed if you don't speak the language.So much historical information from a local guide , really amplifies the experience.

interesting walkabout. Take your camera. This is super-interesting. Evita's resting place is under her family name, Duarte, just FYI. It's a quiet oasis in the middle of the city. Note: Bring mosquito repellent.
Recoleta . Very nice Recoleta, lots of bars , restaurants , very nice area in Buenos Aires, Village Recoleta is great !! La Biela is Fantastic ! Buenos Aires Design!! Love it !!

Euro style with Latin American twist. Truly the Paris of Latin America. Just wander the streets and admire the architecture, take a cafe and melia luna. Enjoy the people watching and great restaurants. More than just the famous cemetry but the church is my favourite of all my travels. Magic !

Nice buildings with lots of history. The recoleta area is a very nice part of Buenos Aires. Lots of nice buildings that are quite european in appearance. It is not as clean as a european city would be and the sidewalks are in pathetic state of repair with missing paving stones and holes in most streets. they are a real tripping hazard! However if you can avoid tripping the walks about the streets are interesting and many nice spots to stop for a meal or coffee

A must visit area in Buenos Aires. This area is an historic very well known spot , not to miss if you are a visitor in Buenos Aires. It has fallen "out of fashion" in a way but it keeps it-´s glamour and I consider it to be yet the finest spot in Buenos Aires. Don´t let yourself be tempted by the fascinating and somehow new Puerto Madero district; when it comes to refined architecture and glamour I think Recoleta is unbeatable!

Feels quite european!. Recoleta is a very nuce place where you can walk either with friends or alone, whatever you it is simply precious! If you like architechture come here and take a look at those neoclassic and luxurious buildings all around; a must-see!

Lovely safe beautiful historic area . Walking, sightseeing, good food, charming elegant and historic area. It's a great area to shop for authentic Argentinean products and take time for lunch or dinner there. I love Mio.

Charming must see. This was a lovely section of BA, very European feeling and the architecture was beautiful. The cemetery is not normally on my must see list but the cemetery here is stunning and very interesting to walk around and view the historical tombs.
A Must See. The area of Recoleta is part of the heart of Buenos Aires. The cemetery is amazing and can't be missed, and the area itself is interesting for it's architecture.
Rich Recoleta. Recoleta is s lovely area with beautiful structures and positive vibe. We enjoyed the walking tour and sightseeing
A neighborhood you should visit. This neighborhood is great, many attractions as the cemetery (where Evita Peron is buried) and the Saturday market with local handicrafts.

Nice neighborhood.. We were here to visit the Cemetery which is an experience in itself. Later, we had a dinner date with a local family, and this lady was kind enough to take us around the area to look at the stores and recommended local delicacies from the supermarket. I love the stores around as there are a variety of stuff offered. It's clean and feel pretty safe.
A must see. A traditional cemetery that is beautiful and very peaceful. Eva Peron is just one of the more well-known Argentinian citizens who was laid to rest here.
Beautifull!. If you don't go to visit, you haven't been to Buenos Aires!!! Very pleasant neighborhood just to walk arround
Elegant neighborhood. Beautiful apartment buildings and grand mansions. Very European feel, including the famous cemetery where Evita is buried.

Old Buenos Aires. This is my favourite neighbourhood in Bs As. Lots of sidewalk cafés, many examples of old French architecture in many apartment buildings, parks and a lazy, monied atmosphere make Recoleta a great place to spend an evening. Chat, people - watch, have a coffee or a whiskey. Time goes slowly here, doesn't seem like you're minutes from the bustle of downtown.

Great Place for Coffee, Shopping and Strolling. Love this part of Buenos Aires with its tree-lined streets, small and unique shops and great places to stop for a drink. It gives you a nice perspective of the quieter parts of the city and the unique European style architecture. I would highly recommend spending a lot of time in this area.

Nice place for an afternoon stroll. Nice place to walk around, you can find many restaurants and cafes. Also visit the Recoleta cemetery, which has a special charm, the Iglesia del Pilar, a beautiful colonial church, the Buenos Aires Design mall and if you want to shop you also have the Recoleta Mall just across the cemetery. This place is worth a visit if you are in Buenos Aires. Also, I would recommend it as a nice and safe area for a stay, easy to get around, there many interesting sites nearby and you can easily access other sites from there.

Nice neighborhood but beware of crooks. As in all cities of the world the places where there are plenty of tourism is a crook's paradise, so keep always an eye on you things.- There are lots of beautiful buildings specially in Avenida Alvear.-

Neighbourhood of Art and Architecture. Recoleta is a lovely residential neighbourhood of architectural interest worth strolling around to get a feel for refined life in Buenos Aires. The neighbourhood also has many cultural attractions, churches, restaurants, bars, and green spaces. It is the neighbourhood where the impressive Recoleta Cemetery is located. Plaza Francia, the square facing the cemetery, is where you’ll find a huge rubber tree that dates back to 1791. It’s a great place to sit and relax after a busy day of sightseeing.
a nice place to walk around for an afternoon.. Lots to look at and many places to eat in the neighbourhood. I found this area quite clean and enjoyable.
Very impressive. I'm from Europe and I've been to many historic cemeteries throughout the world, but this one is special. You should def go and do a guided tour, it's worth it.

Paris-like area!. This ties with Puerto Madero with my favorite areas of Buenos Aires. There is a certain charm and sophistication to this part of town. The shops, restaurants, coffee shops, hotels and people stand out. The tree-aligned streets give you a sense of tranquilly even with the noise of the traffic. It's the kind of place that make you want to go back each and every day!

Nice walk. A really nice place to walk around to explore the neighborhood. Lovely old historical buildings with newer modern offices/apartments give the place a striking contrast. Worth to do a walking tour to find out more about the origin of the historical buildings.
Recoleta. The third cementery in the world, due to the important people burried thereVery important monuments are to be seen Evita is there. Sarmiento, Leloir, Alfonsin, just to mentíon so me of them

A nice Sunday walk. Walking around the cemetary on a Sunday morning is a nice way to start the day. In the afternoon there is an artists market just ouside of the cemetary. Lots of very original things to buy as gifts.

Worth the visit. If possible pick a sunny day, and enjoy a stroll at this cementery, which hosts so many works of art, that you`ll be delighted. Many of the most noticeable Argentines are buried there. There is a place for Evita, on the far left of the entrance. Though it is not monumental, and she is not buried there, at least you can tell your friends you`ve been there.

Interesting area of Buenos Aires. Recoleta area has some great hotels including boutique hotels and good shops. The area has lovely gardens and of course the renowned Recoleta cemetery which is amazing. We went to the cemetery twice as it was fascinating and very unique.
Extremely interesting. Important part of Buenos Aries to see, it is history in real time, very busy suggest going early or almost at closing time
Great locality. Enjoyed coffee, cemetery cruising, churches and magnificent buildings , parks and the walk. Recoleta exhibits the best of the olde world charm of Benos Aires.
Nice quaint area. Relaxing area with some nice sidewalk cafes. Take a cab there because it is a ways away. It would be a nice are to stay in also.
Beautiful area in Buenos Aires. This is a beautiful area and definitely worth at least spending a bit of time there. Many things to see and do including great restaurants. Highly recommended!

Monumental cemetery. The cemetery... is a very quiet place :) a nice place to stay for an hour and enjoy the sound of nature between really old and magnificent graves.
il cimitero... è un posto molto tranquillo :) un buon posto per rilassarsi per un'oretta nella natura, circondati da tombe vecchie e spettacolari!
Fascinating. Home to the cemetery where Eva Peron is buried. A must visit for any visit to BA. Enjoyed the small craft market outside the cemetery and the many parks.

Centuries Old Adorned Church. Overlooked for the more well-known cemetery, the Ricolera Catholic Church has windows that overlook that attraction. Its statuary is large and impressive. They have a small museum on the second level where you can view artifacts for a minimal fee.
Very nice neighborhood . This is a very nice area around the cemetery from which it has its name. Both the area and the cemetery are worth a visit. A place to visit if you come to Buenos Aires

Recoleta Cemetary. What a beautiful necropolis. Definitely hire a tour guide. There is so much history here. Other than Eva Peron, a great many of Buenos Aires politicians, athletes and BA elite are buried here.

Been twice, likely won't make it three.... I have been to the Recoletta area twice 3 years ago. It was neat to say the "I've been there" line and see another country- GREAT FOOD, WINE, and SHOPPING. I enjoyed the bars/restaurants with outdoor seating and spent an afternoon walking around taking pictures but other than the above, did not get to explore other offerings of the area as far as things to do. Be sure to check out the giant tree. A rubber tree? I forget. Super impressive in the middle of town. People don't seem super friendly, nor the opposite, but bring your best Spanish as not many speak English to help you.
One of BsAs important neighbothoos. Several important sites to see in Ricolleta, Major one for me was the cememetary. One can spend a lot of time there. Ricolleta was one of the original barrios.

Interesting Cemetery. On the tourist trail mainly due to the final resting place of Eva Peron, but the cemetery is interesting to wander round and you can see the changes in design and architectural influences over the last 100 years. Most tour groups visit here and it is free to enter but you can easily get a taxi for a reasonable cost.

Nice Area, Lots to See!!. I spent 4 nights in the Recoleta area, and I walked and walked and walked. I enjoyed my visit to this area very much. Sure, it's a city, it's dirty, sidewalks, well, you have to pay attention to where you walk as the sidewalks are in poor condition. Most sidewalks were very narrow. I was rarely hassled by street vendors. You do have to get over all the people wanting to exchange your currency. I felt it easier, and safer, to use an ATM. I got 15 to 1 on my money from the ATM so why bother with street guys? I did a walking tour and a wine tour. These are readily available and I highly recommend them.
Beautiful. Great architecture and history. I had a lovely visit and would recommend it to everyone when in Beunos Aires.

Latin American culture meets European city. This is a great neighborhood to just walk around and enjoy the city. The city is clean, architecture and city landscape is romantic and makes you feel like you're in the heart of Europe, but with people that are way much more nice, and it's super safe. Walking around at night I had no troubles or concerns, people super friendly. People here just know how to live life.

What awonderful surprise. Who would think visiting a cemetery would be memorable. Recoleta is simply fascinating beyond what I can describe. Huge, varied, impressive. Tombs/mausoleums from the 1700's to the present. From crumbling ill maintained to magnicifect, polished marble edifices. Firpo is buried there, dozens of presidents and generals and naturally - Evita. Plan on spending hours wandering the little pathways.

A Cemetery for Argentina's Great and Good and not so Good. Laid out like the streets of Paris, the Recoleta is acres and acres of crypts, each one more ornate than the other. Argentina's famous and infamous families buy a plot and build as they wish. Many generations can be buried in one mausoleum. As with real estate everywhere, price depends on location, location, location - the most expensive being the space next to where Eva Perón is buried. It recently sold for $250,000. The cheapest locations are $12,000. Then there is the annual tax and fees for upkeep. Quite a few of the structures have fallen into disrepair because either the family has died out, moved away or is no longer able to afford the annual fees. Sooner or later, these areas are cleared out and resold. It is important to go with a guide so hear the amazing tales of some of the 'residents' of Recoleta Cemetery. In at least one case, the family's trusted housekeeper was buried with them - not inside the main building but in a little annex just outside. There is not a blade of grass or a tree or flower. If the weather is hot, be sure to wear a hat and use sun protection - the tour entails lots of walking. A truly surreal experience.

Extraordinary on a rainy or cloudy day!. If you find its a rainy day and don't want to be inside a museum...take the Yellow Line Hop On - Hop Off bus to this amazing cemetery in a lovely neighborhood. I thought we'd be in and out in 1/2 hour...instead we took hundreds of pictures and walked the underground crypts and meandered here for over three hours. Finished up with some local ice cream and taxied back to the Hippodrome area/park. A rainy/cloudy day makes great light for pictures. See Evita's resting place. Notice cemetery cats....they are actually tended by a few local ladies (shots, vet visits, etc).

My Base When I'm in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is an upscale neighborhood that is very safe. It is located just off downtown so that if you have a good map and are a walker, you can easily get to the opera house and mainstreet. It's an easy and inexpensive taxi ride to San Telmo, Palermo and the Tigre Delta. Recoleta contains a famous cemetery and beautiful turn of the century mansions that are now embassies and hotels. The streets are tree-lined and pretty. There is a strong police presence, but it isn't threatening. Recoleta has some nice shopping and is full of bakery, coffee and tea houses.

What a Barrio!!. All parts of this suburb of Buenos Aries was out of sight!!!! The people were all so friendly and talkative to me...and what a great place to eat and shop!!!! The different architectural domains is just amazing!!! Make sure you visit this area!!
Typical Shopping mall. The mall itself is quite high prized with a lot of known brands. I do not recommend to go there to buy typical stuff from Argentina as it is quite expensive.

Charm. Walking around Recoleta gives you some felling about the Argentinean life style over the last century.
The Old buildings, cafes and people walking around make it a great place to spend some good walking hours

The Recoleta Area of Buenos Aires has Much to Enjoy. The Recoleta area of Buenos Aires has much to enjoy: casual strolls down tree lined streets, cafes, shops, quaint homes, restaurants, parks, small boutiques and more. Adjacent to other great walking, sightseeing areas.
Amazing. Such an interesting g and impressive Cemetery. Free entrance. Very moving to see Evitas tomb. The surrounding area is very upmarket with beautiful designer shops
I love Recoleta. I was fascinated by Recoleta neighborhood. People are nice and willing to help you out if you encounter difficulties, everyone speaks English quite good. I felt safe.

Safe enjoyable part of the city. Felt very safe saying in Recoleta,even walking back from dinner at night. Great access to taxis. Some nice landmarks to see such as the cemetery and floralis generica. Easy access to other parts of BA,close to internal airport etc. Good restaurants and shops.
Stunning part of town. I love Recoleta, I've been around a lot of BA and enjoyed staying there the most. Some fabulous bars, great food, great mall, and the cemetery is a must see.
Beautiful City to walk around in.. Recoleta is a nice little part of Buenos Aires,you must go see the cemetery,it has quite the history.

A cemetery to top all cemetaries. We stayed across the street from this final resting place and the view from ten floors up is impressive indeed. We spent the morning walking through the site. The respect for those who have passed is palpable. (Some resting places have been defaced and some not fully maintained, but they add texture.) A wonderful way to spend part of a day.
good mixture. nice mx of old charm with cemetery and church but also cool to walk around have gelato, coffee, or meal somewhere here. Felt safe even walking around at night too.
Unique. This place is something really unique. The wealth that BA once had is fully on display. Well worth a look.

Amazing Cemetary - a city within a city. Thousands of mausoleums form a city for the wealthy and distinguised departed of Buenos Aires, among whom is the disavowed former First Lady of Argentina, Eva Peron, intered in the Duante Familia tomb.
Amazing!. Each grave was different, some simple, most ornate. Many in various states of disrepair. Evita's grave was unremarkable, and she was married to the President!
great spot. For photography this is the best place to walk around there are also numerous restaurants you can choose from to eat and several menues to have.

11 years later. Recoleta is a great location in Buenos Aires. Is a residential zone with a lot of fine hotels and stores.I think is the best place is near of everything and the same time is not in the downtown but is not far away.The streets are nice and clean with a lot of green areas and the people is friendly.
Visited . Awesome place! We enjoyed food, the cemetery and the big tree at the square! We also enjoyed great coffee at La biela and great food at the pick market!

Incredible neighborhood. The turn of the century architecture and fairy tale castles which dot the area along with world class shops and of course the Patio Bullrich Mall, makes this neighborhood a magnet for the rich and famous. During our stay at The Brick Hotel, Ricky Martin was up the block at the Four Seasons, while a few doors down Ashton Kutcher stood at the Park Hyatt. Not to mention the fact that the following week, President Obama was at Casa Rosada, nearby. This is the premier neghborhood in Buenos Aires, a great place to visit or better yet, to stay.

Best part of the city!. Recoleta is the nicest neighborhood in BA to walk around. Besides the Bellas Artes and cemetary, go to the Palais de Glaces nearby, and browse the artesanias by the cemetary on Sat and Sunday. Walk down Alvear and right on Montevideo a few blocks to my favorite pasteleria, Dos Escudos. There's plenty of great shops, cafes, and my favorite helado/ gelato shop is Valence on Rodrigue Pena and Juncal- keep walking to Plaza Vincente Lopez, cross the park, and take a right on Juncal. If you're hungry, you'll be passing Las Esclavas, the best and cheapest restaurant which is on the way to Valence, 1/2 block from Plaza Vincente Lopez and Valence. Around the corner from Valence is the Shamrock on Rodrigue Pena, a wildly popular Irish pub with a nightclub downstairs, but don't show up until after midnight. Enjoy!

Jaded Jewel. From the collapsing infrastructure to the run down classical buildings, street people and mountains of doggy doo... Recoleta is not looking so swish. But it is much better than most other districts in BA!
