Amazing. The Recoleta cemetery is amazing. Hard to understand the wealth that would allow for such over the top decorations on burial sites. Really beautiful statues and works of art.

A Grand Dame of a District, Indeed. Recoleta is one grand dame of a city. It sure looks Parisienne. Buildings of about seven to about ten storeys dominate its city skyline. Very different in my eyes that is accustomed to the more Asian texture.It's architecture is old, detailed and amazing. Just like what I hope they would be. As with most cosmopolitan cities all over the world, it has some of the best shops, hotels and restaurants in the city. I come from a mall-popular country in Asia. And while this city has malls, they are not as large and new as what we may have. The fashion is also unique to Argentina except for the international brands. I will have to add that they have some really exceptional clothing stores. The lines may not complete but a shopaholic can still leave the stores with a nice smile.My top of mind favorite shops would be -1) Rossi Carusso for leather jackets, shoes, bags2) Arandu for leather goods 3) La Dolfina for men's clothes & accessories4) La Martina for the same5) Fueguia Perfumeria in Casa Cavia6) Havana for the alfajores I needed to stop and look carefully as some of the details I was not accustomed to. But once I was able to study them, they were just very, very nice.Take BLACK TAXI cabs only, I was forewarned. And most of the cabs in the city were.We were not able to take their trains but I hear they were very inexpensive and efficient.Many museums were here. I was only able to go to the Evita Peron museum. Not enough time.Beautiful churches, monuments all over the city.
Beautiful neighborhood, must see in Buenos Aires. Sophisticated neighborhood, with beautiful parks and several touristic spots. Must see is Cementerio Recoleta and the Gigantic Flower.

A must in Buenos Aires . This neighborhood has a charm like no other. Classic buildings, shops and style. The cementery has it's own importance and you should visit it! Many famous people is there and it is a pearl of architecture
Fabulous history. It is indeed a place of history. Fabulous architecture, well maintained and supervised. Great eateries and shopping.

Very interesting place - a must!. The sprawling cemetery is a must visit in Bueno Aires - beautiful grounds! Some of the coffins are actually placed above-ground (which could scare some), but generally a peaceful place located in the wealthier side of the city, with many good eateries nearby.

There is no way to adequately describe this place!. If you are in BA and miss this, you missed a gem. Budget at least an hour or two to walk the streets and visit with the dearly departed. It's full, so if you want in-you'll have to marry into a family that has a mausoleum already. And don't pet the cats. They seem a little bit sickly.
Ava Peron is buried here. If you have never been to a walled cemeterary, and a private mausoleum like this, then you are in for a surprise.
Wonderful area. This was my favorite area in Buenos Aires. So much to see, and pleasant for walking. Lots of shops, restaurants, the cemetery, and a lovely park with a market on weekends.

A great place to spend a day. Been fascinated from the architecture, old cemetery adjacent to Interesting peaceful Recoleta church that tells lots of historical events. Few meter away enjoyed sitting at the Le Biela Café and watch the street tango. Down the road there was the village shopping center too. Walking distance from Abasto suburb with lots of Kosher restaurants. Especially along Tuchman Street.

Good way to kill some time while waiting to check in!!. It was a great walking tour. We had just landed and we walked over while our room is getting ready. It had beautiful graves and the grounds were beautiful.
I will go back and explore more. Nice walk inside to burn some calories. Free entrance.

Not just the famous cemetery and MALBA. A nice place to walk around.. We went to bot attractions mentioned above, but also walked around "embassy row', upscale shopping places and posh residences. It's a place where tourists unfamiliar with a city wouldn't be afraid to walk by themselves. PS: We walk everywhere. It's the best way to get to know a place.
A spread-out area with lots of attractions. There are statues and memorials everywhere. Lots of parks and green space. Pleasant area to sit. The cemetery on one side.
Beautiful ARea. Very nice area of Buenos Aires. Beautiful streets and buildings. Must stop at La Biela and Cementerio Recoleta. You won't regret it.
Recoleta cemetery . Architecture within the cemetery is amazing. Not a cemetery tour type but this one is very clean and worth the time.
Recoleta Cemetery.. Recoleta cemetery is eerily beautiful and very interesting. Don't forget to stop by and pay respects to Eva Peron (Evita!).

Evita and much more. Obviously for us foreign visitors Recoleta means visiting its cemetery, or should I rather say open air museum?Unmissable visit, and as gruesome as it may sound for those who haven't been yet, walking around the cemetery and admiring the sculptures around the graves is as pleasant as any classical museum.Also, just outside the cemetery and on weekends there is a street market that gets put up, with dozens of vendors selling from antiques to handicrafts.A must go part of Buenos Aires!!

Great Cemetery Visit. Really one of the best cemetery visits on the continent. The sculpture and architecture of some of the tombs is as good as you might find in a museum. Most visitors are just going to snap photos of Evita's tomb, but there is much more to see.
Great place to tour. Elegant and stylish with high end stores and Hotels. Scenic walks, craft booths on weekends. Museums, coffee shops and restaurants are plentiful.

Fascinating Place!. I'm typically not a cemetery fan...but this is a must see! Interesting monuments, combination of old world and new architecture...the grounds were beautiful kept...we found Evita's final resting place with special thanks to our guide otherwise we would be wandering...

What an unusual cemetery. This is an essential part of any tour of Buenos Aires and simply amazed my wife & I. We have never seen anything quite like it!
It's like going to a miniature town with squashed in buildings- except these are full of coffins and underground mausoleums. Fascinating to find Eve Peron's tomb among them.
Fascinating

A must stop in BA. Find a guide or book to describe the cemetery. The map they sell for 20 pesos is worth it if you want some orientation. the place is fascinating, Loads of history, including Eva Peron (Duarte)'s final burial site. Btw, there is a money changer in the strip of shops outside the cemetery--Cubano, who gives very good rates.

Who would ever want to visit a cemetery on vacation? You do!!. Through our cruise line we scheduled a tour of Recoleta. I almost cancelled and am so glad I didn't. At dusk the mausoleum lined streets come alive with cats and the volunteers that care for them. The beauty was a wonderful surprise. It's now my top recommendation to friends visiting Buenos Aires.

Beautiful Tributes!. We were amazed by the size of the cemetery & how regal some of the monuments are. One can easily spend hours wandering & taking in the beautiful architecture. The Evita monument is hard to find; follow the guided tours! Highly recommend spending an afternoon here.

Great!!!. A must for all visitors to Buenis Aires. A real experience, as the show-of rich porteños is absolutely remarkable. Don't miss visiting the beautiful little cathedral right next to the cemetery, but be always on the guard with the pickpockets!
Interesting Barrio to walk area. This is the most upmarket barrio of Buenos Aires and is an interesting place to walk around and view the way the other half live!

Fascinating Memorials!. Visited the Cemetery on my first day in the city and on a tour of the Recoleta area. This is a maze of crypts and statues for the great and the good of Argentina's past. You could easily spend an hour or two wandering among the memorials.The most famous is Eva Peron and you'll easily find her given the tourists who wander down the lane to her grave.

Incredible. I have never visited a cemetery like this one. I have visited many doing genealogical research here in Canada. The beautiful architecture of these mausoleums to former people living in Argentina. Having heard much about Eva Peron we got a chance to visit her mausoleum. Some people are turned off about visiting cemeteries but you must see this one if in Buenos Airies.
Love the weekend market. It is quiet residential area but also cater for tourists with its weekend market and also visit to Evita Peron tomb, must visit when in Buenos Aires.

Emotional. Incredible place. If you know enough about Argentinian history , you can find the tombs of very important politicians, colonels, actors or authors. And of course don't leave it without have visited Eva Peron's House.

A City of the Dead. Recoleta is a "must see" in Buenos Aires. We visited as part of the hop on hop off tourist bus route and there is a subway station nearby also.The cemetery is laid out like a small town except the houses are mausoleums, some almost multi story, and very ornate. Many have "basements" which you can see clearly through the clear glass window and door panes. Despite the visitors it is a surprisingly peaceful place.
Very nice neighborhood.. The hotel we stayed just in front of Cementerio de Recoleta was in this barrio which is very nice with nice buildings and close of other city attractions
Great neighborhood. Stayed in the neighborhood for 8 nights. Great area to use as a base. Plenty of markets, restaurants, and taxis.
A little corner of recorded history. This is a very interesting cemetery where Eva Peron lies amongst other worthies or not so worthies depending on your point of view - definitely worth visiting

Aristocratic part of town. Reminiscent of the old European capitals, Recoleta offers plenty of majestic looking buildings, museums and high class restaurants. Good for a nice walk and a cultural visit!
Interesting. I would normally not go to the cemetery but this was well worth it. Called city of angels and Evita's final resting place. Lots of interesting things to see

Wow, a stunning insight into the wealth of Buenos Aires after life!. A wander around the amazing cemetery of Recoleta is a must if visiting BA. The display of wealth is astounding with many of the mausoleums being worth more than an apartment! This holy piece of ground is immaculate and well cared for however if regular payments aren't kept up to date some of the plots are left to rack and ruin, this merely adds to the historical influence. Many of Argentina's most influential celebrities, politicians and wealthy have tombs here, including that of Eva Peron (Duarte). There is however a slightly creepy side of the cemetery with many coffins/caskets being clearly on view through the glass doors or wrought iron gates of the individual mausoleums.
Recoleta. Buenos Aires is a very passionate city - despite the warnings about crime we had an excellent time. This part of the city is well worth the visit.
An Unusual Cemetery.. a unique cemetery for the rich and the famous. many family mausoleums some of them are known like the famly of Evita Peron. Worth a visit.

Upscale, stylish neighborhood. After a visit to Recoleta Cemetery, take time to peruse the interesting art market in Plaza Francia then explore Recoleta district's posh stores (e.g. Hermes, Fueguia - a high-end parfumerie, custom leather goods, etc.), charming old-world bistros & cafes, and gorgeous architecture reminiscent of Paris in both facades and marble/gilt interiors. The neighborhood is safe, fairly quiet, and makes for a lovely afternoon of people watching. Wanting a snack? Try El Sanjuanino where the empanadas are tasty, the servers gregarious, & the space rather "intimate" (i.e. cramped but makes you feel like you're a part of the community). Then stop at Arkakao for fresh gelato.

One of the best free attractions in South America. The thought of visiting a cemetery on your vacation seems somewhat morbid or eerie and in a way, Recoleta is just that. You can stroll through the cemetery with visible coffins and pictures of loved ones and spy out the wealthier families with air conditioning units attached to their family mausoleums. Seeing is believing here. I've never seen anything like it and doubt I will again. We didn't do a tour but I feel like we should have as it would tell the stories of the people's lives instead of aimlessly wandering around wondering who all these people are. A standout attraction in Buenos Aires.
Gotta do this. So much stuff to see and enjoy. Buenos Aires is a beautiful city and this area contributes so much to that assessment.

Stylish Recoleta. Nice to just walk around in "little Paris", look at the arquitecture, visit the marcet and the cementary, hace some afternoon tea at Alvear Palace Hotel, visit the library....stroll.... Beautiful neighbourhood!
Extremely fascinating. This is not your typical cemetery. Fascinating headstones and much history abound. Evita's final resting place draws many visitors.
Interesting and beautiful. Definitely a must see for Buenos Aires...amazing cemetery with thousands of personal mausoleums including the Duarte family and Evita herself. The history here is amazing.

Cemetery: an outstanding open air museum. Last Sunday I took a guided visit to the cemetery. It was a great experience! The day was sunny. The mausoleums and sculptures could be appreciated in their best. It is incredible to admire so many art expressions all together! Different artists and style designs capture your senses as you walk along the corridors. History is just right there passing in front of you! You only have to be receptive to the tour guide speech or simply recall events you might have lived or read about. On the other hand, you can choose different circuits to visit the area. Not only the cemetery deserves part of your day but the surroundings are worth visiting. Elegant buildings and avenues resembling a French scent, different types of museums, art galleries, design centers and malls, handicrafts fair, musicians playing live, tango dancers, restaurants, coffee shops... What else can you ask for? Enjoy your stay!

Safe area. Recoleta is a popular area and more bourgoeois than Palermo.Has good shopping, nice restaurants and considered a safe area. Make sure you include a trip to the cemetery- preferably not a one way trip.
Love this area. Great upscale area of Buenos Aires--beautiful hotels--great boutique stores and nice malls. Ricotta Mall-ok--

posh buenos aires. this is the posh area of buenos aires. it has a beautiful plaza, a design center and a handicraft fair. several street artists perform on the plaza. you will also find fancy buildings and a mall with a movie theatre.
Like nothing you've ever seen. Can't begin to explain all its uniqueness and its beauty! The mausoleums are all of different styles.

So great to walk and meet new people!. You will feel like walking on 5th Avenue !!, great stores, beautiful buildings and a very Parisian atmosphere.
Don´t forget to visit the Cemetery and some of the museums. If you go on a sunny day, you might enjoy tango dancers

Beautiful neighborhood in BA. This barrio is a must see. The cemetery is quite amazing. There are many cool shops and restaurants. It is definitely an upscale neighborhood with upscale prices. English is common. The mall has a very nice movie theater if you want to check out a film. Most American movies are in English with Spanish subtitles.

Fascinating Place. My family and I explored Recoleta which was just minutes away from the Park Hyatt one morning while visiting BA. The whole scene was interesting and it was clear there was a lot of history. All in all, a quick stroll would be about an hour but to see a fair amount of the property leave 90 minutes on your own for this visit.
Lots to see. Pretty and clean area, with gigantic trees, the cemetery, the cultural space, lots of cafes and shops, the market... at around 8pm it's buzzing with people on their evening stroll.
Great place to begin you tour. Nice historic part of town with old wealth. Must visit the Cemetery when you are there and stop for a cafe.

Not quite the same. The big artisan fair in Recoleta is bigger than ever - and the huge rubber tree is still there. But the dining choices near the cemetery and cutural center/BA Design shopping are not as good as they were when we lived here ten years ago. Some of the better ones have closed and what remains is much more focused on a meal for tourists who won't be coming back! The cemetery is a must-see.

Stylish and Fun, Recoleta is an excellent spot for your stay in Buenos Aires. In Recoleta you can find from a 5-star hotel like the Alvear Palace to cozzy boutique hotels. The area is probably one of the more stylish neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires, with beautiful buildings from the first half of the 20th century. It is a very safe area, full of restaurants for all budgets. You can visit the beautiful Iglesia del Pilar, as well as... the cemetery, with old and pompous tombs and mausoleums. It is minutes away from most neighbourhoods that you will like to visit during your stay in Buenos aires (downtown, San Telmo, Palermo).

Stunning beauty unique in the world. Recoleta's mausoleums are one of a few their kind in the world, and easily the most beautiful amongst them. Both history and art museum, the cemetery is much better with a guide (try BA Walking Tours) who can explain its symbolism, origin, and society ghost tales, and help you find Evita since there are no signs or maps, though still worth wandering through alone. It's also one of the few morning places in the city, opening at 7am.
Chic and posh Neighborhood. Beautiful turn of the XX C buildings. Great for shopping. The cementry is worth a visit. It's considered the 3rd most important in the world. Parks with milenary trees.

Best area of Buenos Aires.. Perfect place to stay when you're visiting this fascinating city. Well preserved early 20th century Beaux-Arts apartment buildings mixed with modern examples, loads of cafes, bakeries and smart shops and within walking distance of many of the city's important landmarks such as the fabulous Teatro Colon. The interesting Santa Fe Avenue borders the barrio. A bit too far to walk to San Telmo but taxis in the city are very reasonable.

Stylesville in buckets!. Most of the good hotels are located in this area, which also has great shops and restaurants. It's very Parisian in feel with lots of grand mansions from the past century and wide boulevards.

Stylish Recoleta is a Fun Place to Stroll, Shop and Eat. We love Recoleta. First of all, it's where Recoleta Cemetery is - where Eva Peron is buried. And the walkway just across from the cemetery has many small cafes and restaurants with outdoor tables. A nice spot for a cofffee drink or refresco after a walk. TheRecoleta neighborhood is known for high end shopping, and all the usually suspects are there! I especially liked Los Posadas - many cool shops and cafés. The streets are tree-lined and charming. On weekends there's a great street fair with over 100 vendors - selling everything from jewelry to leather goods to clothing and knick knacks. Definitely worth a visit.
Here lies Eva Peron. Huge mausoleums - vaguely worth a visit I suppose. Make sure you look at the map at the entrance to find Peron.

Very interesting!. It's very cool to see all these amazing mausoleums. Some were in pretty bad shape which was sad to see, but others were very well kept. I did not do the free tour, but I am sure it would have been interesting to learn about who had been in some of the mausoleums.

Very nice neighborhood and worth a trip.. We walked in this area and it is very "hip" and "artsy". Lots of restaurants, shopping, coffee shops, etc. It has a mixed crowd of young and old and is a nice place to walk around.

Recoleta - A great place to stay while visiting Buenos Aires. Having read all the other trip advisor reviews, and deciding to stay centrally in this area, I agree, Recoleta is one of the best places to stay. The area has lots of beautiful homes, more like palaces, beautiful parks, has the most amazing cemetery you will ever see, and is easy to walk to a-lot of the main attractions.

Old Monied Buenos Aires. Probably one of BA's most famous neighborhoods. Home to politicians, captains of industry and intellectuals. Wander the leafy streets admiring the many highly ornate European-style apartment buildings. There are numerous cafes and restaurants to enjoy a meal surrounded in an old-world atmosphere.
Greatt!. Nice place to take pictures and very nice restaurants with real Argentinian food. Parrilla or pasta, both work out to be the best options to me.

Elegant, safe & beautiful area!. Aristocratic atmosphere in the most posh and rich area in BA. Nice cafe' outdoor & indoor, and lovely feeling, always sun is shining, when artisans market, people coming from all over south america, selling original products ( not made in China!) at reasonable price. Best unique attraction in the area Recoleta Cimitery!
Grave of Eva Peron. There is just a small plaque to indicate that Eva Peron is buried there. Can get quite crowded and you should look out for pick pockets.

Nice area to spend some time.. This is a nice area of Buenos Aries to spend some time.It can be as a part of early morning jog or family walk.Safe area we found close to everything in Centro.Went to this area as part of our city tour.

Lots of interesting buildings, and places to eat!. Great outdoor and indoor cafes. The Cemetery is most interesting, unlike anything in North America! You need to take your time. In Recoleta, there is a modern shopping mall, across the street from the Cemetery. Also, many cafes, to sit, and enjoy the ambience.
Nice neighborhood. Felt great here. Super nice place full of reaturants to choose from. The food here in Argentina is great!

lovely part of Buenos Aires. I prefer to stay in Recoleta when I travel to Buenos Aires because it is full things to do and see and also very safe. Great ambiance on Sundays with the markets and live music at the parks. Great spot to drink some mate with friends while taking in the music.
Beautiful area. This is a great area to stay when in Buenos Aires. There is a great park with a flea market right around the corner as well as shopping.

Perfect Neighborhood to stay while in Buenos Aires. First time in Buenos Aires? Do you enjoy safe city life? Waking up, walking downstairs, take a few steps and find yourself in one of many classical cafés where once famous writers of Buenos Aires would sit, take their coffee and write and create master pieces? Then Recoleta is for you! Take a few more steps and you'll find yourself in the historical Ricoleta cemetery, the final resting place for many Argentinians dating back to 1700s. Did I mention you'll find Evita there?Turn around the corner and you'll see shops, Museums, Parks and numerous Restaurants and bars. From Recoleta you can even walk to other notorious neighborhoods like Palermo. Enjoy your stay, don't forget to order a "cafe con media luna"!
Go for a stroll. Nice to stroll. Recommend doing a walking tour to get all the history including the cemetery. Some nice shops in the area too and good ice cream.

More Beautiful than Expected. I had no idea what La Recoleta Cemetery would be like, but it was surprisingly beautiful. Most of the monuments and mausoleums in the cemetery were very ornate. The main attraction in this cemetery is the burial place of Eva Peron, but it was surprisingly small and not as ornate as others in this cemetery. Because we were on a tour when we visited this cemetery, we had limited time inside the cemetery. I would recommend visiting the cemetery on your own to allow more time there.

Recollections of Recoleta. This is a hauntingly beautiful place to see. Many beautiful statues adorn the multitude of mausoleums packed neatly into this site. The paving stones are uneven and sometimes loose. Not recommended for walkers or wheelchairs. One grave site in particular was the resting place of a young girl who, it was discovered later on, actually was not dead when placed inside, where she died. She is featured as a figure of a beautiful young girl coming out of the site, and closing the door. We were on a city tour with a guide, and it was so mesmerizing that we returned on our own on another day. Go during the weekend and there is a craft/vendor market just outside the premises. Go during the week, and there are not the hoards of people milling about, making photographing the beautiful artwork a challenge. Evita's grave is a major draw on weekends. One did not need a lot of any particular religion to be buried there, just a lot of money. The heirs could sell the mausoleum, so how could one 'forever rest in peace"? Nearby is a huge shopping mall, as well as plenty of restaurants.
Enjoyable. Easy walk around. Felt quite safe. Restaurants and bars plentiful. Central walking distance. Has great photo opportunity . Transport available on goad side

Lovely place.. I walked here from my hotel - took about 40 minutes. Lovely square with restaurants and cultural places to visit like Cemetario de Recoleta and The Cultural Centre. There was a market there too which sold lots of quirky bits.

Amazing cemetary. Everyone goes here to see Evitas grave but there are other lovely statues and stories like the lady who died young and the statue has her in her wedding dress and her dog died the same day so he is there too.

Classic Cemetery with unbelievable monumenmts. Eva Peron has a monument here. To purchase a mausoleum it can cost up to $million. The entire 13 acres is filled with classic designed crypts and the variation of them is amazing.

So much to do and full of history. Is a must always. Recoleta has more than the cementery and the frech style buildings. The most adorable secret is quite hidden behind the cementery. A short stair made in old white marble on Guido street brings to an old fashion french style space, few locals knows it.

Recoleta cementary should be on visitors Agenda. I have spent nearly two hours to watch important Tombs of famous Argentinian people. One of them was Evita Peron and her Duarte family Tomb. This place is easy to find, because most of the visitors are going this way. Near cementary are many
Restaurants, Bars and kiosks.

Interesting place to walk for an hour or so. The time we spent in the cemetery was very interesting. As noted, it's very different and interesting to browse through the crypts and see all the different styles of architecture. Some are quite over the top and visually interesting.

Must see. This cemetery is an amazing peaceful place, great to wander in and reflect about life and its value, beautiful and baroque. Once you've checked the compulsory Eva Peron mausoleum (look under the name Duarte Peron, it is located on the left hand side when you walk in the main alley, block 16) or follow the mass of people ;-) start checking out the empty alleys and look at the beautiful way people (with lots of money, obviously) send their loved ones in the beyond world.Beware of zombie cats!

Paris of the south . It's no wonder Buenos Aires is always described as European in feel. The grand buildings in Recoleta would be at home in Paris, and the welcoming green spaces and squares recall Granada or Lisbon.It may be more expensive to stay here, but do visit for strolling.

Interesting history and architecture. Interesting, but a bit difficult to get around. Probably more interesting for an art/architecture buff than for the casual visito. Make sure to pick up a guide map at the entry.

Mausoleum for Evita (and many other side). Well worth a stroll through this mausoleum. It's like a small town, with streets and alleys. The Duate family crypt is down one alley - strait down the main drag from the entrance and then hang a left - then look for the crowds.

Really cool cemetery. This cemetery is astounding. It's like all the aristocrats wanted to be as prominent in death as in life. The mausoleums are really elaborate, walking through here is a really great way to spend a nice day.

High end shopping and dining. Beautiful and polished area of BA for all you shopping and spending desires. If you like 5th Avenue better than Grenwich Village this is you place. Modern large high end hotels and designer shopping.

Classic and Elegant Neighborhood with European flair and charm. My favorite neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Classic, elegant and this european charm of the 80s in the air. Many shops, steak houses argentinian style, nice building and the famous cemetery where Evita is buried. Even if you don't have a chance of staying in one of its hotels, go there for lunch in one of the incredible steak houses of have an ice cream in Fredo, very traditional argentinian gelateria . Try dulce de leche, just love it.
fabulous place to drive around. This was on our bus tour and the buildings here are very lovely. You probably need to drive slowly but just enjoy the views.

Don't cry for me. Loved my return visit to Buenos Aires and especially the Recoleta cemetery. The family mausoleums are beautiful. I love all of the art styles and beautiful tributes to those buried there. Evita's resting place is well visited but there is so much more.

Amazing the lengths people will go to for posterity..... The grave of Eva Peron is a bit of an anticlimax compared to some of the marble mausoleums! Often a queue to shuffle past her last resting place. If you are into funereal styles this us the place to visit otherwise a quick walk around gives you the impression.

My fav place in Argentina. I love everything about Recoleta, the shopping, the breathtakingly beautiful architecture as well as the many dog walkers who clearly love their job. I am a fan of people who love animals and Argentines most certainly do. Beware the dog poo though :-)

Best part of Buenos Aires to stay!!. Central to everything including the world famous Recoleta Cemetery where Evita is buried ....a must see. Enjoyed strolling the tree-lined streets and stopping in random cafes and shops. Best area to stay in BA.
cemetery wanderings and stray cats. Historic cemetery with many tombs available, should you be interested in a purchase.Meanwhile, the cats make themselves at home there.Great to have a local guide.
Great area. This is a great area with good restaurants and sights. You can easily spend a day here, but the shopping is better other places

Beautiful Area in Buenos Aires. Don't hesitate to visit this area. It is beautiful and safe with great restaurants and shopping. There is beautiful park next to the Recoleta Cemetary. It is also a fabulous place to stay with great hotels.

Good Walking for an Afternoon. We spent a really pleasant afternoon jUst walking the streets on a Sunday. Low traffic, quiet area, great Sunday Market, really interesting church and of course the cemetery where you can see The Eva Peron tomb among many others of important Argentine families. Some great shops but also wonderful architecture. In Beunos Airies it's as important to look u p at the buildings as well as street level, some of the best features are the gables and roofs that have been applied and present some stunning features. It would be easy to spend a free afternoon strolling here. It's a 20 minute walk from the Avenue July Obelisk to the east and very easy to find.

This is a must on your Buenos Aires Itinerary. If you are a foodie then save the steak experience for Recoleta. Fervor is excellent but a little gem that I was taken to by a local with empanadas that are sooo good is El San Juanino it's on Avenida Posadas. There is a plethora of steak houses dotted around the area and I went on a steak fest in my time there and never had a bad meal as the restaurants here have a reputation to upkeep. Even though food and a cemetery doesn't sound appetizing you can visit there and also during the day, it's the kind of cemetery that celebrates life not death so it's a different experience. Also it's a great area at night as the Hard Rock Cafe is just around the corner a good Irish bar called St. Patrick if your looking for a more international style night out, but rest assured there is a cold Quilmes available everywhere in Recoleta.
Lovely part of BA to stay. Lovely and safe upmarket area of the city to stay. Very central and easy location to explore the city. Lots of cafes and restaurants to enjoy. Nice tree lined streets.

Human fantasy has no limits. There is something about the Recoleta cemetery - nowhere you can see so many different styles on such a small space. It bears evidence of the past times, of rich and powerful families and looking at some monuments in the last stage of decay one wonders what their destinies were. A small disappointment - Evita's tomb is a really modest one !

Lovely area. Around the famous Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aries .A wealthy area of the city ,lots of tree lined streets ,with a variety of architecture of the buildings .Different types of shops to browse to avoid the heat of the city .Evidence of the poor of the city sleeping on their mattresses in the park outside the cemetery .
outstanding. take the time on your own to explore this outstanding location. try and get there before the tour groups otherwise it's

Area is good. Visited the famous Eva Peron Recoleta cemetery. If you don't mind cemetaries then the architecture of the tombs is something else. If you don't have a guide you could easily get lost in there. We were on a city tour and visited here.

Mesmerizing. This place is other worldly. I wandered around for over three hours and could have spent more time but the gates were closing. There is a free tour in English a couple of mornings a week and I would suggest doing that but even without a guide you will find the rich history of Buenos Aires surrounding you.
Most Amazing Cemetary. You have never seen a cemetery quite like this one! We were awed at the architecture of the mausoleums. Really not to be missed.

Great place to wander. Recoleta has a world famous cemetery, but also has other attractions. The streets are leafy, the architecture is interesting, and the shopping is eclectic. Don't miss the cemetery, but also, don't miss a couple of hours of walking around the neighbourhood.
Cemetery neighborhood. This neighborhood is quiet and diverse, with pleasant parks which boast some extraordinary trees. Nice places to eat, a museum, handsome buildings. A good place to walk.

Lovely park, pet friendly, easy to navigate. A lovely area with a lovely park, leading to some great sights of Buenos Aires. We came here a few times over the course of our trip as this area as so much to offer from lovely, quaint restaurants, bars and shops. We were here at the perfect time on one of our visits having lunch when an impromptu pair of Tango dances set up and gave a wonderful live performance. If you are lucky enough to have this on your visit, you really are in for a treat.

Great place to visit and explore!. Stayed directly in this area. Many places and sites to see in this area as well as being central walking to major sites and walking tours. Great starting location to see all that Buenos Aires has to offer!

Great place to wander through!. Of course Evita! But don't be disappointed - her spot is very simple, with her family. Aristocrats with loads of money have statues, altars, marble - the money flows in this small cemetery. Great historical and architectural interest, mostly because of the Recoleta Cemetery

If you enjoy walking there is much to see. Bring walking shoes and a sense of adventure and you will be delighted. There is so much to see and experience here. An outdoor street festival and vendors everywhere entertained me for hours.

Of course, Evita.. Hiring a guide is good, but one does not need them The place is small, but you just follow where the visitors are headed to. Tip: Evita is in the mausoleums of the Duarte family. Do not look for Peron
Nice place to visit. This part has a lot of nice monuments you can visit, like Recoleta mall, or the cementario. Also has a lot of nice restaurants in the area.
Beautiful part of town. Beautiful part of town with very interesting and beautiful buildings and varied architecture. The trendy places are generic the world over and here is no exception.

Exclusive Recoleta. This exclusive neighborhood is a must see. Surrounded by parks, open markets, and historic sites, the Cemetery and Church of Our Lady of Pilar are mandatory stops. A wide array of restaurants promise to meet every flavor and taste.

Maybe you can take it with you??. Not unlike the pyramids, the mausoleums in La Recoleta are very elegant monuments to the individuals and families laid to rest there. It is a beautiful place to see, and of course don' t miss the Duarte Family crypt where Evita's body is said to have it's final resting place. Amazingly beautiful stone on some of these crypts!
Beautiful Area. Such a great area to walk around. So much to see. Must be one of the most beautiful parts of the city in a truly beautiful city.
Recoleta is a beautiful district and a great cemetery.. I always enjoy the cemetery, but try to avoid being there when the tour buses pack it. The district is very nice and clean.

An elegant neighborhood. Recoleta is one os the most elegant zone of Buenos Aires city.A lot of Embassies are there. An amaizing trip is organized inside the Recoleta cementery including the visit To Evita Peron's mausoleum. In the weekends there are a colorful draft fair. The Culturla Center is another interesting place as well as the Modern Art Museum.

What an amazing place!. After seeing this we couldn't even imagine how much money people have paid to inter their loved ones in Recoleta. In some masuelums you could see inside and what is inside is amazing ie: stained glass windows, marble altars and statues, paintings, etc. The most moving was a marble statue of a mother reclining with her baby next to her. There were also crypts that are badly neglected and one we actually saw the skeleton of a woman that was exposed.

Wonderful Market!. We had a lovely outdoor brunch at La Biela and then happened into the Recoleta Market which was wonderful. It meandered through a lovely park and all of the artisans were friendly and talented. I purchased many lovely gifts and after the San Telmo market which didn't compare in my estimation, I wish that I had purchased more.

Interesting experience . Although we didn't enter the cemetery, as we didn't find much interest in it, we certainly loved the neighborhood and the lovely shopping mall next to it. Its a nice foot walk around it in a nice weather

Must See. Hard to believe folks lavish this much money on mausoleums for the dead. Yet lucky for us they do as it makes for a most interesting place to visit. Went once in the rain and second time in full sun. Second time was the charm. Just wander and admire. The boxer in his boxing robe is well worth finding after you make the obligatory pass by Evita's final resting place. Then go to Recoleta Mall and get a bird's eye view of the Cemetery from its top floor.

Evita buried with good company. This cemetery was very interesting besides being where Evita was buried. The art deco mausoleums of the very wealthy was very striking. You will also hear many stories about the history surrounding Evita,not all good.

Evita's place, but it tells even more about the country.... Argentina remains a South-American country undoubtedly!All the crypts do exist in other countries (e.g. Peru, etc....) and even in some European countries. But La Recoleta in some way is special:on a relatively limited space a lot of crypts are founded,with some "neoclassic extravaganza" displayed by the powerful and wealthy argentine families and of course there's Evita...

Definitely worth a visit. A very interesting place to visit mainly because of all the famous people buried here and also because it is a massive cemetery of Mausoleums. It was so unusual to look through doors and see actual coffins sitting just inside not encased in any material. The highlight was seeing the final resting place of Eva Peron.

The epitome of peace. Liked this place very much. Situated in the heart of Buenos Aires. it's the epitome of peace. The cemetery is worth visiting and the head plaques are beautiful. The church here is worth visiting.
Recoleta Cemetary. Nice tourist spot. You can visit this spot for about 2-3 hours. There are a number of options for foodies just outside the Cemetary

Most elegant part of BsAs. Old mansions, quiet streets, not far from the hustle and bustle. What's not to like in Recoleta? Well, the economic policies have made the designers shops untenable so they are closed, but in a way this adds some muted charme to the area. Sorry for the fashionistas and nouveau riches who need confirmation of their worth by wearing the right items, but I like it better this way.

The Second Funkiest Cemetary I've Seen. The gold standard for weird cemeteries is Quito, Peru. This is close. A claustrophobic walled village of family tombs, where Buenos Aries families have revered their dead and wealth. Unless you need to know which monolithic pile of marble contains which Argentinian general or Grandee a guide is not needed. Follow the hords following the flag bearing guides to find Evita's shared tomb where she was finally put in her place!

Visit to Recoleta. Aim of the visit was to see Ev Peron's tomb. We walked from Palermo, approximately 6 km walk. This was a great way to visit. The walk was very flat. The neighbourhood is great to wander through. Higher class shops, food produce stalls. The cemetery itself was very interesting. From here you can keep walking to Teatro Colon.
Out for the day . Nice spot to tour hot today being outside bring water sunglasses and a hate easy to walk to from hotel I love to walk anywhere in the city

Exceptional Beauty. It is amazing how a Cemetry can be so Beautiful. The elegant and imposing architecture of the Mausoleums and Crypts is stunning. Eva Peron in the Cemetry is in the Family Duarte Crypt and it was a privilege to honour this Awesome Beautiful Heroine who fought for the rights of her Country Women. A must see.

Beautiful area, the cemetery is busy. A nice area to wander around when you have a few hours to kill. Safe, interesting, and with the cemetery at the heart. Nice bars and cafes to stop off. If you plan to walk, make sure you factor in the hills. They look like slopes but get you after an hour or two!

Get in, pic and go. It´s good neighborhood to walk and see the portenhos.It´s the area where is located the Recolta´s Cemetery and course, the Evita Peron´s thumb.The good things nearby are the local handicraft fair.One time here is enough, for me.

Splendid district. Yes, the district is splendid. I already made a review abbot the Recoleta Cemetery, but want to add a couple of words about the district itself. It is great historical, but at the same time, quite contemporary district in the centre of Buenos-Aieres. It is both great for tourists and for local people to live there. Clean, calm and beautiful neighborhood, cozy cafes, tango street dancers, many plants (like the famous hakaranda) – it is the atmosphere of the Buenos-Aieres indeed. Recoleta and Belgrano were my favorite districts in that beautiful city.So I strongly recommend visiting Recoleta, if you are in Buenos-Aieres.Sincerely yours,Artur

Unique Buenos Aires location. Visiting a cemetery as a tourist attraction may seem odd but this is a unique cultural phenomenon. The cemetery is very large and you can spend many hours exploring the "streets" and architecture of the monuments. There are guides available and there are also bathrooms available.

A Stroll Along Buenos Aires' Champs d' Elysee. A must see for anyone wishing to experience the finest district in all of Buenos Aires! A visual feast featuring late 19th and early 20th Century Architecture, this is the area for the final resting place of many of Argentina's notables, including Evita, former Presidents, poets, actors and athletes.The fashionable streets house superb Art Galleries, Museums, hotels, coffee shops and restaurants. It is an elegant walk through Argentinian History and best done under the expert tutelage of a guide for first time visitors.

Very up market. Some lovely houses, top class hotels intriguing shops clen streets, in fact twit ally sophisticated nd refreshing. Jut a short stroll from the top hotels Alvear Palace, Hyatt, and Four Seasons.
Lot of hype here. Visit the cemetery and see the great mausoleums. Don't expect much from Eva Peron, dig deep and get her whole story 1st. Enjoy the neibourhood.
Beautiful Neighborhood. Beautiful upscale neighborhood. Everyone is friendly. Lots of great restaurants, and hotels. La recoleta cemetery is one of the world greatest with lots of history.

Plenty to See and Eat. Our hotel was near this neighborhood so we walked through here frequently. The buildings are very reminiscent of European architecture. The whole city felt like a mellow version of Milan, Italy. Recoleta has plenty of cool buildings to look at and many restaurants and cafes your can wander between.

The best area to live in for a tourist. Central, walking distance to most of the attractions Recoleta is an easy space to live in. Has great restaurants and shopping areas including the weekend market
Worth a visit. Visiting the cemetery is a must for any first time tourist to BA. Very impressive. Of course, seeing Evita's tomb is a highlight.

Palais de Glace, a museum in Recoleta. I went to watch 2 movies, two days in a row. They were hosting a Movie Festival for the Summer at the Museum, placed at Recoleta (calle Posadas). Very nice building, nice staff, interesting movies, very easy to get there. Very recommendable. The Museum has a permanent collection and then they also host diverse artists e g sculptures, painting, video-art. I ve been there several times, I recommend it.
Interesting. Fascinating place to wander around in. The grave of Evita was still visited by the locals, but all the mausoleums were fascinating

Very interesting. An unusual place for the tourist trail but absolutely worth a visit.Good for photographers and shapes and statues make good subjects.It was extremely busy so there is limited time to noticed famous things like Eva Peron's mosulium.
Fascinating!. The cemetery is a must visit! Great location to begin one's adventure in in BA. Many wonderful places to eat here too.

Paris...sort of. If I didn't know I was in Buenos Aires, I would swear I was in Paris..except everyone is speaking Argentinean Spanish. The Recoletta is beautiful and the palaces, magnificent homes of the wealthy (quite a few are embassies) and cobblestone streets make you feel you are in Europe.The palm trees and other tropical plants may not be something you see on the Champs, but the feel and energy of this part of BA will make you smile.Take some time to soak in this part of the city...you'll be glad you did.
Not to miss. You need a good guide to make it interesting. The stories behind each of the monuments are amazing. Eva Peron rests here and the story of how she came to rest here is fascinating!

Good if you like cementaries. Intresting family vaults nice churchs ( good inside for some good pics)Nice walk around to design area and Florialis Monument. Good in early mornings as little open elsewhere in BA

Could Wander Around for Hours. We really enjoyed our time walking around Recoleta. There is so much history about the country and the people written in the epitaphs on the monuments. It was nice to stroll at our own pace without any tour guides, or people trying to rush you. However, there were a few bits of historical facts shared by a neighboring guide that really enhanced the experience, so that would be a good way to go as well. It is easy to find, and there is no entrance fee.
One of the best fun areas. One of the best fun areas of Buenos Ares. Don't miss the Sunday market. Visit the graveyard. Evita Peron is buried there

Great base for Buenos Aires. We stayed in Recoleta in a rented apartment for six weeks. We chose to stay on the 7th floor to get away from the traffic noise but ended up leaving the windows open and sleeping to the night sounds...I think the noise is part of living in B.A. Recoleta itself offers a lot of museums, parks, walks and interesting buildings but it is also a good base to start a day out to other neighbourhoods. Some days we walked to Palermo and its now very hip Soho area. Other times we hopped on a bus or subte and admired the cheap and user friendly underground system. Regardless of where you want to go Recoleta is a safe place to visit, stay and start exploring the city on foot or by transport.

Would stay here again. Stayed in Recoleta for 4 nights. We loved the quietness and tree lined streets of Recoleta compared to the hustle bustle of Centro. We could walk to the major tourist attractions and and lovely little strip of restaurants.
elaborate and mystical. Amazing cemetery for the rich and famous families of old BA. It has to be the most expensive real estate in the world, and a treat for history buffs.
Visit first thing in the morning. Beat the crowds by going first thing in the morning. Then take a few minutes to visit the tree in front of Recoleta.

Beautiful place. I loved walking through the Recoleta and marveling at the beautiful architecture of the many tombstones. They are very impressive. It definitely says a lot about the Argentine culture.

Great place to stay. We've been in Recoleta, staying in an apartment for 3 months and having walked virtually the length and breadth of the main central areas (Palermo, Belgrano, Puerto Madero, San Telmo etc etc) we definitely feel it's the best. There are bars and restaurants aplenty here, it's very safe and you have easy access to many of the key sights of interest. For anyone planning on a long stay and self catering there are lots of supermarkets, fruit and veg shops, bakers, butchers, some fishmongers etc. Whilst the breadth of products isn't as wide as back home in the UK you'll get most things you want. We've met some lovely people here and thoroughly recommend it. If/when we come back to BA we'll definitely stay in this area again.

Spooky and Spectacular. I have been to cemeteries, but nothing like this. There is a strange airy feeling to walk by such beautiful artwork while being able to see coffins! Recoleta is private cemetery that is open to the public. Cab fare with US dollars is about $6.00, having pesos is better. We didn't pay for a private guide, but walked in there by ourselves. With all the tourists, it's not a quiet place, but a very interesting place. It is very well maintain except for the mausoleum. There is no entrance fee. The maintenance personnel was very helpful in directing us to Eva Peron's family location.After an hour within the Recoleta, that was all that I can handle.There are great restaurants nearby but if one wants to save some dollars, do walk down some of the smaller streets.

Recoleta Cemetery where famous Argentines are buried. This cemetery has ornate covered plots that can cost over $500,000 US dollars. The plots and structures can be 30 feet or more in height and be 25 feet in width or more. Former presidents of Argentina are buried here, including Eva Peron (Evita). Her plot is the most visited and one of the most popular tourist attractions in the country. Well worth a visit!

Great area. Visited the cemetery in Recoleta where Evita is buried. What a strange and interesting place. They stack the coffins 10 deep and you can see a lot of them. The wealthy land owners are buried here so Evita would have hated it but it is a must see if you visit BA.
Amazing neighorhood . Very clean upscale neighborhood with high end stores. Lovely place to walk. Reminds me of the upper East Side in NYC.
Very different. What an interesting cemetery, never seen anything like this in all our travels. Certainly worth a visit, if only to visit Eva Perron's final resting place.

great neighborhood. If you're going to Buenos Aires, stay in Recoleta. There are a number of sights within walking distance such as the Cemetery, the Church of Our Lady of Pilar, The National Art Museum and the wonderful cafe, La Biela.

Strangely beautiful. Visiting a cemetery? How strange. But this one is different. Every family-grave is shaped in a different way and wandering around them is eerily interesting. It's hard to shake of the feeling of being indecent making fotos among the. But of corse there's also the grave of Evita. Harder to find but worth the search.
My favourite part of Buenos Aires. Great architecture, very nice places to eat an drink. If you like to walk that is a place for you. Miles of amazing streets with beautiful buildings and parks.

Highlight of my trip. This place was amazing. I LOVE cemeteries and have to visit them everywhere I go, and this one was incredible. We went on a dark and stormy afternoon, which made it even creepier. Didn't get a tour, which I kind of regret. Easy to find, easy to get lost in, plenty of restaurants outside. My pictures from inside this place are incredible. So gloomy and peaceful and oh I would go back in a heartbeat.

Nice neighborhood - spent a lot of time here . I was staying at the Four Seasons Hotel therefore we were right in Recoleta. But the mix of easily accessible shops, coffee shops, restaurants made it a nice package all around.For wine: find Grand Cru. For Steak: Mirasol (under the bridge - but don't let the location fool you, the food is great!)

Amazing cemetery in the middle of Buenos Aires. This is a must see place! We have visited this cemetery 3 different times, once spending 4 hours just walking around and looking at the unique monuments, statues and crypts. It is hard to describe. The first time we took a guided tour and it was a good introduction. The next two times we purchased a book that told about all the grave site, who was buried there and their history. Fascinating! Recoleta is surrounded by tall apartment buildings, office buildings, hotels and restaurants. Give yourself plenty of time to walk around.

Perfect area to stay.. Let me be clear that I am reviewing the Recoleta area, and not Recoleta Cemetary which is currently rated at number 16. It seems that lots of people are confused and posting reviews of the cemetary here.We are currently staying in a small apartment across the road from the Cemetery. The location could not be better: quietly tucked away, yet only metres from a great mall and all the action and sidewalk cafés/restaurants one could wish for. The atmosphere is very buzzy.The area is clean, safe and visitor friendly. Plenty of high end shops and restaurants, but cheaper ones too. Not to mention Starbucks, McCafe, TGIF and MacDonalds (if you want that type of thing) coexisting beside trendy, sophisticated patisseries and restaurants.Oh, and did I mention that there's an interesting cemetery here too...

Surprise . We came across this place and couldn't believe it. Ok, it's not a museum or an amusement park, but it's pretty interesting and special. Took a note of some of the names of people who are there- the good and the great of Argentina. Especially intrigued by the story of the Irishman who became the 'father of the Argentinian navy'

THE OLD ,ELEGANT BUENOS AIRES. Very popular district in Buenos Aires. It's the old and elegant of this amazing city, full of beautiful buildings ,a park ,the famous Hotel Alvear, the Four Seasons, the best shops and the famous Recoleta Cemetery where is Evita Peron.Also has very good restaurants and cafes.Don't miss it!
Beautiful. A very nice neighborhood of Buenos Aires. Beautiful homes, gardens and streets. Some good restaurants in the area. Must visit!
Nice neighborhood . Nice neighborhood. Nightclub noise, though. Visit the cemetery. Visit it again . then dance the Tango at a club.

A surreal experience. Before visiting Recoleta, I could not have imagined a cemetery to be such a great tourist attraction and for very valid reason. It is so surreal to be here...not to be missed at all.

A must see in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is one of the must see in Buenos Aires. A very practical way to visit it is joining one of the free walking tours, available in Internet and guided by Argentinian university students of History.

Macabre cemetary. Most only visit to see Evita's tomb and it's really not worth the effort. It's a huge collection of over ornate mausoleums. There is a free guided tour but don't bother - it's not dirty your time!
Ritzy part of Buenos Aires. Gorgeous buildings and wonderful neighborhood. Loved the shops and the vibe of this neighborhood best.
Highend area. This is the high end area though not the busiest. Top hotels are all here, but it is still walking distance to the central Florida Street.

Rich suburb of Buenos within close proximty to Palmero. Recolta is Buenos Aires most affluent suburb and as such is a good place to visit but not so much to stay within. I would recommend spending a day visiting both the major tourist sites of Recoleta and Palmero together. To get here you take the metro 'green line' and get off at either the Facultad de medicina or Pueyyredon stop. From there I suggest walking through it's streets visiting it's various sites on the way. Start at Recoleta cementery > Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes AND/OR MALBA > Floralis generalis before tracking home via the closest metro station by walking through one of Palmero's parks.
far away and not so nice. We expected more. It was expensive, a lot of little stores but super expensive and not as nice and special as Barrio La Boca

Great area. Recoleta is an ideal place to stay to see Buenos Aires. Quiet, residential area with small (boutique type) hotels, number of good restaurants (both well and less well known). In addition to the cemetery you are very close to the museum of fine arts (with very good holdings). If you are up to a bit of walking you can walk to most of the adjacent areas of town as well but if walking is not your forte your a short taxi ride from everywhere.

The poshest most upmarket area of Buenos Aires. Best seen on the tour bus. Things to see - Recoleta Cemetario where Eva Peron is buried, Avenue Alvear, the most expensive real estate in BA and the Hotel Alvear the most luxurious hotel, and people watching in the many not too expensive cafes. Also shopping in the designer stores and art galleries, if you can afford it.

Best location in BAs. Recoleta area was for me a good choice to stay during my visit.See why below:1. Near to subway and train stations: Line C and D plus train stations are about 15min walk2. Clean and safe3. Very nice old architecture, french style4. Parks and more parks together with palermo area5. A big quantity of fancy and typical restaurants, burges, bars and coffee shop
Elegant and very green. It's a beautiful part of Buenos Aires. Lots of embassies and beautiful leafy streets. Some nice little restaurants and great gardens. Very safe and neat...

Didn't meet the expectations.. Maybe I just expected too much (I don't like cemetaries in general, but I was nicely surprised by the old cemetary in Salzburg, and after this I thought I might give this one a chance too, especially considering it's famosity). It has a lot of grandeur, but it's not extraordinary beautiful. The grave of Evita Peron is the most famous one, but certainly not the most beautiful one. Some of the graves could use maintenance. It's difficult to orientate at the cemetary, but free guided tours in English and Spanish are offered, which add more extra values to the place, since the stories and history is more interesting than the view itself.

A great place to base yourself in Buenos Aires. We rented a private apartment in Recoleta on Calle Junin and when we got there we discovered that it was about 4 blocks to Recoleta Cemetery, which meant that we were near many great restaurants, parks, museums and shops. We attended the crafts fair outside the Cemetery over the weekend and found a lot of beautiful crafts made by local artists. We ended up spending the bulk of our visit to Buenos Aires in Recoleta because it had everything!

Unmissable. History and atmosphere are here, but go soon, before they introduce an entrance fee. A guide is a must, and on Tuesday and Thursday at 11am there is a free English speaking walking tour. The tour is informative and really brought history to life, without this you just scratch the surface. Very popular with locals and tourists, this is a unique experience.
Love this area!. The city of BsAs is devided in many areas, all lovely in it's own way. La Recoleta is kind of a posh area with a lot of nice arquitecture, restaurants among other.
Love it here . The old world of Parisian splendour and grandeur. Non pretentious in the main and just stunning, especially along Alvear street

Amazing neighboarhood. Without regard of from where are you coming from, al Recoleta neighborhood is breathtaking. The antique cemetery, where you can find tombs of very famous people, the cultural center, where you can hear music, look at paintings and all kind of shows, the antique french style buildings. Unmissable

Unmissable!. No one can come to Buenos Aire without visiting this phenomenon. From the lovely excentric Chunkie KitKat lover in the information booth, to the grandiose mausoleums and the reverential atmosphere. Don't miss it!
Breathtaking tombs from 3 centuries. A must see cemetery, marble and stone art. Its historic- Evita's tomb was not all that interesting compared to the rest of the place.

Elegant beautiful neighborhood. Elegant, beautiful neighborhood with great architecture, parks nearby, many museums, enormous mall, the famous cemetery where Eva Peron is entombed, many restaurants and cafes, all price ranges, the famous La Biela Cafe, safe area for walking.

Overwhelming affluence with expression of all styles of sculupteres. The rich families who escaped the yellow fever epidemic in 1882 established Recoleta which was at the time far from the centre of town . Now the expensive and exclusive part of town . The world renown cemetery is outstanding in the beauty of its design and variety of sculpture styles , including the final rest place of Eva Peron . Must see (preferably with a guide who can tell the stories)

A beautiful residential neighbourhood. Recoleta is a beautiful residential neighbourhood close the centre of Buenoa Aires and famous for the cemetery which contains hundreds of mausoleums and statues. Apart from the cemetery, Recoleta is the location for Argentina's national library, and several museums and art galleries. Some of the streets and buildings are very reminiscent of Paris and it's a most attractive area to explore.
Recoleta. Upmarket area Worth a visit to Cemetry and new terrace area behind for lunch Also visited Eva Perons museumJust behind botanic gardensVery good

Good stop if you are in the area. This is a good place to stop if you are in the area. It is cool to see all the different tombs and how the different families chose to honor their dead. Eva Peron is probably the most famous person buried here.

Fascinating...a must to visit. We spent two hours wandering through this wonderful cemetery...something we would not do at home. This place is very personal and everyone has their favourites to visit. If you come to Buenos Aries ..please go as it is well worth the visit.

Much to offer. This area of Buenos Aires has much to offer. From the famous cemetery to local restaurants and shops and the artisan's market, it is an area that provides much for the tourist. We were lucky to have met Simon at the gates of the Recoleta Cemetery. He provided an excellent tour. He is very knowledgable and provides so much more than one could hope to glean without his services.

Great shopping area. I enjoyed walking around on Alvear. The shopping is good, high end mostly. Don't miss Cardon, two stores, both on Alvear. Park Hyatt has a lovely bar for drinks. Alvear Palace hotel is beautiful. Very safe area.

Who would have thought a cemetery could be so interesting.. Not everyone thinks that a trip to a cemetery is an obvious part of a holiday but this one is fascinating with many of Argentina's leading personalities entombed here in quite elaborate mauseleums. Eva Peron ended her days here after being shunted around the world.

Very pleasant neighborhood. A nice area to walk around. Lovely architecture on many buildings. Streets filled with upscale apartments snd shops , yet everyday people out shopping for groceries and sipping coffee.

Beautiful area of BA to visit. Fantastic area with great cafes and shops, A must place to visit. Take a wander around the mausoleums, see the stunning architecture of the tombs of the very rich families of Buenos Aires . See if you can find Eva Peron's resting place ! It is there !
A must see in Buenos Aires. This is a major attraction in the heart of the Recoleta district. It is amazing to see all the mausoleums from the rich and famous of Buenos Aires History

The lower North Shore of Buenos Aires . We live in Sydney and are staying in a hotel in this suburb. Walking around it definitely has a feeling similar to Neutral Bay or North Sydney. It is very leafy and has a lot of apartment buildings. The sidewalks are relatively well kept (compared to San Telmo and La Boca) and no sign of dog poo despite many dogs shows the type of person who lives in the suburb.We saw quite a few people sleeping rough so you may need to be careful at night.
Stunning architecture. A great region of BA. Fantastic architecture and designer shopping and cafes. Market on a Saturday alongside the cemetery . The cemetery is a must visit.
Beautiful and nostalgic neighborhood.... Spend a whole afternoon, or a full day, in La Recoleta - you won't regret this urban experience in one of the most interesting capital cities in the Americas!

Beautiful area with beautiful architecture . Recoletta is known to be one of the most beautiful and wealthy areas of Buenos Aires. Walking around this area will make you realize why people call Buenos Aires the Paris of South America. I always enjoy walking around this area.

elegant. Recoleta is a nice neighborhood, there is a lot to see, you have a park with vendors every weekend, the cemetery and lots of restaurants with good food and ambiance, you can sit outside and people watch or enjoy the tango dancer that populate the area

One of the must see places in BA. We stayed at the Park Hyatt in the Recoleta. You haven't been to BA if you haven't walked through here. And there are affordable places to grab a bite when you're there.

Dead Interesting!. We would not normally go visit a cemetery while on holiday but this one is so out of the ordinary. There are almost 5000 mausoleums all differing in size and grandeur, the most famous of them being Eva Peron. Do get a map though, it only costs 20 pesos, then you can pick out the ones you want to visit.

Great Atmosphere. Lovely vibrant area of Buenos Aires. The restaurants are a little pushy with their business but other than that I thoroughly enjoyed walking around and soaking up the atmosphere and walking the dance demonstrations.

Loved this area. We stayed in Recoleta for a week and absolutely loved it!! It is very clean, and easy to navigate! Great bookstores, coffee shops and more healthy options like juice and salad bars... If in BA, would highly recommend visiting and staying here!!

Recoleta the Beautiful. It took us about 45 minutes to walk all the way from Plaza San Martin to Recoleta. Very nice upscale neighborhood. Visited Recoleta Cemetery where Mausoliums are most impressive. Took us a long time to find Evita's modest resting place in the Duarte Family Mausolium. Artisans' market in the area is very colorful and interesting as well. Restaurants, Fine Art Museum, Plazas etc. are all in walking distance.

Sun, windowshopping, bookshops and good food . I enjoy walking in Recoleta. You can do many things and mainly see and be seen. This quiet neighbourhood is full of ideas and appealing restaurants and bars. Nice shops and avenues where you can find everything.Nice architecture, a well known cemetery and churches. This place is lively and lovely.

Charming neighbourhood. Our hotel was in this area and we loved walking around the neighbourhood looking for nice cafes ans restaurants. It seems like a decent neighbourhood. There is plenty shopping as well and convenient to get to other places in the city.

Don't Cry for me Argentina - rich and famous dead flaunt their wealth. Visited to see the final resting place of Eva Peron. The cemetery is like hundreds if not thousands of mini churches or shrines to the rich and famous dead of Argentia. Even in death the wealthy flaunt their wealth. The vaults had glass windows in which you can peer and see coffins of dead located decades ago. Fascinating.Peron's family vault was modest by comparison to some which were elaborate, ostentatious and imposing.

Worth the visit. We heard and read much about Recoleta Cemetery. The actual visit did not disappoint. I am interested in old cemeteries and their history and this was an amazing place with many people of importance to Argentinian history resting here, including Eva Peron.
Cemetery at Recoleta. Recoleta is nice surrounding, where there is the famous Cemetery including cemetery of Evita Peron. Also there is a shopping center and a nice park around.

Definitely worth seeing with a guide. We only spent a few hours here walking around with a private guide, but it helped to learn about the historical as well as present life to the buildings, parks, statues and overall neighborhood. Buenos Aires was a bit of a sad place during our week of visiting (hubby was working for 4 of the days so we weren't full-time tourists)--this neighborhood definitely reflected some of the better days of the city's past.
Beautiful and very European. Liked it a lot. It was beautiful and very European style. It was like any street in Paris or Spain. Nothing out of this world. People looked sad and unfriendly.
Nice, upscale neighborhood . Recoleta is suppose to be an upscale neighborhood with fancy restaurants, bars and night clubs. Nice place to walk and enjoy.
Lovely place. Great place to walk around - but make sure to join a walking tour because there's a lot of interesting info to learn about the area!

Cool area and worth a visit. Shops, restaurants and fashionable real estate. Interesting that real estate is so expensive in this area as the majority of places have a view to the cemetery. Worthwhile to walk around just to have a good feel of the area.

Suburban changed into high end palaces etc. It used to be suburban and wetland and summer houses.Now it has all kinds of high end apartments and palaces from late 19 and early 20 centuries. It's fun to walk around ,probably better with a guide as there are so many stories behind the scene of each palaces.

Never seen anything like it.. Recoleta is an amazing part of town with a cemetery for the rich and famous. The cemetery has rows and rows of mausoleums, including that of Eva Peron. The neighborhood is well worth browsing--they had a nice craft market going on the day that we were there.
Very Nice Area. This is an upscale neighbourhood I walked through on my walking tours. The old mansions are magnificent and the various styles of architecture are worth seeing.

This is a con't miss site. Cemeteries are often sites to see, and this is one of the most amazing you will find. The tomb of Evita of course was the highlight, but the history that you see here is a must see.

Quiet, Safe Neighborhood for Exploring Buenos Aires. Recoleta was home to many of the prominent Buenos Aires families in the early 1900s. Today, the French style palaces have been converted into hotels and apartments. But the leafy, shaded streets are quiet and contain many great shops. The Recoleta Cemetery is also within easy walking distance and something that must be seen in person.

Much More than just Evita's last resting place!. If you are staying in one of the top hotels, chances are that you are in this neighborhood. Apart from the cemetery that houses Evita's remains, this is a great neighborhood to walk around, browse through the countless shops and boutiques, stop for a coffee, have a memorable meal, and get a feel for how some of the locals live in this high-end residential district.

The "best" part of the pithole that is Buenos Aires. If you have to go, stay here. There are very few restaurants or places to go, other than four great gelato shops on one street. I would not recommend to any of my friends to go here, but if you must, stay here.

Recoleta Cemetary. If you are interested in architecture, art, design, symbology and a unique time in history (1840-1940) that will never be repeated again, set aside more than a half day at Recoleta Cemetary. If you can, arranged for a qualified tour guide because it's too big to do on your own efficiently. The facades, the stone, the statues, the gates, the alters, the mosaics on the insides, the spiral stairs down two levels below grade, .... it is all over the top and give you insights into the wealth and sophistication of the original family, their beliefs at the time, and the abiltiy for them to have an abundance of choices as to how to be remembered. Evita is the least interesting tomb in this cemetary although one of the better stories. So, take an umbrella because there is no shade here and take your time to appreciate how special a place this is.

Nice for a walk. . Toured as past of a walking tour. One if the cleanest places in the city and nice avenues. We walked in Sunday so shops were closed. With a short visit but not a destination unless you are going to the cemetery.
Things to do in Buenos Aires. Don't miss Recoleta. While everyone goes to see Eva Peron's grave site, there are so many other fascinating ones to see.

A Class Act. It's great to walk around here. People watching; strolling along without a care in the world; stopping every so often for a coffee in a quaint old cafe. There are things to make a beeline for: Cemetario de Recoletas, parks, (my favourite) the National Library of Argentina. The streets ooze elegance, chutzpah…
Recoleta. This is a ritzier part of BA. It is more expensive too. My parents stayed there a year earlier and enjoyed it. It is safer than other parts too.

Beautiful and safe place to eat and stay. Plenty of shops, cafes, ice cream shops (helaterias) and sights nearby.
This area has lots of lovely European architecture, as well as plenty of transportation options.
The neighbourhood is an upscale one, so that you'll have no problems or issues walking around (even late at night).
Pleasure. Nice place lots of places to eat and lots of shops, the locals were very friendly and helpful. There is a craft market where you can shop for jewelry and local stuff.

make sure you get a guide. We hired a guide standing at the entrance; she charged 50 pesos per person and was worth way more than that. We would not have understood much of what we saw, or the history, without a guide. Fascinating place to visit. allow an hour or so.

Bond Street?. The last time we visited Recoleta is was resplendent with all the haute couture shops you'd expect in any large city but - sadly - they have all but closed down in this residential upmarket part of the city. Though Recoleta still remains a lovely area to visit for the parks and its famous mausoleum

Really nice area to stay in. We stayed at an airbnb studio which was in perfect location - surrounded by shops, restaurants and close to everything. Ricoleta is great for waling, although there are plenty of buses, subway nearby and taxi readily available. We loved everything about it. Please keep in mind that shopping around here did not seem like a bargain hunting opportunity.
A can't miss in BsAs!. So many amazing things found here. A trip to the cemetery is a must for any visit. Try a walking tour of the neighborhood with BA free walking tours. 4 hours well spent.

Don't Hurry Through Recoleta. Strolling this neighborhood is really the only way to see it. It is a combination of so many elements --- great shopping, luxury goods, history, convenience and fun restaurants -- so go slow and don't be embarrassed to stare just a little. First, the street architecture is entertaining -- some nouveau but mostly French Fin de Siecle. There are great shops on Alvear, both near the hotel and in the hotel arcade. The Recoleta Cemetario is surrounded on all sides by parks, shops, malls, and restaurants, both inside and on the terraces. The cemetery is completely unexpected: it is grander and more elaborate than you can possibly imagine. There is a donation/fee. Take your time and look closely at the ornate funeral styles. Another stroll will lead to the parks nearby with their monumental statuary.
Loved it. What a great experience. Relaxing area and great place to people watch. Shops and restaurants to experience. .................

Well Worth a Visit. We stayed in Recoleta and had the opportunity to walk around the area and experience it up close.It has some really beautiful old buildings with interesting architecture and a nice park near the cemetery and there are a number of cafes nearby. This park has a market on the weekend which is quite good but the prices are a little expensive for quite simple jewellery etc.It is quieter than some other areas of BA but is still within easy reach of the major city sites and has some very good restaurants.

An interesting area. With only a short time in Buenos Aires, this was an area we wanted to visit and we were not disappointed.The cemetery is not a large area, but there are great opportunities for the photographer and there was an English speaking guide to help.Nearby is a large shopping Mall and there are quite a few restaurants.

Walkabout and Gaze . So much to see and take in, La Recoleta epitomises BA lifestyle, vibrant and visually interesting especially for those who are visiting for the first time, oh come all ye faithful!

Unique. I don't believe there is anything else like this Cemetery . It is as if the dead have their own town. The coffins lie in layers. Some of the mausoleums are so ornate. And it also contains Eva Peron's modest tomb.

Paris in BA. This is an old upscale part of BA. You'll certainly notice it's greatly decorated buildings in mostly Baroque style, reminding you on Paris. The shops are the same, with great quality products, imported goods..etcA lot of well maintained parks also. Take a two hour walk through the neighborhood to or from the famous Recoleta cemetery.
Nice for a stroll. Nice houses, tree-lined avenidas, lovely shops and galleries and a distant feeling of Paris and Madrid.

A little town in itself. Recoleta cemetery, most famous for Evita's (Eva Duarte Peron's) tomb is like a little town of its own. The numerous mausoleums are very tightly assembled and a walk through the many paths offers a lot of insights into life and death of the locals

A nice area to spend an afternoon. It is one of the well known areas of Buenos Aires, best known for the Cemetery, it also is home to many restaurants, bars and stores of all kinds.
