Specially to my liking is the craft fair held Saturday and Sunday afternoons in which they offer typical art and crafts of the country at reasonable prices.
Argentine history in the middle of town. This attraction is not to be missed. A cemetery in the middle of town surrounded by restaurants and cafés. Don´t miss the church with it´s silver altar

Friendly people but the area is very dirty. I was surprised at how much trash I saw in the streets. Could be so much nicer if people cared about where they live. Many reviews mention that this area is affluent but I don't think it shows. Our hotel and location was good. We found some nice cafes and restaurants. Didn't like the sales pitches in front of stores and restaurants begging us to come in. The cemetery was very interesting and great to photograph. Overall ok.
AMAZING BUILDINGS !!!. The Recoleta neighborhood is the trendy part of the city. We did a walking tour around the Hotel in this neighborhood and it is beautiful. Would be like Manhattan in New York.
One of my favorites in BA!. Recoleta has a lot to offer, you must visit the cemetery and the parks along it. There's also a shopping center right next to it.

Recoleta twice. Recoleta is a beautiful neighborhood where is safe to walk around and has a big park. The first time there was after a free tour, we visited the church, the park and Cafe La Biela. We found that there was a art and handicraft market, so we walk around. A man came forward and asked for money to buy food, and I ignored him. Nothing harmful except that he was still waiting from a few steps away causing some uneasy.We went back again for the Recoleta Cementary which is worth the extra trip. I suggest to go for the free tour that takes you to Recoleta in the morning and spend the rest of the day there, plenty to see.

Beautiful Place to visit. Recoleta is a beautiful neighborhood where is safe to walk around, sit at a table at an outdoor cafe to people watch. There are great bars and restaurants while you can see couples dancing tango. I would recommend highly to visit this area during your visit to Buenos Aires.

Best neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. This neighbourhood is full of parks and lovely architecture (mostly french style); coffee shops and bars, and also, the most exclusive stores in the city. You can visit the Nacional Art Museum, wich is free and walk around the classic architectonic style University of Buenos Aires and also walk to the floralis generica, wich is a huge metal flower that moves with the sun. You can see the strange National Library and visit its famous cementery. It's the most beautiful part of the city. And also, if you go on a weekend, you have a huge handycrafts fair with product of a very high quality.
Walk, shop, eat and drink. A great place to walk around, good at nights and pkenty of restaurants and shops... Watch out for pick pockets

Great Visit. the Recoleta Cemetery is a must visit. I would advise getting there early as it's quiet and not as warm. the details on the ornate tumbs are wonderful. There is also an artisan market with great gifts outside 5 days a week.
Shopping and coffee. This is the shopping area of Buenos Aires. Many unique boutiques and coffee shops. Some street and even closed to vehicles.

Beautiful part of the city. I stayed in a hotel here which was a great choice as I was surrounded by gorgeous streets to wander.The architecture and the parks are simple amazing. It reminded me a lot of Paris. Maybe as good as Paris ?
Nice neighborhood!. Good place to stay and visit! Safer than Microcentro and plenty of nice restaurants (reservation - almost is small and family restaurant)

Recoleta cemetery. The most beautiful and impressive cemetery I ever visited. A must to visit. We did it in the pouring rain, very appropriate for all the tears that must have shed there. I'm glad to have seen the tomb of Evita Peron.

A must in BA.. I loved the tranquil heaven - pun meant - in the middle of a horribly busy, noisy and unsafe city. In face I went there twice during my 4 day stay just to escape from it all. it is impossible to get a feel of it in one time anyway.

Very nice neighborhood . You can pretty much walk 24/7 around Recoleta, you will find all sorts of stores and restaurants. Busy streets filled with all sort of people, families and couples.
Bookstores and ice cream shop that are open at 3:00 am.
You can walk to the Cemetery where Eva Perón is buried if you have some spare time.

Landscaping. Beautiful...upmarket...landscaping... Floralis Generica...steel flower in a pool...a place to relax. La Recoleta Cemetry for beautiful structures created as last resting places for the deceased of aristrocratic families.

Fascinating, tranquil City of the Dead tucked into upscale BA. My favorite Buenos Aires landmark, this is a city block's worth of the spooky tombs of Argentina's most influential historical figures. From writers to fighters to plain old rich people, the city's corpses of import lie in a little city of ancient, opulent mausoleums. Eerie, interesting, and beautiful, this is a must-see.
Shopping and amazing architecture. Quick walk through the area reveals some awesome shops but the buildings and architecture is what really sets this place apart.

My new second home!. We were incredibly lucky to find an apartment here in Recolata and have loved exploring its nooks & crannies. Yes, it is wealthy, and this is obvious when you're walking the streets. But it is also beautiful, with a number of parks and many gorgeous old buildings to gaze at, with characters peppering the streets. Love it.

Classiest hood in BA. You can feel the wealth here and just imagine the wealthy and well connected just siphoning off the pesos from the top of every government program. They certainly aren't rich from high tech. But it's a beautiful and very densely populated barrio.
Beautiful neighborhood. Very nice calm neighborhood. The cemetry is not something out of the world, but it worth the visit if you are in the area. Big mall near by, very expensive for me.

Be sensible. I visited Recoleta with my wife. As anywhere in South America it is a good idea not to advertise the fact that you are a tourist and that you may be carrying cash and valuables. A chap from the USA insisted on wearing his rolex on the tour of Recoleta. The next time we saw him he had just been held up at knifepoint and was now minus his Rolex. Lots to see in Recoleta, just keep your wits about you,

Wonderful Neighborhood. We are staying in this area and really are enjoying it. There are so many restaurants, shops and people walking about. We rented an apartment here and can find everything we need within a few blocks It is easy to get to other areas from here as well.

Very nice time. Recoleta has a lot of historic buildings and cute streets and places all over it. To spend a afternoon walking around it is really great and pleasant. I would recommend you to do a city tour first so when you walk around there you would know more about the places you will walk by. For your own safety I would recommend you to take a walking tour with a guide so in this way you would not be alone during your walk around Recoleta. I highly recommend it

Elegant area of BsAs. Love walking this area with fine shops and the Recoleta Cemetary next door. A must is to sit under the tree at La Biela and order coffee or a cold drink and people watch. Great spot in Recoleta.

Beware that the cats might be sick. Well I mostly enjoyed Recoleta, but as a solo traveler this trip I was reluctant to go down the little pathways that didn't have any tourists in them as I saw some sketchy looking men hanging around who looked like they could mug you. They stand out because it is those young men and tourists basically at this cemetery, and cats who upon close inspection, look like they have the mange. I saw Evita's tomb. Carlos Gardel is not here, buried somewhere else and those were the two I was mainly interested in. The cemetery is a little spooky and very atmospheric. I thought of that scene in the House of Spirits where they bury the father at the end. I don't know if it was filmed there but it looked very similar. What is really cool is the tree outside the cemetery -- I believe it is over 200 years old and super magnificent. Check my photo, it is very pretty and worth seeing as much as the cemetery.

Great place to just walk around and look around. We first looked around on the free walking tour, which was fantastic, but also strolled around ourselves. Lots to see and do, with all the different architecture on show! Highlight being the cemetery.

Great place to walk around.. We rented an apartment for a week through Air b-n-b. We've been able to walk to most of the places we wanted to visit. All of metro Buenos Aries seems to be clean and pleasant, but Recoleta is a jewel. Definitely the best neighborhood we've seen. Lots of shopping, many parks and nice people.

Pretty amazing cemetery. This is one of the "myuset see" places in the city. We visited as part of a highlights tour, but was well worth the stop. It's pretty amazing place, much larger than anticipated and had the feel of above ground mausoleum cemeteries of New Orleans, only much more condensed and special. The highlight was the final resting place of Eva Peron.

Walking Through a Story Book - Unique and Interesting Stories Behind Each Grave (Book a Tour Guide for this Place). We had two separate tour guides take us through the Recoleta cemetery, and, other than the Evita Peron tomb, both tour guides had unique and different stories to tell of different tombs. Art and impressiveness aside, I can't imagine having gotten as much out of the Recoleta experience if it had not been for the tour guides and their knowledge of the unique stories of each of the individuals there. It felt like walking through a story book, and I imagine that the individuals buried there must enjoy their people watching of us - possibly maybe even enjoy the visitors. Other than some stairs to enter the cemetery, a stroller was easy to push around (even flooring within the cemetery). There are bathrooms in the cemetery, but they had no toilet paper - so bring your own, just in case. I was fortunate that I had some toilet paper on hand. The restrooms were clean. There is no entrance fee. The Evita Peron tomb is a MUST - not for the impressiveness of the tomb, but for the touristy aspect of it. Read up on her before you go, it will mean more then.
Loved this area. It's so lively and beautiful, I felt like I was in Barcelona. Recoleta cemetery is definitely worth checking out.

Walk, people-watch, cemetery . I got a bit lost wondering around Recoleta. Nice tree-lined streets and up-scale homes. Unlike the Boca, and other points south, Recoleta's boundary lines are harder to follow.
I spent most of the afternoon wondering the streets and visiting the famous cemetery.

Not Impressed. Recoleta is considered to be one of the nicest areas of Buenos Aires. The cemetery filled with mausoleums is well worth a visit and It does have a few historical sights and museums to visit but that's about it. There are a lot of parks but they are very poorly maintained if they are maintained at all and littered with trash. There were numerous groups of men ranging in age from the late teens to upper 20's wandering around everywhere and very little police presence which made my wife and I feel a little unsafe. I hate to bash an entire city but we were not impressed with Buenos Aires including Recoleta. It seems like a city lost souls who are unable to help themselves achieve a decent lifestyle. The long history of corrupt government probably created this situation and it will not change until the people Buenos Aires do something to help themselves and their city.

Impressive. Walking these streets you can really get the sense that this neighborhood was the place for the Aristocracy. Mansions galore. Some of the recent buildings really don't measure up to the hype.
Plenty to do. Nice area blessed with attractions such as modern shopping mall, restaurants, outdoor parks, craft stalls, churches, Recoleta cemetery. Lovely to stroll around on a sunny day.

Home base for a week. I really enjoyed this neighborhood. It is relatively quite but with great restaurants, museums, and of course the cemetery. I loved just walking the streets. It's probably a bit more pricey than other areas of the city and definitely quieter. If you want more of a nightlife, another area would be more your speed. However, the Subte is easy to hop on to Palermo and the cab ride back is under 100 pesos.

Great Neighborhood!!!. A great, green neighborhood, colorful markets and interesting people. The fair is full of stalls from local artists. You can buy woolen clothing, shoes, slippers, art paper, ceramic, fabric, wood and genuine leather. Simply amazing!!!
Worth to check it out!!!!. I loved to walk here, there are so many museums (no entry fees), old houses, palaces, parks over there!!!!!
Beautiful old cemetery. Recoleta is a lovely cemetery with interesting monuments and beautiful sculptures. Good for anafternoon stroll
nice place. A nice place ,espacially in weekend in the shopping mall or in the nearby park where handy crafts are sold.

It's great to visit. I went to recoleta mall it's really nice and 3th floor have some cafe and restaurant and Hereford parrila is has nice view to see cementry and great food and great best exchange money I this shopping mall l will tell best. Rate in city

Calm Historic Area. Recoleta is definitely an area to make a stop during your trip to Buenos Aires. It's an upscale neighborhood that's nice to spend an afternoon walking around. You can visit the Recoleta Cemetery and nearby Museo de Bellas artes while in the area. For Shopping there are some more upscale leather goods stores - I prefer it to the very touristic Calle Florida. That being said, prices will be a bit higher, but worth it. On the weekends there is a "hippie" art fair where you can find hand-made goods - but we didn't find anything to write home about.

Some beautiful buildings in this part of Buenos Aires.. Walking through this part of BA was always a suprise, There are palaces and beautiful Parisienne styled buildings. Many contemporary buildings have the most stunning entrances and doors. There is brass, wrought iron and beautiful woods used with taste and style.A city walk here will also turn up shops with eclectic merchandise. There are many food shops and places to eat.

Beautiful area in Buenos Aires. This is the area that I loved most in Buenos Aires. It reminds me of Paris.Nice streets where you can easily find very nice restaurants and cafés as well as many various shops and boutiques.The park facing the cemeteries is really good.Charming atmosphere while walking in Recoleta.

Cool area with a great art/food fair on the weekend. wonderful opportunity to catch this incredible city's vibes and offers. The whole suburb is ideal for going out and hanging out, amazing cultural centers and museum close by. the market that has a lot of everything will amaze you. just grab a mate (the local tea), have a bite, sit on the grass and watch the happenings
Excellent area of the city. This a beautiful area to walk, enjoy the cafes, have a drink, a gelato. Have lunch under the umbrellas next to the giant rubber trees.
Beautiful, Elegant. filled with the charm of this Parisian style city. You can walk the streets and enjoy the homes, the park, restaurants and shopping.
excellent part of the city. there are various parts of HUGE Buenos Aires and Recoleta is one of areas, which is great to walk around and relax...

Beautiful section of Buneos Aires. We began our walking tour of the Recoleta district with a little shopping. We found a marvelous shop called "Cardon" that was filled with fine leather goods, and very beautiful silver items. The young man and woman in the shop could not have been more helpful and congenial when explaining the leather in the hat my husband bought....it comes from an animal that looks like a giant Guinea pig, very beautiful - the leather, not the animal...no it's not endangered, and is domestically raised. Then we walked to the national art museum, stopped for ice cream at Persicco, returned to the cemetery, watched the tango dancers on the corner, and the numerous dog walkers in the park, and hailed a cab back to the hotel. It's a beautiful part of Buenos Aires.

A must!. Come here to visit the resting place of Evita and countless other prominent Argentinians. Just wandering around the grand masoleums will give one a sense of Argentinian history - the names of those who made history will help to contextualize some of the names you'll see on street signs and plazas. It is located in a lovely part of town with a plethora of wonderful restaurants and cafes.

Recoleta - How much time should one spend looking at old Graves?. Everyone says - Go see Recoleta!My question is...Why?This is a rather large area devoted to large Mausoleums by families obviously trying to out do each other in Grandeur.Evita was very difficult to find - HINT- it is under her family name of DuarteIt was free for us this month, but they are going to start charging admission soon.It is a shame that many mausoleums are in disrepair and some even opened or broken into. If you have nothing to do stop by. If you have a real plan, skip it!
Tango!. Loved it! My favorite neighborhood in beautiful Buenos Aires. You can read some tango lyrics on the floor, and there's a lot of places to eat, shop and take a look around.
Great place to visit. Lots to see in this area. With old buildings and the interesting cemetery where Eva person is buried . Shopping area as well.

Eva Perone. quite difficult to find Eva Peron - map as enter cemetery and her grave is highlighted but no numbers on the mausoleums. She is buried under the family name not Peron. cemetery is fascinating and worth a visit. Lots of guided tours

Historic and upmarket. The cemetery is well worth a visit, Eva Peron is buried there. The market next to the cemetery is good value for jewellery etc. Many very nice coffee shops and restaurants, even an Irish pub! OK to walk around.
Lively and Historic. The Recoletta Flea Market, The Cemetery & the Art Museum are all well worth a wander. Lots of local artisans in the area and parks for kids to play.
Superb Neighborhood. So much to see and do . You can have great meals, go to the market, the cemetery, Shopping, sight seeing, museums ...
Visited the region during the free walking tour. An amazing neighborhood and a beautiful cemetery. The location is filled with Argentinian history and nice bars.
A very fancy Neighborhood. At Recoleta you will find some of the fanciest hotels of Buenos Aires like Park Hyatt Palacio Duhau and the luxurious Park Plaza. Btw. It felt very safe!
Full of charm, ambiance..... Lots of great boutiques, small coffee shops...Loved the Cemetery! Pilar eglise is beautiful...a spot of peace, tranquility

A little of Everything. The general area has very good, ageing buildings, a very good Hotel (Alvear)= and the best restaurant in town (La Bourgogne), The Recolata Cemetry is famend for its small individual family Burial places, the is symbolism galore, a lot Masonic. There are tours where men who don't know the Cemetry eaplain (?) things, Many small restaurants and cafés and mnay top of the line shops (the Nespresso central store). Wlak around, look, ask. A lot of expats live there, students, businessmen, etc. who speak English. A MUSt for visitors!

Beautiful, safe and stylish!. Recoleta is a lovely barrio in Buenos Aires and we stayed in this area for over 2 weeks. It is clean, safe (at all hours, which is rare here!), pedestrian friendly, filled with great cafes and restaurants and has everything you need. Whilst the metro is on the edge of Recoleta, is it still an easy walk or there are taxis available at all hours. In such a big and varying city, it is the best place to stay...and enjoy some time visiting and looking around too. Los Pinos is a fantastic and delicious local restaurant and The Recoleta Cemetery is a must see!
worth a trip. most interesting thing is the tomb of evita peron-even after all these years there are always fresh flowers--but the place is great for photography as well good shadow and architecture

A great place to live. We rented a small condo in the Recoleta area so we could experience first hand living in such a beautiful city. First I have to say how gracious and welcoming the people are. Secondly, anything and everything one needs for a comfortable life is at hand. Schools, universities, libraries, museums, amazing grocery stores and smaller mercados, clothing, books, theatre, and the list goes on. Would be a great place to live to get away from Toronto winters!

greart walking area. take a self guided walking tour of this beautiful area with old mansions turned into hotels and embassies. there are art galleries and lovely boutiques. weekends there is an artisan fair in the plaza Francia. many restaurants in area. 2 hours for a nice leisurely walk. do not miss the ombu trees in plazoleta pellegrini. have lunch or just coffee outside at La Biela cafe

A must if you're in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is on the tourist trail for good reason, it's one of the few places I felt safe walking around on my own in BA. Great place just to hang, soak up the culture, people watch and drink coffee. Well worth exploring.
Great area to walk through. We stayed in the next district over but walked through the recoleta a few times and very interesting place with good shops and cafe's.

nice area, great arquitecture, expensive stores. The district is beatifull, nice cafes and big parks! The Flower was great and the cemetery is just one of the best highlights in Buenos aires, make sure to go before 5 pm because they close it!
Best of Buenos Aires. this is the nicest spot in Buenos Aires.quiet and beautiful neighbourhood with a lot of cafeterias and places to walk

Paris in Buenos Aires. Recoleta has the taste of Paris.Easy to walk, lots of beautiful expensive shops, hotels etc etc. The most upmarket section of the city. Clean and if you love architecture like i do, you will definetly enjoy Buenos Aires most beautiful neighbourhood.

Most prestigious area I Buenos Ayres. If you visit BA this is the area to stay.Quite safe for a walk around, gardens, art galleries, the famous Recoleta Cemetery, Teatro Colon: one of the greatest opera houses in the world, the most beautiful embassies, designers shopping and cosy restaurants.

Beautiful neighborhood. I stayed in Recoletta. I love this neighborhood. It's beautiful, quiet, clean and safe. Close to everything and has great neighborhood restaurants. Reminds me of the Upper East Side in NYC. The famous cemetery and grave of Evita is also here, which was quite moving. I saw almost all of the neighborhoods in Buenos Aires and this was my favorite by far. I wouldn't stay anywhere else.

A Fine Neighborhood. This is a beautiful. old neighborhood with a lot of historical facades. We actually stayed at an apartment here on Junin and were very pleased with the location. Many restaurants and shops. Great for strolling and window shopping.

Buenos Aires geme. The Recoleta is an upscale neighborhood with plenty of restaurants, museums and parks and the famous Recoleta Cemetery. The Buenos Aires Design is a great mall with upscale stores for designers. Great stuff! The park becomes even more alive on weekends with the street fair with its various local artists exhibiting, and of course selling, their art crafts. Highly recommended place to visit if you're in the great capital of Argentina!

Upper east side with panache. We are staying across the street from the Alvear palace. It's like being in a time warp where people are groomed to the nines regardless of their economic status. The porteros( concierges) take pride in polishing the brass on the doors. It's so elegant and civilized. Aesthetically ,the beaux art building make me feel like I'm in Europe. Love it here!
beautiful neighborhood. the architecture alone is worth the walk around this area, but the cemetery and the shopping are outstanding and interesting

Ricoleta free walking tour. Great experience, Mariano was well informed, funny, helpful. Highly recommend to take all his tours. I walked in Ricoleta for 10 days by myself and missed a lot of important buildings
Great Area. Recoletta is a nice area to walk around and spend your day. Shops, restaurants and other little cafes. Definitely something to do while in BA.

Recoleta Cemetary. The cemetary in Recoleta is absolutely stunning. We only got in a few minutes before it closed (it says it closes at 6pm but the guard said 5:30 so go earlier if you can!). Even though we didn't have much time, it was probably one of my favorite sites to see in BA. Check it out!
Wonderful neighborhood . Probably the best neighborhood to stroll around, have something to eat and just relax. And even if the fancy shops might be over ones budget, they are still worth a look.

Lovely area of city.... Went with guide a part of private tour of city & returned on Sunday to experience craft market in park & to have drinks watching local & tourists alike going about their business, this on the advice of our guide & was very relaxing & enjoyable after previous 3 days of intense sight seeing. Cemetery & cathedral are a must as so interesting .

Must see neighborhood. When traveling to Buenos Aires, one of the must see neighborhoods is Recoleta. Walk along and see the beautiful architecture. A must see place is Recoleta Cementary. I know, but trust me, you will be amazed.They say people saved their whole life so they could be buried here. The marble statues, stain glass. You can wander around in here for hours. Everyone wants to see Evita's family tomb, but just passing all the others is a shame. This is the who's who of Argentine history. Right across the park is a pedestrian walkway where you can stop for a coffee or tea, or if you are really thirsty, Buller, a brew pub. There is high end shopping at Patio Bullrich. Go to the Hotel Alvear for tea time, or just stroll away and see what restaurant you discover. This area is fill of everything.

Red light area. Is meant to be main tourist area but is full of bars that are actually brothels. I know it sounds hard to believe but escorts wait for clients to have a drink before approaching them. New Port is a perfect example.

Interesting neighborhood. Arrived at La Recoleta by subway, which was really easy considering I was staying in the microcentro. The neighborhood is rather residential and safe. While there, you must visit the cemetary - it is spectacular and you can find some very famous people's tombs and family mausoleums.
Love this area. Very nice and safe area with a lot of nice restaurants. Walkable to some landmarks in BA and a good area to stay

Lovely Area to Walk, Eat & Shop. Walked through Recoleta on my way to visit cemetery after seeing The San Martin Statue on Santa Fe. Then walked down to Av. Santa Fe to catch subway to Palermo. The area has great shopping, wonderful building to admire and lots of places to eat or have coffee. A must visit in Buenos Aires.

Beautiful Area to Stroll Through. This is a fantastic area of Buenos Aires to walk around in, if you have several hours. I walked from Palermo Soho across neighborhoods to Recoleta, and stopped several times for espresso and later for lunch. Fantastic food, architecture, and very friendly people.
A Must Visit!!. The cemetery is like nothing I have ever seen before. Such an experience. The area is beautiful with nice cafes. It is a must in Buenos Aires
Best neighborhood in town. The most romantic and lovely one. Its always clean and the most safety one in BA. Best restaurants and hotels all aver.

One of the places you just have visit. We went to the Cemetery and rode around the area on bikes. It is is just one of the areas you need to see when in Buenos Aries. Could you live without it, probably yes but why? Beautiful streets, met others that stayed in the area and loved it at night.
Decadent . Nothing compared with the charm of years agoRestaurants very low qualityThe good ones are gone Very disappointed

worth the visit. this is by far the most impressive cemetery i have seen. one normally thinks that i don't want to waist time seeing a cemetery but this one is quite something and its a must go. not to miss

good for shopping, go to the cemetery and the park (market on Sats). Nice leather and wine stores around. There is an amazing customized perfume shop too.
The cemetery is pretty cool too. Don´t really recommend the market on Saturday, the one in San Telmo is way better.
Upmarket. The recoleta area is an upmarket area of buenos Aires, with small malls and lots of restaurants in tree-lined roads. It is also the place where the massive cemetery le Recoleta is situated
Beautiful Place. Recoleta is very busy place in Buenos Aires and the area is very beautiful and close to shopping Malls and some Restaurents
Nice walk. Nice place to go for a wonder. Lots of shops in this very central area of Buenos Aires. Lots of places where to change local currency
Lovely Place. Great to spend some time to walk around with nice little cafes. Weekends are great as they have flea markets showcasing interesting arts made by the locals.

Just another medium-to-upper class residential area. Recoleta is, just like Palermo, the "other" medium-to-upper class residential area of Buenos Aires; and walking along its streets offers just the same feeling and sensations you experience walking along similar streets in any other huge metropolis around the world. It may sound weirsd and strange at the same time, but the Recoleta Cemetery is probably the most interesting thing to visit in this area. Some streets get crowdy at night as club-goers populate them especially on week ends.

Paris in south america. You can find the most elegant buildings at this borough, such as palaces. Everything is elegant there: how people dresses, buildings, cars, shops, restaurantes.. Looks like you are in Paris.. So chic!!!
BsAs Barrio. A beautiful place with Argentinian caracteristics.There's a alfajor with the name of the barrio - Tasty!

Get lost in Recoleta. I absolutely fell in love with this neighbourhood. Get lost in it. Walk it up and down and you will find the most interesting buildings and ice cream shops and bars and restaurants. This neighbourhood oozes money and elegance, but you don't have to pay to walk around and check out its beauty. And, the Recoleta cemetery is right here!!!!

This is the place to walk around having coffee and browsing the upmarket shops. Recoleta is where the old rich in BA stay. It has good restaurants and coffee shops as well as many upmarket boutiques for shopping. This is a highly recommended place to just stroll and soak in the atmosphere of a quiet afternoon. Before or after you trundle down Florida street (ie. the main pedestrian
shopping street)
Old world European charm in the Southern Hemisphere.. Lots of great things to see in Recoleta, in particular the cemetery. A highlight is the tomb of Eva Peron.
Paris . Elegant and luxury neighborhood with a lot of mansion and a baroque architecture, recoleta is pretty much like Paris. The shops, malls and restaurants are consequently most expensive.

A must do. interesting place to visit a must when in town
take your time to explore this place as it has many hidden treasures

Looking for Evita?. Interesting place for a cemetery! The main attraction of course, is Evita Peron's resting place which is quite simple. Some remarkable sculptures adorning some of the grander tombstones and mausoleums. Be careful of pickpockets --- my friend lost her IPhone while another nearly lost his iPad. They caught the boy thief but an accomplice posing as a tourist took him away.

Creepy but Elegant. I know, for some, not high on the list of things to do; visiting a cemetery. This one is worth a peek, you can see very strange and opulent structures and see exposed wooded coffins. This place is still very sought after and plots are more expensive than the homes locals live in.

Recoleta. Just got to be done, shame there was no guide maps or information in the local information centre. Some fantastic architecture, some bordering on weird and spooky. Having said that a great place to visit.
Great architecture - Recoleta. The Recoleta cemetry is magnificient as is the rest of Recoleta. At least visit Evita Peron's mausoleum when you're there! And do visit the metal flower!1
Must see in BA. Trendy neighborhood. Lots of shops and restaurants. Touristic area. Close to the famous cemetery were Evita is BURIED.

A nice part of town to walk around. "Recoleta" is really a suburb of BA. There are many places to walk around and see, and it has many great places to eat.It along with Belgrano are the two nicest neighborhoods in BA. Recoleta is very different in that there is more history here, and restaurants. Recoleta gets most of the tourists, and I never heard one said that they would be visiting Belgrano.On Sundays, there is a great artist fair around the Church of the Recoleta.I hope you enjoy your visit to Recoleta.
Great evening place. Just a beautiful part of Buenos Aires to visit. It it unlike any other part of the city due to its older style arcuitecture and boutique shops in the area.

Cool and trendy Neighborhood. Very cool and trendy neighborhood. Lots of places to shop and eat. The cemetery is really interesting and had lot of things to explore. Recommend that people get their hotel in this neighborhood. Very safe and convenient to transportation or you can walk to other neighborhoods.
Beautiful barrio. Loved visiting this barrio. Beautiful and historic. Take a book and your mate and enjoy the parks for a few hours. Stop by the church and cemetery.

An European flavor. A wonderful place full with history. Very classy. A must go when you visiting Buenos Aires. Only old cities in Europe combine a cemetery with good restaurants. Recoleta is the proof that Buenos Aires is the most European city in the American continent.

Never thought I'd write a review about a Cemetery!. Take the time to walk around the cemetery with a local guide, there are lot of interesting facts that you won't find out without one, not just about Eva Peron.

Another face of Buenos Aires.. We stayed in a hotel and visited cemetery, La Biela, a bookstore and explored many streets. This is the nicest neighbourhood in town and does seem to be a Paris of South America but a lot taller.

Recoleta - Best Fair in Buenos Aires. Great place to walk around and shop. Loved the fair...lots of great artisan souvenirs to take back home. Loved visiting the church and cemetery right next to the fair.
I love recoletta. i love recoletta I feel super safe here and have done lots os sightsseing it´s great for pictures! megusta mucho para caminar también
Fancy Buenos Aires. Just in the centre of Buenos Aires, wandering the streets of Recoleta will make you think you are in Europe - but then the atmosphere and ambient will tell you otherwise.
Lovely area for walking and history. Lovely area with a nice feel. A visit to the cemetery is a must, to see Eva Peron's grave. A great place to walk around and soak up the history.

A huge area of 4800 mausoleums . There is a map on sale so that you don't get lost! Unfortunately the tour that we were on rushed us around so that we could not really enjoy the place. However, I did not find it that intriguing - I feel there are many other cemeteries in the world that have more appeal.However, every tourist should visit this as it truly is huge and very much part of the country's history.

GREAT PLACE. Recoleta is one of the nice places to visit at buenos aires. Excelent restaurants, restos and souvenirs places. About cementery is nice place to visit. But at weekend you have street market at recoleta, VERY GOOD.
Beautiful Area!. I love the architecture in this area, it reminds me of Europe. It's a nice place to walk around and grab some gelato with friends.
super nice area. nice area to do some window shopping or just stroll around....safe area with also lots of cafes and restaurants

Cemetery. The Cemetery at Recoleta was amazing. I went alone and without a guide, but thoroughly enjoyed exploring this miniature city of the dead. You can spend several hours in there if you want to linger, or you can hit the high spots and get the vibe of the place in an hour or so. It's pretty amazing.If you're looking for Evita's grave, check the map in the lobby when you come in. The grave is modest, and it's difficult to find. Your best bet is to find one of the groundsmen to point you in the right direction. It would have been nice if they had a sign, since while I was searching I found several other people in the same boat I was in. (Hint: the grave is to the left about half way back, it's dark in color, and in a narrow avenue).

Nice place to travel in (mainly weekends). Recoleta area has several nice place to visit:The Cemetery which is interesting by itself to visit, it has amazing thumbs and look more like high end neighborhoods. The Museum of modern art – small but nice Museum across the street.The Recoleta market which open every weekend (Sunday and Saturday) on square next to the cemetery. The market is easier to travel and more organized from the San Telmo market but price might be sometime more higher. I would not miss it. During weekends there are some live show over there.One tip , if you want to eat try to get some distance from the main tourist area for better offers ...
a must in BA. difficult to describe, a unique monumental and peaceful graveyard, you won't find anything like that anywhere else

Recoleta ... Cemetery, Museums, Parks. I lived in Recoleta and it is one of my favorite neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. A lovely mixture of Spanish and French architecture, wonderful huge parks and several great Museums as well as the Cultural Center and Our Lady of Pilar church and the Recoleta Cemetery.You can't go wrong if you stay there on a visit or just spend as much time as possible there.

Great home base in Buenos Aires.. I just spent 2 weeks in Recoleta. Lovely, safe place to stay in Buenos Aires. I walked to most attractions, Cemetery, Museums, Palermo, etc. I felt very comfortable walking around day or night. Of course you must be vigilant where ever you travel.

Wonderful architecture. A beautiful neighbourhood in Buenos Aires with plenty of cafes to sit and watch the world go by. The cafes all serve delicious "medialunas". We watched the free Tango demonstrations out front of La Biela cafe. The architecture in Recoleta is stunning. We were able to walk safely from our hotel, which was located nearby in the Microcentro neighbourhood, to Recoleta and enjoy the wide boulevards and interesting buildings along the way.

Stay if you can, this place is great. I stayed here for a week and loved the neighbourhood. Everything you need nearby and an easy walk to the cemetery. Lots of people about, very safe. If you can't stay spend a few hours here to experience a great BA neighbourhood.

Time flies when walking around the grounds . A good way to pass a couple of hours. I would suggest taking a guided tour, since there is so much history.
Even id you don't, you'll enjoy it. Take your camera!

Brilliant for moody photographs. This was a planned visit, later that day we were to join the Viator city bus tour from around the corner.
The tombs are amazing and make great subject matter to photograph. It was raining the day we went so the light was fantastic .
Recoleta, A must visit in Buenos Aires. Beautiful neighborhood where the famous cemetery resides. I love the gardens and little cafes and restaurants all over...
Recoleta Area. Really nice area, you can find everything and it is close to downtown. It's cementery is famus because Evita Perin is there.

Beautiful neighbourhood. It is the perfect place to have a nice walk on a sunny day, sorrounded buy very nice parks, we visited this area on sunday and there was a street market with many local food and artisan items. All the bars around here are also really nice to get a coffe under the sun. The cementery of Recoleta is really impressive and it is really worth a walk inside it.

Must see . Recoleta is one of the most important touristic neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. Night life there is particularly excellent ( many bars and clubs where foreigners roam) but a sunny Sunday stroll there cannot be easily forgotten. Highly recommendable is the cemetery ( specially if you are onto photography)
Class and fun. An interesting and really modern area with numerous eating places and modern shops. Much more elegant and tidy.

Recoleta is a MUST GO in Buenos Aires!. You wont be able to say that you know Buenos Aires if you didn't take the time to walk around Recoleta. A cemetery that features aristocratic surnames of the local high society, a cultural center, a Church , called Del Pilar, a nice square called France, and a super traditional restaurant / bar: La Biela, where you can drink a coffee and see whats going on in the neighborhood.

Elegant Buenos Aires. It is one of the most beautiful parts of Buenos Aires! It shows the glamour of past times, elegant, and classy. Easy to walk!!! Great coffee shops in almost every block were you can have a cortado (macchiato) with croissants or walk thru the beautiful parks. Every weekend Plaza Francia has what they call "ferias" or flea market full of local talented artisans. La Recoleta is a must visit in Buenos Aires.

Clean and beautiful -- with lots of green spaces. Recoleta is a very beautiful part of the city well known for its tree-lined clean and organized streets. The shopping here is first rate and you will find all the known designers here. If you are looking for tango shoes, you will find THE Comme il Faut shoe store here full of amazing tango shoes and at prices that are affordable compared to New York prices. Recoleta also has many well-known restaurants and museums. It is a very safe area of the city as well. This is a good place to stay for first-time visitors to Buenos Aires.
Must see... Loved everything in this section. The architecture is amazing...didn't buy a thing..just enjoyed the sights..

Atypical cemetery of historic edifices worth viewing.. Interesting cemetery of ornate edifices with stained glass windows and famous people in the history of Argentina are placed side by side for easy strolling and viewing.

Duarte Family Tomb. The final resting place of Eva Peron is here in the cemetery. One has to wander between the large free standing tombs to find the black stone vault of Eva's family, the Duarte, in which here coffin was interred

Recoleta---most attractive part of Buenos Aires. Recoleta is where the wealthy and powerful of Buenos Aires live, with excellent shops and restaurants that cater to wealthy people, and the vast, beautiful Plaza Recoleta. There is a large handicrafts and gifts fair there on weekends, where vendors offer everything imaginable that is handmade by local artisans and craftsmen. Bargains galore. And don't forget Restaurant Row, which has several restaurants with tables out under the enormous spreading rubber trees, some of the biggest in the world. Cafe Biela is the favorite hangout of many Buenos Aires lovers. Just hope you are lucky and can get a table!! Fervor is another excellent restaurant nearby. But Mr Black's Establishment for Young Ladies, which used to be across the street from the Alvear Palace Hotel, is now closed forever.

Go and visit!. We got lost exploring the cemeteries in this area for hours they are all very impressive and it is an experience. They definitely have a different view on death with coffins and bodies exposed in several of the older graves, very interesting!
Excellent place to wander away the afternoon. Summer is the perfect time to visit this welcoming, walkable neighborhood. The restaurants and shops were accommodating to American visitors.
Very nice neighborhood.. It's a very nice place to stay in the Argentina capitol! Nice neighborhood to walk.Lovely buildings to see and daydream of you choosing one to live!
Great place to walk around. Very nice buildings, several blocks to walk and imagine how Buenos Aires was at its glamour age, the cementery was what most impresssedme

Great location for city walks. We took our first trip to Buenos Aires and stayed in the Recoleta area. This was very convenient to shopping, the marvelous cemetery, so many parks, cafes and the new Dock area. This section of town is very walkable and easy to get around. There are great restaurants, outdoor cafes, and coffee houses as well as museums and embassies with great architecture. The larger buildings remind me of being on a Parisian street. On Sunday there is an Arts show down by the church and Cemetery. The local artist bring their paintings, crafts, leathers, textiles and a variety of other beautiful crafts and set up tents in the park.
Recoleta is Charming. Recoleta is a must see. Visit the cemetery and walk along the Avenida Alvear. Nice restaurants in Av Posadas/Av. Liberdad.

Beautiful part of the city. Fantastic place to stay! Beautiful architecture and delicious restaurants. The cemetery is a must see even if you don't usually make it a point to hang out with that crowd ;)
Holiday. This is one of the best areas in Buenos Aires. Everything is beautiful there. I don't know what more to say. If you are in B. A. Go there to see for yourself.
A must see in Buenos Aires. A must see on your trip to Buenos Aires. This is the cemetery where the wealthy from yesteryear buried their loved ones in the most fanciful structures.
Recoleta... the genteel barrio. Quiet and elegant, lots of lovely shops and cafes, and the cemetery is a must visit... a quiet historicaloasis in the middle of a bustling City

Different and interesting. I visited this cemetery as I have never seen anything like this before. It opens early in the morning and it was totally empty at 7 am in the morning except for the staff cleaning and working. If you are near it is worth seeing it as it is for free.

It's worth coming back here!. I have been to this cemetery before-- many times-- but I always love walking around-- it's a peaceful place and full of Argentinean history. And it's free. I returned to Sarmiento's mausoleum again!
Arts and fun. Great place, love the feira...got lots of stuff!Nice place to walk, read a book, hang with dog..thats lots of cafés and bars!
Interesting!. Interesting cemetery! Has to be seen, even though I couldn't understand why before going there. One of the musts in Buenos Aires.
See the cemetery. The best place to stay in Buenos Aires. The cemetery was one of the highlights of the trip. Great cafes and restaurants
Nice area! Cemetery is a must!. I love the cemetery!! You could get lost in there for hours looking at all the monuments. I highly recommend a visit to this area!

Historic location, warning: could be creepy. Recoleta is a unique and historic location. It is an active cemetery, so if that creeps you out--be forewarned. You can roam around for free. We hired a free-lance guide at the entrance and that was well worth it. You can find Eva Peron's grave by following the crowds.
A Fun Part of Town. Recoleta is a fun and beautiful part of the city and well worth a visit or hotel stay. The cemetery is a don't miss attraction.

Best area to walk. Best area to walk. Great parks , nice monuments , beautiful houses , a lot of open air . I was walking back and forward every day and watching how people clean pavement infront their houses each morning .
Beautiful place. Beautiful quiet area, we had a coffee and pastries, as we set outside and people watch. Its amazing to see such beautiful buildings.
Recoleta Cemetery. It is a nice area. The restaurants aren't as interesting as in the Palermo district but the cemetery is worth a visit for sure!

Simply Amazing. This area its great for local shopping! Remember the seasons are the opposite than in USA.the month of May for example is winter in Argentina.........sooooo go shopping for a great coat and cashemeres and be "a la mode", and ready for USA winter!
A piece of Buenos Aires. Beautiful and classical. You should not travel to Buenos Aires without walking around the city, and La Recoleta is the perfect place to walk, eat and spend the afternoon.

lovely neighborhood. We rented a beautiful apartment on air bnb on avenida libertarian.it was noisy with a lot of street traffic but the neighborhood was very nice.we were very close to the museo de las bellas artes.there were supermarkets, coffee shops and restaurants all around.we ate at the mirador steak house and a lovely little place called the daily coffee which had a fabulous nice de chorizo. Highly recommended neighborhood.

Beautiful Recoleta. Recoleta is an amazing area in Buenos Aires if you are looking for our history and art. Full of museums (Museo de Bellas Artes, Palace de Glace, Centro Cultural Recoleta, among others), art galleries, the Catedral de Luján and the Cemetery, where our most important historical characters rest in peace. If you take a walk in this area you must go to France Park (Plaza Francia) and find a typical craft fair with local products and craft. Then take a walk through Alvear Avenue where you will find The Alvear Hotel (a must - take a coffee in the open garden!) and also you'll see the french architectural influence.In a few words, Recoleta is one of the most important part of the city (along with San Telmo), where you could see most of our history and understand the Argentinian diversity!

Swank. Recoleta is of course the swankiest are of BA and is not to be missed. The shopping, cafes and of course the famous cemetery are all outstanding. Not much night life, so try Palermo Soho for a younger crowd.

beautiful charming area. this area was very quiert compared to the city centre. although i went in july which is the winter it was still very pleasant and dry and strolling around, charming area and market was great. highly reccommend that.such beautiful buildings and people are so nice and friendly.
Old area of Buenos Aires city. Pretty buildings and home to cemetery. My guide told about all the famous people and interesting history of the area.

Take your time to discover Recoleta. During this trip, Easter 2015, we have spend 2 nights and 3 days in a cozy hotel boutique in Recoleta. Walking distance to everything, nice dining places around, good jazz bar, just another great trip to Buenos Aires

Recoleta - A Great Central Location!. Recoleta is a fun place to be in Buenos Aires. Known for the Recoleta Cemetery, where Eva Peron is buried, there are many fine restaurants, a mall with cinema, a chocolate store and many ice cream places. The contemporary art museum is a must see for art enthusiasts at about 36 argentine pesos. There is also a free photography museum that takes only about an hour to breeze through. Hotel Etoile is my fAvorite hotel because of the staff. Recoleta is busy most in summer. I recommend a quick taxi ride to Avenida de nueve de Julio in the day or by night for a tango show. Puerto Medero is nearby here. Recoleta is a good central location

Don't miss it!. After braving a sea of people and "Cambio" men trying to buy any US dollars you may have, it was a welcome relief to stumble across the Recoleta district for a little respite. There appears to be some great little shops and restaurants that are a bit more upmarket than you may find elsewhere. Whilst in the Recoleta, make time to visit the cemetery. Eva Peron is a famous resident here but some of the other grave sites are opulence beyond belief and will no doubt blow your mind.
very unique. I have never seen anything like this. Very peaceful right smack in the middle of the town. Even with a map, it was difficult to locate some of the mausoleums. Very very nice place.

Extraordinary cemetry and elegant neighborhood. Most visitors think that Recoleta is just the name of an extraordinary cemetery with mausoleums and grand memorials to some of Argentina's most famous people (including, of course, Eva Perón). The cemetery should definitely be on your list of places to visit, but Recoleta is also a neighbourhood with delightful streets and twentieth and late nineteenth century buildings, cafes, shops and lots of opportunities to browse and soak up the atmosphere of an elegant part of Buenos Aires. It definitely is worth including in your itinerary. If you're staying in the Micro-Center take buses #59 or #10 and they will take you through Recoleta.

Fascinating cemetery. The Eva Peron vault is here- but so are dozens of fascinating vaults and stories. Didn't think I would enjoy this but there are very few cemeteries like this. It's quite historic and our guide was well informed.

Magnificent!. I love cemeteries. Expansive park settings, old ones, new ones. Recoleta is awe inspiring, breathtaking and completely different from anything else. It is like a small city. Towering marble statues, beautiful mausoleums along narrow cobblestone walkways. Centuries of family histories together for eternity.

Wander through the beautiful streets of Recoleta. If you enjoy wandering through streets with beautiful buildings and nice parks, look no further. Recoleta is more than just the place where Evita is buried. It is a vibrant neighborhood filled with beautiful buildings, parks, musuems, cafes, and restaurants.
Recoleta. Brush up on your history to get the most of the Recoleta. We didn't but were able to get some insight into the most famous people buried here- Eva Peron being one of the most famous.

Wealthy city center residential and shopping area. One of the nicest and safest neighborhoods of BA. Some of the most expensive hotels are in Recoleta as well as boutiques, shops, restaurants and cafes. It is easily accessible from anywhere in BA. I would recommend visiting the Cemetery and BA Design to see the latest in furniture design. I have bought leather placemats at the Claudia Adorno shop. Each was 84 pesos and of excellent quality. I also enjoyed the ice cream shops, cafes and tree-lined streets with elegant Argentinians going about their business.
Walk through Recoleta full of lovely buildings.. Great area of Buenos Aires with lovely buildings, embassies, shops, hotels and exciting walks. Crowded with walkers mostly during rush hours.

Very cool neighborhood in the heart of BA. Very nice, upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Excellent restaurants, hotels and shopping and a great location if you are using it as home base for exploring the city.

Upscale stroll. Recoleta is the upscale of the 9 BA districts. Can you name the other 8? Great shopping and cafes. Many great choices for dinners. Keep in mind that for the evening many restaurants don't get busy until 9 pm. Always suggest reservations

Affluent suburb, very safe but lacking in atmosphere. Recoleta is a very nice, well-heeled area. It is immediately clear that residents are quite well-off! We went to Palermo to take a look at the famous cemetery - well worth a visit - and also had lunch at one of the many nice-looking cafes. Lunch broke our budget a wee bit, but was well worth it.All in all it's a swanky part of town - worth a visit for the cemetery, or if you'd like to experience a slightly different vibe in BA, but lacks a bit of atmosphere compared to other suburbs.
The heart of Buenos Aires.. The heart of Buenos Aires, Great place to wander and don't foget to get a coffee or a glass of wine in La Biela. The best cafe in town.
Mini Paris. Great architecture, hospitable people and fantastic views. Restaurants and tangerias are superb. Worth a full day walk! I felt at times in Paris, no joke.

A must when visiting Buenos Aires. This is one of the prettiest, cleanest and Europe-like areas in Buenos Aires. There are many restaurants and sidewalk cafes with many locals hanging out; it's a safe are to walk during the day and stroll during the night. Highly recommend staying in this area.
Amazing Place to Visit. Recoleta is a must-see in Buenos Aires! The monuments are spectacular. It's like being in an outdoor museum!
Love Recoleta. We stayed in the Recoleta area on our visit to Buenos Aires We loved it here. Very charming, upscale, great shopping and restaurants.
Wonderful neighborhood. Great place to walk around. There is tons of shopping and places to walk around and explore. I liked it a lot.

Lovely neighbourhood and cemetery . The neighbourhood is really pleasant to walk around and the huge cemetery is stunning and definitely worth a wander. We probably spent over an hour exploring, although some kind of guide book or tour would be well worth it as half the time we didn't really know whose mausoleums we were looking at!
The high end neighborhood of BA.. Great shops, restaurants, cafes and people watching. Buildings are classical. The cemetery is a must visit. Palacio Duhau is impressive.
Loved it!. I simply loved it. If in Buenos Aires, you need to spend some time in Recoleta. So cozy, so classy, so Argentina.

A Must See In Buenos Aires. The Cemetery was most interesting and we spent a lot of time there looking around the Mausoleums, especially the final resting place of Eva Peron. The history in this location was fascinating.

Lovely neighborhood. Don't miss a walk through the cemetery.. Recoleta is a neighborhood full of cafes and shopping, but the cemetery is really the main spectacle. The mausoleums are breathtaking, and it is free to enter.
A TRIP TO THE PAST. Here you will find ancient tumbs of the most important people of Argentina around 1800. Unfortunately many of them are abandoned and look in ruins.

EXCLUSIVE. I decided not to pay for a hotel room when I visited the city, instead, I rented a very nice apartment in Recoleta. The sector is full of nightlife, stores, restaurants and everything visitors will need for a lovely stay. Recoleta is one of the most traditional areas of Buenos Aires but at the same time it is very exclusive. Pizza lovers will be really happy since there are pizza restaurants almost at every corner. The zone is safe and the buildings look great, similar to some Paris' suburbs.

Creepy but worth a look.. Before I went I didn't get what the hype was about but when you go you realise why. It's creepy and packed with huge tombs and walking tours are good to get a bit of the history Aswell. Worth a visit.

Recoleta - the place to stay in B.A.. Recoleta is the wonderful district of Buenos Aires which provides green spaces, cafes and restaurants, art and culture, and, of course, the Recoleta Cemetery which has the tomb of Eva Peron of Evita fame. It is a lovely cemetery in a lovely area of the city, where you feel safe and the shopping is fantastic!

Charming . If you are looking for old world charm this is the place to visit. As a photographer, I had to consciously put down my camera so that I could enjoy my surroundings in the present and not through photos. I rented a studio here for my stay I. BA and while it was in an old building it was very well renovated on the inside. I enjoyed waking through the neighbourhood imagining what it must have looked like 100 years ago. Do not skip this on your visit.
Upmarket district visit. Spend a day wandering around this neighbourhood. Go to the cemetery , find Evita's tomb. Look out for massive gum trees in the main square, mix with the upper classes of BA
Interesting Place. High class locality with a friendly park, church, museum, a shopping mall, stores and restaurants. A place of great historical and architectural importance.

History abounds. Easy to get around to explore the sights. People were so friendly. Ate out locally. Trees and parks. Great vibe and atmosphere. Hoping to get back there one day. I was there in April 2013.

Wonderful old neighborhood with lots to do and see.. Wonderful old neighborhood with lots to do and see. Restaurants are good and within walking distance.I particularly like the tree canopied streets in this neighborhood.
Cultural landmark. A definite must see. So many different styles. Amazing details, a photographers dream! From generals to presidents to paupers, the array of crypts is amazing

An area of great historical and architectural interest. Recoleta is an area of great historical and architectural interest. It is one of the most affluent neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. There are a number of museums and cultural centres and some of the most prestigious schools in the city. Many people associate Recoleta with its cemetery and Eva Peron-that alone is an excellent reason to visit the area. We did not use a tour guide but did have a very good guide book.

A vey high class neighborhood worth to visit. A very well known neighborhood in Buenos Aires with a friendly park, church, museum, a shopping mall, stores and restaurants. Certainly one of the most pleasant places to visit if you have 2-3 hours to spend out of the work, you and your fiends will enjoy, every Porteño will advise you the best restaurant where to eat a juicy bife de lomo, che!

Interesting Place To Wander Around In. You start your tour of La Recoleta by entering through the church. There are tours if you like, but I just did my own walking tour. There are signs, but they are in Spanish. The cemetery is where many of Argentina's elite are buried, among them Eva Perón, which is probably the most popular tomb there. The place can be confusing, but there are signs leading you to the most popular tombs. For Americans who are not used to above ground tombs, this is an interesting place. You can wander around La Recoleta for quite a while. The variety of different designs of the tombs is quite amazing. Some of them are quite beautiful and tastefully done, while others are gaudy and awful. Some are well-maintained while others are quickly crumbling into dust. But if you want to kill an hour or so, this is an interesting place to do it.
Lots To Do. Some great restaurants and night spots. Right across from the cemetery where Evita rests. This area is also undergoing some revitalization efforts. Worth the visit.

Great. Great place for a walking! Nice coffe shops and the famous cemetery to know. Totally recomended! The square in front of the cemetery is friendly and beautiful. Is not an enormous place, but is really nice.
nice area. the only area in Buenos Aires I actually felt safe in! Least amount of graffiti and dog mess piles of any other neighborhood. Shame there is no convenient subway line.

BEAUTIFUL SECTION, BUT NOT TYPICAL. Recoleta is probably the most beautiful and prosperous area of Buenos Aires. It showcases the best hotels, high-end stores and excellent restaurants, but it is not all there is to see in the city. In fact, it is by no means typical of the way locals live. If you want to see the "real" city, you'll have to venture outside Recoleta into the more middle-class and working-class neighborhoods. These are actually more interesting and will give you a glimpse into the lives of the majority of the people.

Great, safe, and amicable neighborhood. I had the opportunity to live in Recoleta for an entire month. Within a week, the local merchants knew who I was and were always very amicable and friendly. Because I was on vacation/work, I had the opportunity to walk around recoleta at all times of the day and I always felt safe, even at 4am. When taking taxis to Recoleta, the drivers always waited for me to get into my building. And because recoleta is a very nice neighborhood, going running (which I did twice a week) was incredibly entertaining. Parks, coffee shops, pizza places, small restaurants, even big and expensive restaurants were always open and welcoming.

Worth visiting. Recoleta is situated not far from the city centre. I walked down from Hotel Plaza to Recoleta in about 30 minutes. The graveyard there seems to be the place where the wealthy in Buenos Aires are interred. Eva Peron's grave is a favourite of Argentinian (and other) visitors. Be sure to look for the Duarte family in the index at the entrance.

nothing special. The only thing special to do in Recoleta is going to the Cemetery Other than that there is just the city, buildings, shopping and cinemas. Go to Recoleta for dinner if you don't like cemeteries

Cemetery. Wish that we had the time to view the area and not just the cemetery. Lots of quite interesting mausoleums though. A very sunny, but cold morning gave amazing light to the various statuary used throughout.

Cemetery different - the rest rather samey. We did the Dk guidebook tour of recoleta.Subway to Aguera and walked down.OK without being spectacular.Cemetery unusual and definitely worth a visit - and it is free - shuts at 5.45pm

Neighborhood. It is much more than the cemetery, there are several mini neighborhoods. The area North of Santa Fe is a bit more upscale with stately trees & elegant buildings. South of Santa Fe is acceptable but nosier and more barren. Then South of Corrientes one might see sign of poverty, such as people camping on the street, & sloppy demolition work. There are bus lines running throughout the neighborhood, on streets that are not expected to be major arteries. The advantage is the availability of public transportation, the disadvantage is of course the noise.
Nice area. Beautiful walk, lots of European like buildings. Lots of things to see and do in the area. Totally worth visiting this area.
Must see in BA. It was worth it to leave Palermo to see Recoleta. Totally different feel, and interesting cemetery located next to the basilica.
Little Paris. A beautiful old neighborhood with mansions and superb restaurants. The cemetery is on all the recommended tours, it's a great area to walk through.

Go visit. Just go.. Recoleta is a Beautiful part of the city. It has wonderful restaurants and a more upscale feel to it. When you go, don't forget to visit the cementary! It's an amazing piece of french heritage. Also, this is where Evita Peron lies. The last time I went there, 8 years ago, I got to see women crying for her and understood how deeply she influenced the people of that era. Don't miss that!!
Best place to stay in Buenos Aires. We took hotel in Recoleta with view on the Cementary. It was great view. Recoleta is quite, safe and beautiful part of Buenos Aires.

The mini PARIS. I found this neighborhood to be very charming and clean. It actually reminded me of Paris.I love buildings with rich architecture.There are few attractions in this neighborhood and a lot of resturants too.Most of the things are within a walking distance like Buenos aires design , the cemetry , recoleta mall , etc. Lovely place to stay

Just "La Recoleta". It is a very posh neighborhood, you might go to the cementary to see the monument for Eva Peron,"Evita", I like to walk around look at the different stores, drink a cafecito or a cortado(expreso demi tasse w/milk), in one of the many cafes, seating out or inside depending on the weather, observing people passing by,and relax, its vacation time.

Charming . As most of places in Buenos Aires, it's charming, nice, worth the visit. Easy to get there by subte (metro/subway), you can see Evita's grave, visit the Mall, pretty much walk and get to know BAs

Great Neighbohood. Great to walk around anytime - Near the subway, it has everything you need - good restaurants, bars, markets, museums, etc.I great recommend if you want to stay on a cool, acessible place.

La Biela. This is an iconic bar- restaurant in Recoleta! I eat here often and their food is very fresh! And a lot of options! It is across from the Cementerio de La Recoleta! And all the "porteños" come here!

A great mini taste of Buenos Aires. What a great day. Took the open air bus (cheapest and easiest way to get around the entire city - you just hop on and off whenever and wherever you want) and got off in Ricoleta. Started with the little stone paved streets with artists and souvenier shops, stopped for coffee (the best) and watched the Tango dancers dancing in the street! Went on to the Ricoletta cemetary. All are above ground with a lot of history, paved walkways, and ultimately Evita's grave. Rich with history. Outside, beautiful street sculptures, dog walkers (what a hoot!) and interesting shops. A great day!

Stroll and Shop in BA. A beautiful old neighborhood with mansions, restaurants and high-end shopping. The cemetery is on all the recommended tours, but there's not that much there (but Evita, and that's not much to look at unless you are a particular fan) but it's a great area to walk through.

Weekend is best. Great neighborhood with large park space, large market on the weekend, and the most impressive Cemetery I have every seen. Expect large crowds on the weekend during the summer and spring, but no too crowded during the winter or fall, but with still the same attractions and green space to enjoy.
Upmarket neighborhood. Shopping is great, as well as a number of sights such as the cemetery . Safe to walk around and enjoy your day

Restaurants and Tango Dancing. A really nice area in Buenoes Aires and lots of nice restaurants and you can watch Tango dancing frequently while you are sitting have a drink or meal. Well worth visiting this area.

Great area for food, shops and sight seeing.. Hotels close by, easy walking to see a lot of the tourist sites. If you like walking staying in this area is a fine choice. We walked to the city centre and then to a shopping centre that seemed miles away. not that far from Santa Fe street that offers shopping and restaurants.

A must when in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is famous not only for its cemitery where Evita Peron, among other famous people was buried, but also for the sophisticated neighborhood where one can find signature stores and unique arquitecture buildings. Very good restaurants can also be found like "Fervor" and " "Pecora Nera" and the beautiful Hotel Alvear, the most luxurious in the city. The 5 o'clock tea at Alvear hotel is a must!
Walk in cementery.. Is interesting,it's in the middle of Recoleta. Full of restaurants around and next to Del Pilar Church.its a different experience.
Thanatourism at its best. Great destination for those interested in thanatourism. It mirrors the city of the living. Only for fanatics: Eva Duarte's family tomb.

A VISIT TO EVITA PERON MAUSOLEUM. Amazing architectural mausoleums in Recoleta cemeterty, the mausoleums of the rich and famous. There were no staff to give us directions or directional signs going to the famous legendary Evita Peron mausoleum. We have to do it on own opwn like other tourists.

I have a thing for cemeteries.... This place is just gorgeous. Personally I could care less about Eva Paron and her fascist husband and their mausoleum. The architecture here is amazing and some of the family plots are oer 100 years old. Coincidentally it is also the most expensive real estate in all of B.S. A.S. I would find myself here day after day just wondering around and admiring the masonry (also a thing of mine...). For those who are Evita fans it is a must do. Id say the same for those into cemeteries and or masonry. It really isnt as macabre as it sounds.

The Most Fun with Dead People. You would think looking at a cemetery would be creepy, but this one is way too much fun! It is amazing how beautiful the graves are and how much time was spent making them. The famous Eva doesn't even have the biggest grave! Well worth the walking around.
Beautiful neighborhood. If you are in Buenos Aires don't miss a stroll through Recoleta neighborhood. Gorgeous neighborhood....delightful architecture, shopping and restaurants!

Area for Eva Peron's resting place and nice architecture.. Anyone interested in Argentine political history this area of Buenos Aires is a must. It has the cemetery where Eva Peron was laid to rest. Contrary to what you expect, her remains are in a small box/door area with in the cemetery. It is nothing grand considering the effect she had on the country and her husband's prestige. At the end of her life it seems that she became an embarrassment to the government's in power. The area also has nice restaurants and coffee houses. Overall it is an interesting place to visit.

Loved It. All in all I found my visit to Buenos Aires a wonderful experience.The place has a joyous feeling despite the fact that the country is probably on 'it's uppers'.Recoleta is an interesting part of town, not just for the Cemetery where 'the great and the good are buried' , but also for the general area. The market, the parks, the bars and restaurants all very good.

Recoleta cemetery Bueonos Aires. This cemetery is well worth a visit if you are in Buenos Aires for a few days. Has some beautiful mausoleums including the family of Eva Peron. There are a lot of cats which are fed by the locals.

Nice neiborhood close to city center. I liked do be close to city center where I have business meetings, and also close to parks and the Malba. It's not so good for shopping and restaurants, but it's close to Palermo wich is the most for that.

Nice surprise. I visit Recoleta with a group of colleagues in our first day in Argentina. Here you can experience the life of the locals meeting in the cafés to chat, some to watch the news or games and others to walk or run in the vicinity in a beautiful historic scenario. On top of this while I was enjoying the area there was a music store playing great music. If I go back to Argentina, will definitely go again to recreate that experience.
Recoleta- perfect home base for our trip. We stayed in Recoleta and really found the relaxing atmosphere, history and culture to be preferable to Palermo/Palermo Soho.
Something out of a Stephen King novel. Creepy, interesting, haunting and yes, in a strange way, enjoyable. Go have a glass of wine afterwards in one of the many cafes. You will need it.
Great architeture. A neighbourhood where you can find many different styles of architecture and very expensive malls. It's good to walk around and enjoy the sights.

Cool suburb of Buenos Aires.. This is such a cool neighborhood! Take your time walking the streets and be sure to visit on a Sunday when the market is on. Great food, bargains and entertainment. The cemetery where Eva Peron lies can also be found there. Highly recommended!
Must visit. Its better to get a free map and walk on your own. Free guides are available but the excursion with them is very long ;-( Unless you have plenty of time.

For me it is the most beautiful and elegant Buenos Aires neighborhood. Since my first time in Buenos Aires, in 1982, I am always pleased to walk in its streets. Buildings, houses, trees, parks, gardens, shops and locals are nice and elegant.

Great to stay in.. Great place to stay in while in Buenos Aires. You have everything you need within walking distance. No need to go anywhere else if you don't want to. The store and shops are more on the high end so not a bargain hunters dream. But some great restaurants with great prices. Don't bother popping into a Burger King or McDonald's for a quick bite, the exchange rate is not kind to them. You will end up spending more on a burger and fries than a nice sit down meal at a great restaurant. i.e. $12 for a hamburger.Recoleta Cemetery is a must stop as is the adjoining church. The mausoleums range from over the top statuary to Egyptian themed. Meticulously maintained, with fresh flowers and scrubbed clean to broken down and falling in. Be prepared to see rotting caskets withing feet of where you are walking but it is an amazing place to really see the history of the city and country. I went with my friend who was born and raised in B.A. so it was nice to hear him talk about certain figures buried there. Lots of nice cafes, with wifi, down the street and an indoor mall if you want to get out of the heat.I stayed in Recoleta for a week and feel like I only scratched the surface.
Best neighborhood. Best place to stay and visit. It´s safe, beautiful and easy to explore. You can find great free walking tours around.
Nice Place to Window Shop. Great place to spend the day just walking around and window shop. A must stop at the Recoleta Church and Cemetary.

Nice little town to be dead in.. An amazing cemetery, with very inviting, dwarf-like buildings for the dead. Most kept up very well, others breaking down, and revealing old and small caskets. Great place for a murder mystery.

pleasent and interesting. Visit the cemetery! The mausoleums are huge, beautiful, overall impressive. And it should not take too much time. There are nice places to eat and shop nearby (there is a Hard Rock Cafe for instance) And metro station is.. well, you can walk if you have time. It took me about 20-30 minutes if I remember correctly.Bad part is, don't buy stuff from the bazaars there. They sell the same stuff for twice price. (Same staff; at Florida street etc.)

Just roam and enjoy but see cemetery first!. Very safe, great little restaurants and bakeries. See the cements ry first, free of charge but you can buy a nice little tour map for $2 that is very useful. Also, stop and see the adjoining church. Then just roam Recoleta itself. More modern and angl than other areas but very nice.

Iconic. Considered one of the top 5 in the world. Wander aimlessly or hire a personal tour guide when you get there. "Simon" is a great guide for English speakers and hangs out in front of the entrance (as do other tour guides).

Posh Buenos Aires. One of the most expensive áreas of Buenos Aires.
Very nice to walk around at take in the great Buenos Aires has to offer.
Visit Recoleta restaurant strips, Library, Callao, Posadas streets.
If you like to walk the cities you visit, Buenos Aires and REcoleta are waiting.

Nice area. Would stay here again.. I stayed in an apartment near the Pueyrredon subway station. Recoleta is a nice, safe area with lots of places to stay, good restaurants and shopping. Recoleta is a pretty central location and has some important sights including the cemetery. I would definitely recommend a visit to this area.

favorite neighborhood. Always my favorite in Buenos Aires. Rich, traditional neighborhood, it used to have a neverending nightlife before the crisis in 2008; unfortunately that changed a lot, but the place still retains its charm. Charming shops, bakeries etc.

A Must See in Argentina. I have visited Recoleta twice. The first time was with a guide who did a great job giving the history of the Recoleta and pointing out some interesting things. I recommend that approach. The second time, we strolled around with a group of friends who had not seen it and without a guide, you miss quite a bit.
Must explore Recoleta. This is a really neat area to explore. You will be able to see Evita Peron's grave in the cemetery here.
Nice place to walk around. We liked the tour through the cemetery. It was very interesting and different. To walk through the neighborhood, seeing the people and the restaurants was really nice.

Beautiful Architecture and a Taste of the Golden Days. Recoleta is a must when visiting Argentina, The architecture is very grand and gives one a taste of the old glory days of Argentina, many apartments are 1 per floor in beautiful old french style buildings. I would recommend a visit to the cemetery and coffee or tea in the Alvear palace, its like going back in time. Also the Park Hyatt hotel is nearby and an excellent spot for lunch on the beautiful terrace. the hotel itself is in a building which is simply a piece of history.
