The bar i am told dates back to the 1500's and the wood was shipped from Normandy etc etc

Recoleta. Recoleta is spacious and green,away from the city centre. La Biel is a traditional cafe,charming service relaxed place to be, the cementario is unlike anything else. Needs to be seen,preferably with a guide.

Architectural place. The cemetery is really a place to know the Argentinian history. The graves architecture and also the coffins exposed behind the glass doors are impressive. I was waiting for more in the Evita grave.

Buenos Aires Vacation. Recoletta is the perfect location to stay in, with great hotels, lot of parks, restaurants, the Bellas Artes Museum, the well known Recoletta Cemetery and many other interesting places.

A great place to get lost in. I've visited a few major cemetaries and there's nothing quite like this place. The money the old families spent on their tombs must have cost them a fortune. A strange and interesting place.

A Must See in Buenos Aires. The artistic crypts are incredible. Some have fallen into disrepair which makes it a bit creepy, but you could spend hours here capturing the different light on the ancient sculptures. Eva Peron is buried here.

Beautiful neighbourhood . We stayed 2 nights in recoleta and could quite happily have stayed more. Very leafy, green neighbourhood with plenty of restaurants and bars. The cemetery is a must see and the sunday we were there they had beautiful markets with cold beer, bbq meats, beautiful leatherwork, tango, live music and crafts in the park outside the cemetery walls. Great way to spend a sunday, go grab a chorizo and a cold beer and sit on the hill and do some people watching while soaking up the amazing atmosphere

Beautiful Part of this Huge City. We spent some of our time in Patagonia no then Christmas in BA. We found a lovely apartment on AirBandB right near the center of Recoleta. Beautiful location and close to many attractions and restaurants. We were a block from the Cemetery and about six blocks from the Botanical Gardens. You can walk every where, even to the street markets on the weekend which were towns of fun. Tango dancing on the streets, numerous shops with clothes and crafts and leather goods for incredible prices. You are not seeing all of BA but this is a very lovely piece that is well worth a visit. Apartments were smallish but very nice, just remember to have currency as your deposits will be in cash. ATMs generally only disperse $200 equivalents at a time so be prepared.

Interesting Place. We stayed in our hotel here and it was very central for interesting bars and restaurants as well as the cemetery of course. Had a very good shopping mall nearby and the night life is excellent. Would highly recommend!

Recoleta, historical neighbourhood. GORGEOUS buildings, great shopping. Lots of great patios and cafes. Ice Cream shops every couple of blocks. Close to the famous Recoleta Cemetery which is also definitely worth the visit. MUST see while in Buenos Aires

The place to go to see Evita's grave. It is like entering an alternative reality! Some graves probably as expensive as a mansion! Graves very old belonging to the well to do families of Buenos Aires. A very interesting place to visit and learn about argentinan history.
chic neighborhood. Charming area, with lots of posh boutiques, art galleries and good restaurants. Quiet, calm neighborhood.
evita. evita is buried in the cemetery in recoleta. lots of night life. some good some bad. late night, night life. expensive bars for buenos aires.

A Glimpse of the Old Buenos Aires... There was a time when Buenos Aires was consider the Paris of the South and in this neighborhood, you can see why. Most of the area is well maintain with beautiful french style buildings and lots of embassies and governmental offices. The area is one of the safest as well and easy to move around. Its a perfect area to get lost and find a nice cafe to spend sometime. Just don't miss it.

Most exclusive cemetery in the world.. This must be the most exclusive, and the most expensive cemetery complex in the world. This is where Peron's family bodies are kept. It is so beautiful with classic carvings, that it is more astonishing than creepy. Must visit!
Don't miss. One of the nicest areas in Buenos Aires. I suggest to take a guided tour in the cemetery (free of charge) and listen to the interesting stories

Wonderful spot, full of interest and charm. I have to say my memories of Buenos Aires are mixed. One thing I learnt from experience - don't hail a cab off the road. Instead, use a registered company and book in advance. However, against that negative was the experience of places like Recoleta. What a superb area, charming feel, lovely sidewalk cafes and the cemetery is a must. You need to allow time to explore at leisure as my partner and I did. The photos were fabulous!

Save a day to know Recoleta. Recoleta is not just a neighboor, is a place full of diferent options to know, From visits to Recoleta Cemetery to Basilica del Pilar the Museum or, to get a cofee or drinks in any of the multiple options near by. Also you have Recoleta Cultural Center and each weekend will find a lot of people selling their products.,
Nice neighborhood with a historic character. Love this area of Buenos Aires, nice shopping and great restaurants. Lots of wonderful historical corners.

Best place to stay in Buenos Aires Don t miss this city. Is really a good place to choose your hotel, elegant, many bars and restaurants around,and of course the famous cementry, parks, museums, shopping in Alvear ave, where are the brands, walk to Arroyo and Posadas street, it seems to be in Paris...but iin south América, many places to visit, take the tourist bus, information tourist center in La Biela door very amazing bar.....You can rent a bike near
History. A lot of good history. Good places to walk around. It is very close to libertador park which is beautiful.
A must see location. It is elegant and upscale. Nice side streets with elegant mansions. Very nice areas to visit in Recoleta.
Where is Evita. Nice to see if you haven't seen any cemeteries like this in f.e. Paris yet. Basically heading out straight to Evita's family tomb. Lots of cute cats around

amazing cementry. We were amazed at this place since you can spend as much time as you like. You can see crypts that are over 100 years old. This place in itself gives us a history of Buenos aires past including Eva Peron grave. It is a most see place in Argentina.

One of the best neighborhoods. My whole purpose of stepping into Recoleta was to of course visit the cemetery which it is famous for but as soon as I landed here I found a whole lot of reasons to stay here. The neighbourhood has amazing architectural pieces around and is a fun neighbourhood. Of course very upscale part of Buenos Aires. The cemetery is not the only best part of the neighbourhood. You can easily spend a couple of hours around here exploring various landmarks, art installations and the very many shops and restaurants

Highly recommend the free tour. Walked through on my own, and came a few days later for the free English tour. The tour was very helpful in understanding and appreciating the history of this unique place. A highlight of the trip.

Fascinating visit. I was skeptical visiting a graveyard but this is really amazing. They crypts are spectacular and you could spend all day walking around. I don't recommend visiting at dusk, very creepy!

Visiting Eva Perons grave. the cemetary where Eva Peron is buried gets very busy as all the tours go there - advice to get there early. To find her grave number you need to look up her family name of Duarte then follow the map to the location. Lots of very fancy mausoleums and family tombs - well worth a visit

site of Evitas tomb...and others. great place...but you really need a map or a guide. I think that there are other important people buried here and lots of questions that cannot be answered, by only self exploration.

Gem of a Neighborhood!. Very nice and upbeat neighborhood where you can walk around at anytime. Full of very nice shops ($$$), restaurants and cafes! Also the very famous Cemetery where Evita Peron is buried, is there among museums and points of interests. Extremely clean and very European!!! In Buenos Aires, this is definitely the place to be!

Recoleta Attractions. The architecture of the buildings in some of areas of Recoleta were influenced by the type of settlers who moved to the area. The buildings looked very exquisite and well crafted. There are a number of attractions in this area that visitors will enjoy seeing. However, I am unable to put any pictures because my camera was stolen on the day when I went on this tour.

Recoleta is where it's at!!!. Great upscale area. They have a artists flea market on Saturday mornings that was fantastic. Evita Peron is buried in the Recoleta Cemetary (good luck finding her crypt . . it is the best kept secret in Buenos Aires.

A traditional yet cool district. Recoleta is a traditional colorful district. There you can find many good restaurants and bars in Vicente López St. where there is also a mall with many trandy shops. I highly recommend the restaurant El Sanjuanino in Posadas St. which offers the typical empanadas (delicious!). The visit to Recoleta cementery is an interesting option. Buenos Aires Design is big mall with beautiful terraces facing a park full of restaurants and bars, very nice! don´t miss Recoleta!

A "must do" in BA. Visiting the graveyard is like taking an architectural and historical tour in miniature. It was absolutely interesting and beautiful. It seems safer than the graveyard in New Orleans but do be aware of your surroundings and as always in BA, do not bring a lot with you when you go outside.

Worth many visits. An area which draws you like a magnet,one feels like walking by many times. Each building has a history and a story. La Recoleta cemetery is where Eva Peron is buried. This area has many dining options .

A great neighborhood and a place to wander. Recoleta is a neighborhood in Buenos Aires most famous for La Recoleta Cemetery which houses the elaborate burial sites of many of Argentina's elite--including that of Eva Peron. One can wander for hours through the cemetery as well as throughout the neighborhood which contains many restaurants and shops.

Must See. Can't go to Buenos Aires without stopping for a walk through Recoleta. Interesting phenomena...large, quite stately crypts, some in various stages of disrepair, and of course, the resting place of Eva Peron Duarte.

Walking was lovely!. I walked through endless streets and explored plazas and other lovely sights in Recoleta. Finding Evita's grave was my main objective, but I was pleasantly surprised to enjoy the entire area. It was easily my favorite part of Buenos Aires.
Must see this is something. You will not see this kind of place anywhere else. All those graves you can't even call them graves. They are like monuments, all unique

Woah.. Lots of beautiful memorials to visit, also quite morbid-feeling even on a sunny day. I just stopped in here on the Lonely Planet guidebook's recommendation but ended up spending a little extra time as my travel companion was also captivated by the avenues and avenues of tombs, and imagining the great families and ghosts who come to rest here.

Great area--- central to everything!. Great neighborhood, and in walking distance to some great sights. Recoleta cemetery very close, walk to San Martin area, and not far to Palermo! Inexpensive taxi's abound!

Fascinating. Its worth taking a guided tour which we did. It was free and the guide was extremely informative and very knowledgable. Got to see the Duarte Crypt which is where Eva Peron is laid to rest. Very interesting if slightly macabre.

amazing and different experience!. Definitely worth a visit! Totally different from anything I have ever seen before. Found our way around ourselves fine and found Evita from the map in entrance. Didn't do a guided tour and felt happy with what we saw.
Across the road from recoleta cemetery freddos ice cream place is worth a trio too, yum!
Cemetery where Evita is entombed. We did a guided walk around Buenos Aires and went to the cemetery it was amazing the amount of money you can spend to look good when your dead, well worth a trip

Recoleta Neighborhood Buenos Aires. I’m staying in a small studio apartment in Recoleta but have barely explored the neighborhood and am making progress every day. It’s north of the City Center and shares a border with Almagro, Palermo, and Retiro.Recoleta is known for stately homes and plush hotels and considered by many to be the most affluent neighborhood in Buenos Aires. It is an area of immense historical interest.The barrio became popular in the late 18th century when an outbreak of yellow fever in the southern suburbs forced people to move north. Those who migrated divided large estates into smaller plots in a residential barrio and built stately homes.Ricoleta’s highlight is the Recoleta Cemetery. Covering about 14 acres. The cemetery is a mini-village of tombs. Some are lavish and others crumbling.Some of the museums and cultural attractions in Recoleta include a cultural center with art, concerts, theatrical performances, and festivals. Recoleta is also home to the Museo Nacional de Bellas Ares, displaying work by Goya and Rembrandt - it's a must see!Ricoleta has many plazas and parks. Don't miss Plaza Francia for its weekend artisan market Feria de Artesanos de Plaza Francia, commonly known as the ‘Hippy Fair’. Parque Thais and Plaza Justo Jose de Urquiza are other popular parks in Recoleta not to be missed.

The cult of the dead is alive and well in Recoleta. Fantastic! The wealthiest families in B.A. have been trying to outdo each other by building incredible mausoleums. The brought over famous artists from Europe so what you have is a Disneyland of baroque sculpture perhaps unmatched in any necropolis anywhere in the world. I went at least 3 times and never got enough.
Beautiful Area. We went to the mausoleum, specifically to see Eva Peron's crypt, to the church, and browsed the stalls in the outdoor market. They had a little of everything!

Fascinating and Beautiful. We always visit cemeteries when we travel, but this one is at the top of the list! The arrangement and variety of graves, statues, and mausoleums is fascinating and beautiful.Thankfully, our guide pointed out the grave of Eva Peron.

Beautiful, high-end part of Buenos Aires. A couple of friends and I visited the Recoleta cemetery in the morning and then walked around town for several hours in the afternoon. The neighborhood was a stark contrast to San Telmo and Barracas where we had spent time the day and night before. Much more ritzy and expensive. There are a lot of beautiful buildings, good shopping, and good food in the area. Definitely worth wandering around.

Wonderful neighborhood restaurants and parks. Our favorite walking neighborhood is Recoleta. Of course, everyone visits the cemetery. But across from the cemetery and church is a wonderful little park with the most amazing rubber trees and their incredible roots. I never tire of walking through and seeing them again. There are lots of cheap places to grab a quick meal, or there are very nice restaurants with white table cloths. This is a great neighborhood to stay in a hotel or to visit during your vacation.
Charming Neighborhood. Great place to stroll in the afternoon and to dine at night. Our hotel was located at Recoleta, we were not disappointed.

Who chooses to visit a cemetery? You should!. Recoleta is already known as a BA destination, but the arrangement of graves, monoliths, mausoleums and simple burial sites is fascinating. Don't get scammed by the individuals outside the cemetery - if you want to donate to the restoration work, save your pesos for the legitimate guides and collections within the grounds.
Beautiful Zone. Dont forget to visit the cemetery of recoleta. Evita Perón is resting there and other famous people.Is a open air museum.

pretty creepy. this place is creepy! the death vaults are poorly maintained, broken doors and windows, some doors open to the public, which makes it even creepier. Don't go too late if you scare easily.
upscale area. upsale area of BA - very safe - good to walk through it on your way to the cemetery. Nice shops but not too many restaurants - is partially resedential

Worth visiting. i am not one for graveyards...but this is one with a difference...Eva Peron is buried here and As is the irishman Admiral Browne who founded the Argentine navy .....it is amazing and the general recoleta area is well worth a stroll....the famous pink palace is here too, I visited on my last visit but now it is cordoned off and not open to visitors

A must stop!. Similar to Pere Lachaise in Paris....but what really made the stop worth it for us, we're the humongous trees in the surrounding plazas in the neighborhood...big enough for someone to decide to make a home inside one of the grooves...I kid you not! Wonderful walk.
Recoleta. the neighborhood is very nice! the streets are beautiful, the architecture is interesting. there are restaurants, shoppings, bars, hotels and the very interesting cemetery of the city.

Nice strolling, relaxing in a beautiful environment. Recoleta is the posh part of Buenos Aires. It's where people with money used to go to be seen, because not everybody could afford having a coffee on one of the nice, upper class terraces. Nowadays the,area attracts loads of tourists, mostly because of its history, cemetery and park. Nearby plenty of shopping opportunities in 5th avenue style shops in avenida Alvear and Quintana (La Martina, Ralph Lauren, Armani, etc). Lots of restaurants in the area as well, but beware of many tourist traps. Have a coffee at La Biela, where, if you're into that and lucky, you may spot some local politicians or even Hollywood actors (Robert Duvall is a fan, so I've heard). There's also a arts and crafts market with lots of hippie like vendors.The shopping centre of Recoleta also offers some refreshment in summer with nice shops.

Grab a Guide and explore. We went on a two hour walking tour while waiting for our room to be ready, let me say after 24 hours in transit it took something special to get our group excited; but this worked. Our guide made the area come to life! The beautiful embassies, the cemetery and the stories she told were great. Think of getting a tour as without her we would have missed out on the gorgeous gardens at the Hyatt, the lore of the building beside and also a great way to get your bearings.
Beautiful. One of my favorite neighborhoods in buenos aires. Must visit the Recoleta cemetery and the weekend fair at plaza francia.

A must see. This epic cemetery is a must see when visiting Buenos Aires. Not just for Evita's grave, which is rather small and could easily be missed if it weren't for the crowds gathering around it. The grave sites are huge.

Our first visit to Buenos Aires. The cemetery of Recoleta is a piece of Argentinian history. Presidents are buried here and more importantly looking at the various names visitors can realise the importance and contribution of migrants to this country. In addition Recoleta is a fine collection of sculptures.
Vibey suburb!. Brilliant suburb to visit; lots of walking around the town; site-seeing, shopping, restaurants! Definitely a tourist destination!

Great place to stay. We stayed in Recoleta, was a safe area wonderful architecture, shopping and restaurants. The cemetery is a must to visit.
We enjoyed our stay here, lots to see and do.

Affluent, chic, it's got everything! Muy bueno barrio!. Possibly the most affluent barrio (area) of Buenos Aires. Perhaps best known for the impressive Recoleta Cemetry (which I reviewed a couple of months ago). Lots of museums, chic cafes, exclusive avenues, a tourist can find something of interest at any time. Go to Plaza Francia at the weekend! Muy, muy recomendable!!

I felt that I was in the 16th Arrondisement of Paris. I was so impressed by the architecture of Recoleta that I literally felt that I was back in Paris; the architecture was that stunning. It is without a doubt one of the most classiest,and most elegant neighborhoods in the world. The cafes,boutiques,restaurants,hotels,and of course the Recoleta cemetery all added to the atmosphere. It is a fantastic place to visit.

Best area to stay in. Recoleta is an elegant neighborhood with an abundance of shops and restaurants. It is also close to the must see cemetery and is a nice place to walk around in. There are many buses that take you to the areas in the city.

Sights to see. We were on an organized tour...but the best way to get a good view of the city is by using the hop on, hop off city tour system. It will help in your organizing your holiday since Buenos Aires is a very big city. Churches are usually interesting to visit.
Best neightbourhood in BA. Its ambience is luxurious, and antique at the same time, very stylish. The neighbourhood itself is an atraction, But everywhere you go, you'll find a new one

The best of Buenos Aires. We took a tour from BA Free Tours and walked to neighborhood. Fascinating history and architecture. Then we went back for Recoleta Cemetery and fine dining. People walk the streets at all hours.

Great safe place to walk & wander day or night. The mix of new and old architecture is awesome. It certainly lived up to its reputation as the Paris of the south. I just loved walking randomly around the streets during the day window shopping and at nighttime it comes alive with great restaurant on every street.

visit the cemetery. most representative area of BA, reminder of the wealth of the city last century
you must not miss the cemetery, Recoleta Art centre, avenida Alvear
there is a huge artisan fair on weekends

Recoleta. Recoleta has some nice shops, and cafées and even a new mall.
Also museums.
I mainly visit because I wanted to see the Cementery, but found nice cafées and shops.

A nice Paseo and a place to eat. The environment is unique. Good food. Avoid Cabana las Lilas if you care for your $$$$$ there are so many alternatives for same or better quality without tourists. It may get cold. Be properly dressed to avoid a cold out of home.
Great area to stay!. We rented an apartment on airbnb and loved the area. Tons of shopping, lots of restaurants and cafes and nearby to Sante Fe and Callao where there was a convenient subway.

decent. it´s nice place and very curios for me. Because there cemetery near there with a lot of restaurants and cafes. So people really like to go out near cemetery. Finally, we ate some decent place with view for entrance to cemetery. It´s funny and you can´t find out something like that in the world. It makes this place unique, for that reason i recommend that place. Furthermore, porteños (habitants of BA) suppose this place for reach people
The most chic neighborhood in Buenos Aires. The streets in Recoleta seems some Paris nice neighborhoods. Go visit the Recoleta cemetery and especially the surrounding area of "Plaza Francia"
Great upscale area.. This area is the place to be in Buenos Aires. They have a great outdoor market selling crafts and there is a cemetery there that you cannot believe.

Don't miss it. This is just a beautiful memorial park with out of sight mausoleums and crypts. The architecture is diverse and beautiful, if not somewhat over the top. To be buried here means you had to make a huge fortune in your lifetime-they say people who lived an extravagant lifestyle paid even more to be buried here.
Trendyupmarket neighborhood. Great shopping and people watching! Many coffee bars with amazing pastres even better than Vienna.came here to dine at several fantastic restaurants. Fevor

Great area to walk around. Recoleta is an upscale neighborhood in BA and has a lot of places to visit. On weekends there is a fair in the plaza, where you can buy crafts, jewelry and food. There are also some restaurants and a cultural centre (no fee) where you can take lessons. Close by is the Recoleta Cementery, with really interesting history. You need to check it out when in BA.

a nice and elegant area for walking or going out. Our hotel the Alvear Palace was nearby, and we took a long walk in the area after we checked in. It was a Friday afternoon. The area was crowded, with many people taking drinks at terraces of numerous restaurants and cafes. There are beautiful parks, elegant shops and an nice artifacts market on Saturday morning.
Wow. The cementry of Recoleta is very impressive. The shops are expensive in this part of the city, but the cloths are nice.

Fun market with Evita's Tomb in the background. Recoleta Market is similar to San Telmo's (where I was last week.) but it is prettier. In San Telmo's, you will navigate flat, dirty cobblestone streets In Recoleta, you climb up a slight curvy hill, Eva Peron's tall white grave marker is in the background. But I cannot recall if the shopping street was paved. Both offer many different handmade items. Lots of jewelry, clothing and leather goods. Oranges are fresh-squeezed on the sidewalk. Peanuts are wrapped up for sale. The churros are warm and sugary. . Both markets are crowded, so get there early before they really fill up. This market seemed cleaner to me than the one in San Telmo's.

Great area to stay - Recol. We recently stayed in Recoleta on our trip to BA. The area is the perfect place . It feels like you are in Paris with the architecture and tree lined streets. Lots of cafes and restaurants. The area is a bit calmer than Palermo and other areas, which makes it a nice retreat after a long day exploring. Visit the Revoleta Cementary while here - unbelievable mausoleums!

Upscale neighborhood. You will see dog walkers with ten or so dogs on leashes. Upscale shopping and restaurants and nice green areas and parks. Luxury highrises and hotels. It's a clean, safe, nice area to walk. You're where the high end old money people live. Just as older parts of the city look like Paris in architecture, this area feels like Paris.

Pretty area with magnificent cemetery. This is a pretty Parisian-look area of the city with a large park area in which to sit and have lunch. The cemetery is of course a 'must see' sight and quite grand with marble and stone mausoleums and tombs which are richly carved and decorated. Eva Peron is buried here also. An interesting tourist sight to view if in Buenos Aires.

Nice and safe place to stay and visit. I spent 3 nights in Recoleta and enjoyed my time their, has no problems with the area with a good mix of shops and restaurants.Also good public transport to get to other areas.Also several nice parks close by, with one of them having a nice memorial for the soldiers lost in battle.Would happily stay in the area again.

Who thought visiting a graveyard could be so much fun!. We paid our respects to Eva Peron who was finally laid to rest in the Durante grave here in Recoleta. This is the graveyard for the rich and well to do of Buenos Aires so visiting the tombs is an eye opener as some have the most amazing structures, some a a bit creepy as you can still see the coffins. Outside the graveyard you have a good selection of restaurants but this is a well to do area so expect to pay over th odds. Great market on the green on Sunday's and if weather is good often some free live entertainment. There is also a design shopping centre and Hard Rock Cafe , if that is you thing.

European town in South America!. After crossing 2 continents and some 30 hours of traveling, one reaches South America from India. And what you get to see is a typical European City. Some say like Knighstbridge, Paris, Prague etc., this place reeks of European flavor everywhere, the streets, the buildings, pubs, sidewalk cafes etc. Move away if you want to see South America!

The Cemetary is a must !. The are of Recoleta is the equivilent in London of Knightsbridge - fancy very traditional mansion appartments, coffee shops, jewellers and discrete luxury hotels. It is interesting to walk through to get to the Cemetary. If looking for Eva Peron's tomb, look for her family name Duarte. There is a list on a board as you enter the cemetary on the left. She only has a brass plaque on the outside of a very modest black marble tomb in a narrow alley, to the far left as you go in. Looking in the thousands of crumbling tombs is a pleasant way the spend the afternoon. If you leave the cemetary, tund left down the slope the free, Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes is only a few minutes walk.
excellent neighborhood. Safe, beautiful, relaxed, out door cafes, Hyatt and Alvear Palace best hotels but smaller ones in neighborhood. Sophisticated more so than Sohos more youth oreinted.
Historical speciality. Very interesting monument. We have seen many cemetaries around the world, this is one we remember. Of course everyone wants to see Evita

Nice area to stay. Beautiful historic buildings and don't forget cemetery. Felt safe in this area. We stayed in IQ Calleo temporary apartments that were great value for money, well furnished, spacious, lovely private formal garden view.

Completely fascinating. These tombs probably cost more than your house! Seriously, the architectural styles represented here make this a mini lecture on the history of architecture. Many of the structures are in disrepair which made them even more fascinating as you could peer inside and the the caskets and opulence meant only for the dead. A must-see in Buenos Aires.

The best sight --even if a little creepy.. The cemetery is worth an afternoon. We loved wandering the 6 plus acres looking at the artistry of the tombs and peeking in. Our daughter really enjoyed it. You can get lost but that is ok because all are magnificent in their own way.

Not to be missed when in BA!. Landmark in Buenos Aires, a must for every visitor to the city. Pintoresque buildings, huge parks, wonderful museums very close to each other, fine dining, excellent shopping. Best to visit on weekends, when the artisan's fair is open.
Argentina's "Paris". Beautiful and tranquil community of residences, parks, architecture, and great shops and cafe's. Don't miss it. The nearby cemetery is fascinating.
Always stay here. I travel to Buenos Aires quite frequently on business and always stay in Recoleta. It reminds me of Paris, great architecture, little shops and a busy city feel to it.

Europe in South-America. great shops, lots of trees, beautiful old buildings, good restaurants - it feels like a combination of Paris, Madrid and even a little bit of London ... clearly the area in BA with chic!

Evita. Walked through the area to visit the cemetery. Very interesting to see the different designs of the family tombs of the rich and famous. Left the cemetery and walked through a market area, which was quite pleasant.

A must. While graveyards are obviously not everyone's idea of a vacation must there is so much history here it really should be on everyone's list of things to do. The mausoleums of pretty much every major Argentine family - including Eva Peron.
Beautiful area. Do not miss the cemetery and basilica. It was interesting and sad to see the grave of Evita. The basilica was a beautiful Spanish style church. Not to be missed.
Cats rule here. Amazingly beautiful art in a cemetery! Well kept, easy access, and cats enjoying life unbothered by us humans.
A Must See. We were surprised by what we saw. No ordinary cemetery. Mausoleum were huge.Eva Peron's was small in comparison
City of the dead.. This is an extraordinary place - not like other cemeteries. DO NOT MISS THIS! It is a fascinating place to learn about the city's history.

Beautiful Cemetary. Seeing all the beautiful mausoleums and Evita Peron's grave. It was very peaceful and one had an interesting history about someone who got buried alive when she was believed to be dead. She had narcolepsy.
Cementario de la Recoleta. It is one of the biggest "death city" in the world. Mausoleum of Evita Perron. Very impressive to see all the coffins, statues etc.

BEWARE of the CEMETRY. I assume this review heading is for the cemetery, not the general area. No SUBTE subway stop, so you need to get a taxi here. Was only P40 from Plaza de Mayo. A lady is hawking self-guided tour maps in either a green kiosk outside the cemetery, or in the marble gated entrance. recommended amount is P0 to get the map which highlights some main tombs. BE CAREFUL !! She seemed to spend an unusually long time talking to me, ad touching my arms, before she would let me go. Which seemed a bit odd. Then after i was walking for a few minutes, some items fell out my backpack. The zips were wide open, impossible they would open like that. There were few people where i was walking inside, so i am 99% sure the map lady was in cahoots with an accomplice in the gate area. I might be wrong, but anyway, keep your wits about you. Inside many interesting tombs, Eva Perons is under the family name DURANTE, to the nine o'clock position from entrance, just set back off the the left alley. Its a simple tomb with a plain marble face. Not many taxis in the vicinity, some are loitering for longer cab fares at the taxi stand. so i walked 2 blocks away before getting a taxi
Nice place to stay. We stayed in this area, prices are a little more, but some great eating options and close to the embassy building, which look really cool. Also, close to other attractions.

A great place to spend time. This place has it all, great architecture, wonderful bistros,pleasant strolling areas and of course the superb city of the dead memorials that is located here (Evita is here). The area is close to the downtown and a short walk from Florida street.

surprised. i did not think i would enjoy visiting a cemetery; and did not look it up before going for some reason … loved it ! went with a guide from buenos tours (i recommend) and he explained everything history/political context etc it was fabulous!

free and educational. Much bigger than you think, there is a lot to see and worth taking your camera. Most people just see Evita's resting place, which is like just seeing the Mona Lisa in the Louvre. You dont need a map, though a pompous woman with a fake British accent can sell you one. Most people you wont know, so it might be worth taking a free tour for more depth.
Beautiful European neighbourhood . Recoleta looks very prestigious and beautiful. Many museums, the Cemetery, monuments and palaces. One day could be enough if you are not going inside the museums.
Atmosphere. Lovely safe and traditional district,classy, lovely buildings, interesting just to walk around and get a feeling of swish Buenos Aries, lovely cafes and of course the Recoleta cemetary.

Funky Fun. This a very alive and active area with brightly colored buildings and trendy shops. This is a fun area to browse the streets or sit in an outdoor cafe patio and sip a delicious beverage and listen to the music all around. This is a must see area and is easily accessed by the public bus system however it is about a 45 minute ride, but well worth the trip.
Really interesting. Just strolling through what is like a village of little stone houses but they are the grand resting places of ArgentinasWealthy is a great way to spend the afternoon.

Evita's Last resting Place. Unfortunately it was raining when we arrived here and there was a funeral going on. So it was a little distracting. The "graves" were certainly interesting and yes one must see the movie Evita or read the book before going here as it is significant. It is apparent that the people loved Evita and her story is interesting.
A very amazing cemetery. A cemetery with very beautiful statues and tombstones. Make sure to see Evita's grave (you'll recognise it by the amount of flowers).

shopping. Four places in Recoleta to consider.Rossi & Caruso: if that US 30K is burning a hole in your pocket and you just have to have a king-size chinchilla throw for your bed then this is the place. Me, I passed on the chinchilla throw but went for the great leather carry all. L Vuitton may be a more recognizable logo but we're talking marginal benefit to marginal cost. Great leather store.Lopez Taibo: wonderful leather shoes. Fell in love with a leather jacket there but didn't have my size. Kitty corner across from APH.Cravall: just up the street from L Taibo. Well dressed older gentleman letting you in (should you pass the screening...) is founder. His son, Frederico, is spot on. Knows his stuff. Engaging fellow. You will not be disappointed by selection or prices.Arandu: another leather place. Serious polo store too. Check out the belt selections. Better bags at Rossi & Caruso in my oh so humble opinion.At the time, USD was trading 1.5x official rate so green money ruled.

Must visit area in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is the area where the famous cemetery and church are located. The cemetery has some very unique and beautiful tombs. The most visited tomb is, of course, Evita Peron. However she is buried under her family name, Durant.The area around the cemetery and church has lots of nice restaurants, hotels, and shops. The Galerias Pacifico mall is also located near-by.
Very interesting.. Lots of interesting history here. Free. Take an umbrella the sun is hot. Easy to walk to and an interesting church next to it.

Nice district of BA. To get to the cemetery walking from the centre of BA you pass through Recoleta. It's a small town within a city. Great shops and restaurants abound in the tree lined streets making it a lovely place to wander. When you have visited the cemetery ignore the expensive restaurants and bars outside and walk two minutes into the Main Street where you will find better and cheaper outlets.
Recoleta experience. Visited area in 2006. cemetary is unique and a must see attraction. The whole area is great for walking, eating or shopping.

Comfortable area for dining and shopping. We loved Recoleta. It's a combination of Paris and the Upper East Side of Manhatten. Great small restaurants. La Olla de Felix should not be missed. Lots of small stores and several malls for shopping. Best area to stay in Buenos Aires. we loved our hotel-Buenos Aires Grand Hotel.

Lovely area full of Parks and of course the famous cemetery. The hight light of this area is the famous Cemetry and the Church right next to it.Its worth a visit. The cemetery is very unique with beautiful tombs. There are a lot of guides available who would take you around for a small fee. We had a superb guide who took great pains to explain each tomb and the history behind the cemetery as well as the people. We spent nearly 11/2 hours there. Ofcourse the highlight of the cemetery is the one of Eva Peron, which wasn't as impressive as the others.A place worth a visit.
Interesting. Well planned and interesting to visit. Really ornate Tombs and monuments dedicated to loved ones. The famous Eva Peron is buried there along with many other dignitaries.

Tales of the Dead. This hallowed place is fascinating, multi layered and has many colorful stories about the people buried there. To fully appreciate it, take a tour with a guide or with a guide book because there is a lot more to this crowded cemetery than just Evita's gravesite. The story of her stolen body and subsequent return is a book in itself. It's definitely worth visiting.
Interesting Cemetery -- Don't miss it.... When visiting Buenos Aires make sure you take the time to visit Recoleta Cemetery -- you will find the monuments interesting -- quite unusual.
Great area. Loved walking around in this area. Good choice of restaurants and bars. Cementary was very cool. Reminded me of Pere La Chaise in Paris.
Pedestrian Area but with Few Truly Unique Shops. An attractive pedestrian area, however the stores held limited interest for us. The mall Galerias Pacifico is located there also.
Nice area for cafes and outdoor dining. Nice area where you can sit outside and enjoy the sunshine with an ice cold Quilmes! Very lively atmosphere and great for people watching and some sightseeing.
Four Stars. Shaded neighborhoods with lots of trees. Easy walking district. Good people watching. Good restaurants.

Great place for lovers of architecture. There's just so much to see and do in this part of BA. There is of course the Our Lady of Pilar Basilica (founded 1732) which is just beside the Recoleta cemetery. Inside the church you can visit the Del Pilar Cloisters which is a collection of old vests, statues, antipendium and bibels & missal. The cemetery itself is amazing with all lavishness people put into building and decorating family graves. Just across the cemetery you will find a great number of trendy cafés and restaurants to suit your taste and wallet.
A lovely area. Safe to walk around. Lots of good places to eat. Great ice cream!Lots of interesting places to visit in this area.

Beautiful neighborhood and cemetery. Obviously you go to the Recoleta to see the cemetery which is very interesting. However, the whole neighborhood is lovely and relatively free of the grafitti that seems to be everywhere in BA. We stopped by the Sunday market in the square in the late afternoon and there wasn't much there so I'd skip that but the park itself is nice.

Markets, churches and fantastic cemetary. This was a great walking area- so much to see. The Cemetary is a must do- rows and rows of family crypts, sculptures, mausoleums, and history. Evita Peron is buried there. Street markets fill the blocks behind the cemetary on Saturday, I think.

Architecture at its best. A beautiful area to walk round we did it with a guide as part of a tour and it was very interesting about the rich landowners having to sell to upscale hotel chains because of the economy, thankfully most of these fabulous buildings have been saved, nice cafes and restaurants too, and of course the shopping is good if you have a healthy bank balance would recommend a visit to this part of town.
Cemetery visit. Fascinating place. Remember to look for Duarte if you are seeking Eva Peron's family grave. This was her maiden/family name.
Worth the walk in this upscale barrio. Also need to visit the cemetery which is interesting. Quite run down as all Buenos Aires because of their weak economy.

Loved walking around this area.. A visit to the cemetary is enlightening not just to see Eva Peron's resting place. The area has superb architecture and is where the wealthy hang out consequently great for sipping a coffee and people watching.

High Point Of Buenos Aires Elite. if high end shopping is your deal, this is the area.You can stroll through the streets and smell the money and political influence wielded by the embassies housed in beautiful but fortified palaces in the small winding streets.A hour walk will allow you to tour the important embassies and beautiful buildings in the shade of luxurious vegetation.Further north, the Bullrich mall and its high end boutiques await your spending spree.

Nice safe neighbourhood. I really liked this area. It's very safe and the streets are quite pretty around here. It feels a bit more well off. As others have said, some of the restaurants can be a bit overpriced so look for value! Although that can be said about a lot of Buenos Aires anyways. Overall this is a nice place to walk around, people watch, visit the cemetery or sit in the park.

Recoleta. Shaded sidewalks plenty of restaurants, friendly people. Some areas remind me of Paris With their wide avenues and narrow smaller streets that only go one way. Plenty of shopping from well named stores to smaller boutiques.

Safe area to visit.. Area worth visiting. However, some restaurants can be overpriced around cemetery area. Shame to see some quality shops closing down. We were told this is due to import ban. Area is quite safe residential and hotel area.
A must see!. This cemetery reads like a who's who in Argentine history. We loved reading the different surnames on the tombs. Fascinating and very worth your time!

The perfect place to stay. A great place from which to explore Buenos Aires. Elegant and safe with many of the art museums and other attractions within walking distance. Easy bus connections to the rest of the city. The parks here are enormous and beautiful. Most of the embassies are nearby in a gorgeous neighborhood. Plenty of great restaurants, and of course, the famous cemetery. There's a huge craft fair near it every Saturday.
Classic. the Recoleta area is more classic and expensive area. Very nice designer shops around and great restaurants and hotels. Very safe and good place to enjoy Buenos Aires
Walking Recoleta Neighborhood. Fun walk through the well-known Recoleta neighborhood. Nice parks and home...plus we found a bakery and a chocolate shop!
Stones tells History. Nice area, quiet and sheltered from daily life, interesting graveyard that tells the story and history of Argentina .Highly recommend!
Shopping. This is a very pretty brand orientated shopping mall in the centre of the city. it had nothing we could not get at home in London

Great place to grab a drink. Good restaurants, bars, and as with each neighborhood it has its own character. If you are a budget traveler this is a great place to take a stroll during the first part of your day and check out the sculptures and the park. Of course you can miss Recoleta Cemetery. My first visit here in 2009 was the reason that i found my extended family in BsAs.

Great place to stay. stayed at the Sofitel. Very easy to walk to many sights in the district. The parks are lovely, shopping is good although ever all stores have left town because of the currency problems. Lots of nice restaurants and bars. The cemetery is well worth visiting.

Great place to stay when visiting Buenos Aires. We selected to stay in La Recoleta after our cruise to the Antartica as we found out this area of the city to offer the best compromise between great sightseeing and cost ! Our hotel was on Callao Street between Santa Fe and Cordoba , close to the subway station (Callao) and at a walk able distance to the Recoleta Cemetery area ! There are plenty of good restaurants , shopping stores and historical landmarks to choose from and the area is safe ! Our room was on the 6th floor of the building which was high enough to avoid the noise at street level and offer us some relaxing nights ! We found out the prices of an hotel room to be about 25% cheaper than the other tourist areas of BA

Don't miss Recoleta when visiting Buenos Aires. This beautiful neighborhood features distinctive architecture, outdoor cafes, beautiful shops, and all sorts of interesting attractions, including the Recoleta cemetery, el Basilica Pilar (and the fair with hundreds of vendors on Saturday and Sunday), the iconic Alvear Palace and Hyatt Hotels, art galleries, and more. Highly recommended for a stroll, exploration, and food.

Nice Part of Town. Recoleta in my opinion is the best location to be if vacationing in B.A.You can practically walk to all the tourist attractions.Only a word of caution, if you decide on staying on Pueyrredon and Las Herras, there is construction for a new subway station. You might want to stay on an upper floor to minimize construction noise. Otherwise, we loved the area and would return.

Go for a walk.. The Recoleta district of Buenos Aires contains several streets that are pedestrian only. These streets are lined with many interesting shops as well as street vendors, and there is no lack of human traffic if people watching is your thing. The call of "Cambio, Cambio" is frequent. These black market money changers offer a much better rate for currency exchange than you will get at the bank. The district is loaded with architectural gems as well, so don't forget to look up.

By far my favourite area in BA. Recoleta is a mix of interesting locations. The main attraction is the cimitery but all around is full of shops and restaurants. Restaurants close to the cimitery are a bit too touristy so better to go for something easy like icecream or cakes. The market around the cimitery is very authentic with local artists.

Recoleta nice neighborhood. I am staying in an apartment in the Recoleta neighbourhood and although it is a little far from the tango scene, it is fairly clean and safe ( in BA standards as this city is VERY dirty and in my mind somewhat dangerous). My apartment is on a busy street however and quite noisy so I have to sleep with ear plugs. The main street (General Las Heras) is wide and noisy but the side streets are quieter and nice to walk along. I have found most everything I need here from key cutting to butcher shops and the buses go most everywhere I need to go. The Recoleta Cemetery is close and if you are a good "walker", this neighbourhood is a great starting point in any direction. I walk here often alone at night on my way home from a milonga, and have never felt threatened. Dodging cars crossing the street is another thing and I have experienced people almost getting hit (including me) on at least three occasions. It would be terrifying to bring small children to BA, but if you had to choose a neighbourhood, this might be one of the better ones, especially as there are a few parks in the area.
Cool area. Fun area to stay in although very NYC like. Great restaurants and pretty easy to walk. The Saturday market was excellent.

Recoleta Cemetery. A must see.. I didn't expect to be reviewing a cemetery, but this is no ordinary cemetery. There are paved 'streets' lined with mausoleums in a huge variety of architectural styles built over some hundreds of years. It is fascinating. Evita's mausoleum is there and there was a constant stream of tourists in that street. There were several tourist groups in the cemetery while we were there but the site is large and it did not feel crowded.
Saturday Market is Wonderful!. Bring your pesos and start shopping seriously! Lots of leather and jewelry and musical instruments and art and weaving and and and and....you could spend all day here!

Walking in Recolatta. It's truly inspiring to walk through a sculpture garden in memory of if folks who have passed.
Magnificent pieces of Art in honor of those lives have impacted us.
Most unusual with lots of history.

Lovely area. Recoleta is a beautiful district of Buenos Aires and one of the main tourist destinations is the cemetery where Eva Peron is. A very serene place to stroll around. When we stopped at a bar to have a drink we checked the bar prices first and were amazed to see that the bar/cafe we looked at was charging £5 for a coca cola. We of course declined and found a bar further back offering more sensible prices.

Evita museum. Make it a point to go to the museum displaying Evita's clothes, shoes, photos, death mask, etc. At first I found very little English on the displays but as I moved farther in, I found enough to make the museum very worthwhile. Then go to her final resting place in the Recoleta cemetary. The tombs there are fascinating, but you will have to search for her tomb. She is listed under the Duarte tomb because she was buried with her father, Duarte, instead of in the Peron tomb, due to Peron's next wife prohibiting it.

Recoleta is a HUGE posh area and not just a cemetery - get real!. Recoleta is not just a cemetery, but a large and very rich, classy area in which to spend as much time as possible. From the centre of the city it is a fifteen minute walk away and it gets posher and smarter the closer you get to it. There are a colossal amount of expensive flats in the areas (about 400,000 U.S. dollars for most), plenty of smart shops, lots of posh cafes and a wide array of independent shops. Throw in a few old ladies walking their poodles, the tomb of that old deceased has-been Eva Peron, the brilliant market on a saturday, the design centre, the art gallery and the best church in the city ................ and you'll want to buy a little flat here so you can visit regularly. Without doubt the smartet part of the city ............. if you like Mayfair in London....... you'll like this area.
INTERESTING. Probably one of the most amazing cemeteries in the world. Unlike anything I have seen before. Some very fancy accommodations for a cemetery!
Eva Peron. great to wander around the tombs, Evita's is no 88. A family tomb with no pretence. A bit of quiet in bustling Buenos Aires

Great area to check out architecture. The buildings in the area were stunning and we enjoyed walking around the area during the day time. We did a free walking tour that took us to parts of the this area that was great.

Great view during the evening. Recoleta is a great square where you have the cemetery where Evita Peron tumble is, you have a mall with great view, a small and beautiful church, great restaurants and the amazing thing there is the green area where you can seat, relax and comtemplate the huge and tremendous impressive trees. You may consider going during the day and one night for dinner, since the church during the evening is beautiful.

Weirdly interesting!. I'm not one to tour around a cemetery, but this particular cemetery is quite interesting. Everything above ground and it covers a huge area in the center of the city. Interesting to see old & falling apart vaults next to refurbished, ultra modern vaults...and of course, you can't leave without finding where Evita resides!

Pretty area with lots to see and do. The Recoleta Cementary is one of the big attractions - amazing to see the resources used for this. There are many other nice things to see and do in Recoleta - lots of lovely parks (plazas) with heroic statues, some lovely old buildings, many museums, art galleries, shops, good cafes. Stop in for a drink at the Hotel Alvear - it's worth seeing the inside and is a nice peaceful interlude, and is reasonably priced for a drink.
A real look into history. The tombs were magnificent and a real reflection of the rich dead of B.A.. Amazingly clean as well and well kept
Great neighborhood. Very good neighborhood; good base for a tourist; walking distance to many museums. Felt safe at night.

Tree lines streets and some very nice shops. It's very refreshing in a large city to be able to walk along tree lined and branch overhanging streets especially when the temperatures are high. Somehow it almost cools you straight away.There are some very good shops and cafe's in this area and also some green open areas like small parks. There are also some of the best flowers stalls (which smell fantastic) that I have seen in a long while. Some great apartment blocks and old houses many with flowers and greenery around them.I walked extensively around the area and thoroughly enjoyed it.If you shop and have US$ then you can easily get a rate of 14-15 peso/$ (instead of the government rate of around 8.3) and many shops will offer you an additional discount of up to 20% if you are buying presents/gifts etc. The 'blue' dollar is alive and well and required in all of Argentina.
A Cemetary - Who would have thought. The cemetary was very unique and historical in content. Guide maps or identificatioin markings were not available that would made the visit easier.

Interesting place to wander. Interesting to visit but could really have done with a map- had to note down where the 'famous' ones were and we only looked for these as guide book mentioned them. I would have liked to be able to find them by style ie art nouveau. Also, English tours are only on certain days now not daily

This is a must see area with very high end shops that you only read about. Lots of little cafes.. We walked to this area from our hotel. We stopped at cafe's along the way usually just to have a beverage and people watch. You will walk past shops that you have only read about. Though the Argentina money exchange is pro-American don't expect to get products at better prices. The only way to take advantage of the exchange rate is through services (hair, nails, massage) and only tipping 10%.
Pleasant neighborhood. Pleasant neighborhood with good restaurants (check on Lola in other review) and some attractions, including the old cemetery which commonly has a tourist swarm.

Recoleta. This is a wonderful place to stay when visiting Buenos Aires. There are many things to do as well as tree-lined streets and quiet parks. The sense of history is everywhere with the monuments in the plazas. There are also modern elements and conveniences that make it a good place to walk through or stay for a while.
Beautiful neighborhood. This is an area of BA where you can spend at least a few days exploring. The shopping, architecture and tourist sites are really spectacular and easily walkable.
Cemetery. You have to see Evita's grave. It ia not so luxury as the otheres graves from the place, but you feel something.
Fascinating. Definitely worth a visit. Fascinating cemetery with beautiful tombs. Lots of tour groups in front of evita perrone's tomb

Ricoleta and the Intersur Hotel. Clean, safe, upmarket and select, sophisticated all describe this part of Buenos Aires.
The Hotel Intersur Ricoleta is professional in all aspects..from dealing with foreign exchange, to the spa services and overall hospitality. I recommend it highly.

A must in Buenos Aires. French style buildings with more than 100 years, the cemetery with all the national heroes, ex presidents, the french style cafes full of tables in the sidewalks, under the tree... everything makes Recoleta different to other neighborhoods. Some of the avenues crossing the area are just like Paris with less glamour. Great park, nice shoppings and restaurants and a fantastic mix of old and new, people from all around the world. It's probably the most cosmopolitan area in town.

Not only traditional families and Evita's crypt: prestigious celebrities. A visit to a cemetery always provides you with surprises... if you know what to look for. Most of the tourists visit this place to see Evita's crypt but there are many important persons from the Argentine culture: two Nobel Prizes (Mr. Carlos Saavedra Lamas, Peace, 1936, and Dr. Luis Federico Leloir, Chemestry, 1970), at least 10 great writers: José Hernandez ("Martin FIerro"), Oliverio Girondo ("Espantapájaros", scarecrow ), Adolfo Bioy Casares, Silvina and Victoria Ocampo, Estanislao del Campo, Miguel Cané, Paul Groussac. Medical doctors that know give their names to the most important hospitals: Dr. Cosme Argerich, Dr. Francisco Muñiz, Dr. Guillermo Rawson and Dr. Toribio Ayerza, these two last scientists founded the Red Cross in Argentina. If this is not enough, see the architecture and the famly stories and you will take full advantage of this visit.

Interesting cemetery with lots of history. We went with a tour during the middle of the week and the only place is was very crowded was around Eva Duarte Peron's family crypt. I found it interesting to just wander around and look at the different grave sites--some modern but most of them from many years ago.
A lovely neighbourhood to walk around. This upmarket area of Buenos Aires features trendy outdoor cafes and boutiques. Ensure you visit Recoleta Cemetary and pay homage to Evita.

A place to walk by!. This place has the Cementry with very famous people tombs like Evita and Perón, but also has a lot of shops, a museum and also during weekends you can find an artesans shops selling a lot of cool stuff very original.

A glimpse of the Argentina that was..... This wealthy suburb of central Buenos Aires , depicts the opulence of the country at the beginning of the 20th century, and what Argentina could have been if anarchy and successive populist governments could have been avoided. Old mansions, 5 star hotels , restaurants and fancy shopping are the trademarks of this area.Don’t miss it, but do not be deceived, this is a snapshot of a bygone Argentina.

Posthumous Excess - a densely glorious testamentary to Argentine History. Probably the world's most famous cemetery is this icon to wealth and status in Argentina, including Evita's Duarte family mausoleum being that of another family which unfortunately was not in a favored status with the Peron family, so, out with the old and in with the new...the coldest eviction! This is not a cemetery folks as much as it is the Upper East Side of mausoleum construction - wall to wall frightfully expensive and creative brick, marble, mortar, and bronze odes to the deceased. It is a place not to miss, and I have been through it several times. Should I end this with an....Amen?

A great neighbourhood with a cosmopolitan flavour.... Like the buildings, the tree-lined street, the general quietness considering that it is very much in the central part of town. Good taste and elegance is in the air...the shops, the restaurants, the coffee shops, the locals...

If you want to be where the Old High Class lives. This is the place where the Middle class (that used to be High Class) lives. This is exactly the stronghold of conservatives, when in the early XX century all Middle Class people were proud to be European, not Latin American. When Buenos Aires was named the Paris of Latin America.

Strangely beautiful. This review relates specifically to the Cemetery in Recoleta which is a small but intriguing city for the dead in the very heart of hustle and bustle. There are the exquisite family mausolea, in grand marble and decorated inside with fine lace and precious metal plaques. Adjacent are neglected, once grand ones covered in cobwebs, decaying elegantly with coffins stacked high inside, but starting to fall apart. Follow the crowd for Evita's family crypt - it's quite a narrow space, so a handful of visitors makes it very crowded, but a little patience allows for a photo or two.

Interesting place, love the latin cemeteries. It was just cool to go wandering around. I went to look for Evita's but it was really nice to go wander around. I was there on the weekend and there was a really nice market all around recoleta.
Touristy but worth the visit. There is no entry fee but many tourist busses, Go as early as possible as Eva Peron's resting place is crowded.
This is where we finally finish after travelling across the globe. It is a beautiful, humbling ,maffluent area - great perspective on life and this why travel is worth it!

Fancy cemetery. This tourist spot (and it was the one place we saw lots of tourists) is quite crowded. The mausoleums were quite beautiful and lined up like a little town. The little church next door (where the friars originally lived when the cemetery was just an orchard) is well worth a visit. Small charge to enter the church, none to go to the cemetery.

Baires' good face. In addition to being one of the most affluent neighborhoods of Buenos Aires due to its lavish homes and luxury hotels, Recoleta is also an area rich of historical and architectural interest and cultural spaces.
Interesting and historical place. Definitely worth a visit if you are in BA. The tombs are all unique and laid out as though they are along little streets and avenues.

Great neighborhood to explore. I'm staying in this neighborhood and enjoy living here. It's very similar to the Upper West Side of NYC--filled with fashionable boutiques and a very upscale vibe. Best of all, it includes the world famous Receoleta Cemetery. The ideal weekend stroll is to enjoy a cup of tea, stroll through the cemetery admiring the history, then taking a quick siesta in the nearby park.
The best available in Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires has a (unjustified) reputation for being an exciting city with lots to do and see. Well the cemetery at Recoleta is the most exciting place in town,

Good museums, shopping and the old cemetary. The cemetery is a stop for the cruise ships (pick a day when they're NOT in port!), because it's a tourist destination, having Evita's tomb & all. The museums in this area are first rate, notably MALBA & Bellas Artes.

Incredible Neighborhood. This was not the first time i visit a cemetary as a tourist attraction. However, this was the most beautiful one I have visited. The architecture of the space makes for a interesting visit. You can see all the tombs of famous leaders, musicians, artist and more. A humbling experience for someone who enjoys history and calming strolls. Whether you just visit to get away from the busy city, or to view the tombstones, you wont be dissapointed. Its somewhat of a maze so try to carry a map as to not get overwhelmed. I would recommend getting a guide so you can read up about each tomb that interest you. If not the repetition may leave you uninterested. It can get hot if its sunny out so be sure to stay hydrated and dress appropriately.

Recoleta Cemetary. Very interesting place to visit with beautiful mausoleums statues etc. Like a small town it's so big. We went looking for the tomb of Eva Peron, but got sidetracked - her tomb is not easy to find and it was a very hot day, so gave up looking in the end.

Peaceful and calm yet interesting!. This is the first time i visit a cemetry and knew that its a tourist attraction. Im so amazed by it. It so calm and peaceful once you step inside. No loud music, no loud voice etc, slow strolling, viewing of each tomb is really amazing. I get to see all the tombs and how it can be build this way to remiscing the past. Some of the tombs was really beautiful. Should really visit it!
Perfectly located and calm. The Recoleta neighborhood is quiet, historic, and surrounded by museums. It is a very safe place to stay on your first trip (or second or third) to Buenos Aires.
Aged and tasteful. Unusual Monuments distinguished people of the city.The general impression is quite priyatnoe.Mne, enough forty minutes ;)
Interesting part of Argentine History. Fascinating. Blend of new and old. Some fascinating "tributes". Yes...Eva Perone's gravesite worth seeing. A part of Buenos Aires history....
Pretty area to wander and enjoy the park. Great place to wander and enjoy the cemetery and the park among many other sights. Great on a Sunday when there is a market and lots of activity.

Lovely area. We walked to Recoleta from Palmero then joined an English tour starting out in the cemetary. The crypts are for the wealthy, the politically connected and historical families if BA - fascinating stories with many, primarily Eva Peron (Duarte). A must see inBA. Outside the cemetary is an upscale mall with many options for restaurants. An interesting day.

It is a cemetery so not too lively. We walked in one afternoon to see Evita's tomb. It took a while but found it with the help of a tour. The remainder is a graveyard. Very interesting tombs and history but maybe it is me, you have seen one tomb well, let's go somewhere else.
Cemetry. T his was something special. Evs Peron's was here and the family cripts are amazing. And the day we went it rained ... perfect for a cemetery.

A nice vivid part of town. Aside from the famous cemetery with Evitá Perron´s tomb, definitivly worth a visit and to walk around the cemetery .We were there around lunch time, negative part it was really hot, but not many People. Otherwise, this is a part of town with Shopping, Restaurant, Business area, and green Areas.

More than just a cemetery. My favourite barrio of Buenos Aires. A lot more to it than the famous cemetery, good as it is, together with the Cultural Center and the beautiful white-washed Basilica of Nostra Senora del Pilar in the same strip. There are excellent accommodations, a few good places to eat, lots of green space, and two of the major museums of the city (Bellas Artes and Decorative Arts). It hosts several faculties of the University of Buenos Aires (Law, Medicine, Dentistry and Pharmacy), as well as the remarkable National Library that resembles a huge rectangular sculpture standing on a pedestal that is much too small for it. Shopping opportunities abound: the lower-end Recoleta Mall is the place to go indoors for the bargains, while the open-air market on the edge of the park facing the Museo de Bellas Artes offers a colorful array of what most open-air markets offer. But there is no lack of expensive high-end shopping at internationally renowned outlets as well. Several of the hotels and apartment blocks are truly up-market, and I advise you to step into the foyer of the Alvear Palace Hotel to see one of the most gorgeously decorated interiors of the city. As in most S. American cities, handsome statues of dubious heroes abound ( Mitre Bartolome, Guillermo Rawson, Carlos Alvear), as well as several that can be considered works of pure art ( The Archer, The Last Centaur, a dramatic Nude Male Torso by Fernando Botero, and the celebrated but now half-deceased metal sculpture Floralis Generica by Edward Catalino that was designed to open at dawn and close at dusk, but whose mechanism has been “kaput” for several years). There is so much grass and parkland upon which you can stroll, in contrast to the dangerously crumbling sidewalks facing pedestrians in most other parts of the city.
GREAT AREA. This is a great area to walk around - very safe. Lots of nice little restaurants and also some boutiques. Can be an expensive area but well worth a walk around

A peaceful retreat in BA . Easy to find your way around. On a hot summer's day, a fascinating walk in this busy city among modern and gothic style mausoleum.. Free admission too . In the lovely Ricoleta are of the city, there is a map at entrance and a list of families interred. Evita is buried with others in the Duarte family, under this name . You can't miss it as there will be a mass of flowers and people around it.

Mixed neighborhood with very Upscale areas. There are sections of the community that contain Embassies, high-end shopping and the toniest hotels, but just blocks away are regular middle class areas with shops, restaurants and cafes that cater to the locals rather than tourists. We spend the better part of two days walking Recoleta. There are more tourist sites in this district than any of the others including churches, museums, the Recoleta Cemetary and European-style stone mansions that date back to the 19th century. There is no shortage of things to do and see in this area. Most of the time of the average visitor will be spent in the Microcenter (where we stayed) or Recoleta, although most o the other areas have a distinct charm and there own must-see attractions.
Morbid but fascinating to see. Free, easy to walk round, but no map nor details of the families interred there. Eva Peron's mausoleum not easy to find
Beautiful area. Many nice old buildings, the Recoleta cemetary close by and just a nice area to have a stroll. Also a bit safer than areas of BA.

Amazing!. If you're talking about the cemetery, Recoleta is one to behold! Free admission, and you'll find willing guides at the front entrance. However, most guidebooks willingly give tourists the directions to the crypt of Evita Peron. More interesting, however, are some of the hundreds of family mausoleums throughout the cemetery. You can wander here for hours, and you WILL get lost!
The city of the dead. Amazing concept: mausoleum after mausoleum after mausoleum … and then Eva Duarte de Peron's mausoleum!

I love the neighborhood. Great neighborhood. Reminds me of New Orleans in the US. Many great restaurants and there is a Street Fair of local crafts on Saturday. Volta ice cream is a must. The Cemetary is worth a couple hours of your time. The art museum is within walking distance. The silver flower is also close. Very easy to use the bus and subway ( a very cheap way to travel around the city.). I liked all the mini markets, inexpensive wine, and the safe feel,of the community.
Great local steak restaurant. Excellent old style Argentinean steak restaurant, no frills, excellent food and service. We went back twice.

An unusual cemetery. This site is so different from cemeteries in the US. No grass but lots of mausoleums - each in competition with the next for beauty. This is the final resting place for Eva Peron. 'Don't Cry for Me Argentina' went through my head all day!

A charming and calm area. Characterised by wide boulevards and high quality property,shops and hotels Recolata has a very European feel. It is a pleasure to walk around visiting it's many sights feeling safe even at night

Eva Peron's grave. Worth visiting, Recoleta is a pleasant area, we did not have time to visit the museum next door.We had a very good guide who took us all around the cemetery which made it more interesting.This area has quite a high crime record so ladies no jewellery !
Lovely neighbourhood!. Wonderful place to walk around. Plenty of sights to see and things to do, from the cemetery to the flea market
Beautiful place. Just walk round here with shops, restaurants and you'll see a lovely part of the city. Walked through here as a tour then grabbed a drink. Very cute

Bring a map. We did not have a map and rambled along in the heat and humidity because we wanted to explore on our own. Tombs of all materials and sizes can be found here. Fun to look for burial places of the famous such as Evita Peron.

This is a "Must Visit" location. So much to see from various architectural periods. I could have spent the whole day in the Cemetario Recoleta. The latest entrance is 17:00hrs as it closes at 17:30 so take note.

Great place to walk around, just noisy to stay in.. Interesting area with a bit of a Parisian feel but noisy as he'll to stay in. Sirens go off, garbage collected and still people get up and about early!

This is definitely worth a miss.. This is a cemetery filled with mausoleums from different periods of Argentinian notables (sans Juan Peron). The big claim to fame is that people flock to the mausoleum where Evita Peron is inturned, in her family's (Duarte) mausoleum. People stand in line to take photos of the brass plaque, and WITH the brass plaque, on the wall indicating that she resides within. Your time in Buenos Aires can be better spent elsewhere.

Good place to die. To save you time, Evita is buried in The Duarte Family mausoleum. All of the mausoleums are pretty much over the top. It is more of a display of the trappings of wealth than a cemetery. Definitely worth the visit.

Must see for Buenos Aires. Very unusual cemetery that is a destination all of its own. There were markets and restaurants all around and nice area to see. The cemetery is huge with many famous people and interesting stories about who and what has happened here. I wish I had a guide book but just walked around on our own--next time will get more info prior to know what I am seeing.

Unbelievable grandeur for the Deceased. One of the most interesting cemeteries to visit. Enormous number of tombs tracing the history of the rich and famous of Buenos Aires. While the crowd is attracted to the Eva Peron burial (tomb 88) there is a great amount of history to discover walking the myriad of aisles

Amazing cemetery. I never thought I would be recommending a cemetery but it is built like a little town and is really quite amazing. People visit to see Eve Peron's grave. Ironically she would probably never have wanted to be buried in such a posh place.
Different. Completely unique and different experience. Has a character and charm. Feels a bit strange when you just walk in. For people who doesn't like cemeteries not recommended.

Best BA shopping. We stayed in recoletta so I explored i like M shoes for men . good spot for some alligator or crocs . the sane mall across from the park hyatt has nice leather bags and backpacks . i scored a bag as nice as a berlutti for 400. the same malll has a nice wine store . just up the street is a wine store that will ship and i scored some nice cobos , luigi and catena zapata malbecs there is a nice mall near the alvear palace with silver for the dining room with great serving pieces . the martina stores have a polo theme but there are nice leather outfits

touristic but real. This neighborhood is touristic but real. It has great bones. Love the cemetery in low season when it is clse to empty (almost never), The area is filled with parks and museums many of which hardly ever get full. Go there!! Have a coffee and just chill in an outdoor cafe!!
Recoleta the upscale neighberhood. We stay in Recoleta and love it, we feel secure, can walk at night. We are close to most of the things to see, we feel like we are in Paris.

Recoleta. Recoleta neighborhood will remind visitors of the upper East Side of New York or perhaps the 6th arrondissement of Paris. Lots of very nice apartment buildings, five star hotels, intermixed with old mansions now occupied by embassies. There are numerous good restaurants and opportunities for window shopping. However, as is the case with most of Buenos Aires, this is a residential neighborhood and not a tourist destination. The residents of Buenos Aires justifiably compare their city's architecture to Paris, and the street vibe does match that city, as well. However, the absence of world-class museums, historical buildings, and general cultural excitement would justify only a brief visit here. In contrast, one could spend a month in Paris or New York and still not have time to visit all that is available. Furthermore, it was most disturbing to be warned by everyone, guides, hotel employees, etc, to be very wary of pickpockets and avoid carrying passports, money even in the busy commercial streets of downtown or the elegant residential areas.A final word to the wise. Bring US dollars to use for any purchases because the Argentinian peso has no value either in or out of the country. Everyone, and I mean EVERYONE, will eagerly accept dollars and give you an exchange rate far better than the official 8.5 pesos to the dollar. On average, we got 12 to the dollar in restaurants, stores and taxis and might have gotten even more with a bit more aggressive bargaining. That just seemed too crass for us with the locals already under so much financial strain from their own government. (DO NOT USE THE STREET MONEY CHANGERS! You will encounter them everywhere, even waling around the shopping district shouting "cambio." The rate might be better but the risk of crime would be worse. It would also be illegal.)
Interesting. We went here on sightseeing trip via the hop on hop off bus. Old and new architecture. This is a must see stop.

A part of the city. Beside the cemetery Recoleta is worth to visit. You will find a lot of nice old buildings, shopping areas with expensive boutiques and costly restaurants. For me Recoleta is not the most interesting place to go.

Interesting Stories. The variety and artistry of the mausoleums is impressive. We had an excellent private guide who told us dozens of stories about the people buried here, many famous military or politicians, some young people who died way too early under interesting circumstances. The most popular spot is the Duarte family mausoleum where Evita is buried. The cemetery is very large so a good guide is highly recommended.

Nice area, upscale, greenspaces. Europeans Style Green Spaces with lots of vendors with handmade crafts. Many of the jewelry offerings were quite good and unique. The restaurant scene is also very nice here and there are great places to grab a beer near the Cemetery.

An up-market area of Buenos Aires. An excellent hotel - see review of The Brick Hotel, Posadas 1232. The cemetery where Eva Peron is buried is in this area. There are a number of small restaurants and coffee shops, with some shopping [for those who enjoy it!]. It appears to be a 'safe' area in which to walk.
