Safe and affordable. We found Recoleta really safe with plenty of eateries and at affordable prices. Highlights of the area are the Cemetery, the beautiful garden, the Floralis Generica and Recoleta Mall. Definitely a place to stay while in BsAs.

sui generis and oh so porteno. There is a reason that all the guidebooks suggest a visit to Recoleta cemetery. Yes the sculptures in the various (above ground) tombs are often magnificent, and seeing the tributes left to Evita are moving. But more than that, there is something very evocative about the whole experience, which captures part of the BA experience of passion, refinement, art, sorrow and also joy in life. this is one place you must visit if you go to BA

Love the area. Walking distance from our hotel. Great place to wonder around, eat some great Empanadas or just seat in the park and appreciate the views. The Cemetery is an amazing quiet and beautiful place to walk around also.

Do not miss the market on weekend. May be not the most expensive flats but you feel the quality. The street bazaar is active only at weekend; Saturday and Sunday. Cemetery is stunning, we are all engineers in the family and get shocked with the solutions they found and discussed a lot for reasoning. Must to see..

Don't miss Recoleta cemetery. I stayed with a group of friends in Recoleta over the New Year period. It was a great place to stay, safe, beautiful parks, buildings and restaurants. Don't miss the Recoleta cemetery - its like the set of a mini Adams Family. The day we went there were no English tours so we followed a tour group to the grave of Eva Perron, then we walked around on our own.
My favorite area. Loved the cemetery, the street vendors and atmosphere! We spent the majority of our time in this neighborhood.

Houses the famous Recoleta cemetery where Evita is buried. Recoleta is an older part of the city and has many old buildings, upscale shops, shopping malls, coffee shops and restaurants. The most famous sight in the area is the cemetery which is home to the tomb of Evita and is a busy tourist attraction. The area is nice to walk around with some nice cafés to sit outside and people watch. We were advised to not wear jewelrey and watches in the area as pickpockets are rife.
amazing cemetery. awesome cemetery - a true tribute to the past. The tombs have definite wow factor. A nice day to pass a couple of hours

Lovely neighborhhood to stay in..... This was a great place to stay. The neighborhood is not only beautiful, but safe. There is an abundance of hotels, restaurants, shopping, and things/places to see. There are parks, the famous cemetary, a local market on Sunday, and the list goes on. Great central place to be!

Best place to stay in B. Aires. The better neighborhood , with good restaurants and a quiet surrounding, cinemas at ths Recoleta mall, Alvear avenue, not too far away from downtown, still a fine place to be.

Upscale Neighborhood . This is the neighborhood in which the famous Recoleta Cemetery is located.Since the neighborhood is a must-see, chances are, you will be in Recoleta. Take an hour or so just to stroll through the streets or have a cup of Argentine coffee or ice cream at of the cafes in Recoleta.Some of the fancier hotels, such as the Alvear Palace, are also located in this neighborhood.

A nice stroll. I love it all. A cafecito under the big big GOMERO!!May be sometimes too crowded!You must go and see the Cemetary of RECOLETA, with all the famous people buried there!Even Evita Peron is there!!

Great place to stay. There's shopping and restaurants to explore. I would strongly recommend for travelers who stay in Buenos Aires for a few days. It is the safe and is accessible by major public transportation.

interesting landmark. It's free to see this interesting landmark in the Recoleta. Take advantage of it if you are nearby. I don't think it warrants a special trip if you aren't however. Don't make the same mistake we did and go in the heat of the day in the middle of the summer though!

Evita's grave and Flea Market. The Recoleta Flea Market is located adjacent to a huge cemetery where Evita Peron is buried. The flea market is open on Sundays and offers a huge variety of handwork, food, artwork, jewelry, etc. Allow hours to see all the vendors. Also, this is a good place to use your US dollars - I got a great exchange rate from the vendors.

Nice place for a stroll. This area of town, BA, is one of the nicest to visit and see many sites including the stores, museums, and places where the very well to do lived in style years ago, as well as some who live quite nicely now.
decent area for cemetary and some shopping. Good for a cemetary visit and some lite shopping. There is a big Mall there also but really who cares about a mall

Refined Recoleta. Recoleta is quiet, the buildings are European and it is one of the cleaner barrios in BA. The best things are the ice-cream (we ate at 2 shops comparing the flavours and textures), the empanadas and the 'blue' market (money exchange). The blue market is located just behind one of the deluxe hotels. A long line forms after 4pm and everyone is there to either buy pesos with $US or to buy $US with pesos. This is quite the experience to know that one can gain at least 5% more than the bank rate. Recoleta is a quiet retreat but It is more fun staying in other areas of BA.
great shopping area. There are many boutique stores that are high end fashion and well prices. Known for their leather goods.
A very special cemetery where Evita Peron has her maoseleum. I ´liked the trees in the cemetery. It was it bit difficult to, out of my point of view, understand the way they bury their loved ones.

Lovely cemetary, unique!. The entire place is just so different from other cemeteries. It's a one of a kind experience, besides, if you're a fan of Eva Perone, she's buried there. The area around the cemetery is also nice to visit
Attractive Neighborhood. We stayed in Recoleta and were very happy with our selection. We walked around both day and night and never felt uncomfortable. The area appears clean, safe and upscale.

Incredible cemetery. I have been to quite a few interesting cemeteries around the world, including the famous ones in Paris, Moscow and St. Petersburg, but this one tops all. It is a city within a city with magnificent grave structures. The Recoleta neighborhood also offers museums, restaurants and cafes, certainly worth a visit.

Wonderful older residential area. Nice townhouses and apartments. Quiet.. Great for walking and near cemetery. We walked from Puerto Madero...long walk, but on a nice day, quite pleasant. Mature trees add ambiance and provide shade. One of the best areas to live.
relaxing walkabout. nice shopping, relaxed vibe. cemetary sounds like a strange experience but really teaches you so much about the history of Argentina. Don't miss it

Enjoylable. Just go there and explore for yourself and them please share with me .......remember nothing in Argentina is cheap ......you will get a great food and night life with south american style ....

Elegant and safe. By far the best neighborhood in Buenos Aires. So many attractions and restaurants, The delis are great. Empanadas. Attentive service at La Biela. Architecture is beautiful.Shopping for leather was very good, Of course the wine and beer was excellent as well as other places in Argentina

Great classy place. This place is worth the visit. Highly recommended. Clean beautiful surroundings. The cemetery was out of this world. So interesting with a story behind each musoleum. It was interfering to see Evitas tomb and the story behind it

Monuments to Mortality.. The Cemeteria is awe-inspiring. Mausaleums as far as the eye can see, in various states of repair, most in good condition, provided a quiet few moments. Pensive visitors, and tourists looking for Eva Peron's marker wandered through, pausing to inspect monuments to mortality. And just outside the cemetery, a huge street fair. Vibrant.

The Wonderful Church and Environs. Worship was in progress---the atmosphere was wonderful on that Sunday morning---plus the fair adjacent to the church yard was amazing......we also visited Evita's tomb----the architecture in that cemetery was so well preserved.
A must to do in BA. Nightlife, restaurants, nice for shopping, and walk. The cemetery is in the center and Evita's space is inside. Sundays are nice to experience the flea market.
Evita's Grave. Surprised to find out that this massive complex is right in the middle of the city. Finally saw Evita's grave. Take a local guide otherwise very difficult to know what is what.
Classy and elegant with great shopping!. This part of Buenos Aires seems like cut out of a shopping fairy tale. If you are interesting in riding or horse sports this "barrio" is a must-see.
Great tour. On saturday it has a street-market with handicraft and some art presentations. Also is close to the Recoleta Cemetery which is very beautiful and peaceful.
Great Barrio. We stayed in Recoleta while in BA. Safe neighborhood and a lot of shopping. Well, for me just window shopping! I loved our hotel, Club Frances, but might stay in Palermo next visit.

History and lifestyle.. A wonderful area to stay in or to visit. Great architecture, excellent shops, wide range of restaurants and cafes, very good atmosphere, not to be missed. There is a lot more than the Cemetery, worth visiting and the Church next to it. The Centro Cultural Recoleta is host to interesting and varied art expositions.
Relaxing. Good restaurants, great view and beautiful neighborhood. Where you can find also the famous cemetery and a lot of shopping points.
It is a MUST. You should visit on weekends. Nice to have lunch on the sidewalks, to visit the open air fair, walk around and visit the Cemetery

A Genteel Life. Our hotel was in Recoleta, and so this became our neighborhood. Sitting outside in the cafes, eating delicious chorizo and cheese at a little market with just a couple of tables, window shopping, people watching and just having a good time. If I lived in BA, this is the neighborhood I'd choose.
Wonderful exciting neighborhood. Lots of shopping, elegant hotels, nightlife and oh that phenomenal cemetery!!! Easy to walk around and learn about history and culture of early Buenos Aires.
Very good!. Look to visit the old cemetery, its a beautiful place great architecture to see. Many places to walk around and great restaurants!

Poetry building. We rented and apartment at Poetry building. It was a great location. Food stores, restaurants and shopping near by. Friendly staff and nicely decorated. It matched the time period of the building. A good value to for folks traveling from the U.S.

Nice piece of history. If you are on your own, do take the free tours (11 am) it is worth it, if you want buy the booklet/map, only 15 pesos but not very helpful since it is only a map... but the guide is really nice and answers questioons if you do have any, shows you around and tells you a bit of the history of this coountry. I thought it would be creepy (kind of is) to visit a cemetery as a tourist, but loved the insight on the history of the country. and I could not have done that without the tour.

Must see in Buenos Aires. As everyone says, this is a must see for tourists! Most people want to see Evita's place. There's an interactive map on front that shows you the location.Hint: The restaurants right across the entrance are tourist traps with really mediocre food. Skip them and go get some good food somewhere else!
cemetary. very old and beautifull cemetary where all the important persons of Buenos aires and argentina are burried , amazing atmosphere
a beautiful cemetery. A beautiful and special cemetery. Well worth a visit. Tours are available, but also fun to just wander by yourself

bustling. Great shopping and people watching. This barrio is fascinating and so much fun to scout out a wonderful restaurant, and do some good shopping. The cemetery is fascinating, and the Igelsia there just beautiful, the fair outside the gates is touristy but legitimate.
Beautiful neighborhood. Expensive shopping, beautiful architecture nice side walks actually feel comfortable walking around.

Nice area of BA if you ignore the homeless. This is a fun area to walk in. We stayed in the area and walked almost every street and there are interesting things all around. Lots of shops and at least one café on every corner. The only thing we did not like was if you wish to take any early morning walk (9am is early there) there are homeless people sleeping in shop doorways. Be sure to stop by one of the many parks and watch the professional dog walkers.

Upscale Neighborhood. This is an upscale neighborhood with plenty of shops and outdoor cafes that are ideal for people watching. There is also a large park to explore, along with manicured, tree-lined streets.
Very nice area. Recoleta is a very nice area. Nice parks, nice tree lined streets, many restaurants, interesting sites, very pretty. It reminds me of an area in a European city.
A Must. This is a amazing area The Recoleta Cemetery,and the Church .We have never seen anything like it. This is the resting place for of Eva Duarte Peron.(EVITA.

Beautiful area to take a walk. Being from New York City, I love to explore new cities on foot. The Recoleta neighborhood was just beautiful with a little something for everyone - cute cafés, beautiful buildings and architecture etc.

History in granite. Cool place to visit. Noted as one of the highlights of BA and it's true. The area is great to walk around and the cafes lines along the east side of the cemetery are great spots to people-watch.

Typical neighbourhood. This is a typical neighbourhood of Buenos Aires. Lot's of old mansions with beautiful architeture to be admired. The richest people used to live here. Now it has a lot of select stores and small places to eat or have a coffee. Worth taking a walk around here.

Beautiful and historic area. This is a really nice area to visit. We walked around looking at the architecture and gardens. There were both historic buildings to look at and an outside market to buy locally made items.

Very interesting and nice.. Good shopping possibilities for small presents. Houses beautifully decorated.
Very good coffee shops.
A unique experience. Great fotos ops with many famous burials. I visited the boxer Luis Angel Firpo's, President Alfonsin and Evita Duarte's resting places.

Very nice area. If you like walking a city an discovering hidden little places, this is your spot. Very european architecture, friendly people...be sure to pay a visit to the cementery. Yes! The cementery is one of the hotspots with coffes and restaurantes just outside
Highend neighbourhood. Luxury surroundings and classy eating establishments- near Eva Peron's burial site and near lots of major attractions
Bustling neighborhood. Lots to see and do in this neighborhood of Buenos Aires. The cemetery is very interesting and the public spaces and restaurants are inviting.
As good as it gets. A lovely neighbourhood, French in architecture but with our latin charm. Good shopping area. Safer by day.

Beautiful area..a must visit.. We were there at the weekend and all the craft stalls were set up ..........so great ideas for prezzies.
You could spend forever walking around enjoying the architecture, coffee in lovely restaurants.
The museums,cemetery all within walking distance.

Friendly. La Recoleta is a very nice place to meet any kind of people; it's very friendly and colourful, but, you have to go on weekends when the artisans show their crafts, musicians play their instruments, acrobats show their talents...You can see many locals drinking some mate with friends. You may eat out on the terraces of the Buenos Aires Design. I recommend, if it doesn't rain, an informal 'n simple meal in "Camping": really cool, you feel as in a camping site, share your table with nice people, you may select your own music...while enjoying the view...
Best place in town!!. Best neigborhood of all buenos aires.... Nice people, best restaurants... A lot of parks and plazas, safe, and with lots of hotels atound the corner !!!
Nicest part of town. I had more fun in Palermo, but Recoleta looks like the ritziest area of the city. The Modern Art Museum is a must see if you're into art at all.

Take a Walk and Enjoy the Architecture. Great neighborhood to walk and explore the city. On the week end they have a great craft fair with lots of vendors and music as well.
Very enjoyable way to spend an afternoon.

Recoleta area. We stayed in the plaza Francia hotel in Recoleta. The Recoleta area is where you want to stay in Buenos Aires. First of all it's very safe, second - it's a walking distance to virtually everything, lots of hotels, restaurants, shops, banks, a main mall is there as well as many attractions: The cemetery, the Bella Artes museum, Evita memorial...Highly recommended.
Nice part of town. Not as upscale as Puerto Madero. Nice architecture of homes, nice to walk around. Some high end stores. Safe area

awesome for an afternoon. Perhaps the most famous cemetery in the world, it does not disappoint. You can spend almost a full day wandering and enjoying the beautiful sculptures, and art here. There are city cats inside so be warned. Some of the tombs are crumbling and some caskets exposed. If you can handle that, you are in for a treat here so relax in the peaceful park-like area.

Just beautiful!!!. Fantastic buildings, wide avenues, beautiful streets and lots of green. Expensive stores, but a nice place to go window shopping. There are lots of fair price eateries. A must see area in Buenos Aires.

Lots to do and see and most in walking distance. Unless you are my daughter who feels all too far. There was quite a bit to see and do exploring the different streets and neighborhoods was a great experience. I enjoy a immersion into the culture, and renting an apartment is the way to go. You mingle in with the locals and enjoy the culture. The person I reneted from was very understanding espicially when my flight from NY arrived at 4:30am. He had someone waiting for me at the apartment in the early AM and allowed me to stay late as my return flight did not depart until 11 pm

Cemetery is BA's #1 Tourist Attraction. Go figure- it must mean something that Recoleta Cemetery is BA's number one tourist attraction. You have to go there. We enjoyed poking around looking at the monuments but also watching all the people going there. Focused on Eva Duarte de Peron's mausoleum.

Wonderful and bizarre. I am a massive fan of Eva Peron and since my birthday and Peron Day are very close, finding her final resting place was pretty easy in this birthday trip. Eva aside, nothing in the world resembles this cemetery. It is like a small town with roads and streets and stories and history. An absolute must visit....esp if you like cats!
Attractive, upmarket barrio. We enjoyed walking around Recoleta, one of the classier barrios of BA. Handsome architecture, expensive shops and, of course, the famous cemetery, more than wort a visit.

Upper East Side NYC. Can close your eyes and open and for a moment you believe you might be strolling the upper east-side of NYC i.e.; Madison Avenue.
Great variety of shops and restaurants. Worth a several hours of easy walking.

Luxury and Class. Our hotel was situated in this neighborhood. It is named for the Recollect Fathers (Franciscan order) who had a monastery by the cemetery. It is a really nice area with many quality stores, restaurants, private mansions, foreign embassies and hotels. You feel very safe to walk at night. Unfortunately, we were not able to visit the cemetery, but there is a nice little church of historical value (Nuestra Senora Del Pilar) that is always open, that you can visit. We were never able to get a straight answer about the cemetery; one security guard said it was closed for renovation, one said it was only open early Saturday, alas we were not able to visit. In front of the cemetery is an enormous Rubber Tree known as "the Gran Gomero" it was planted in 1791 and it is well worth going to see and maybe taking your picture next to it! There are many parks in this neighborhood.
like Paris. really nice area, high style, with good bars and restaurants, nice atmosphere, just be careful with the prices and the taxi drivers

Evita in the Market Place. Recoleta has a cultural centre which hosts painting and photographic exhibitions amongst other things. It's worth a visit.. At the weekends the whole square in front of the cemetary and extending down the hill is lined with market stalls selling all sorts of handcrafts and souvenirs...a good place to buy presents to take home. The area has some great restaurants and coffee shops. Then there is the cemetery where "Evita" is buried. It can take some time to wander around it...watch out for the cats.
Glamour!. This is a fantastic neighborhood to just wander! Block after block of great architecture, fantastic shops, and great food! Worth spending time here!

Not just a Cementery. The Recolecta is most know for the Cementery, the is unique place, the visitor ( not matter you are not a gothic) will love. Is a piece of art, and an open Book of the History of Buenos Aires, But the neighborhood have a cultural center, a lot restaurants and store. You can dedicate all afternoon to fooling around

Just to relax. Is a very nice neighborhood to walk around. Have great shops to see, not very cheap, but worth going to.The cemetery is really big and interesting, lots of important people buried in there.
Best place to stay.. For me the best place to stay in Buenos Aires. Lot's of parks, restaurants and Nightlife. For sure would stay again and again there.

Impressive !. It's so impressive the old cemetery, with the tumbs of Eva Peron and many others importante figures of Argentina's history, like generals, politicians. It's walls do not has graffitis beacuse some advices warns peopple not do that.

A quaint little area. A very nice area of BA, a good place to buy some cheap currency also. There are lots of nice food and drink places within walking distance and also lots of markets here. This is a must see when visiting BA.

Definitely Worth It. We toured the district and Recoleta Cemetery with a guide (John with Buenos Aires Taxis) and it added so much insight to our trip. Tons of history and cultural insight. It's a beautiful area!

Staying in Recoletta. My wife and I recently stayed in Recoletta for a week. Our hotel, Ayres de Recoletta, was excellent and a half a block from Recoletta Cemetary. This area is a desirable neighborhood for its shops, restaurants and access to museums and parks. It's the best choice when you don't want to stay in the crowded and noisy downtown area. It was walking distance from everything for us.

barrio Recoleta. a very popular barrio (1970) in B.A. close to downtown,retiro bus station,and aeroparque, Pueyrredon ave is the main artery in one city block you will find: a restaurant or cafe, a pharmacy, a fashion boutique and a flowers stand. "el olmo" the best corner restaurant for pizza and beer. trust me!

Paris in Buenos Aires. This is a great neighborhood. It is clean, filled with attractions and restaurants, and a place to just wander and soak in the sights and sounds of the City. The church and the huge cemetery nearby are fascinating, and free.

We walked everywhere from la Ricoleta.. Many things to do or see are within 30 minutes walking distance of our hotel. Here, one can also get a taste of how locals live. Most memorable was a visit to the National Cemetery where Evita Peron is memorialized.

Interesting place. The cemetery is a fascinating place to wander around. You wonder as to how much money has been spent on some of the huge mausoleums. It is also a bit eerie peering through the doors at the inside of some of them.

Eerie. It's located in a nice area, close to many shops. It's a nice place to visit on a quiet morning/afternoon. There is a lady who sells maps of the cemetery at the entrance. It's not mandatory to buy them nor are they very easy to follow. We only used it to try and find Evita's burial (which does not stand out in anyway, which may make it hard to find). It was a bit eerie at times walking around when you think about a cemetery being a tourist attraction. Some of the mausoleums have stairs that lead down to who knows what :/ Some of them are very elaborate and hard to believe how much was put into them. You could definitely visit the cemetery on your own or you can pay for a tour guide to learn the history and about all the "important" people buried there.

A piece of times gone. Recoleta was, without debate, the classic neighbourhood of Argentinean ruling class in the late XIX century, beginning of XX century.Going around you will probably feel a Parisian atmosphere in some of its streets (Alvear Avenue) and cafes (La Biela).Nice place to visit. And inside it, in the cemetery of Recoleta, you can find the grave of someone who was, arguably, the most ferocious enemy of that ruling class: Eva Perón. An Argentinean paradox.

One of the best places to visit in Buenos Aires. Excellent place, good restaurants, hotels, nice to walk. Amazing: The traditional Empanadas Argentinas with onion and cheese at the Continental Restaurant.

I love the neighborhood!. This neighborhood reminds me of "Shitamachis" in Tokyo. The people are very warm, welcoming and kind. And the neighborhood is very safe, and well patrolled with police and security around every corner! I lived there for two months and this would be my choice of residential neighborhoods if I ever moved to BA.

recoleta. Nice safe place to stay. a bit far from the center (30 minutes walk) but very close to palermo garden.
Quite quiet place, less Noisy than the center, residential part of BsAs.

Great Neighborhood. It's more than just a cemetery. There are shops, restaurants and all manner of nightlife. I loved almost all of BsAs but I stayed in Recoleta mostly and it was great. You could do an entire vacation just in this neighborhood.

Amazing. This is a great find. I didn't plan on going and then a co-worker said not to miss it. You don't have to be there all that long, but it is a wonderful old cemetery including the grave of Eva Peron. Really interesting.
A nice part of BA: residential and it del fairly safe. The fact that the famous cemetery, containing Eva Peron's tomb and many other amazing monuments, was next door.

Wonderful area of Buenos Aries. This is the 2nd consecutive Fall that we've spent in Argentina, instead of Ohio. The weather ranges from the 60's to 80's, with nights in the 50's & 60's. A nice part of the city that has almost no crime, plenty of restaurants, confiterias(bakeries), clothing stores and many small family run businesses. Walking is the best method of transportation, but taxi's almost outnumber personal cars. So, if traveling to other parts of the city, then a taxi is a safe/reliable/modestly priced option. There are buses & the subway, which can be crowded. We've exchanged our dollars at the blue rate, which makes Argentina very reasonable for us. Recently, we went to a travel agency to get a quote in pesos on a flight. We asked and was told of a place that would exchange dollars at the blue rate. Even though we rent an apartment with a kitchen, our favorite activity is eating at the area establishments. There are many, small & large. We haven't found one we didn't like. Just walking around and feeling like a local, is a great way to vacation.

Central to everything. Great spot to stay, we booked into the Design Suite hotel, it's easy walking distance to a lot of attractions, taxis are cheap, we enjoyed our stay here, not too far away for the main streets and of course not as noisey.

Weird but interesting. This is a village of dead people, strange experience but interesting. We spent about 2hrs wondering around and it just seemed weird seeing coffins and such like in little buildings in what we're like streets
dark and interesting. do go on saturday as theres a craft market outside the cemetery, and go a bit later as eary in the morning most of the markets are not open yet

Impressive place. Impressive place, full of art and history. I think is one of the MUST SEE places of Buenos Aires. We wanted to go straight to Evita's mausolem but after an hour we realised we were still wandering around and not seeing Evita's grave yet. Very unique place.
A real must see !. This place is unbelievable ! It's historie , art , tradition and everything you want to know about the argentinian past

Cemetery is a must. As a whole, the neighborhood of Recoleta didn't live up to the hype, BUT the cemetery did. Went back several times. A quiet, strange oasis in the midst of a bustling city. Many grave sites (an understatement...these are elaborate mausoleums of the rich and famous) are active/being visited, while others are in complete disrepair. Unbelievable statuary. Cats wondering the premises. If you enjoyed visiting the cemeteries in New Orleans or Paris, you will love this. PS...very nice, tiny lunch/pastry place nearby -- Florencio. Look it up and go.

what a fantastic place. I was able to go twice inside. Once with a guide (part of the free walking tour of the area) for a short while. We only stop at Durante crypt where is Evita resting place and listed to the adventure her corpse when through. The 2nd time I asked the English speaking guide for recommendation of what to see for a short time I had available. She suggested to go to the far end of the cemetery for some fantastic monuments. What a discovery. Very few tourists, some great art and very famous people from Argentina history. I am sure the guide will be able to tell lots of stories about all these people. But just to admire beautiful monuments is was well worth it.
Take a wander. Definitely go for a wander around the streets of Recoleta. Such beauty and history. There is so much going on. Take your time and enjoy the green spaces to relax.

Interesting Stalls. We went on a day when the weather was a bit hit and miss - cloudy and a bit cold This meant that a lot of the stalls were not set up. Found the pricesto be reasonable and they will take USD dollars if you dont have ARG currency. Worth a visit
Stunningly beautiful. We didn't expect too much about this place, but it blew our minds. It's a sematary with beautiful, museum-like, statues and decorations.Visit this place, you won't regret it!
Perfect in the Spring. Recoleta is an awesome place to walk around and just soak in the sites! Check out Plaza Francia and the Cemetery

Beautiful Cemetery!. I was a bit nervous since I am not usually one to explore cemeteries, but WOW! There is so much detail and history around every corner. This isn't like any cemetery Ive visited before! We also walked around the park outside and got some espresso at a nearby cafe. We enjoyed this entire area and it made for a great days adventure!It was one of the highlights of our trip and I would highly suggest you visit if you are in Buenos Aires.
Recoleta. A very nice part of town with a number of very interesting attractions. The Argentina they want you to see.

Excellent Neighborhood to Walk & Explore. Recoleta is definitely one of my favorite places in Buenos Aires. I had originally planned on visiting Recoleta not really expecting to see much other than the Recoleta Cemetery. However, once I started walking there from blocks away I was impressed by the unique & extravagant architecture that every building had. It ranged from the older stone buildings to the more modern steel and glass skyscrapers.Walking around I found myself in a boutique bread shop which was a pleasant and unexpected treat. Then walked over to the Cemetery and found myself exploring it for over an hour and a half even though I went in thinking I would only see Evita's grave. I could have easily spent more time, but being a tourist with a long list of places to visit I thought I should continue to my next destination.The church next to the Cemetery is beautiful. The park, the trees, the museum and other attractions in Recoleta are really just perfect to spend a whole day just walking around and taking your time.

Nice neighborhood to wander. Walked to Recoleta from the Florida street shops. It's a nice neighborhood, the architecture of the buildings is really nice. It's more upscale, so you see the European elegance to the buildings. The park in Recoleta is nice and there are artisans selling their goods, which was cool to see. The famous cemetery is in this neighborhood. It's a bit odd for a cemetery to be an attraction, but honestly, it was eerily beautiful.

A very chic area!. I liked the neighborhood. Our hotel was right behind the Recoleta Cemetery (where Evita is buried), so lots of activity there. There is a mall and lots of restaurants and coffee shops nearby as well. The shopping is also good. I liked the Alvear hotel in which I would have most enjoy afternoon tea if we had a couple of more days in BA.
Interesting. The cemetery is an interesting place to visit. Almost like a small city. It would be better to visit with a guide. I went there by myself, so missed the history and lots of stories.
Charming neighborhood. Nice and charming neighborhood with some good restaurants and cafes, including La Biela.Good for morning weekends relax...

Recoleta - A Must Visit!. Recoleta is where I live at the moment, and, apart from being an attractive and safe neighborhood, it is an area of great historical and architectural interest.Home to the famous Recoleta Cemetery it also has fine art museums, a cathedral, a cultural center, parks, good restaurants and cafes, malls, and other attractions like an outdoor sculpture walk, running tracks, the national library etc. Very centrally located in the city of Buenos Aires, it is easily accessible by public transport or taxi.Most of the attractions are free.
Nice street market. Nice shopping area with a very nice street/flee market on weekends and great restaurants and bars.Evita crypt and other impressive cemetery structures are just a gate away.
Finding Eva Peron's mauseleum. The area is beautiful with the monastery but be prepared for a weird experience when visiting the graveyard. We followed the crowds to find Eva Peron's grave!

Nice area to wander through. We went to this area to see Eva Peron's gravesite, but found a nice neighborhood full of good restaurants and shops. The Recoleta Cemetery is very nice to stroll through. We did not exactly know where Eva's tomb was so we strolled through the graveyard. There are very nice examples of Art Nouveau and Art Deco sculpture as well as classical types of gravestones. In the spring, be sure to take DEET, the mosquitos are biting!
See the cemetary. The Recoleta cemetary is fascinating. It has the most extravagent, over the top crypts which are basically free standing buildings. The designs are incredible.

Lovely area. Loved all of the stores, the people were so friendly and when we visited the cemetery, it was in much better shape than my last visit. People still come to Eva Peron's burial place, touch her face and lay flowers down to her memory.
Good place to watch the high flyers of BA. The area is surrounded by expensive shops and hotels and you can just stand and watch the locals and tourists pass by.
A tourist area. A nice area has a Hard Rock Cafe there and a market I enjoyed shopping at. I also bought some art at a gallery there in the area.

A "HAS BEEN" DISTRICT. La Recoleta has lost 90% of its charm and quality. Although one of the best hotels in Buenos Aires, The Alvear, is located there, there has been a deep drop in the class and quality of its restautrants and bars. A real shame.
Must visit when in BA.. Very nice and upscale neighborhood. Very nice shopping indoor mall. The big attraction for me was definitely the cemetery where Evita Peron is at.
Must visit. Iconic site - pick up a Map at the gate to ensure you find your way to Eva Peron's tomb. Toilet facilities are available.
Lovely area. The Cemetaria, Florida Street, walking up 9 the Avenue, the Obelisk and Portena Tango Show, San Martin Square
Recoleta Cemetery. I have never seen anything like this. Very impressive. Very photogenic. Visited Eva Peron's and now know that Duarte is her maiden name.
Don't miss the cemetery.. Recoleta is a great area to walk around and take in the city's activities. The cemetery is a must and it helps if you've got a guide to show you around.
Great old neighborhood. Great historic neighborhood with the famous cemetery. Go to see famous gravestones including that of Evita!

Sundays are a must. I love coming to Recoleta on Sundays. There is always so much going on. Street musician’s, art vendors, cafes to sit and talk. It's a great place to relax and have a cup of coffee in one of the many cafes while listening to the local musicians.

Central, enriching, and safe. Do not miss the cemetery and hire a guide to tell you more, so to understand Argentina like a book you would begin through its last chapters, but do miss most of the tourist restaurants in front of it. Walk 15 min further to the Malba museum or to the Teatro Colon. Hotels and restaurants are great in Recoleta but it also is an every day charming area where you soon feel home. We stayed a the Poetry Building hotel for one week and loved it. Enjoy.

Stay in this neighborhood if you can. We stayed in a condo in Recoleta and were delighted with this location. Safe at all hours, convenient to great restaurants, bakeries, sight seeing, etc. It is definitely a pricey neighborhood, but well worth it for the location.

On Saturdays you can combine it with a market!. We went to Ricoleta around noon on a Saturday and spent a few hours walking around the neighbourhood and the cemetery. Recoleta is very beautiful and even though Saturday means it crowded it is worth it as you also get to visit the market outside the cemetery. A bit overpriced perhaps but still one of the best markets I visited in BA.

Viva Recoleta. Recoleta is a beautiful old neighborhood, very upscale, with lively cafes and chic boutiques. Both times I visited .BA I rented an apartment here, which is easy to do and far more economical than staying in a hotel.

quiet walk through history. We visited La Recoleta on the same day we arrived in BA. It's a great visit to walk off the kinks of a long flight. There are a couple of little cats that great you as you walk in, along with potential walking tour guides that will politely either offer a tour or point out some must-sees on a map and let you wander on your own. If they determine you are from the US or most non-European, non-South American countries, they'll mostly aim you to Evita Peron's crypt, but it's nothing to take personal, it's probably who you wanted to see, anyway.We visited in the afternoon and the waning light over the mausoleums made for great photographs, and it was great atmosphere to alternately ponder the beautiful memorials of beloved family and gasp in recognition at great names from Latin American history.Make a mental note of some unique landmarks as you enter, every white marble angel looks the same after a few hours and it can take a minute to find your way back if you're not in an area with a famous person featured on the map.Unlike history-laden cemeteries in the US, there will not be paper and utensils to take a rubbing of a meaningful epitaph, and folks will give odd looks if you ask for it. Just take pictures instead.

Paris of South America. Bring a camera and comfortable shoes...this is one of the most beautiful cities in the world. Stop into LaBiela for an outdoor dining experience viewing the Plaza Francais. The Doors here are astounding! The Palace Hotel and the shops surrounding it are with the journey.
Nice neighborhood. Recoleta is a nice neighborhood, you have a lot of interesting and touristic places like "The recoleta's cemetery" and the architecture of the buildings over here is just amazing.

good creepy. so much family, so much history..... amazing to see family mausoleums and wonder about the past, about the people and about the way we celebrate the ritual of death. definitely a place to visit. lovely statuary, beautiful memorials to the long- gone. missed the free guided tour, and had to wander through in a hurry. was surprised to see EVita buried in the family tomb without much hoo-ha except that everyone goes there and puts flowers.
wow. haven't been to a cemetery like this before. a very interesting way of celebrating the dead. I wish more cemeteries can be made like this.
Find Eva Peron. It is worth visiting the Recoleta cemetary, where most famous Argentinians have their resting place, very impressive and it was fun to try to find Evita's monument.

Mysterious Place!. I am not a psycho or anything, I just cemetaries in general and this has been my favorite so far! I am sure you all will like it if you don't like this sort of places. It's filled with marvelous statues in different styles.
great neighborhood. I love Recoleta with full of history, attractions. Don't miss the cemetery with impressive mausoleums.

Don't miss the cemetery. Love to walk that zone, very nice with large parking near the cemetery, try to visit this one (in the day), its very morbid, but a place to visit.
In the near by zone you have malls, a lot of restaurants and cafes.
Fascinating cemetery. Beautiful cemetery, showcasing long lost wealth of Buenos Aires. Add to it the grave of Evita with truly moved Argentinians praying next to it - a must see!
Great Neighborhood. They call BA the Paris of South America and this neighborhood is why. Walk around the cemetery and have a Farnet Branca and coke at a cafe nearby like the locals.
nice neiborhood in B A. is the nicest neiborhood in B A and very traditional , visit the cementery and the church , lots of resturants boutiques and top hotels in the area .

Favorite district in Buenos Aires. It is a clean, well-kept district full of history and attractions, particularly the Recoleta Cemetery, which is an extensive mausoleum. There are also open market opens on the weekend with an array of merchandise, food, and local musicians.
I also felt very safe there.

Local vibes and Lifestyle. The hood to stay! If you want to feel like a true porteño of a middle to high class... this is your place! Its close to Palermo (the hipster side of Buenos Aires) it has a lot of cool hotels, restaurants, spa, museums... etcClose to Barrio Parque, where people lives with class and old school style (very european architecture and huge mansions to admire). Also close to Plaza Francia, a very popular park during the weekends. And you will be able to reach any other neighbourhood from it.

Wonderful neighbourhood. We chose to stay at a hotel in Recoleta and were not disappointed. The neighbourhood is quiet, safe and full of cafes, restaurants, shopping and sites of cultural importance. A must see part of the city...especially the cemetery which is not only a treasure trove of architecturally stunning mausoleums but an important repository of Argentine history through the centuries.

BUENOS AIRES RECOLETA THE BEST. Recoleta, you can start at the Cementery to understand part of the history of Buenos Aires, then you can visit Iglesia del Pilar, right on the side of the Cementery, then relax for half an hour at the Bar right where is one of the Oldest Trees of Buenos Aires, seat outside and enjoy a nice expresso...then you can walk again to the park and visit museums, art galleries, then you can walk Avenida Alvear and enjoy this wonderful Avenue, and you can visit Hotel Alvear, Hotel Palacio Duhau Hyatt, Jokey Club the Elite Club of Buenos Aires high society, French Embassy, Brasilian Embassy, Vaticano Embassy, wonderful buildings...then visit the most exclusive Mall right on Posadas Street Patio Bullrich , walk Avenida Callao, Avenue Quintana and have a wonderful Ice Cream in the corner of Avenue Quintana and Ayacucho Street at Volta one of the best Ice Cream parlors of the world....Recoleta is wonderful....dont't miss it.

Recoleta. The best place to stay in Buenos Aires is Recoleta. There are a lot of restaurants and malls. The food is fantastic, the cemetery is nearby and there are a lot of parks and it is very safe. I loved it!
Lovely area. This area is a convenient base to many attractions in Buenos Aires. The area is safe with good restaurants close by .

Pretty and well worth a visit. Probably my favourite area of Buenos Aires, Recoleta is a beautiful place to spend an afternoon walking around. Very cheap to get to in a taxi from the city centre. The cemetery is beautiful and has an interesting history. Although we missed the English speaking tour, we managed to find a lady who gave us a short private tour for a very reasonable price.

No the best part of the city. Revolted use to be the chicest part of the city, unfortunately not anymore. Use to be the safety place, the rich & famous area but this days remain a little bit empty. Only the great Alvear palace hotel remains, everything else like Cartier boutique or Louis Vuitton boutique close and remain only the memories of the Paris essence of this area. Still nice to visit but nothing to do around.

More than a suburb. Recoleta is not only a tourist destination due to its amazing cemetario, but also it's weekend markets, music, shops and general village atmosphere. When we were last there a new train station was in the process of being installed. I felt safer in Recoleta at night than I do in most areas of Sydney. Go!
Nice neighborhood. Beautiful area where you mix with the local culture. Beautiful squres, restaurants, local store, walkable a very secure.
Heart of the city. Nice area for shopping and walking . many stores,cafe's and restaurants. In weekends it is full with activities and has an open local market where you find a lot of local stuff.

Walking Dead. Churchyards is an interesting socio-history-economic parameter to judge the past and present of a city and its population. In this case Recoleta is interesting place and the architecture of the tombs and mausoleums. Most interesting, in my opinion , is the the people who visits and could be divided in tourists, guides and non-tourists.Fascinating is also the stray-cats where some are so old and beaten that you can question if they are alive... On Sundays there is a market place for art and on the side is a cultural center that can function as an perfect extension of the Walk.

One of BA's better areas. A quality are but would agree with EOL George below, some areas are more fun and funky for the younger ones, others have a quietness about them. Recoleta has a lot of quality shops and restaurants - whilst many go to see the cemetery, couldn't persuade my wife that this has any interest.

Unique!. My parents recommended I go and see the Recoleta cemetary, since it made a big impression on them when they visited a few years back. I am glad they did because if not I would not have come here. It is a strange place, like a city in the city with beautiful architecture and I have never seen anything like it. The surrounding area of Recoleta is really nice to spend some time also.
A great neighborhood. Fabulous restaurants, craft fair on the weekends, clean streets, nice parks - a great neighborhood to stay in.
Not easy to find Evita. Great graves! Be careful because this looks like a good spot for pick pockets. Lots of secluded area.

Great place to stay. In what can be a pretty sketchy city to stay Recoleta is one of the best barrios for folks 40+. Plenty of great restaurants, the BA Cultural Center, a good mall, a great park and the Recoleta Cemetery all in walking distance. And most importantly it's safer than much of the rest of the city.I'd suggest Palermo for the younger party crowd but in reality cabs are SO ridiculously inexpensive here (traveled all around the city and never spent more than $6 US) Recoleta is a good alternative if you want some quiet time.
Tango on the street. It is so different, and worth visiting if only for the amazing colourful pictures to look at later on...it is beautiful. Full of people and local artisans and tango dancers!

Church and Mausoleum. We walked to the area from our Hotel and we enjoyed the day in the area. It was Sunday, so the Church was open with a beautiful Mass in progress, with the Cloisters being open to visitors, the Sunday markets and the Mausoleum of Evita Peron. We found everything to be convenient and we enjoyed our day immensely.

Charming, Classic and Safe. At times we felt like we were in Italy, or France as we walked comfortably around this classic upscale Buenos Aires neighborhood.While we did not find the shopping particularly great we enjoyed the cafes, store windows and general ambiance charming and more than memorable. Our hotel was situation in this area, The Park Hyatt.

Impressive!. The Recoleta cemetery was just in front of our hotel (L'Etoile) and this was the very first site we visited in Buenos Aires. We were really impressed by the architecture and the general impression of peaceful 'grandeur' of this site. We certainly recomend this visit.
We stayed in Recoleta. We decided to stay in Recoleta at an AirBNB apartment. Beautiful part of the city. Feels like the upper east side of NYC. Loved the Recoleta Cemetery

Interesting. . If you are interested in history, then Recoleta cemetery is a great place to learn about famous personages who lived and died in Argentina. If you are just a casual observer, then the cemetery is simply just a unique experience regardless of anything else. It was fun to see mausoleum after mausoleum reading the name and stumbling accords Eva Duarte Peron's site. Personally, I got tired after about an hour but I do recommend because it is a once in lifetime type of site to see.

Interesting. Not just about Eva Peron, the place is beautiful and cared for and ha some amazing monuments. It did feel a bit creepy at first but after a while it was nice to sit on a bench or stroll around and take a look at the other parts apart from the Eva memorial

Little Paris. I have lived in Recoleta for 1.8 years now and I just feel like in Europe. Lovely architecture, plenty of places where to eat out and of course, it is quite safe. Av Santa Fe can get very busy so I recommend to avoid it during the rush hours :)
Safe. Nice safe area to stay in. Buildings are fantastic. Very central. Beautiful market on weekends. The cemetary is a must see. Would recommend a tour guide as they explain everything.
love it. One of the most amazing neighborhoods in the city. Always a delight to just wander about in and soak up the atmosphere.

Awesome to have a walk. Recoleta is one of the most charming neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. Recoleta Cemitery, Buenos Aires Design Mall - where the Hard Rock Buenos Aires is in - and lots of restaurants around.

very happy with this area. I stayed in this area and I was very happy with it. There are a lot of restaurants to choose from. A lovely park area. Taxis easy and they are very cheap in Buenos Aires. On the weekends there are markets in the park. I felt very safe here as in all of Buenos Aires.

Visit to the cemetery. Part of a city tour, visited the usual test tourists do e.g. Eva Peron, bit over done but was more interested to see others e.g. Fr Antonio Fahy, an Irish priest who supported local Irish immigrants abc William Brown a sea captain who assisted in Argentina's independence against the Spanish. Well worth visiting.
Nice neighborhood, interesting cemetary. While in Buenos Aries, you must see the lovely cemetery with hundreds of mausoleums in all shapes and sizes dating back 2 hundred years.

Surprising.... Nice place where to spend weekend. Interesting art to be seen. I always refused to go to the cemetery as I thought it was "morbid" and I "didn't want to walk on people's graves" HOWEVER I was SO WRONG as the cemetery is like a "CITY IN THE CITY" - FACINATING. There is so much art to see and take pictures of that I ended up with almost 400 photos :-) Of course there are restaurants and shops and all that if you are interested, however I had more enjoyable time talking to artist who were selling their art as well as taking photos of "metal statues" just beyond Plaza Francia.

Good neighborhood for wandering. I enjoyed walking around this neighborhood and finding small shops and restaurants away from the main tourist area near the cemetary. The fresh fruit and veggies in the shops were very nicely displayed, and a tasty addition to our "picnic" lunches, along with the Parma-Styled ham from a nearby deli.
Excellent neighborhood. Maybe the best "barrio" of the city. All you want to do you can find there. Restaurants, hotels, bars, shopping, art gallerys, luxury shops and jewerys.

Recolet Rocks. Beautiful upscale neighborhood with lots of shops, restaurants, cafe's and beautiful architecture. So make sure you look up while walking to take in the beauty of the buildings. And if you are there on the weekend, make sure to walk to Plaza Francia where there is an outdoor fair of vendors selling beautiful artisanal and regional items.

Fascinating!. We thought this would be similar to the cemeteries in New Orleans - but it was much more interesting. Clean, safe. Walk around in a unique place that attracts people from around the world. There's much more to see besides Evita's final resting place. But if you want to see it - stop at the front and pinpoint it on the map. It's to the back on the left.

walk about. The area is lovely, lots of green. Safe to walk about. Close to Embassies. Lot's of small cafe, park . Just a very lovely neighbourhood. Easy access from the waterfront with taxi's and buses around. Hop on the open roof tour bus to have a better view

Graveyard, market and museums. Visit on a Sunday when the craft market is just downhill from the graveyard. Eva Peron's grave is something to seek as is the devotion she still attracts. Have a wander around the rest of the cemetery, say hello to the grizzly looking cats and guess at what horrors lie downstairs in those crypts.

Paris in South America!!. While walking through its streets, you feel like being in Paris, right here in South America!! The buildings, cafes, trees....Go there and check for yourself! You will be amazed too!!
A different feeling. Really beautiful place and nice to be slightly out of main Buenos Aires. Cemetery has some amazing graves but was a little eery.
Classy area to stay in. We enjoyed our hotel in the Recoleta area and found the cemetery to be most interesting and requiring a good amount of time to fully appreciate all the tombs and gravestones.

Clasical neighborhood in Buenos Aires.... Great place,,where people lives, a place to, walk...good hotels like the Alvear Palace...the traditional LA BIELA cafe, don't miss sitting outside under the big Ombu tree and have beer with picadita argentina, or coffe...or...stop to buy some clothes...and visit the "Cementerio de Recoleta..There is an expensive area but chick...this is one the the most expensive places to live in BS.AS....
Parks and Cemetery. Gorgeous apartments and restaurants abound - the famous graveyard holds Evita's remains and is still a place of pilgrimage.

Lovely architecture, but market was disappointing. The Sunday market was a bit sad; maybe because the weather was bad. I had hoped to find a fun, bustling atmosphere, but many of those displaying their wares looked bored, and the wares themselves weren't exceptional. Walking around Recoleta was lovely though, very nice archictecture on some streets. Not much to do, though - can't get into most buildings.

Trip to Buenos Aires. Really loved the Recoleta cemetery Magnificent architecture ,gives one a real sense of the wealth that was in this wonderful city at the start of the twentieth century. Also went to Madero Tango and loved it
great. you cannot miss the recoleta neighborhood in buenos aires. we studied at the ibero spanish school and stayed at an apartment in recoleta buenos aires everything was great
Nice place to stay. Near Santa Fé, close to the subte (underground), with lots of shops and cafés. Don´t forget to visit the book shop El ateneo.
Lovely neighborhood. Looks really European. It has great stores and restaurants. I really enjoyed staying there, it's charming.

Lovely neighborhood. Recoleta is an upscale neighborhood. You can visit the interesting Recoleta cemetery (English tours on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 11AM for free) to see Evita's family crypt as well as the crypts of political, historical and military figures. Walking toward the Museo Bellas Artes, you will find nice parks and a huge flea market on Sunday.

Incredible Recoleta!. This cemetery is amazing! We accepted the offer of a 'private tour' from an ex-pat English 'local'- his wealth of knowledge on the cemetery really enhanced our visit (& yes we checked his info out, & it was all correct). This is a Buenos Aires 'must see'.

You could spend hours in the cemetery. This is one of the most interesting areas of BA, and of course the cemetery should be high on your list of places to visit, you could spend hours in this fascinating place.

Would you believe it's a cemetery?. That's right, it is. But very special with wonderful monuments. One of the most visited is the burial place of Eva Peron. Use a tour guide. The little church just to the right of the cemetery is a beautiful little place to visit. Don't miss it.
A classic weekend tour. Either to visit the classic handcraft fair, or sit for a while one sunny dat at any street coffee of the bneighbourhood, it is a point in Buenos Aires you cannot miss.

Nice. Very nice neighborhood, it reminded me of Europe.
I remember i enter to the a wonderful hotel y drank a really nice coffe.
5 tars for remembers.
My favourite spot in BsAs. Beautiful and cozy area, I suggest you spend half a day there going to the cementery and havinng a coffee in one of the outdoor cafés

Didn't think a cemetary could be so interesting. This is definitely the most interesting cemetary I've seen in the world. It's more like a sculpture park than a cemetary. Tip: you can get great views from above from the mcdonalds in the mall near recoleta.

Thumbs up for Recoleta Neighborhood. The neighborhood Recoleta is really nice. Just to explore random streets, it won´t be long until you will spot nice restaurants, cafes and shops. Close to the cemetery is a small shopping mall, the mall is not that special but it houses a number of restaurants and nice places to chill or to grab a quick bite, enjoy a high tea. I used the mall it to hide for the rain, there is also a movie theater.

boring. read my lonely planet book it saying the icon of recoleta big flower it will open in the morning close at evening. visit recoleta is in my south america bucket list. unfortunately, really disappointed! because that big flower doesn't work any more.

My Vote For Best Neighborhood To Stay In BA. This is simply a beautiful neighborhood. Very European feel with tree lined streets and a comfortable, safe feeling. A wonderful place to mix with locals as there are supermarkets and small stores. There are a great many restaurants within walking distance of the numerous hotels. There is good public transportation and taxis are abundant and inexpensive.

Nice neighborhood, lots of places to eat. Good place to stay. Recoleta is one of the better and safer neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. There's an assortment of shopping, lots of restaurants, and some of the city's more interesting attractions are nearby, like the Recoleta cemetery. Definitely worth considering this as a base of exploration for Buenos Aires

Very specific place.. I`m not sure it`s a good idea to walk around the cemetery. But not in Buenos Aires. Here you don`t think about your very short being. Here you just have a rest, a pause in the excellent Baires looking at this architectural collection of post mortem vanity by noble families of BA.

Must See Neighborhood!. The Recoleta Neigborhood in Buenos Aires is a 'Must See' on anyone's itinerary. The Cemetery is vast with so many majestic tombstones is was hard to adsorb it all ... the Church next to the cemetery is beautiful ... and the park across the way has trees which look like they have to be the homes of gnomes & waifs. Excellent restaurants & parillas ... pubs & bars ... you can sit and people watch to your hearts content or just enjoy the beautiful surroundings. Plan on at least half a day to really explore ... you won't be disappointed.

Incredible to see. It was truly a fascination place to see the monuments constructed for the dead. Eva Peron is probably the most visited but definitely not the grandest. Some are very sad as they depict lives and some sad memories such as a mother and child who dies from an epidemic. Watch your stop though. Cat poo everywhere!

A good place to visit and eat. Recoleta is an a neighborhood located in Buenos Aires where modern art with modern taste live. They have great restaurants with Churrascos to die for. The chimichurri in this neighborhood is great. There are little strips of streets with fine bodegas to buy souvenirs.

Very pleasant neighborhood!. It really worth spending some time there, just walking around. The streets are delightful. There are many coffee shops, bookstores around. It is also nice to visit the cemitery.

Chic Buenos Aires. Though known for its Cemetery, Recoleta is a neighborhood that has so much more to it. The area is one of the safest, cleanest and nicest in Buenos Aires. Great shops and restaurants as well as lodging. Patio Bullrich is a small shopping mall housed in a lovely historic building. Hotel Alvear serves brunch and high tea in a superb building. Palacio Duhau houses a luxury hotel as well as a superb restaurant. And so on. The architecture shows a marked French influence to it. Do not miss. Recoleta is chic Buenos Aires.

Great neighborhood! Nice walk, safe and quiet area. Recoleta is one of the neighborhood that we most liked it. We had a great walk from the city centre to this area. Very safe, clean, quiet and with lots of restaurants to enjoy. And a historic and important cemetery.

The nicest area. We stayed in the Recoleta area of BA and we really enjoy walking around the neighborhood. The shops were interesting and the restaurants were good. We also enjoyed the market on Sunday and the Cemetery. I would highly recommend this area to stay in for your home base.

Humbling and Interesting. It's interesting to think of a cemetery as a tourist spot. It's sacred. It's personal. It's beautiful. The tombs were so fascinating and to catch a glimpse into the lives of so many different families really makes you think. Who were they, what were their lives like, who did they love, etc. I loved it.

Not your "same old" cemetery..... Over 15 acres of unique architectural edifices housing remains of famous and infamous Argentiinians. Yes, Evita is there but not on the map...fun to locate the Duarte mausoleum .

Recoleta. Junín y Guido. In one of the reviews, Junín y Guido is situated in Almagro. NEVER IN THE LIFE! Almagro is a less than middle class neighbourhood, Junín y Guido belongs to the RECOLETA district.

A must-see area of Buenos Aires. Recoleta cemetery is like a miniature stone city (no grass) of mausoleums. The artisan fair with friendly vendors and music on the grass was exceptional. On-off tourist bus has a stop nearby without need to go downtown to start at the beginning.
Do not miss. This place would be great on a dark, dreary Halloween night but sunshine works almost as well. Not to be missed.

My favorite neighborhood in Buenos Aires. I loved walking around Recoleta and stopping at the little cafes that could be found on every block. Everyone I came across in the stores, restaurants, and museums were very friendly and helpful. I felt very safe walking around alone in this neighborhood at all hours and there is a lot to do on it's border with Palermo.

Recoleta - the most chic quartier in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is by far the most chic quartier in Buenos Aires.
The main spot is Alvear Ave, walk it all the way to the French Embassy. It feels like in Paris.
Touristy but interesting. Plenty of tourists but interesting neughborhood and cemetery. Quite informative on the way wealthy Argentine view themselves in the world.

This is a must tour while in BA. The Recoleta neighborhood offers wonderful sights and activities. Walking the tree lined streets, visiting the cemetary, catching mass, and visiting the various market stalls and shops could not have been more enjoyable and I am not a shopper.

Fascinating. From the Evita Peron Mausoleum, to the exquisite building of the French Embassy, Recoleta shows the grandiose Buenos Aires past. Very close to downtown, it's fancy (and expensive) restaurants are diverse in stiles and tastes. It's original arquitecture can still be seen in many buildings, some dating close to a century. During the weekends, the artists present their production at the plaza close to the cemetery. Surprising stuff could be found.
Beatiful Cemetary. Lots of history in this cemetery. Very clean and well kept and easy to stroll around and see the various mausoleums and all the history of Buenos Aires.
It's Okay!. The cemetery has some old tombs there, I am not sure one needs to spend more than an hour or two there.

you think you are in an european city. old buildings disposed back to back, old blocks, traditional arquitecture, everything links to and older era when buenos aires was the european city of latin america. this section of the city mantains its charms and offers a very nice scenario for a strolling afternoon.

Architectural splendor and glamour. A trip to Bs As is incomplete without a leisurely stroll through La Recoleta. Start at the church, walk through it and the cemetery (Evita is buried there). The little monasterio museum is totally worth it, so do that. Then go back out to the main street and treat yourself to a coffee, or whiskey, and little sandwich at La Biela restaurant. Thus fortified you should proceed to walk the main street and any little side streets that catch your eye. Classic architecture fans and lovers of beauty will delight in the details of doors, windows, cornices, hardware, balconies...or maybe that's just me showing my inner wanna be architect. Shoppers will find plenty to buy, mostly on the higher end, but worth it because it is very high quality, especially leather goods.
Must visit. Loved this place, highly recommend a visit. Especially if you've never been to anything like this before. It was beautiful, allow plenty of time to see it all properly without rushing.

If Paris is missing an Arrondissement it is Recoleta.. It is an elegant part of town (the most) with the top hotels, restaurants and flagship stores in Buenos Aires. Calle Las Posadas has it all. The Recoleta Cementery is at the end of the street and worth a visit on a weekend afternoon.
must see neighborhood. Enjoyed a nice stroll through the streets of La Recoleta visiting galeries all the way to the cemetery. Nice neighborhood.

Amazing Cemetery. Recoleta Cemetery is a must see during a stay in Buenos Aires. The cemetery dates from the mid-1800s and contains thousands of mausoleums. The interesting aspect of Recoleta is the statuary throughout. Some of the most beautiful sculptures in Buenos Aires can be found here. Make sure that you purchase a map at the entrance for 15 pesos ($2.00 US) since the cemetery is quite large and can be confusing without some plan. For fans of Evita Peron, her tomb is located here and is one of the major stops on the walk through the cemetery. Plan two to three hours to explore Recoleta at a leisurely pace. There are mosquitos galore here--bring some bug repellent if this can be a problem. There is a café located nearby for lunch (La Biela--see separate review) that is perfect. If you missed Recoleta, you missed one of the best sightseeing venues in Buenos Aires!

Real SoHo Area. After visiting many of the major neighborhoods this was one of the last visited. What a nice surprise to find a somewhat clean, upscale area with high end stores, and less crowds in general compared to other parts of BA. This is much nicer than all the other areas visited. There is a upscale mall next to Ricoleta Cemetery. McDonalds has a fantastic view from the third floor balcony facing the cemetery, if you want a peek before entering.

Interesting.... The mausoleum in Recoleta is an unusual and incredible place. Dating back to the '18' hundreds, it is home to quite a number of well known people. A 'beautiful' place, it is worth a visit.

Best neighbourhood to take a walk. Although Recoleta has the most expensive hotels, i think it's here you can live like a local. There's a lot of things to do and visit in short walks, parks, stores, museums, pubs.... And it' s not so dirty as downtown, which has many things to do also, but is decadent.

Nice Area to walk around. Ava's tomb is not easy to find. They say free tour when you arrive BUT it's not. If you take the tour mostly they tell you about a few famous people and the architecture of the tombs. If you ask a worker they will direct you. You will have an easier time in Buenos Aires if you speak Spanish. There are some very nice shops and a mall in the area. Good for half day. Took this in when we got off the Hop on Hop off bus.
Eva. Interesting but not fantastic. Eva tomb is the only REAL interesting burial site. not worth LOT OF TIME.

Wonderful and safe. This area of BA is beautiful, quaint and safe. We loved staying in Recoleta as it was close to the things we wanted to stay and had the feeling of a village inside the big city. Highly recommended place to stay if you are visiting BA and want to be out of the glitz of Puerto Madero or the hustle of Palermo.

Class Personified. Recoleta is classy. In a city where even high rent areas have graffiti on the wall, Recoleta has less. It exudes wealth and "if you have to ask" attitude. Everyone is so above it all that no one is above anything. Which translates into a kind of snooty anonymity. It has tourists, but they're not as visible and everywhere as in Palermo. It's the kind of place to be if quiet opulence and understated elegance make you feel "happy". If walking down quiet, treed streets, past architecturally beautiful penthouse buildings, gazing into storefront windows at clothes that only make it to the runway in the company of the serenely uber-rich is your thing - Recoleta is your place. But beware - it'll cost you! Plenty.

beautiful ...... like being in Europe with a Latin twist. this communa of Buenos Aires is absolutely beautiful. Take your time, walk and walk and walk! you will see stunning architecture and beautiful green areas. Pretty streets and of course the famous Recoleta Cemetary where you can pay your respects to Evita!

Very pretty neighborhood. Recoleta is a great neighborhood to wander. Must see if the Recoleta Cemetery, its beautiful and eerie. The theater Colon is also in this area. Nice place to stay, lots of hotels, restaurants and activity but I think Palermo Soho is best.

Recoleta. Recoleta is one of the most attractive areas of BA. We rented there the same apartment for four consecutive years. You can never tire of walking around this area. The museums and art centres [ e.g. that of fine art , palais de glace, the Recoleta art centre ] are delightful. The Recoleta cemetery is unique. Many famous Argentinian politicians, artists, writers and industrialists are buried there.  Cafes like Biela, Monet, Babieka, Josephina, the Tea connection, Tabak and many others are the places to sit to enjoy your "café con leche con medialunas" , lunch or dinner among the locals and watch the world goes by. An afternoon tea at the Alvear Palace hotel is expensive but unforgettable! The Recoleta Mall and Patio Bullrich are sufficiently sophisticated for the serious shopper but are of course expensive. You may want to try Avenida Santa Fe where the prices are not as expensive. There are Many excellent book stores including El Ateneo and Cuspide and many, many more.The Recoleta design centre is a very interesting place. The Saturday and Sunday market in the park in front of the Recoleta art centre is something to be seen. And last but not least the Street Tango show in the park right beside Café Biela, is very enjoyable. We took so many videos of the couple who dance there and they are very good !!It is a pleasure to walk the streets of Recoleta from the very sophisticated, Avenida Alvear, Pte. Quintana, Callao, to the typical of the neighbourhood like Posadas, Montevideo, Rodrigues Pena, Pueyrredon and many others.Recoleta is the place to stay, walk and enjoy while in BA.
Great relaxed feel. Situated in a smart residential area, with park, church and cemetery nearby there are many lovely cafes here to people watch.

Interesting Area. We drove by an interesting steel flower and past the very elaborate embassies. These were originally built as private homes by the land barons using French architects. However, the high point of this area was our visit to the Ricoleta Cemetery. It is very unusual with the mausoleums lined up almost like row houses. The designs were eclectic, from Greek temples to modern buildings. Some even had stained glass and gold leaf decorations. The most famous, for us, person buried here is Eva Peron.
Attractive area. This is a very attractive area with plazas and restaurants a coffee shops. Real big trees adorn the plaza. The Recoleta Cementery is were the tomb of Eva Peron is located.

Good shopping. Upscale neighborhood with quality goods. Ritzy, people here can be snobby, and rude. The money here is what brings thievery so be careful. The park here is very nice, smaller sections than Los Bosques de Palermo but nice. For example, Plaza Francia is a very busy plaza with so much going on like the fair, people, shows, the graveyard where Evita, and Carlos Gardel are buried. Closer to the port than Avenue Santa Fe. I used to live next to the park for some time, and I really enjoyed it. I made some very good friends there.

Must for weekend market . Affluent area full of shops. Try and go when the weekend market is on as it great to rummage through the products. All the traders speak English. Good selection of trinkets and food. Easy to join the visit with the cemetery and the tomb of Eva Peron.

Fantastic walking, sightseeing, shopping. Safe, classy part of town, ideal for walking. Lots of French architecture - many buildings would fit right into Paris. Street shopping as well as the Bullrich Patio mall. Ave Alvear. Lunch at Cafe La Biela. Cemetery. Pilar church.

Great Place. We always go to the cemetery on the weekends for the "Hippie Market". There are fantastic deals. We also enjoy the Cafes by the church. I must say our favorite is the Volta Ice Cream parlor down the street. You cannot go wrong with anything you try there.

Recoleta Cemetery. The cemetery is interesting, but we aspected a little more, we saw more interesting cemeteries (also in Milano, the "Monumentale"). The tomb of Evita Peron is not signalled and everybody is looking for it, but it has no special interest. Most of the tombs are in a degraded state.
Good BA area. We liked the Alvear Palace hotel and the surrounding lovely shops. We found the best shoes and handbags there having gotten tired of the Florida street and Palermo

Don't miss the cemetery...I'm not kidding!. When in the Recoleta neighborhood of BA, DO NOT MISS a walk through the cemetery! I know that sounds creepy and ghoulish, but it's the most fascinating collection of monuments, crypts and almost mini-cathedrals that you'll ever see. A photographer's dream for sure. Yes - Evita is buried there, but don't make that the only reason you visit. It's an incredible way to spend a few hours in BA.

Great free tour. We went twice to the Recoletta Cemetery. First we went on our own because we missed the English tour (11am Tues and Thurs). It is a beautiful place. We went the second time to get the FREE guided tour. Our guide was a font of knowledge and did a great job of including the history of Argentina and the meanings of the symbols used in the burials. We stayed in the neighbourhood as well and it was a great place to stay.

A grave experience - people are dying to go there. Ricoleta Cemetry is where Eva Peron was finally buried, in the Duarte family tomb. The easiest way to know what you are seeing is to join a guided party at hte front gate. English guides are available at certain times of the day ... we wondered around by ourselves though.The cemetry is like a large village, with a large number of streets filled with a bizarre range of what can only be called houses for tombs. Some really ornate and temple-like; many with Victorian pathos and angels guarding the dead. One has two like-size sculptures of soldiers on either side of the door. The most touching is the bronze statue of a daughter who did not return from a skiing trip .. she is joined in bronze by her faithful dog at her feet; with his shiny nose that visitors stroke for luck, keeping it brightly burnished. The place is huge and not easy to find one's way around - but if one follows the crowd, then the destination will be Eva Peron. The site is really interesting, yet vaguely disturbing. Some of the "houses" have the doors hanging off the hinges, due to the fact that there is nobody left in that family to maintain the family crypt. Others are immaculate. In between two of the tombs there is what looks like a really poor offering .... what a shock, then, to hear voices coming from it! With relief, but an enhanced feeling of bizzarenes, we realised that it was just a maintenance hut with a group of workmen inside, taking a break and a snack ... but why did they eat in the dark?The happiest creatures in the ground appeared to be the several cats, rolling or sleeping in the sun.This is a must-visit, but after a while it does start to press on one's very being and that is the time to leave to join the excellent crafts market on the parkland just outside the gates.BUT ... if you want a really strange end to the day; turn right out of the cemetry gates and go into the mall about 100m away. Ascend the escalator and head for McDonalds and there you will see that the best overhead view of the cemetry (which is right below the window) can be had whilst eating a big Mac .... and if you eat too many of those, you too could be joining the residents, but probably not in quite such splendour!

A City/Country Icon. The cemetery is unique to BA and shouldn't be missed if you're visiting Buenos Aires. Wander through the pathways and look at the tombs and mausoleums dating back to the founding families. Obtain a map if you want to see Evita's tomb because it's not specially marked and it's easy to get lost. Nearby is a park where handicraft vendors sell their wares on the weekends (and even some weekday evenings in the summer). Single guys will appreciate the local clubs like Newport after 11 pm. It's a longish but walkable distance to the Retiro, which is action central for the city.
nice area with some intersting places. the old cemetery is interesting and also the streets where the old houses are and you can feel the old rich history of Buenos aires

Recoleta is the area in which the Alvear palace is located. It also has beautiful boutiques for leather and clothing. A. Liked most everything.
