Didn't like the waiters at the tango shows pushing drinks at you.,.loved walking everywhere which is what one can do if staying at the Alvesr Palace. San Telmo is the place to be on a weekend day just to browse if nothing else. It crowded and fun. Going out to the swamp area and boating through the reeds makes you think of the bayou.
free and different. A peaceful place. Fascinating tombs sometimes very ornate, coffins visible sometimes, many old tombs contrast with stark modern ones. Can be explored without a map.
Historic. Tombs of the affluent past in Argentina. Free admission and absoluteley unique. Safe location with security and safe walking in area.

Great history. The cemetery is very interesting and of course is dominated by the mausoleum of evict a which still has fresh flowers delivered every day. A lovely Sunday craft market in the adjacent park but be wary of food/drink prices in the surrounding streets

One of the wonderful cemetaries in the world. This is a site not to miss in Buenos Aires. Some of the most unique tombs in the world inside this cemetery of the aristocrats of Argentina. Eva Peron had a very modest resting place. Enjoyed the tomb of Luis Fripo, the great Chilean boxer. Great carvings and statutes in many parts of the cemetary

Nice at the end of morning. There is a square where the cemitery of Evita is located that has a handicraft market at saturdays. There are two or three bars where you could have some Quilmes while wait for your wife buy some stuffs.

unlike any cemetery I have ever visited. The price is right (free), and the 1 mile walk from our hotel pleasant. This cemetery is unlike any other I have other seen. It is more or less its own little city with the mausoleums essentially their own buildings along something resembling little streets.

Recoleta great for walking around and exploring. I am told Recoleta is "old Money" There is a visible police presence.The area has plenty of French inspired architecture,wide avenues,nice parks,museums,good shopping and some outdoor cafes great for people watching.

A nice place to visit. Ono of the more fashionable neiborghoods of Buenos Aires, you'll find many residences built by famous architects in the early twentieth century, some of them recycled as embassies or 5* hotels. Many parks, a couple of exposition centers and the Museum of Arts are within the limits. During the weekends, you can stroll through a craft market.

very cute. One of my favorite stops in Buenos Aires, especially the old quarters full of colors where the original Italian immigrants lived. There are many souvenir shops, some with good bargains for leather, wool scarves and stones.

Cemetery: a MUST DO. This is one of Buenos Aires major attractions. You must visit the cemetery and listen to the stories. It´s like a city within the city, with avenues, narrow streets, trees....and lots of art works. It´s the largest coleection of stain-glass in the world. Fantastic.
over the top cemetery. nothing like it anywhere else in the world. so glad we went and had no idea of the elaborate décor for mausoleums.

Weekends are the best!. I love going to Recoleta on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon (especially if it's nice out). It is like going to a nice, relaxing, hippyish music festival. There are hundreds of excellent vendors selling everything from clothing, jewelry, accessories, artwork, to mate gourds and food. I bought many souvenirs there. There are people playing live music, sitting/laying in the park, and entertainment (tango dancers, clowns, music etc.) The Recoleta Cemetery is right there and it is a very interesting/historical place to check out. Buller's Brew Pub is near and they have VERY good IPA (hard to find in BA). The parks are beautiful and the vibe is good

Worth to spend a few hours. The cementary is what you go for, and it's a beautiful cementary. You can take a private tour or on thursday at 11.00 a group tour. I just like to wander around and admire the graves. Afterwards there are many bars and restaurants to sip on a coffe watch the crowd passing by

Something Different. This isn't the type of thing you see every day but it's certainly worth taking a look. It's very interesting and certainly worth a look. We did the self guided tour and really enjoyed it.

Not your ordinary cemetary. We didn't know what to expect when our tour guide took us here. This is a very unique place, unlike others we have toured (e.g. arlington national cemetary). It also houses the mausoleum where eva peron is buried. absolutely a must visit in Buenos Aires. The mausoleums are set up like an exclusive enclave, where you can see each trying to out do the others with size and art work.
Charming neighbourhood. Very beautiful neighbourhood. The cemetery worths the visit. The park in front of the cemetery have very good options of bars and restaurants.

Haunted...intriguing.... Probably one of the most fascinating and haunted places ever! La Recoleta boasts a beautiful church and a stunningly spooky cemetery.. probably made most famous/infamous by the mausoleum of the Duarte family and Eva (Evita) Peron. However there are many more beautiful and fascinating tombs, as well as some haunted and moldering ones! with some tragic histories...a guide is available to tell you the stories! A place you will never forget!

Great place to visit. This was one of the most fascinating places in Bueno Aires we visited. They have an official tour every day at 11:00 in English, but we missed it. However, there are independent tour guides who will lead you and any small group of people around for an hour. We took a tour with a lady who was just excellent and provided a lot of history.

Great Site-Seeing. We wandered around Recoleta for a couple of days and had a chance to see the craft market, the cemetery, and lots of shops, restaurants and cafes. This area is truly charming. The Saturday market is reportedly the best in BA and if you're looking for local handicarafts and souvenirs this is the place to go to find really great quality, and unique, articles. The cemetary offers a different way to learn much of the history of the city but be sure to get a guided tour so you don't miss the highlights. There are plenty of charming places to dine when taking a break from window shopping and the streets themselves are simply beautiful.
nice shopping area. Lots of shops and restaurants. Seems to be a very popular area of the city! Great spot for a hotel stay as it is within walking distance to many attractions
a good place to gather history. visiting this neighborhood and cemetery gives you a quick glimpse into Argentinian history and an important neighborhood even today

Worth A visit. I recommend you take a walk around the area and admire the posh neighborhood with beautiful and fancy buildings. Nowhere in the world would you perhaps find the elaborate Tombs Mausoleums and Graves distinguished by personalized monuments and personal details. Also visit the grave of EVITA, an ordinary resting place of extraordinary and most powerful women of her time.

Sunday Market is Amazing. There is a Sunday market just by the cemetery that has a good art collection to offer. Also, there are usually a lot of musicians playing after the market it over, so hang in there after dark and enjoy the folk musicians. The cemetery is a must, be sure to check the timings before you go; do not fall for the paid maps outside, there are maps inside for free!

Week-end must. Make sure to set aside at least one week-end afternoon to visit La Recoleta. Start with the cemetery, the third most important in the world. Eva Duarte de Peron's tomb is a must and there are two daily free tours. If you like history and beautiful sculptures, this is a must.The street market is great, spiced with music and tango dancing. You'll enjoy very creative arts and crafts as well as good food.
Good enough to see, not to stay. The cemetery is a must see, other than that it is mainly nice apartment buildings and restaurants. You should spend a day there, but that is all you need.

Recoleta summay - waste of time. I understand the importance of the place to the Argentinian people - however, I find the cemetery boring, and frankly - building small palaces for dead people is a bit strange. For me it was a waste of time

lovely area. We enjoyed part of our tour walking around the Recoleta area. It is an old part of town with nice homes and some mansions - great architecture to enjoy. The parks are lovely and green with lots of old trees as well. Nice cafes in the area for relaxing and having a refreshment. Loved going through the old cemetery and especially seeing Evita's tomb. Also enjoyed the little church near by.

Steeped in history. We had a private guide for just the two of us, so he was part of what made this place so very fascinating. I'm not sure we would have had the same feel if we were walking through on our own, although this is usually our preferred way to travel. (Exploring on our own.) Everyone knows this place as where Eva Peron's tomb is, but hearing so much of the history and story of so many others, it is much more.

Don't miss it!. Although Evita's mausoleum isn't as spectacular as you might imagine, the whole cemetary is fascinating. Definitely get on a guided tour if you want to get the most from the stories behind the differing tombs. Our highlight? The tomb of Liliana Crociati de Szaszak – remember to rub Sabú's nose for good luck when you are there... I did and fell off a horse in El Calafate 10 days later!

Great Area to Stay. Great area to stay...central to everything and you can walk everywhere. Very leafy and attractive area and we felt safe whenever we were out. Lots of restaurants, supermarkets, cafes in the area.

After the cemetery--walk the neighborhood. Consensus crowns the Recoleta cemetery and Eva Peron's tomb as the area's number one sight. But after that, I recommend a walk along Alvear Avenue and side streets; great architecture (see why Buenos Aires is compared to Paris), lovely residential streets, grand deluxe hotels and cafes (the tea at the Alvear Palace Hotel is wonderful-reserve it) and boutique shopping. Its a different kind of atmosphere; even among the hotels and cafes, we felt the tourist 's city slip away.

much more than the cemetary. Guides always emphasize Evita's tomb. Hard for Norte Americanos to realize her place in the pantheon of Argentine heros. The total cemetary architectural concept is interesting. Better yet are the cafes, open areas. activities. Easy walking and you gain a feel for Buenos Aires. You are not hemmed in. Did not find one eating place or cafe stop better than others but choices are there.

Sophisticated suburb. Ricoletta shows it's class in it's buildings and fine restaurants and on weekends has an open air market which is good for browsing for souvenirs or just window shopping. Also very close to the famous cemetery of same name which is well worth a look.

Recoleta, something for everybody. Variety of restaurants, nice outdoor settings. Historic cemetery with mausoleos of important portenos throughout history. Place of worship in the chapel. Cultural centre with exhibitons and performances. Weekend art and craft market with numerous varieties of stalls. A must during a visit in Buenos Aires.
Felt like a local. Very ideal area to stay. It was close to everything and we just jumped on the metro. Handy to parks, shopping and restaurants.

A type of history. The cemetary is open every day; and in some Buenos Aires travel guides we read that there are free English tours of the cemetary at certain times of the day. When we arrived there we learned that all English tours are at a price so we better bought a one-page map of the cemetary in English for 15 Peso and did the tour by ourselves.

Nice area with huge cemetery. Like the atmosphere with street cafe and musician playing. Street market selling souvenirs and handmade goods. Tourist information to guide you around. Lots of taxis around if you need it.
A very unique cementary. Read so much about this place. Words cannot describe the interesting history of it's residents. A must see.
Great Architecture. A must see when in Buenos Aires! Walk through the district as there are: musuems, parks, malls, and the cemetery.

Really worth a visit - hire a guide. This is full of fascinating stories - ones that guidebooks don;t explain so it is really worthwhile paying the small charge to one of the official guides who are inside the main entrance. We spent an hour with a lovely lady who brought the stories to life - so interesting.

A Must See In Buenos Aires. Pictures do not adequately show or describe this tourist attraction. It is, however, still a viable and ongoing cemetery, where people visit their family members. Certain tombs and mausoleums do show neglect but the diverse architecture is well worth the trip. Take the time to walk it and read some of the names and years people were buried. A great review of some of the history of Buenos Aires.

Fantastic Area. My husband and I stayed at the Grand Hotel for five nights in Recoleta before our cruise.We loved this area. We saw a lot of Buenos Aries while we were there and we liked this area the best. It was in some ways reminiscent of Paris and we love Paris. There are many restaurants in the area, the Recoleta mall, the cemetary, many specialty food and grocery stores, a weekend craft fair by the cemetary, etc...We walked like a couple of fools in this city. We would say let's get a cab and then we would just keep walking. We walked from Recoleta to the marina, the racetrack/casino, Palermo, and even Boca. We did take a cab from Boca back because it was a ways. I felt very safe. In Recoleta if I pulled out our map people would ask us if we needed help. I did find that very few people speak English so a dictionary would be helpful especially with menus. I ate some things I didn't expect. LOL

NIce central BA location. This is a great location that is in a safe neighborhood relatively convenient to most of the things we wanted to do. Interesting a Saturday morning walk here was mostly in the company of elderly well to do folks on the way to do grocery shopping or young parents with their kids (as opposed to Palermo SOHO were in the afternoon we saw mostly denizens enjoying their home turf. We we close enough at the Buenos Aires Grand Hotel to walk to the legendary cemetary in one direction and the Casa Rosita in the other other. It felt secure to be here.

Smart side of city. Great location with good Hotels, lots of shops, really nice bars and restaurants. There are lots of lovely parks and of course the famous, very popular cemetery. Worth a visit or base yourself there when in the city.

A beautiful neighbourhood. We stayed at the Park Hyatt, about ten minutes down from the famous Recoleta Cemetery. A lovely neighbourhood, it is leafy yet filled with beautiful old architecture.This is an upper-end neighbourhood, so it is relatively clean, safe and nice to walk around in. No cobblestone, like San Telmo, but fancy niche stores, like one just for jockeys, and lovely high-restaurants, like Fervor. Wandering around, you can see the palatial Four Seasons Hotel, which used to be a single residence and other historical buildings like that.
So much money spent for such ornate resting places. It was an incredible place of artistic death. I wondered how many of these crypts were worth more than an expensive home for the living.
Easy walking. The streets felt safe and it was easy to walk to the cemetery, shops and the large mall. Beautiful buildings and as so many reviews report, very much like European cities.

Eva wasn't crying on my visit. Spooky but incredibly interesting area - tourist groups following guides displaying umbrellas with numbers on - solo visitors pretending not to be listening to the guide commentaries and people like me who couldn't fathom out how I could find the Eva Peron Mausoleum. I found it and recommend you try too!
Amazing neighborhood. Such a beautiful place to walk around and spend some time. Of course, the main attraction is the cemetery, but just walking around this glamorous part of town is worthwhile.

Recoleta Cemetery. This is an entire "city of the dead" with streets, elaborate mausoleums, and interesting (and creepy) things around every corner. Plan several hours here to explore, rather than just going to Evita's grave.

Posh area and the cemetery should not be missed. This is one of the more expensive areas of Buenos Aires. It is filled with expensive homes and apartments. The area has trendy shops and eating establishments. This is one of the safest neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. The cemetery where Eva Peron as well as other dignitaries and well-off families is filled things of historical significance and interesting architecture. It will take an hour or so to see and appreciate this place.
Eva Peron. The Mausoleums in the cemetery are ornate. It was so interesting to see where Eva Peron is laid to rest. I was expecting it would be much bigger.
Market on Sundays. This is a popular area with many cafes and nice restaurants, walk around and enjoy, there is a market on Sundays with many stalls and interesting typical things.

Do not miss a visit to the Cemetery!. This is one of the big events in Buenos Aires. I don't think there is another cemetery like this in the world. The architecture is amazing. You will get more out of it if you have a guide. There are free tours on Tuesday and Thursday at 11am, but good private guides hangout in front. They charge around $20 for the tour. Worth it!

History and Architecture. It is hard to think of visiting Buenos Aires without strolling through this famous landmark. There is Evita Peron's mausoleum to see (if only to say you were there). The real interest lies in the ornate architecture of the final resting places of famous and non-famous residents of the city. This almost ostentatious design of the mausoleums is typical of many Spanish cemeteries. I'm not sure what the deceased did in life to warrant these, but I thoroughly enjoy the sculptures and other adornments found here. They are testimony to human vanity and spirituality at the same time. A must see for any B.A. tourist.By the way, the Recoletta neighborhood is great in its own right. Nice shops, good restaurants, coffee shops, and bars.

Best place to stay in Buenos Aires.. Great area to rent an apartment. The streets are quiet and thought of as safe. We rented a place through VRBO that had all the amenities we could ask for. There are restaurants in Recoleta. The cemetery [a must visit] is nearby.

One of the Best Neighborhoods in BA. The Recoleta neighborhood in BA is my favorite place. The wide boulevards and large French style mansions make you feel that you are in Europe. The area is safe to walk in, and I spent countless hours just wandering the area by myself with no hassles or issues. The neighborhood is well known for its shopping opportunities, including leading French and Italian designers. The centerpiece of the area is the Recoleta Cemetery that is free to visit and deserves a couple of hours. There are a number of nice green parks, the most interesting is Plaza Francia just outside of the Cemetery. Plaza Francia is also the home to a couple of extremely large and old trees that need to be seen. Take a couple of hours here, see the sights, have an ice cream, say hi to Evita in the Cemetery and relax. Sunday’s are especially great when the ‘feria hippie’ sets up in the park. Artisans fill the park and surrounding area with booths selling their interesting wares. Fun galore.

Recoletta Cemetery -Do not miss this. Recoleta Cemetery is the history of Argentina encapsulated in a city block. The chapel and basilica are beautiful and the cemetery is ONE of a KIND. One could spend an afternoon walking the narrow alleys and seeing burial sites that are truly unique with flowers, family photos and family pets buried with their masters!

Nice upscale neighborhood. A place to have good food, do some expensive shopping and feel totally safe. The neighborhood is somewhat historic and mostly residential, but there are many good restaurants (some are at hotels) that are tucked away in side streets.

interesting cemetery. I was unsure of what to expect from this cemetery. My husband and I took a bus to get there and found it without problems. I found the place extremely interesting. There were old tombs (like little houses) with broken windows and decaying wooden coffins that you can almost touch--eerie, but creepily fascinating. Many had unfortunately been vandalized. Others were well-maintained. You can take a tour, buy a map, or wander on your own. Go early in the summer because a lot of heat radiates off of all the cement.
nice area. A fantastic safe area. Lots of great places to eat and drink in a safe environment. Great architecture.

Recoleta - Puerto Madero. taxi in Buenos Aires is relatively cheap. Around town will cost you no more than $4 per ride. Take a taxi to PUERTO MADERO where you find fine restaurants serving mouth watering stakes and other south american food Walk along the river and enjoy the views it is lovely in the day and romantic at night fall

Don't miss this in Buenos Aires!!!. The website tells you the time for free English led tours and they were on the mark. Just meet at the entrance. Our group was about 20 and led by an excellent woman who spoke loudly and clearly and kept the group moving without being too pushy. We saw parts of history and she put it into context. Took about 1 1/2 hours and then we wandered a little longer on our own. Cemetery is also close to the Hard Rock if you have to buy a collector t-shirt like we did.
bueno. i like the cementeery it architecture and way to build the crypts are awsome, really recomend it to visit, i have go after the orange free walking tour and i really enjoy it

nice neighbourhood. Lovely neighbourhood with nice cafes etc. Walk through it and up to Avenida Santa Fe. This will put you in Palermo neighbourhood. Walk down Santa Fe to Plaza San Martin at the beginning of Calle Florida. Calle Florida is a long traffic free street with shops and cafes. At its end are the Government buildings and plazas. Great tour for a few hours.
Beautiful area. Our hotel Alvear Palace was gorgeous and the service extremely warm and personable. I highly recommend. The shopping in the mall adjacent to the hotel is upscale and lovely.

Classy and with style. Beatiful neighborhood that made me remember of Paris. The best shops are here, very classy and elegant. The architecture of the old mansions is very well preserved and it is very charming the mixture of this with the cemetery and the colonial church at the Plaza. A must in BA without any doubt

One of the most interesting sites to visit. Both interesting and historical. To the western eye, quite a strange place as other than New Orleans it is rare to see graveyards like this. Truly an historical record with crypts of many president's and of course Evita. The elaborate nature of the crypts is quite astonishing - like a small city.
History not to be missed. A must on your 1st visit, Eva Peron along with past Presidents & people of history, It's a cemetery of mausoleums

Nice neighbourhood to stay or visit. It is an upscale neighborhood and not to far from the interesting sites and the centro. We stayed at a suites hotel here and it was a pleasant stay: enough nice restaurants and shops around the corner. Quiet and away from the tourist traps. The only big tourist attraction is the cemetery and the fair in the weekends. For the rest, you can feel a local with the locals.

Has a bit of everything. From Recoleta Shopping Mall with a quality multiplex cinema to numerous outdoor dining spots and one of the world best cemeteries (Evita is there), Recoleta is at the heart of the Capital Federal in Buenos Aires. Walk the streets in and around the area and look at the wonderful architecture as each building is better than the prior one. In addition the area has many vendors on the weekend as you stroll the green areas in Recoleta. Buenos Aires has numerous parks and green areas and some of the best looking trees in the world. The Hotel Alvear, a world class old hotel, is located in Recoleta. If I were living in BA this would be one of the two areas I would look, the other being some areas of Palermo.

had a layover, went for a walk. so my flight had a 12 hour layover....really...so i went for a walk..the taxi was about 25 bucks each way so i went. had a chance to go to a few bars and then walked around recoleta. recoleta is nice. the area is actually very cool. but remember you dont want to be here too late at night. it gets dangerous. but if you keep it safe and in some cases take a taxi from site to site, it is actually a fun place. i also like walking the street Guido during the day. there area a lot of high end stores and a lot of antique shops. go. and look around. but please be safe.

Best neighbourhood. I like the Alvear and Callao corner, the Alvear Palace Hotel, the Duahau Hyatt, Café Restaurant La Biela (Quintana y Junín), the old and enormous gum trees in the park near the Pilar Church. If there is something I disliked is the fair on Sundays, just a few stands sell good manufactured products and the crowd is rather annoying. Tourists may occasionally enjoy the tango show of rather shabby couples.
Must see attraction. Very interesting cemetery, the last resting place of the rich, the powerful, the famous. Elaborate mausoleums including that of Evita Peron
Revisiting with family. Love the location.Loved the craft market.Plenty bars shops and the cemetery is wonderful.Nothing to dislike

Interesting. The area is nice to roam around -- albeit expensive -- we would up in the area after visiting the cemetery. We did however find a great restaurant called la Milanesa there that fit our budget. The mall there was also a nice respite from the heat!

Great neighborhood and great weekend Hippie Market. This is the best place to be on the weekend. Spent a great time at the Hippie Market on Saturday - only on weekends! Artists bring their wares and sell them. I have bought beautiful silver jewelry, funky clothes, and beautiful wood items. Then, a short walk to the cemetery where Eva Peron is buried - it is like a little city and fascinating to see all the tombs. Then, go on and have a great lunch or dinner - outside with great Argentinian wine and great steak. Their beef is the best in South America, even better than Brazil's and I love it there too.
Unique atmosphere. Beautiful architecture - like Paris and Barcelona, parks, wide streets and sidewalks, restaurants with typical cuisine. Very pleasant place to walk.

Rich and sophisticated neighborhood. This part of town is the best of Buenos Aires. We were pleased to stay in it. It's walkable or easy to take busses to wherever you may want to go. Most of the big attractions are fairly close and going to places like San Telmo or the Teatre Colón are an easy bus ride away
Like Europe. The wide streets dotted with lush green trees and beautiful buildings allowed for a safe and very pleasing stroll along the numerous "boulevard's"

tour the dead. the cemetray is always worth a visitwith or without a tourguidethe graves are spectacularEvitas rather timid among the otherstake your timeread names and strolli liked the houses around the cemitary

Atmospheric area but far from hip. Visit but don't stand here. There are parks and amazing mansions. There is an interesting cemetery. Some great cafes abound as well. You might want to stroll through the place, but don't choose a hotel here.

Cemetary to "die for"!!!! :). My 2nd time here...and it is still amazing!! The entire neighborhood is great...with high end shops, great restaurants (dine outside if you can) and of course...the burial place of Evita Peron. If you are in BA on a Sunday be sure to visit the "farias" ...which is an incredible out-door market with at least 100 vendors with many beautiful hand make crafts...and you get to meet the creators of what you buy!!!

Recoleta Cemetery. This is a must see place in Buenos Aires. The extent, size & variety of the mausoleums is astonishing - and that's just referring to what you see above ground level! The cost of one of these must have been tremendous, even in the early years. At ground level, you can view some caskets through glass panels. I understand that, if you are a family member of the deceased, you can go below ground level as well to visit the caskets of all of your deceased relatives! The cemetery is laid out in streets with signs directing you to important mausoleums,such as where Evita is entombed. A fascinating and history awakening place.

Pretty neighborhood. Recoleta is an upscale pretty neighborhood. It is walking distance to all other areas and we felt safe walking around at night. We liked Palermo Soho better but it is not as conveniently located as Recoleta.
Elegance frozen in time. Beautiful ld buildings and restaurants.Very sad that it is populated only by the grandparents of all the young people that have left Argentina.

Upmarket area. Visited Hard Rock Cafe which was very good value for moneyFood was excellent lots of cocktails, beer and food for about USD30 per headDidn't have to queue it was very quiet which was a plus as normally Hard Rock Cafés very busy not particularly easy to find had to ask about 5 times for directions

Recoleta Cemetery. We walked around the Recoleta section of Buenos Aires on a private guided tour. We saw 400 year old Ficus trees, which were amazing. We also saw the large Cemetery, which included Eva Peron's tomb. This is a very interesting part of the city, with a lot of history.

Great part of the city. I was in Buenos Aires on business and had one free day. After asking advice on Tripadvisor about were to stay I booked a hotel in Recoleta.I can't judge about other locations in BA but this was a great location to walk around for a day and get a feel for the neighborhood. Amazing buildings, plenty to see, good vibe and very safe.

Great area to stay!. Spent a wonderful six nights at a hotel on Callao Avenue.The area has a lot of beautiful architecture also hotels, one must see the Ducau Palace Hotel.The streets are lined with trees and a great advantage is that the cemetery is located there.

A lovely part of the city. Our hotel was here and we spent many happy evenings and afternoons wandering around the up-market streets and squares. The cemetary is definitely worth a visit and not at all macabre, and there is a fabulous fig tree that provides great shade for ice-cream eating in the afternoon. The weekend craft market is entertaining for a stroll, but don't expect to find anything really worth buying.

Well worth the visit!. There is a certain feeling in this area of Buenos Aires. The architecture, historical aspects, and of course the Recoleta Cemetery where Eva Peron's body rests all provide for a mixture of emotions to a visitor. Once in the cemetery, grab a map, or just follow the crowds to see Eva's site. They do have guided tours. The entire area and surrounding Recoleta neighbourhood is very clean. We spent half a day sightseeing here, shopping and enjoyed a lovely meal in an outdoor cafe.

Nice place - and a cemetery to boot!. Recoleta is famous for the cemetery in its midst. The cemetery is famous because it is where Eva Peron, amongst other famous people in Argentina's history. Once outside the cemetery there are a number of cafes and restaurants for fine or quick dining. If nothing else, don't miss visiting this iconic cemetery, then visit one of the many cafes for coffee!

Must see!. From the nice and must see neighborhood surounding the cemetery to the cemetery itself,this is a must see to have a complet feel and history of Buenos Aires.
Is amazing how much from the past you can see and understand by visiting the Recoleta Cemetery.
A very nice neighbourhood to visit. There are many museums, and interesting places to see including a cemetery. The museums are either very cheap to enter or entirely free.

Recoleta Cemetery. Final resting place of Eva Peron, numerous Argentine presidents, military and jockey club leaders. Mausoleums are a small city of varying architectural styles from Baroque to Beaux Artes to modern. A must see in Buenos Aires.
Recoleta looks like Paris. Its very clean and full of shops, restaurants and bars. Best place to stay whilst visiting Buenos Aires.

Free walking Tour of Recoleta. Having been in BA in 2010 and done this walk before, we decided to do it again. The young lady, Laura, gave us a very interesting 3 hour walking tour through central and northern Recoleta. Some of the places we walked through were the same as 2010, but the information, from a positive perspective, was very interesting. We found Laura very helpful in many ways and we strongly recommend the walk. PS a tip in USD would be very welcomed by Laura.
Best place to stay. Love the cafe culture and excellent restaurants. Feel very safe in this part of town. Also one of the most famous cemeteries in the world here - Evita's mausoleum.

Where the rich and famous have lived/live. Beautiful colonial buildings, wide tree lined avenues, and of course, the amazing cemetery like none you've ever seen before! The Portenos from Recoleta spent lavishly while alive and after death. Great restaurants and high end shopping in this neighborhood, too.
Good neighborhood. Best place in Town for living, shopping and going out. Great parks, nice shops and good food and drinks at several bars and restaurants around the graveyards...

Take the tour. It is a cemetery after all! The great part is the free tour. English tours are limited so check to make sure. Engage the guides... they have fascinating stories & will give honest opinions on characters.

Nice area for an afternoon stroll. As we were staying in the Retiro area, Recolta was a delightful contrast. We walked down most of streets stopping in some lovely parks and ended up at La Recoleta cemetery which you really must visit especially the large older mausolean at the back . Lots of good window shopping and lovely apartment buildings to look at.

Great neighborhood. I had the pleasure of being able to stay in this neighborhood. I made great lifelong friends and now always have a home to go to when in Buenos Aires. The architecture is beautiful.. its the Paris of South America. You can always catch a free city tour and have a young local explain it all to you with much heart and sentiment. Buenos Aires is a lovely city; cafes and much dining options. Great night life and always an energetic crowd.

Nice neighborhood to call home.. Seemed to be very safe and had many cafes, the art fair on the weekend, the interesting old Cemetery where you can find interesting old Tombs (including Evita) We enjoyed staying in the neighborhood with our teens, and could walk most everywhere. If not, taxis are very reasonable.

Hippy markets and Spanish reggae. If you like the above then go to Recoletta. Obviously Evita's grave and the steel flower are close by but our favourite place to go on the weekend was the park where they have markets, baked goods and Spanish reggae. Take a blanket some mate and check it out.

Perfect Location to explore all of BA. With 5 friends I rented an apartment on Libertad Avenue in Recoleta. The area boasts everything from wide avenues to small local tree-lined streets and a host of dining and shopping opportunities. Its central location in BA is a definite plus as we could walk to most of the attractions we were interested in.

Beautiful area, incredible cemetary. The Recoleta area and cemetery are a must see. Beautiful part of the city that is great to stroll thru. Club Francis Hotel was great. While I have never thought a cemetery would be a good place to visit this was incredible. The history, stories, and just the presence of the place is beyond words. Like no place else we have ever been. Went back a 2nd time it was so amazing.

Old money district of BA. Some beautiful old homes - beautiful hotels and good restaurants. Very safe area for walking - no subways were built to this area, but taxis are very inexpensive if you need something beyond walking distance,

Great area to stay. Recoleta is a clean and beautiful area, with plenty parks, cafes, restaurants and supermarkets. We definitely preferred it over Palermo. What makes it even more enjoyable is the proximity to the Recoleta cemetery. It is nice to walk around as it's well shaded from the sidewalk trees. One downside is that, even though this is one of the nicest neighborhoods in Buenos Aires, the residents don't bother cleaning up after their dogs. We noticed this everywhere in BA, but were more saddened to observe it here.

The richest of Argentina.... this is probably one of the most expensive areas of BUenos Aires, they have museums, restaurants, bars, even the Cementery is a popular tourist destination. The construction, landscape, etc everything is very chic...go for a walk. They have tons of restaurants with sitting outside.
You have to visit this place!. Beautiful, peaceful and kind a creepy at the same time.This a must for the Buenos Aires visitor especially as a photographer.

Recoleta. Buenos Aires. Recoleta is a quiet and clean neighbourhood in the heart of Buenos Aires, you are can walk everywhere with numerous shops and restaurants This was one of those places that is worth seeing The architecture is reminiscent of ParisVisit the cemetery it is a major sightseeing spot in the city and definitely worth a visit. Free tours are offered regularly

elegant and tourist friendly. Recoleta houses some of the most iconic features of BA. Sounds strange but the cemetery is a not to be missed visit, filled with gorgeous sculptural tombs which house the remains of some of Argentina's most outstanding citizens. There are wonderful restaurants and shopsand a good dose of café life

Interesting but not the highlight of our vist to Buenos Aires. The area is famous for its cemetery with Eva Peron's tomb. Visiting the cemetery was interesting and a must for a visit to the city, but not one of our high points of the city.

Fascinating!. The cemeteries are a work of art. Make sure you take a guided tour, really worth it. You learn about the significance of this monument, history and the architecture. Fascinated to hear the details about the families who are buried in this place!
lots to explore. very good restaurants, good shopping and several very high end malls that don't look or feel like malls at all. street scene is very paris-like, St Germain comes to mind.

Look out for the dog poohs. We went to Recoleta on a Sunday for the market. There are some lovely (old and huge) 'rubber' trees around the grassy areas. We went around the market, which was pretty much like all the markets you have ever been to, with one or two stalls with slightly different products.So not great, the Sunday market on Defensa is probably better...What Recoleta has in slightly greater abundance (although it is a problem throughout Buenos Aires to a greater or lesser degree) is dog pooh. Locals say that it is because the dogs in the slightly posher area of Recoleta are walked 10 or 15 at a time by professional dog walkers - and they don't 'pick up' the poohs. OK, it must be quite difficult if you have a large number of dogs, but even so..........
Very unusual...must see!. Sights within a city! Fascinating cultural experience. We enjoyed the tour in which our guide described the various tombs and the religious and political diversity.
BsAs most famous ... and dead. An interesting place to visit, great architecture and excellent photo ops. Evita's place is a bit crowded. go very early to avoid the crowds

Recoleta District. This area is upmarket and quiet. It is very safe and has many great cafes the best of which is La Biela. The only downside is that it is not serviced by the subway but there are many taxis and buses or you can do as we did and just walk. If you are thinking of staying in Buenos Aires, Recoleta is the area you want to be in.

Don't forget the cemetery views from the Recoleta Mall.. The Recoleta cemetery is a must-do for any Buenos Aires visitor. Don't forget the views of the cemetery from the Recoleta mall. It makes for another interesting perspective to your photo collection. Also there are good restaurants inside

Visit the cemetary. If you love statues and momuments you will love this cemetary. An amazing place with impressive statues of the past presidents, the city's elite familes, military heroes, etc. You can even peer inside and see the occasionaly caskets.

The Recoleta Handicraft Fair on the weekends are great!. The fair is filled with stalls offering everything from hand painted ceramic decorative pieces to jewellery with semi-precious stones. Lots of fun people (and dog) watching, musicians, tango dancers, and local snacks. The stall owners are charming and don't mind your not buying anything! They are happy to chat with you, offer free samples and wave you goodbye. Be sure to visit the del Pilar Church opposite famous Le Biel Restaurant with the giant fig tree.

A happening part of town. A visit to the famous cemetary, including the resting place of Eva Peron, is only part of the atmosphere of this part of the city. It is filled with hotels, restaurants, coffee shops, and bars. While filled with tourists, there is a great local vibe which lends itself to the fashionable ambiance.
A must see. What to say about a cementry. Well you have to see this but before go read some info at wikipedia. Then you understand more about this place and who is there.

I Took My Husabnd Here Although He was Reluctant.. I have been there (Recoleta Cemetery) in 2011 but my husband was not with me then. I took him there even when he was reluctant to do so.I was disappointed that they did not have any maps when we got there. I asked some of the tourists where Evita Peron was buried and they were very helpful.My husband was glad that he went. He said it did not look a cemetery. It looked like a small city. The shops near the cemetery were nice. There were several nice restaurants around.
search. mandatory arrestsearch before entering the first restaurant, the menu number,waiters will always offer the most expensive option, stay tunedtake a taxi!
Great way to get to know B.A. There are lots of shops and restaurants. Out door cafes and green areas. The church and the cemetery are must sees.
Cementery!!!. Dont miss the cementery. It's just unbelieveable. It's a magestic piece of art. Go wit time and get a good map.
beatifull place. we spend an afternoon with my family and i really love it, we go to bellas artes museum and i really recomend it to all

The Place Where Those with Old Money Reside. The cemetery is okay, but a hour is plenty of time to walk around and find Evita's grave. Remember, her body is in the Duarte mausoleum, That's her maiden name. The neighborhood is a bit sterile. I prefer San Telmo.

Don't leave this off your list because you think it's too creepy!. We loved seeing this beautiful place, and considered it a highlight of our trip to Buenos Aires. The cemetery is just beautiful, and it is very interesting to walk up and down the pathways and look at the monuments to families from a hundred years ago, or last week. Of course, Eva Peron's memorial will get attention, but there are so many beautiful, highly artistic sculptural masterpieces in Recoletta that are worth seeing. And it is peaceful, of course. I think it is definitely worth a visit.
Worthwhile visiting. We visited an aret museum the cemetery where Eva Peron is buried a church and a pleasant cafe restaurant.

Recoleta is a must see. Fascinating diversity of graves make this a photographer's paradise. Naturally, Eva Person is the highlight but we enjoyed others even more. Go with a guide; the background information is worth the cost.

Safe but not much to do. While all the fancy hotel seem to be situated in Recoleta: the Alvear Palace, the Park Hyatt and the Four Seasons I was surprised how few shops and restaurants were in the area. It was safe to walk around but not many places to walk to. We walked to the Recoleta Market which has terrific handmade crafts/jewelry but was only open on the weekend. We also walked to Bullrich Mall, across from the Ceasar Palace hotel. There were few options on the streets.

Where to stay in Recoleto. My husband & I arrived in BA on Dec 31. We wanted to experience Buenos Aires like locals so on our first trip to South America we chose an air bnb rental in Polermo. The apartment was nice & our host was very helpful. Because to the heat wave, the electricity went out a couple of times during the night & it was sweltering. We didn't want to risk it happening during the next 10 days of our stay so our host lowed us to cancel. We then decided to try Recoleta and went to air bnb again. We've been at a wonderful apartment in a classic building & highly recommend air bnb for a local experience. It's also very reasonable, $100/night. Our host has recommended the best value wines and where to find them, Frappe on Av Callao. We chose a Cab-Malbec blend. 10% discount on 6 bottles. He also arranged currency exchange for us this morning at a source he knows. We netted $9.4 ARS per US dollar.
Nice area!. I love this area of Buenos Aires. There are lots of outdoor cafés and it is a nice location as a base. You can walk to a lot of attractions or take one of the easily available taxis.
must see!!. culturally this area has history and a sense of old and new BA. cemetery interesting, walking down ritzy streets and marveling the architecture.
Lovely area !!. The area is beautiful with a lot trees along the wide and busy avenues. I would recommend everyone to visit Recoleta cemetery as it's a very interesting place.

Surprised how much we enjoyed the cemetery.. Upon advice from our hotel (Miravida Soho) we hired an English speaking guide at the entrance. His knowledge of the place and history made the visit especailly interesting.

Great experience, most impressive sight in BA. This is one of the most impressive sights I have been at Buenos Aires; authentic, historic and again impressive.Although it might be creepy to some, go here.It tells the rich and disturbing history of Argentina. In order to have the full experience, I would recommend to have guide, which is a bit expensive, but worth the money. But take an official guide!

Where we stayed. Glad we stayed in this area as I felt it was very convenient to get around. We were able to walk to many of the sights and walked back from Florida Street as well. I did some browsing at some of the better stores and felt very safe walking around.

History Exposed. Visit when it's not in the 90s! Absolutely one of the world's most impressive cemeteries. Take a tour, otherwise you're just looking at beautiful statues. We happened upon tour guide, Simon Gadsdon, who toured us through the entire cemetery in about an hour. Without his knowledge, we wouldn't have gotten the full impact of Recoleta.
Paris in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is a quiet and clean neighborhood in the heart of Buenos Aires. The architecture is reminiscent of Paris
Safe and Central. We were at Loi suites in Recoleta. Excellent location, safe and convenient . Able to walk everywhere, Right near cemetery and numerous excellent shops. restaurants

Amazing Historic Cemetery. Wonderful historic cemetery, that is free to the public. People stand in front and offer a tour for money, but you do not need to hire a guide. Great place to wonder on your own, so save your money

Lives up to the hype. . Recoleta was certainly what it promised to be: upscale neighborhood with plenty of great shopping and food. We walked for a few hours visiting multiple stores, restaurants and the cemetery (the only overrated part of Recoleta.) the area was very beautiful and felt completely safe the entire walk.
Amazing Cemetery. This was one of those places that seeing is believing. It should be on the top of everyones list to see.
Nice. Nice place, with lots of bars (the ones you'll go in the middle of the day to drink a beer!), wine shops, a nice mall and the recoleta cemitery.

Robbed at Recoleta market. Recoleta area itself seems lovely. We enjoyed visiting the cemetery and the Recoleta craft market on a Saturday. My husband and I have travelled many places through out the world and are very vigilant and aware of our surroundings. We were warned about not wearing upscale watches in the Florida Avenue pedestrian mall and we were careful the entire time about this (so we thought). At the Recoleta market on a Saturday morning, a young man ran and almost fell upon my husband. He pushed against my husband and grasped his watch. The band snapped and my husband grabbed the man who ran across the street. The man had a buddy waiting with a motorcycle and they sped off. No one at the market was able to help. We wonder if someone tipped the man off from the market. The policeman that we located on a nearby corner did not speak any English. We received conflicting information about how/where to report the incident. It turns out there are numerous districts of police within the city and each is responsible only for their area. The tourist police is not open on weekends. The appropriate district for the area (District 17) was backed up for hours, we were told there were 4 reports at least in front of us. It was our departure day and we didn't have the time to even go. We were also told that the police are pretty useless anyway.

Cemetery and market awesome on Sunday. Very unique and tranquil place to visit. Worth seeing. Busy with tourists but also gives it it's charm. Market is full of one of a kind items not found elsewhere
I would live here!. A very pleasant neighborhood, with beautiful architechture of late 1800. Careful with the restaurants near to Cementerio de la Recoleta, expensive and with food average to bad!

good location. Safe, easy to go around; hotels and shops are very nearby.
friendly locals and all very helpful.
Stay in Recoleta, Puerto Madero, Palermo and play everywhere

The Essence of Buenos Aires. It seems a little odd to visit a cemetery while on vacation, but it is a major sightseeing spot in the city and definitely worth a visit. Free tours are offered regularly, and they are helpful to make sense of what you see.

Safe and upper-class part of the big city. We fortunately had a rental apartment in this part of town and enjoyed it very much. We felt safe and enjoyed the peace and tranquility and the friendly people. Close to a lot of local attractions and with nice boutiques and designer shops as well a good grocery stores and fruit stands and to the stop for the sightseeing bus. We enjoyed our stay in this area very much and consider this as the ideal part for a good impression of Buenos Aires.

Wonderful neighborhood. We stayed in Recoleta for two weeks and loved every block! In addition to all the attractions--Cemeterio, Pilar church, Plaza Francia, Avendia Alevear--you will find every service you will need and lots of good restaurants. Comfortable area for walking; very easy to find taxis.

Great neighborhood around Cemetery. The cemetery seems to get all the attention but the area around it is great for people watching and a great park area. On the weekends it's packed with artists selling touristy trinkets and souvenirs if that's your thing.

Go on the weekend. . .. Fantastic market, car show and the cemetery - what a wonderful way to spend a day. . . just watch out for the scammers at the entrance of the cemetery that will try and weasel an "entrance fee" from you (there is none). The market has many unique kiosks manned by the artists that have created their goods for sale. Tip - avoid the large, tourist trap restaurant at the top of the hill. . . expensive and the food is not good.

The Truth is I Never Left You. The search for Evita cannot conclude without a visit to the mausoleum of the Familia Duarte in the famous cemetery in Recoleta. The Duarte mausoleum is tame compared to many of the others throughout the cemetery. Well worth the trek.

A very distinguished place of the town. Great buildings, expensive shops, the best Hotels, nice people, quite, not so many cars and less buses. Buenos Aires, as every big town, has a lot of faces. This is one of the nicest faces you will find there. Parks, incredible trees, the Cemetary. Yes, of course. Don't you dare to miss the Cemetery.

nice area interesting cemetary. Recoleta is an upscale area of BA with the most prestigious cemetary in BA. It is very interesting to visit. As I'm not particularly a 'city' person, I can't say it would be high on my list of places to see but having seen it, I'm not repentant of having spent the time.

Safety and good food.. Wouldn't stay in any other area as this was safe and easy. Lots of nice restaurants and hotels. Cemetery, church, museums and shopping are all easy walks. I'm not a fan of the cabs unless you get the hotel to grab a decent one for you. We took local bus 93 or 130 which was safe and we met helpful people and saved our feet and pocketbook. Purchase bus passes at drugstores.

A great homage to the dead . Waw ! A wonderful city of the dead. This place was the highlight of my journey in BA. However, I was sad to see some graveyards neglected by the relatives and families. What a shame. This place is a treasure of memories for all the famous Argentinian people. There are a lot of intellectual people, industrialists, diplomats, and great people buried in there. let's not forget the architectural masterpieces that are the graveyards themselves.However, More care and attention should be given this place. For example, there is graveyard with a small broken glass in the ceiling. It costs nothing to replace, but all the rain leaking into the structure is seriously damaging the wonderful coffins in there. I really felt sad and sorry for those resting in there. Maybe there is no trace of the family or relatives, but they were once important people, part of Argentinian history. I believe more care should be given to them.

A nice place for a Sunday stroll. Recoleta is a quiet, upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires just perfect for a long stroll. The architecture of the buildings is grand, and most buildings are very well-maintained. There are plenty of restaurants, bars and boutiques in the area, so lots to see and do. We were there on a Sunday, so there was a busy street market on the big plaza in front of the cemetery. No visit to Buenos Aires would be complete without a visit to this beautiful neighborhood. We truly loved it!

Beautiful City of Souls. Incredible place, wide alleys with tombs and mausoleums the size of small churches, competing in architectural and artistic beauty, beautifully landscaped and full of friendly resident cats.

Wonderful Neighborhood. Wonderful area to stay for a few days when visiting BA. It is and up scale and safe area to walk,shop, eat and simply enjoy the architecture of the grand buildings. It is centrally located and easyto get a taxi from. One can visit the cemetery, shop at small boutique shops or at the Mall at PatioBullrich or weekend market on Sat & Sunday, sample ice-cream, or dine atsome of the best Italian restaurants in BA. Piegari is located across from the Four Seasons inthe Recova Area & our favorite, La Pecora Nera is on Ayacuyo.Best time to visit is in spring, the month of November if you love flowers. The jacaranda trees arein full bloom and the city looks like one giant flower arrangement. It takes 20 min. to walk from theCemetery to the Palermo Parks if you are a runner or walker.
LOVE Recoleta!. Great place to spend quality time checking out history, museums, markets, great shopping and great food.

The Rich are Rich even in Death. A must see if you are interested in mausoleum architecture and you want to see where Evita is buried ..The Evita mausoleum is hard to find as she is buried with her father's family ..after being moved around several times this is her final resting place and is a real disappointment. Follow a line of people going through the cemetery and they are usually heading that way or just say "Evita?" to one of the workers and they will walk you there (show them a tip for service) . The rich and famous of Argentina are buried here in massive edifices that resemble small houses in size . Who says that you cannot take it with you ??

Upscale area of Buenos Aires with Famous Cemetery and Cultural Center. The Recoleta cemetery is mentioned in all Buenos Aires guidebooks. It is interesting to walk around these elaborate,aristocratic family tombs with statues, cerubs, etc. and to visit the tomb of Evita Peron. Besides Evita, many of those buried here are not familiar names to non-Argentinians.During my visit, the Recoleta Cultural Center, an impressive rose-colored old mansion, hosted several of the Buenos Aires Jazz Festival concerts in an outdoor setting. The Center is active year-round and a great place to enjoy and find out more about the local music and arts scene.

A touristy but enyoyable neighbourhood. ...and afterwards, why not try Pani, an independent cafe we discovered just opposite the walls of the cemetery? It reminded us of a quaint but elegant English cafe. Alternatively, there's always afternoon tea at the Alvear Palace Hotel a couple of blocks away.

The place to be.. When people talk about BA being the Paris of the south, this is the neighborhood they are talking about. It would be quite easy to visit.BA, never leave this area and have a perfectly successful trip. Go there, stay there, you will be more than pleased with your experience.

Historical value. A visit to the Recoletta cemetery, especially when accompanied by a guide, gives an excellent overview of the upper classes of Buenos Aires in the early 20th century. You can visit the graves of many important historical figures of Buenos Aires including most presidents and Evita Perron. The various family cripts are a study in architecture and this visit is a must when in Buenos Aires.
Beautiful area.. Beautiful neighborhood. We went to the Cemetario de Recoleta and then to La Biela for lunch. Sat outside and enjoyed the area. Upscale shopping, etc...safe, nice area to walk around.

Very very nice, but not what everyone says!. Recoleta is a very nice place, but it's certainly not what everyone says. It's not the nicest area in BsAs (it may be the most expensive one, but Palermo Soho is certainly better).Nice squares with some street art and a lot of culture, with the cemetery nearby full of famous Argentinians such as Evita Perón... very interesting.The only reason why I didn't rate it 5 stars is because it's valued a lot more than it deserves.
Must do when I B.A.. Great place with tons of restaurants and a very lively atmosphere. Beware of pick-pockets and purse snatchers. Use common sense and you'll be just fine.

A great area to visit.. Very fashionable and with the famous cemetery and La Biela Cafe this is a great part to spend a few hours. The cemetery is best visited with a guide or a good book for reference.

Very nice neighbourhood to walk, have a coffee, an icecream or dinner. Both locals and tourists enjoy this posh district. Recoleta is filled with cafés, ice cream parlors, restaurants and expensive designer shops.I have enjoyed it at all times of the day: mornings are quiet, afternoons are more active, and in the evenings tends to be full of people.A coffee at La Biela (next to the cemetery) and an ice cream just across the street from La Biela are highly recommended activities: ice cream in Argentina is quite good, and there's dozens of flavours. If you have a sweet-tooth try dulce de leche con almendras (caramel with almonds).

cool neighborhood. young and hip, recoleta seems to have a lot of cafes and restaurants right along the main park and the downtown. Of course the main draw is the cementary which is as beautiful as advertised although a bit run down.

Great neighborhood!. I am glad I chose to stay here instead of Palermo (which is nice to visit, even nicer to leave). Safe, central, walkable to all the sights (Cemetery, Plaza De Mayo, Teatro Colon, Calle Florida, Museo De Bellas Artes and MALBA) and a short cab ride elsewhere. Highlights of the area are good restaurants (El Mirasol, La Pecora Nera, Smeterling, even the empanadas at La Cocina), shops (Celadonio Lohidoy - now on Uruguay, check his website), Patio Bullrich.

Nice place for a day of walking . Easy to navigate, many nice cafés, shops, and a cemetery make this upscale neighborhood a great destination. There is also a performing arts center to partake of concerts and other events.

Good place to go and drink a coffee as a "local" porteño.. Odd thing to go, the whole place is around the cementery, one of the best in the city… At night there are lot of places to eat and some night life.

Recoleta. Great markets on weekends, lots of arts and craft. Home to the famous cemetry with the Evita mausoleum, Extensive cultural centre offers something for any taste. Lots of restaurants, but not cheap. Best to have an executive menu for lunch, evenings are more expensiv

Very nice. This is an expensive residential area of Buenos Aires and it´s well worth seeing. On Sundays you find artisans selling all kinds of things in Plaza Francia, where you can also catch some live open air shows. There is also the Recoleta Cementery, also very popular. Evita is burried here and also many other important people. Nice for a walk. You can also find many restaurants in the area. It´s a nice place.
The rich area of Buenos Aires. Nice place, well maintened. A must-go place is Floralis Genérica, a huge metal flower with a nice grass park. There is the place where you rest from your trip.

my favourite place!. Just strolling along, enjoying a cool drink or a coffee, ambience is terrific at all times of day or night.... don´t miss the "feria de artesanos" on Saturdays and Sundays....masses of stalls to choose some presents to take home with you. the Pilar church with its lovely altar piece and of course the cemetery and the obliged visit to Eva Perón´s tomb... lovely shops along Alvear and Quintana and the design center and and and.....

People are dying to get in.. As cemeteries go, it's one of the better ones. Well worth wandering around for an afternoon and the surrounding area is very busy with stalls and entertainment for the tourists. When you're done walking around the cemetery you can relax on the grass outside and people watch.

Foot walk!!. Recoleta is Buenos Aires, no argue about that. A definitely must go. You'll love this safe walk around, see the buildings and check the many cafes in the neighbourhood. If you have a nice shoe, just walk. Av. Alvear and Callao are very nice. Five stars since when you go to a new city you want to see what's typical about it. You'll get that from Recoleta!

Worth stopping in. The Recoleta is good for a 30 minute stop. There are mausoleums dating back 100 years with the top Argentina political figures. The bazaar the operates out in front is much more worthwhile. Many people selling hand made crafts and a beautiful park to enjoy the day.
Extraordinary cemetary. The architecture and variety of the mausoleums make a visit as interesting as learning about all the historical personages buried there.

Lovely place to walk. We spent hours in this part of the city, it is a very safe place to walk around, meet people, go to parks, shop, grab a bite or do pretty much anything. We stopped at some cafes and enjoyed the view. We also went to the cemetery and spent a couple hours hanging out in the park. You should definitely plan to visit this part of town!

A great area to walk and window shop and to enjoy the wonderful restaurants…... It is an area or a better class neighbourhood within the city,safer to walk on the streets than other areas and where wealthy residents choose to reside with fabulous condo's and the luxury of excellent security everywhere.The shops of this area of the city cater to the well heeled individual and the restaurants abound with the local A lists,the opportunity to eat well extends to all over the city however this particular area is much more refined and well worth time to visit,an area to find amazing things and at amazing prices……...

Lovely neighborhood. We spent several days in Buenos Aires walking all over and decided this was our favorite part of the city. We felt safe and there are many cafes, restaurants, and shops for browsing.

Great area lots to do. This area is quite nice to stay in and visit lots of nice shops and restaurants.
On the weekends there is a huge street fair in the park in front of the cemetery, you might spend a couple hours there buying gifts to bring home.

A must when visiting Buenos Aires. This is the part of Buenos Aires to go on a lazy afternoon or evening to have a glass of your favourite wine or a nice whisky out in the open air next to the Recoleta park and cemetery. Not just any cemetery, it is the one where Eva Peron was entombed and the family vault is still there. Super place to visit with lots of cafes and on the weekends they have an open market (for antiques go to San Telmo on a Sunday). So enjoy the best of Buenos Aires in La Recoleta.
Lots to see and do. Check out the artisan market on Saturday and Sunday, starts at 12PM, and the hundreds of small businesses, restaurants and coffee cafes in the Recoleta area.
Recoleta. The Paris of the South. We stayed in Recoleta in a very charming apartment and loved walking the streets to eat, shop, and just browse. Lovely residential neighborhood and great restaurants

Make sure to get a guide. This place really is fascinating, but you really need a guide to get the true experience and history of the place. Ignore folks that are soliciting you a the entrance unless you truly get something like a map, but there is a plaque inside that you can look at for a map if you don't want another piece of paper to carry around.We waited a bit after waking around on our own and found a woman that gave us an hour tour for $10USD. She took us around and showed us the historically significant tombs (presidents, Eva person etc) and also told us a lot of the history around some unique architecture. We thorough enjoyed the time there with her more than if we were on our own.

Spectacular part of BA. Felt like the patrician parts of other great cities like New York or Paris. Stayed in two GREAT hotels. Loi Suites and Caesar Park that were right in heart of the barrio. Restaurants, galleries, fine food. Yum! Esp loved La Dorita. The surprise fav dinner choice.

The neighborhood to stay in!. Recolata is a great area of Buenois Aires to call home for stay. We rented a 2 bedroom apartment on Pueyrredon Avenue for les than $100 a night. There are lots of shops, ... cheese, meats, bread, pastry, wine, and many small restaurants within a 3-4 block radius. The area is safe, brightly lit busy roads.
Macabre. A visit is a must. The mausoleums in the cemetery are set in out in streets, complete with doors, windows and internal layers. Unique, yet macabre and interesting.

A great part of Buenos Aires. BA is a very, very big city with many great neighborhoods. One of the very best if Recoleta, especially the world famous cemetery. On a Saturday afternoon we had a wonderful time at the crafts, artisan market and a lunch in the biggest outside cafe, afterwards watch a couple doing tango outside. Truly spectacular day.

Must see. Beautiful area in BA. Easy to walk around in. Hard rock café and has craft market at weekends which is worth going to. A bit more upmarket souvenirs for tourists. The cemetery is a must see even if you feel it is a bit weird. Full of mausoleums that look like mini churches and cathedrals. Eva Peron buried here under her family name of Duarte. Apart from the plaque it is not as grand or inspiring as some of the others! Some really old with coffins beginning to decay, rusty doors and windows. Health and safety would have a field day. Full of history so take tour if you want to find out who's there but if you are interested in just looking and wondering then do it on your own. Would like to see the cemetery in another 100 years....

Beautiful Historic Area! Very Parisian!. Every time we come to Buenos Aires we stay in Recoleta due to its amazing vibe, great parisian style architecture and is a very safe neighbourhood.It is quite a touristy spot but is popular with the locals due to the amazing restaurants! I would recommend that anyone who is visiting Buenos Aires to at least spend half a day wondering through Recoleta!The Recoleta cemetery is a must see!
Beautiful. Beautiful neighborhood, walking distance from downtown and near Puerto Madero. Go to El Sanjuanino for empanadas.
Weird and wonderful.. Fabulous cemetery in the middle of town. It is full of huge mausoleums that will astound and amaze you with their ridiculous extravagance. Well worth a visit.

Very Fun Hustle And Bustle Area. Stayed here in 2011. It is an area with a lot of modern shops and places to eat. It is basically where you want to be if you are looking for nightlife in Buenos Aires.
Beautiful area. Lovely neighborhood. Was amazing walking around. The cemetery and trying to find Eva Peron's site took a long time. Wish we have skipped that and just walked around the area.

Very nice place to go for a walk. Walked from Sheraton to Recoleta on a saturday morning. Could have taken taxi, but weather was fine and took only 30 min to get to the church and cemetary. Nice park in area where there was art fare on saturday I went. Plus the obligatory stop at the cemetary to see Eva's tomb.
Great place to stay. Great neighborhood. Close to the center and we felt very safe. We rented movies and found a laundromat which washed our cloths very in expensively. Highly recommend.
Wonderful strolling. Recoleta is a beautiful and architectually very interesting district in Buenos Aires. A morning stroll with breakfast in a local restaurant is recomended.
One of the prettiest areas of Buenos Aires. The Recoleta area is one of my favorite parts of Buenos Aires. It presents an "artsy" look and vibe, and has some great shops, restaurants, and cafés.

Spectacular piece of history. We took an English tour for 2 hrs and the guide was full on meaningful Argentian history. Check the schedule as the tour only runs certain days....fascinating to hear and even ore fascinating to see the various styles of architecture.
Thought it would have been trendier!. The museum of art is amazing, the recoleta cemetery is a must see, the parks are nice, but it doesn't have the charm of other neighbourhoods...

cool place to visit!. This was, a few decades ago, the upscale neighborhood of the city, and it still keeps some of its old fashion magic. The streets and buildings are very very cool, with a nice architecture and all of them well kept by their owners. Here in Recoleta you will also find many options of good restaurants (although what matter is the best Ice Cream ever, Freddo!)

Paying respects. A beautiful location with some amazing final resting places to stroll around and feel the wealth that so apparently existed in BA long ago. Of course there is Evita's grave which is what most people go to see. On a hot day where a hat (big hat) and sunnies, as the sun reflects off every surface!

Older part of town with quaint streets and nice shopping. We enjoyed just walking the pretty tree lined streets and popping in the cute shops and boutiques. There are some nice cafes with tables along the street and some fancy hotels and stores. Of course we went to the famous cemetery as well which is a must see for any visitor to Buenos Aires.

Amazing Architecture. Visiting this cementery was one of the highlights of my trip. The architectural and historical value of this visit makes it so worth doing. The mausoleums and cripts are magnificent. Should have spent another hour exploring but was on a guided tour.
don't miss the cemetery. We never thought a cemetery would be so amazing to stroll through !! The area all around it is nice as well. Fun to see the buildings, parks and dog walkers.
Lovely place to eat. It has gardens on the outskirts and lovely restaurants you can smell BBQ smoke to which ever road you turn down it is also much safer than the main city centre.

Very interesting. We visited the cemetery which is quite stunning. We had a guided tour which is helpful to understand the construction there. Also, Eva Peron's burial site is there. The neighborhood is also a great place to walk and sightsee.

Eerie but WORTH IT!. Visiting a cementery may sound strange but the architectural and historical value of this visit are bar-none. The mausoleums and cripts are magnificent and the site is absolutely worth a visit. There is a famous church right next door as well.

Posh neighborhood of Buenos Aires. The area is idel to walk. I t has a shopping center "Patio Bullrich". In the area are various top hotels, parks, cafes, restaurants and the cementery is close by as well as art expositions.

Great neighborhood. Walk around this beautiful neighborhood (Quintana, Alvear, Posadas, Ayacucho, Callao, Rodriguez Peña, Montevideo and Parera St.) have a coffee at La Biela, lunch at Dos Escudos (Quintana Av.) and dinner at Piegari (the pasta restaurant at Posadas under the 9 de Julio and order Cuerdas de Guitarra a la Arriabata). You may want to buy something at the Patio Bullrich Shopping on Posadas.

Awesome to walk. If you like walking and stopping by street side restaurants, taking in a bit of shopping and some sightseeing without having to spend too much time, this area will ensure your day is well spent. From mini mercados to souvenir shops to weekend artisan markets ( Sunday only in feria style on the street), this area has it all. By day, walk to the cemetary, see the famous graves and head to one of the restaurants just outside - from Italian bistros to German, Victorian themed and regular cafe's - for brunch and then walk around the bustling streets until sundown when one of the many bars in the area can be tried. Hard rock cafe is in the area too. All in all a nice neighbourhood.
A must to see. I would say this is a must see in Buenos Aires. The mausoleums are quite beautiful and moving. It is also amazing to walk through so much history there. Very moving for sure
Not just a cemetery. nice neighbourhood great cafe's micro brewery but the cemetery is definitely worth the walk Eva peron's remains were brought back here

Amazing and HUGE!. Place was huge and amazing! Went to have a look around and see Eva peron of course, not sure how i felt about the markets being outside of a cemetery, but had a look through nontheless!

Recoleta Cemetery. This was a highlight of our trip. Recoleta is much like Paris' Pere LaChaise Cemetery. It is smaller and in most ares better maintained though. In addition to the most famous crypt, Eva Duarte Peron, there are many for Argentine presidents, captains of industry, religious figures, and others of import. It was a wonderful way to wander around in peace and quiet in the middle of the bustling city and see a lot of interesting things. It's very close to one of the hop-on, hop-off bus stops and a tourist office.There is no admission fee and a very good map is available at the gate for a very small price. Guides are available for very reasonable prices. I would definitely visit again and spend much more time.

May be touristy, but still beautiful and worth a visit. I'm not really a morbid person, but whenever I travel I am always fascinated by how different cultures cemeteries look. They can say such interesting things about the people of that culture. So although Recoleta does not necessarily reflect the final resting place of most everyday Argentinians, it still shows the beauty and detail that Buenos Aires is full of. Great area around too, with plenty of shops and restaurants. Easy to get to!
Good stop in BA. Great cemetery in a cool neighborhood. Worth a stop for the layout and some history. We made it part of the city bus tour so we could catch another bus every 20 minutes or so.

Nicer area of BA!. Fun, and gimmicky area and very touristy. Recommend staying in Recoleta only 3 days, then move hotels to Palermo or Palermo Soho hotel so you get feel of a real BA neighborhood as opposed to very tourist area.
The place to be !!. This is where the money lives and where those with the money stay....A very nice few blocks of interesting architecture splattered with boutique and high end brand shops...

safe, up market. Equivalent to New York's upper east side and London's Chelsea, but with an Argentine spin. Safe to walk the streets at night. The restaurants around the cementary are a bit pricy and touristy, but many good ones in the general area. The parks are beautiful and well kept.

So glamorous & stylish!. La Recoleta is a downtown residential neighborhood in Buenos Aires. It is an area characterized by glamorous architecture. It is full of history and it is the cultural center of the city as well.Its name has its origins in the Monastery of The Recollect Fathers (Franciscan Order) who arrived at the area in the early 18th century. Those priests founded a monastery, a church dedicated to Nuestra Señora del Pilar and a cemetery attached to the complex, still proudly standing defying the passing of time. La Recoleta boasts of many “mosts”: the Alvear Palace Hotel, the most sumptuous in all of Latin America, the Cemetery, comparable to the one in Paris, and among the most sumptuous in the world, huge and luxurious private family mansions, foreign embassies, elegant modern constructions, etc.  What you can visit: the National Fine Arts Museum, the National Library , the Recoleta Cultural Center, the Recoleta Cemetery (where Eva perón’s tomb is located), the Palais de Glace, Libertador Avenue, Carlos Thays Park, many University Colleges : of Law, of Medicine, of Dentistry, of Pharmacy and Biochemistry, the newly opened Recoleta Mall, La Biela Bar (one of the most traditional in Bs As), great sculptures, the Floralis Genérica, Alvear Avenue (with great examples of “chateaux”, Parisian style petit hotels, the Palacio Duhau, the Nunciature of the Vatican, the French Embassy, the Brazilian Embassy, the Jockey Club, the Buenos Aires Design Shopping Center, Francia Square (with an amazing monument given by the French people to Argentina on the 100th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence). Other green spaces not to be missed: , the República Federativa do Brasil Park, Rubén Darío Square, República Oriental del Uruguay Square, Dante Alighieri Square … the list seems to be endless.A special mention for the restaurants, bars and discos in the area: among the finest in Buenos Aires. Tango shows, excellent beefs, delicious Argentinian wines from Mendoza and Cafallate. What else can you ask for?Buenos Aires has often been referred to as the "Paris of South America". La Recoleta pays homage to this nickname!A pleasure to walk in the neighbourhood, its glamorous roads and tree-lined avenues.

nice food and entertainment specially on weekend.. there is handcraft market on Saturday and Sunday, also lots of live music and street performance. The Tango dance usually get most of the audience attention :)

Upscale. I live in Ricoletta @ 4 months per year. it is an upscale neighborhood with beautiful builds, good parks, monuments at every turn and museum everywhere.
