The center of Ricoletta is the Cementerio ...I know, strangle but it is one of the top sights in BA. Nice place to spend a day exploring.

Amazing Cemetery.. Spent a few hours wondering around the Recoleta Cemetery during our visit to Buenos Aires. It is a place that should not be missed. The rows and rows of tombs, crypts and mausoleums from the plain to the most ornate. well worth the time. There was a lady at the entrance, who worked as a volunteer for the Cemetery Association, selling maps of the Cemetery. Well worth the 10 pesos.

Just go!. Cemeteries are not on everybody's favourite things to do on holiday..there are the greats in Paris and London, however the Duarte family tomb for their Eva is simple in marked contrast to the opulent mausoleums close by.....quite wonderful Sunday morning stroll and popular.

Main tourist area in Old Buenos Aires.. Lots of action and nightlife in the main tourist area of Buenos Aires. Bars, restaurants, night clubs, shopping. One of the more expensive areas in Buenos Aires, but on weekends the park turns into a craft store mecca where handmade goods are sold.

Fun times. The Recoleta has wonderful restaurant, all levels. From great inexpensive empanadas at San Juanita, a bit more mid range for a great steak experience at La Dorita, to a five stars at the Hyatt restaurant, the Duhau restaurant with an amazing garden.

Mistery, history and shopping. La Recoleta is everything on Sundays, from history at the cementery and La Piedad Church to art at the Museum of Contemporary art to high value shopping or some good priced hand craft in the plaza. It is a good visit if you start early in the morning and stay for dinner in one of their picadas places.

the place to stay. lots of cafes, restaurants,shops, the art fair on weekends,be there!Two shoppings, the new one in front at the cemitery, the Patio Burlich, the restaurants in front at the four season.
Fancy. Great neighborhood. Quiet, clean and of a high standard. Close to major attractions. I was able to walk to many places. Felt very safe and comfortable.

Quiet and lovely. Even during the winter months this a beautiful part of Buenos Aires. The streets are clean and quieter than in other parts of the city. There are great small restaurants and of course a visit to the beautiful cemetery is a must!

Recoleta area of Buenos Ayres. A green area of Buenos Ayres featuring the large cemetary which is worth a visit. There is a shopping mall nearby and a large selection of fashion shops and restaurants.

too crowded. too crowded.
Not well organized. Too many shops. Too many...I like the open place we once had, now it is like a shopping mall to open skies. we need to organize our parks in a way those who want to just sit on the grass are not going to hang ourselves from a tree...
Well, it is my experience..

Walk about. Leafy and calm. Then the frenzy of the Recoleta Craft Market on weekends. Recoleta Cemetery is another world. Visit Evita's final resting place. Great little restaurants and cafes to pop into.

if I had to buy a flat ...it would be in recoleta. Hermes, Louis Vuitton Arandu , the Alvear Hotel ...all the best places to shop, to eat and sleep. this is the best place where you want to walk around, to stroll or shop. As I said, this is really the place to be when you are in BA.

Atmospherically beautiful 'resting' place...... I personally find cemeteries fascinating because having a place to ‘rest’ is a natural progression for everyone in life’s journey. How people remember loved ones of both genders, past Presidents, the rich, the famous, scholars, national heroes etc are exemplified in La Recoleta Cemetery.If you can call a burial ground atmospherically beautiful then we found it here in the hundreds upon hundreds of elaborately vaulted above ground tombs – a huge number decorated with statues. Built initially around a convent and church in 1732 (Our Lady of Pilar), it gave way eventually to this enormous public cemetery. Nearly a hundred of these tombs are deemed National Historical Monuments but many others have fallen into disrepair - families run out of money, dynasties disappear and in places coffins are exposed.The ominous entry façade has Doric columns, Neo – Classical style architecture and as you look up before entering a Latin inscription Expectamus Dominum (Waiting For Our Saviour?) gives you an idea of what lies ahead.The main tree lined walkways has a perplexing number of labyrinthine sidewalks on the left and right.These are filled with mausoleums & tombs interred with the wealthy or adored which is why most visitors come to see Eva Perón's resting place in the Duarte family vault – just follow the groups. Unless you have a map of the cemetery, then it becomes overwhelmingly confusing - you can get lost.The entry office has a free photocopied map to locate some of the most ‘famous’ tombs or if you have a photographic memory, a wall map is also near the entry - take a snap on your phone.We were in awe of these sculptured masterpieces located around every corner or sidewalk but take some water, as it gets hot in here. However, like any famous ‘attraction’, a couple of good cafes and souvenir kiosks are outside near a lovely open space. Entrance is free, open daily 7am – 6pm – not a place for after dark as with most cemeteries they have some 'ghost' stories!We loved it!Enjoy your experience!

Nice walk. If you feel like ambrace the city and the magnificent architecture, and feel safe at the same time!!! this is the hood!!! just be cafull of the side walk cause is bumppy and a few dogs are leaving their "gift" everywhere. Use comfy shoes bring your camera and enjoy!!!
Worth Viewing. The beauty of life remembered and fine art displayed free for all to see. Come early as it closed at 5pm

Great place if you like cemetery's. Fantastic cemetery Lovely tombs and ornate mosuleumsMany coffins visable as designed that way Evita perons grave hereFree to enterNot far from centreCheap taxisBargain price first thoughNice city to visit Great steak!Recommended

Cemetery: Breathtaking and truly moving. As morbid as it sounds, this is an absolutely must see. Go and relax and be respectful as you let the very special feeling of the cemetry wash over you. I was moved to tears walking into the cemetwry. You will have no option but to be quiet and to wander in awe of the beautiful crypts.

Good place to stay in BA. Many hotel options, walking distance to restaurants . Because of it's central location you can walk to Palermo, Florida and puerto madero.
Some areas remind Paris!!!
Also malls and fancy stores.

With Parissian similitudes.... Recoleta district has similarities with Paris. But Paris is Paris, no doubt.
Top points to visit: Plaza Francia weekend craft fair, Alvear avenue and Hotel, Guido street and restaurants, Buenos Aires Design center and the Cemetery, here you have guided visits (find out in advance).

The "posh" side of town.... I booked an exclusive apartment/suite in Recoleta, Buenos Aires after reading reviews about this place being safe to walk around especially at night. I enjoyed this area, it was close enough to walk to the places I needed close by though if I were to come back, I think I would have selected Palermo as my first option as its more vibey and is not as inflated as the restaurants, panderias, mercados and parilla's as Recoleta. Older people who have lots of money hang out in Recoleta at night.... (Just an observation)Still enjoyed my location but if you're looking for a bustling ambiance, Recoleta is not the place for you.

Fantastic Tour. I went with two other co-workers, and we ended up deciding to use on of those "Free Tours", and we were SO SO glad we did. For you English speakers, look for Simon Gadson. He was fantastic, well worth the $20 tip. Simon knew stories behind the more interesting tombs, and brought us to others we wouldn't have even had a chance to think about looking for. It was a great tour, I highly recommend!

Recoleta Cemetary. We took a walking tour (english) with a man named Simon- he offers free walking tours (you just tip) and we found him outside the cemetary at 11am on Tuesday. I wouldn't have enjoyed the cemetary as much without the tour. He offered a lot of interesting stories and explained a lot of the history.

ONE OF THE NICEST QUARTERS IN TOWN. An active cemetery, circled by a brick-made wall (with almost military details) surrounded by restaurants, cafés, night-clubs and shopping-centers? Yes, that can only happen here! The cemetery houses an incredible collection of familiar tombs in all imaginable architectural styles recorded in human history. Evita Perón`s body is here, and so most of Argentinean figures and aristocrats. Excellent food and wine is found in cozy places (for all pockets, for there are pizza parlors too) all around the high red walls. Very nice parks surround the place, which also houses an interesting cultural center, and a recycled monastery, today a lovely food and shops place. From it`s top, the imposing building of the University of Buenos Aires Law School, can be sighted.

beautiful scenery, lovely atmosphere. It was definately one of the best days of my trip to Buenos Aires. the Recoleta Cemetery is a must-see! the tombs are beautifully decorated with sculptures, and everywhere you look there's something nice to appreciate. Lovely art fair on saturdays!
Chic Neighborhood. Recoleta has something for everyone and it is all with a few blocks walk--be it an upscale shop, top restaurant, local food, antiques, museums, you can find it easily and safely.
Good weekend market. Interesting area, large weekend market after midday Saturday, near to the cemetery, the tulip, Hard Rock cafe and other eateries.
Wonderful neighborhood. We rented an apartment in La Recoleta. It is a wonderful neighborhood with the old BA charm. Full of excellent restaurants, shops, and safe.

Beautiful neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Take a stroll, immerse yourself in the sounds and sights. I was lucky enough to walk through the streets and found tango performance by dancers in training. If you visit the Plaza Intendente Alvear not only will you find many crafts and local artisans, but also free performances. There is also the Recoleta Cemetery where you will find Evita Duarte Peron's tomb. If not, just enjoy the French architecture. Beautiful neighborhood.
Haunting and Beautiful. This is a magic place where you can get lost in the History of Argentina. It is the case that great art and statuary can often be found in graveyards and this is no exception.

One of the nicer areas of Buenos Aires. The artisan market I saw on the weekend, combined with the cemetery where Evita is interred, count for some of the appeal of Recoleta, while the green space and the museums help, as well. Cleaner and more open than most of BA, Recoleta feels safe.
recoleta. same as cemetery, please see above. we only went to the cemetery, church, flea market and had a drink at starbucks. there is a large shopping centre there too

Recoleta Cementerio. The cemetery is legendary and lives up to its reputation. What a unique experience. Even if you are not familiar with the names, the architecture and atmosphere of the cemetery are enthralling. And the resident cats living there keep it light and lively. I definitely recommend going there!

Upscale Neighbourhood. Once all of BsAs was like this - clean, broad even pavements, well-kept buildings, chic boutiques - they say. Not everywhere can be upscale, but it's a relief to walk without fear of breaking your ankles. Why come here? Apart from Cementerio de la Recoleta - well worth a visit, the nation's history written in stone - and its surrounding green spaces, there's the adjacent Nuestra Senora del Pilar convent church, plus craft market, the nearby Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes (MNBA), and the Buenos Aires Design home goods shopping centre. Have a coffee at La Biela on the corner while you plan your stroll. Or come back for lunch at one of the restaurants on the same south-west side of the plaza.

Beautiful architecture and history combined!. This is an interesting site to visit while in BA, even if you're not a big fan of art and architecture. Recoleta's cemetery is voted one of the most important in the world, for both historical and artistic characteristics. There you will find the crypts of important political, cultural, and historical figures of Argentina. The neighborhood is quite charming with a great variety of restaurants.

Don't miss this. Very unique and wonderful cemetery. It is important to take the time to walk through the many pathways. Thankfully I had a tour guide, Carina Alejandra, who shared with me the special stories and took me to all the key spots. What a special place, one I'm sure has many photo opportunities if I could've spent more time.
Fascinating!. Didn't know you could buy grave sites for $60K. Families owned their own little "crypts". Get a tour guide if you are walking in yourself. It is worth it!

Recoleta, where Evita sleeps. A wonderful study of architecture and stone angels. Very quiet, beautiful, unusual. A must see for visiting Buenos Aires, we took the self tour and were satisfied with the results.

Snazziest cemetery in the world... Market was brilliant!. We spent easily 3 hours today wandering through the artisans' market. Markets everywhere in the world tend to be same same (but same). This was an amazing artisans market - the jewelly was different, the crafts were different, the bags were different stunning leather, different designs, rustic through to high quality through to cute coin purses for US$3. AND look out for nifty coin based jewelley for very little dosh - great rings and pendants for US$5-6each - at almost every stall we were delighted. Look out for very inexpensive jewellery in "Alpaca" - no - not the woolly cutie pies from Peru - it is basically a base metal/stainless steel or like the old EPNS cuttlery you might have from your granny.... you might pay US$1-2 for a ring. Lots of silver - "Plata" 925/950/1000 (the good stuff). It's been a long time since we enjoyed a market so much. And a great many countries. Look out for fine jewellery also... handmade, highly polished silver rings set with precious stones from garnets through to emeralds.... US$60-200. Cemetery was also great. The rock concert next door certainly can't disturb the neighbours...Ignore the opportunistic gits at the gate who tell you entry is free then give you handwritten directions to Mme Peron's tomb. Then ask for money. Jeez... follow your nose (and the thousands of tourists) and if you like kitty cats, get the camera onto black & white and prepare for some classic shots.

Interesting walk. We arrived at the cemetery thinking we would quickly walk through and find Evita's crypt and go. It was really an interesting place so we ended up walking around for a couple hours. Coming in the entrance we were approached by multiple people wanting a donation for their cause. One volunteered wanted me to buy a map for $2 USD. I didn't really see any need since I didn't know anyone other than Evita. The volunteer was very mad at me and made me feel bad for a moment. I think if I went again, I would just push past all the people wanting donations. To find Evita's crypt you should remember she was Eva Duarte and she is in the Duarte family crypt. It is rather inconspicuous. It is worth the walk and the more time you spend there the less creepy it will feel.

Evita Peron, Markets, Cafe Monet. Went to Recoleta cemetary...unfortunately, only tour available for English speakers was on Tuesday morning (11am) and I was there Saturday. Able to find Evita Peron memorial, but really needed a guide to talk about the other parts of the cemetary. The market was excellent, with some interesting products.......alot of the things looked like they were genuinely handmade and not mass produced. And about a block away from square and cemetary is the Cafe Monet..........good food, lots of locals and very reasonably priced.

A Good Location to Stay and Visit. We stayed at Loi Suites Recoleta which was a great area and a safe area to stay and visit. We were able to walk to most attractions of interest including to Recoleta Cemetery where there was an abundance of history. The nearby Parks also made for a pleasant walk.

nice neighbourhood to walk through. A nice neighbourhood to walk through. A more expensive/luxurious region of the city. Has the historic Recoleta cemetary. Mall in Recoleta as well (with expensive stores). A quote from a tour book - "heavily made up ladies in their fur coats walking tiny dogs on Channel leashes"

My favorite spot in Argentina. Recoleta is a great place to walk around and buy souvenirs. Make sure to go to the feria on the weekends. They have a large selection of things to bring back as souvenirs. The Recoleta Cementary is beautiful as well and free!

rough around the edges. The inflation and overall economic woes of Argentina have taken its toll. The sidewalks are dirty and in a terrible state of repair. Everybody walkes around with a worried look on their faces. Customer service in the shops is almost non existent.

Take your breath away... WOW..I have never seen anything like this before. This place blew my mind. A city of the dead with so many stories. Potentially can spend hours in here just looking through the fine work and admiring the beauty of each tomb. Make sure to take the free tour. I belive every tuesday and thursdays from 11AM in English. Went to Recoleta twice and can go once more if I get the time. Very beautiful and highly recommended. I don't think I can see this kind of grand Cemetery anywhere else in the World.

Historical area. Perfect area to stay in. Clean and felt very safe. Tour of the cemetery is worth the time and money. Evening walking tour is also very interesting and enjoyable. No charge but strong arm donation at the end -- worth it anyway.

Well Worth Seeing. The Recoleta area itself has the feel of an upscale Paris neighborhood. It's a pleasant place for a stroll. The cemetery is clearly the high point. The ornate mausoleums are not only sights in their own rights but give you a good insight in to the nature of the culture of the Argentinian upper classes. Try to visit when there's a craft market going on.
NIce area to wander around. Good shops, nice restaurants with outdoor seating and of course, don't go without a walk around the cemetery.

Nice place to relax especially on weekends!. There's a nadcraft market on weekends where you can negociate and buy some great leather goods and souvenirs; they're not happy about negociating but they will be a lot more friendly if you have dollars as it's very hard for them to buy foreign currency.

cool neighborhood. one of the areas worth visiting in Buenos Aires. has more than just a historic luxurious cemetary. the neighborhood itself is cool and pretty to hang around with friends, sit in a cafe or in Freddo(one of the best ice cream places), or just chill on the grass on a sunday. don't miss the huge tree located not far from the cemetary.

Stroll through the weekend market. The vendors are friendly but not pushy and have a variety of items to offer. I purchased recycled glass earrings, caramel nuts, and empanadas. The Floralis Generica is across the street so it's worth walking across the colorful bridge. Enjoy!

Classic!. I just love walking around Recoleta suburb and see the windows or even seat in a place for a bubbles ahahah, in a sunny afternoon! Seriously!? It's a must to enjoy, guys if you love Buenos Aires and know about its history you would feel very nice doing simple things and you feel special in this lovely city.

Loved the Recoleta neighborhood. We stayed in Recoleta for four nights in April 2013 (at the Intersur Recoleta hotel which we loved) and really enjoyed this neighborhood.Not only did we feel safe, we were close to the Recoleta Cemetary, the Sunday art fair and lots of restaurants/cafes. We also felt like we were in an area that was less touristry than the area near Avenida Florida where a friend of ours was staying. If visiting Buenos Aires again, we'd definitely stay in Recoleta.

A little morbid but very interesting. It seems weird to visit a cemetery on your vacation, but it was really interesting to see all the elaborate monuments that were built for the people interred here. We did visit Evita's tomb, and it was a little difficult to find as it's down one of the "side streets". We caught the tail end of the English tour offered and I wish we would have been able to hear the whole tour as what we heard was interesting. I think the English tours are offered on Tues and Thurs at 11am. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful area of BA. Nice plaza, nice market on the weekend. Many nice malls nearby as well as beautiful attractions. Easy to get to. Nice church and cemetery nearby.

elegance. Very elegant district with some exclusive shopping. Perfect if you are needing to fit out your string of polo ponies, but great also for fashion. Great restaurants. Don't miss La Biela for coffee. The cemetery is impressive and you can find Eva Peron's mausoleum there under her family name Duarte. Historic church nearby.
Beautiful neighborhood. Loved walking through Recoletta Cemetery, despite the rain. Also, some there is high-end, very authentic shopping in the area.
Silent village. You must go early in the morning and buy the book of the Recoleta with the map so you can walk and read everything about this place.
Safest area in B.A.. Good location. Near the cemetery museums and shops. This is where the Park Hyatt, the Four Seasons and Alvear Palace are located.
Great place for taking photographs. Loved it, great area to hang out in for the day. I could spend hours here photographing the cemetery and especially Evita's tomb.

Great place to spend the day. Recoleta reminded us of a little suburb of Paris. Really beautiful and lots of nice cafes if you wonder far enough from the main tourist drag (i.e. where the cemetery is). Recoleta easily takes up a day of one's time, especially if art is of interest. We want on Saturday when there was a market around the park. It was quite busy so don't go on a Sat if you like the peace and quiet!

my favourite place in BA. LOVE THE AREA! just get lost and discover the amazing architecture. very french style!do not miss: La Biela cafe one of the oldest in the area and famous because Borges and other personalities used to go there.The cemetery where evita peron tomb is.also nice cultural centre near by
If you don't mind visiting a cemetery.... It is an amazing place, very unusual type of cemetery. It could have better maintenance, but all in all it was worth a visit.
Little France in BA. You can't miss this posh district if you are in BA and if you can afford it, book a hotel in this area.

RECOLETA GO ON WEEK ENDS. Recoleta is only worthy to visit the week ends, rstaurants are no longer fancy, too tourist Iglesia del Pilar colonial is oka, but again go on week ends there is a fair around

The Parisian district of Buenos Aires. Whilst the cemetery is the main attraction in Recoleta , the surrounding area has a very Parisian theme to it. Next to the cemetery is a very beautiful, well-kept 18th parish. It is immaculate and I definitely recommend you go in. Not far from the cemetery is a modern mall with a big McDonald’s on the ground floor.

The best place to "be" in Buenos Aires. If you can afford a good hotel in this district , such as the Gran Hotel Buenos Aires or the Hyatt ,this is absolutely the best area in which to stay for a few days. Apart from the famous (notorious?) Recoleta Cemetery, the entire barrio is great for strolling, upmarket shopping, street cafes and restaurants. It is also surprisingly easy to get to other parts of the city by taxi (of which there are hundreds). At present (mid-May) you can double your money by buying pesos on the blue market...hence everything is virtually half price for tourists with foreign currency. US dollar is around 5.5 pesos at official rate and 9.6 on the parallel market. Mind you they do not do blue market currency swaps in the hotels. Now is the time to go!!!!!
Nice and safe neighbourhood. Good high class neighborhood, many international brands and shops. Good for shopping on a high budged.
Outdoor dining.. Liked the Famous cemetary - lovely lunch- Eva Peron- small indoor mall. Bring US dollars! A lot of them, do business in dollars and save a lot of money.
Bs As's best!. Recoleta concentrates the best of the best in Bs As. From the beautiful streets Alvear and Quintana avenue to the upscale shops and restaurants, this is the place to be!
Great area. This is one of the best areas of Buenos Aires. Stayed right in the Recoleta, nice restaurant, shops and sightseeing.
A Bit of History. It's lovely walking around in this part of the neighbourhood, some lovely old buildings which are well kept. It's old mixed with the new (my favourite kind).

Just an awe inspiring place with all the marble and granite.. Loved looking back into history and how wonderful the craftsman were that made these huge mausoleums. They had such talent, and to see everything still perserved after all this time AMAZING

Gorgeous neighborhood.... We stayed at the Park Hyatt in Recoleta and found the area to be fantastic. Lot's of history with the many mansions reflecting BA's past, mixed with plenty of upscale shops and restaurants. It is also an active neighborhood with local restaurants where no one speaks English, but where the locals are so friendly you feel right at home. This is by far the only neighborhood worth seeing in BA, but it's definitely one you need to spend time in. Oh yea...don't forget to visit the cemetery in Recoleta where Eva Peron rests. Kind of weird seeing peoples caskets in their crypts, but again, a part of BA that is a must see.

Lots of handicraft stuff to buy. Good place to visit if you enjoy the street market to get handicrafts from locals. Pretty far from subway so I would recommend taking tourist bus or expect to have a long walk from the closest subway station.

Bring your wallet - great boutiques!. We are staying at the beautiful Park Hyatt Palace in Recoleta and have had time to explore this beautiful neighborhood. If you are looking for Hermes, Louis V and those types of boutiques this is your place. Lovely to walk around, people watch and shop.

Lovely leafy neighbourhood with great facilities around. Beautiful parks, great selection of restaurants, and of course the famous Recoleta Cemetery where you will find the final resting place of Eva Peron.
Interesting history. Unique place.. Get a tour guide if you can, then wander around to take more in. Visit the next door old church. You won't see something like this many other places in the world.

The dead centre of Buenos Aires!. I didn't expect a visit to a cemetery on my holiday, so was a bit surprised when the guide took me to one. Interesting, but a bit weird. Massive marble coffin houses for the rich and famous of the city. Evita Peron is buried there.

Ritzy neighbourhood reminiscent of la Rive Gauche, perfect for a Sunday afternoon. Beautiful, Paris-inspired architecture. Safe streets free of graffiti. Upscale shops and hotels. Clear, evenly paved sidewalks. When people call Buenos Aires the "Paris of South America," they are referring to Recoleta. (I actually think the rest of BsAs resembles Lisboa very closely.)Come on a Sunday afternoon. Take the Subte to Callao station. Stroll down the luxurious streets, have a coffee or helado before heading to the Recoleta Fair in front of the cemetery. Browse the local artisan kiosks and pick up a few souvenirs. Do a quick walk-through of the Cultural Centre, and then head for the cemetery just before sundown. When you're done, head to one of the main streets and hail a cab for a ride back to the city where the more affordable hotels are.

Riches of Buenos Aires on display. Recoleta is a rich neighbourhood and it shows. The most luxurious hotels, fancy shops and shopping malls as well as restaurants are here and of course the rich grand houses and the tree lines streets. It is a very safe neighbourhood and it is worth a stroll on a nice sunny day.

Don't just go for Evita's tomb. Too many tourists asking where Evita is buried and crowding round that tomb. We spent our first hour here looking at the fascinating tombs of prominent Buenos Aires citizens. Don't fall for the scam artists outside the entrance, even if they show you a badge. Wait till you get inside and then buy the map from the official volunteers - you will need it! Then go and have a drink at one of the cafes across the park, as they are really good, and not that much overpriced considering the location. Take bug spray, as there are mosquitos in the water used for the flowers placed on the graves.

We're in the money!. You can see how the riches used to live (and are still living.) The buildings are gorgeous. It's definitely the quiter of the neighborhoods we visited in Buenos Aires. A break for beverages at La Biela is a must. Good spot to people watch as well.

A little bit fancy. This suburb is a bit upmarket so clean, tidy and safe to walk around. I felt very comfortable staying here and was able to walk to all the attractions I wanted to see, with the furthest being about a 20 min walk away. Now that I am familiar with most of the suburbs, I still think Recoleta would my preference.
One of my favorites places. History. Elegance. Perfume. And the Cementery. It was my favorite place in Buenos Aires. Next time I will choose an hotel at this area.
SAFE AREA. In a quiet, safe area with cobbled streets. Several bars/restaurants/shops etc. Recoleta Cemetery well worth a visit.

Recoleta Cemetary - Don't miss it!. Not your ordinary cemetery. The mausoleums and tombs at the famous Recoleta cemetery are stunning. Plan at least three hours to walk around the 13+ acres. If you are a photography enthusiast, don't forget your camera! Each mausoleum seems to tell a story with it's beautiful grand statuary. Entrance and scheduled tours are free; find a local guide book for information. Don't miss the tomb of Luis Angel Firpo and of course, the Duarte family where Evita lays to rest.

lovely part of buenos aires. We stayed in Recoleta and loved the area. It is very handy for walking or taxi to the rest of the city. It felt very safe was very clean and lots of great restaurants/cafe's to frequent. Wouldn't stay anywhere else!

Interesting to visit a cemetary and Evita.... Located in Recoleta, Buenos Aires, this unique cemetery is the final resting place for notables - especially the Duartes (Eva and Juan Peron). If you are staying in Recoleta, it's worth a quick visit to see history - if not you are NOT missing much. They still leave flowers their on a daily basis.

A cluster of tiny crypts. Pretty enough crypts, some the size of a cupboard all squeezed in together. Everyone goes there to see Evita's grave, however it's for who she was, not because it's bigger or much prettier than the others. There are no directions to you either need to have someone show you where it is or spot the cluster of tourists in the distance and run after them.

One side of the living spectrum in Buenos Aires.. This is a beautiful area of Buenos Aires and certainly an area to visit but only one side of the spectrum of this city. If one stays here make certain to go to the other areas of the city to see how the majority of people live.

Beautiful and historic. This is a not-to-be-missed attraction. It's so interesting with so much history - Evita and Juan Peron to name just a few of those buried there. It's very quiet with winding little walkways. Be sure to take your camera - especially if you love doors. We went with a guide and it was worth the expense.

Reserved Recoleta. Recoleta is a nice area, very European with its tree lined streets and beautiful architecture. However there's not a great deal to do. Recoleta Cemetery is fascinating but that's about it. Shopping is average and very expensive. There's a few good restaurants around. We enjoyed it but expected a bit more. We stayed here a week and was a bit bored by the end of it.

Sculpture & Marble. The cemetery is rows of mausoleums that tower one and two stories high. It is impossible to photograph the scale of the place because these mini buildings are so close together...I had the sense of the power of love that the heirs had for these people, their families and their legacies. Eva Peron is the most contemporary and controversial. She is buried here in her family's plot - or place.

Charming. A Charming location with many interesting atractives. Nearby there is the charming Recoleta Cemetery ,where is buried Evita. There are a Mall and tradicional restaurants too. An old church and a cultural center complete the tour .

A welcome relief. After two weeks in San Telmo, I thought Recoleta was just lovely. It evoked a major European city, with many buildings in the French style. It was clean, with wide sidewalks for strolling, upmarket and gracious. It's very close to the centre of the city and you can even walk there if you cared to. There are plenty of small shops, boutiques, eateries and supermarkets around. Plus, there are many attractions nearby, such as Recoleta Cemetary, where Eva Peron is buried, the local weekend artisan's market, with interesting innovative wares, pretty parklands with lots of statuary and public art, galleries and the famous giant Floralis Generica, the huge stainless steel flower, which opens and closes like a daisy, according to the sun patterns. It may be a bit more costly than other parts of BsAs, but not outrageously so. The exception is Recoleta Mall and particularly Patio Bullrich for outrageously expensive shopping and gawping at wealthy women, wearing lots of peroxide hair and fake leopard skin. I could only afford an expensive coffee at Patio Bullrich, priced at three times the going rate outside, for the same standard.The area is well maintained and safe to stroll in at night. People often say that San Telmo is the "real Buenos Aires", but, as I have commented elsewhere, i don't know why some people think that you need dirt, grime, decay and menace to have a real experience. I'm sure that Recoleta residents think their lives are just as real. The famous La Biela cafe is there and is open till about 2am. I went there on foot several times late at night quite happily.If I went back to BsAs, i would choose Recoleta again.
Always nice. Take a nice stroll here and relax. You can enjoy a lovely atmosphere. It is always nice to be back to wander around this place.

Wonderful. stayed in the area for 2 weeks. Walked and saw everything. Safe at night as we went out often.
Careful with sidewalks as not maintained well in some parts.
Amazing place. The cemetry is a very unique experience. It's not so much a graveyard as a "small city". Definitely worth visiting.

Residential area. Recoleta is a fashionable up scale residential area with many beautifull European styled buildings drowing is a sea of modern appartment/condos. Take the time to stoll through this neighbourhood and watch the life of its residents unfold before your eyes. Stop at a local coffee shop. Or walk down Avear to the park where there is a market on the weekend.
Elegant. Elegant european style area in the french style. Tranquil green spaces. The buildings are the highlight along with Eva Peron's grave.

Cool find. If you're wandering around Recoleta, there's a shop called 30 Quarenta at Arroyo 890, filled with old toys that have been turned into lamps and furniture. It's like a walk down memory lane with memories given new life. The owner, Miguel and all the shop assistants speak English. I bought an old poster and wish I had room for one of the lamps made from children's blocks. A cool find.

Best neighborhood in BA!. Really the best place to stay and visit in BA. Very safe , very pretty, and lots of history. Don't miss Recoleta cemetery, La Biela for lunch, the restaurant street nearby especially Piegari, and the market on the square on weekends.

Family Place to Stay and/or Visit. Recoleta is well known by Evita's cemetery. But it's not all. It has a rich night, a lot of restaurants and pubs, Hard Rock cafe, a Mall, a design shopping, a lot of coffee shops, Ferrari, Mont Blanc and other boutiques.On Saturday and Sunday there are a market-place for handicraft and local sales person. A nice place to visit.There are two winnery shops there. If ou want o buy a good wine do so at the one iin the mall, not the one at Junin street. The wines at this particular store are cheaper, but they get sun light directly, what make them taste quite odd.

Visit the cemetary. We have visited the Area which is quite dinamic the week end with a market and artists performing in the park. It is worth visiting the cemetary. Some people have built fanatastic monument for life after death !

Recoleta Walking Tour Including Cemetary. This area is well worth a visit. Wander the streets that still house beautiful old mansions, embassies and art galleries. A visit with English speaking guide of Recoleta Cemetery to see the resting places of the rich and famous including Eva Peron (Evita) is also worth the hour that it takes. A 1/2 day walking tour of Recoleta is highly recommended.

Love It. This is an historic and beautiful area. I particularly enjoy the open market which opens on the weekend. There you can find handcrafted items, food and entertainment. Within an easy walk, near the park, is a great little pizza shop.
Wonderful. Our visit to the cemetery was terrific and enlightening. We also spent time at the National Museum of Fine Arts, which was great. A fun area to walk and that was what we did.
A must see. Probably the best site to visit in BA. We used a local guide to see ad understand the various tombs. Would highly recommend doing the same.

City of the Dead Show-Offs. This cemetery carries oneupmanship beyond the grave. Several square blocks tight-packed with funerary monuments, mostly in black granite; friends of the deceased have sometimes added bronze plaques.

Exquisite mausoleums...fabulous modern art...and a basilica older than Buenos Aires. You get it all in Recoleta...the cemetery, an absolutely delightful old convent that has been turned into the most fascinating contemporary arts center and a Basilica that was built long before anything else. If you are looking for Eva Peron's tomb, she is buried with her family...look for a plain black granite faced mausoleum with Familia Duarte on top. It is easy to spot no matter what time of year you visit...someone has left fresh flowers and notes. She is still their St. Evita.

Tango and Evita. well worth a visit - this is the upscale part of BA. Lots of shopping and beautiful homes (palaces, actually). Eva Peron is buried in the cemetary there but make sure you inderstand where you are going, easy to get lost. There is a map at the entry - use it! Tango dancing under the giant rubber tree and craft stalls on weekends.

Not enough time to spend here. Lots of street vendors, musicians, artists, food vendors. Places to sit and people-watch. The cemetary is fun to walk around though when we got there we couldn't find any maps. There are tours going on in different languages. For those who need their Hard Rock Cafe or their Starbucks, you can find those here.
Tireless.... I don't think you could ever get tired of wandering around Recoleta. Always something new to discover.

Cemetery a must. We spent over an hour at the cemetery with an English speaking guide. To just walk around on your own does not give you a true overview of what you are looking at. It is a must see though, there is so much history.

A memory of the golden ages of Argentina. Just clean,elegant, french, european, place full of history. As my local guide told me all about the golden ages I could imagine how was it throught the architecture and the cementery.
Recoleta Cemetery. What a terrific cemetery! I've never seen anything like it. Eva Peron's tomb very plain but others were so elaborate

Fantastic Modern Art Gallery. The area was shown on the City tour, and so I went back to it as I liked the look of it. The art gallery was great with lots to see but the whole area was really beautiful.

Nice area, less likely to get assaulted. stroll the streets of Recoleta and reduce your chances of getting mugged by 85%, nice, shaded streets, original boutiques and coffee bars, too many pizza joints, but but reasonably priced, as long as you stay clear of the Design Center and Cemetery areas.

Impressive cemetery.. Who would ever think that a cemetery would be a place to go while on vacation! One sees the elaborate measures taken to house the dead including ornate sculptures and stain glass windows.

Welcoming neighborhood. Recoleta doesn't just have a pretty sounding name, it's located an easy walk to the famous cemetery. There's great shopping on nearby Avenida Santa Fe, banks, flower stalls, good restaurants, and comfortable mid-range hotels.

Excellent and Safe location in Buenos Aires. We were very pleased with our stay in Recoleta. It was an excellent and central location to all the other neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. Very clean and safe as well. This had a nice mix of the modern and historic aspects of the city which we appreciated. Really can't beat the location - especially if you want to get around and explore; both from a cost and distance perspective.

Amazing place. Very impressive. Loved it. My husband and I spent hours there and we were impressed with all the status and sculptures around us. It's huge so wear comfortable shoes. At the entrance you will find a map which will help you spot the Evita tomb. Be careful you might get lost!

Cool place to visit. Recoleta cemetery is a great place to visit and learn a bit of Argentinian history and absorb some culture! We timed our visit with the free english speaking tour, well worth it! The cemetery is huge and without a guide you would miss so much.

Great neighborhood. We stayed at the wonderful Ayres Apartments Recoleta. The location and all there is to see and do in this beautiful area of BA make it worth the visit for a day, or to call home base.

One of the few safe neighborhoods in a crime scarred city. Don't go to Buenes Aires if you can avoid it. But if you have to go, Recoleta is one of the few safer neighborhoods with much less graffiti an broken sidewalks than the rest of the city. Everyone in Buenes Aires is out to scam you, rob you, or otherwise try to get over on you. Terrible city for a tourist. Avoid it if you can.
Great Cemetery. Much like the above ground cemeteries in New Orleans. Eva Perone's tomb is under her maiden name, Duarte.

Nicer area of Buenos Aires, but not that special. Was one of the more upscale places in the city, but not all that exceptional. In general, the city felt safe. Surprised to see homeless families living outside the parliament (not so far away), but unlike Europe - nobody seems drunk.
Must see in BA. Lot of history and places to visit in Recoleta. You can spend half a day looking around historic sites. A free walking tour is recommended
Great location!. Lots to do and see in Recoleta neighborhood, and easy to get to central city and Palermo. Highly recommend this location.
Beautiful Neighborhood. An amazing neighborhood, with great architecture and sights! Very safe and comfortable. Make certain to have your camera ready!

Lovely area of Buenos Aires. This area of BA has lovely parks and restaurants especially located close to the Cemetary. On the weekends local artisans bring their wares to sell at the park and you can get some lovely crafted items.

Beautiful area of Buenos Aires with lots to see & do. Sightseeing is so easy from this beautiful area of the city. As a tourist I felt very safe and was able to walk to many of the best sights. This included the cemetery where Eva María Duarte de Perón (Evita) rests in peace. There is a street/park fair every Sunday, so if you're in town don't miss this terrific, no cost way to spend an afternoon. Buenos Aires also has wonderful ice cream and you can also find fabulous Italian Gelato. Don't miss it. Just can't say enough about this wonderful area of Buenos Aires.

Very Different. Visiting the very large cemetery is like visiting a small town, with many ornate tombs and fantastic statues ever present. The highlight for me was the tomb of Eva Peron. I recommend a visit for something completely different.
another one of those you just have to. go there. if your are in buenos aires for the first time seeing the sites, certainly this makes the list.
Evita is not the only one here!. Who would have thought that a cemetery could be so interesting! A must see while in BA. Impressive burial sites of many of Argentina's famous.
Who knew cemeteries could be so fascinating?. We came here primarily to see the Duarte family mausoleum but were blown away by this unique place. Could have spend a whole morning wandering around.
Interesting. Interesting to wander around. Reasonable street market and street tango show. Surrounding cafes expensive and nothing special.

Beautiful. Gorgeous neighbourhood for just wandering around, window shopping. The cemetery is interesting and there is a good market just outside it on Saturdays and Sundays. Love the Parisian architecture, makes me want to go back to Paris!

a beautiful area. it is obvious that here care is taken with keeping the streets repaired and cleaner than other areas. Still it is sad to see that apparently security measures are needed to keep it safe and nice. very pleasant.
Walking in the rain. We had a long, enjoyable walk in the district, including the famous Recoleta Cemetary. Next to Avenida Alvear are the most beautiful palaces of the city.
one of the cities nicest residential areas. Great section of the city with many old and new apartment residences, parks and green areas, coffee and ice cream shops as well as great shopping.
Nice area of town. It was clean with great shops and restaurants. It is like the Buenos Aires upper east side. I had to get used to how so many of the shops were always closed, however.

"Litttle Paris". The streets of Recoleta are dotted with designer boutiques, fablulous fabric and furniture shops, wonderul restaurants and sidewalk cafes, great parks and make sure to look up and notice the wonderful architecture. Often called "Little Paris" the barrio has all the charm of a European city.
Amazing Visit. This was an amazing visit and so much history and to see. Highly recommend. We spend about 1.5 hours there and this was adequate amount of time.

an unintentional visit.. We decided to just meander from our hotel,and accidentley found ourselves in the recoleta district. visited the church which was very nice and a local craft market before deciding to go into the cemetery. We were amazed at the sheer scale of the tombs and the vast array. I know it sounds a bit morbid to think of this being a tourist attraction but we found it very interesting and now understand why this is one of the premier attractions of BA.
Recoleta is the BH of BA. Fabulous shopping. Amazing architecture. Espresso cafes. The best of the best. LOVED every minute of it. Walking distance from the Park Tower Hotel. Enjoy!

Between Palermo and San Telmo. Great part of town. Ice cream, one hundred or so coffee shops, some very good restaurants, a couple of shopping malls, lots of small stores, a nice park, la biela, and of course the cemetery, just to mention a few attractions. You could pass some days here. Easy to get cabs from here, and many parts of Buenos Aires are walkable from here.

A great neighbourhood to stay in Buenos Aires. Stayed in Recoleta. Went to the cemetery twice. Eva Peron is resting in peace at this cemetery. I would be 100% to say she is the most visited person at this cemetery. The street were safe at night while we walked around. It becomes busy after 8pm and on weekends. Hubby and I walked from Recoleta to the Canals, Maya square, and Pacifica plaza. (Approx 4hrs).

A great way to spend an afternoon.. This mixed residential/commercial area is very scenic and easily walkable. Interesting architecture and small shops. Wander around and stop at one of the little shops and enjoy some locally-made ice cream. For me, the main draw of the area was the cemetery. You just can't understand the attraction until you see it. Rows of wonderfully designed mini-buildings that contain family crypts separated by small streets make it into a literal city of the dead. Very surreal but we spent hours wandering through and could have spent more if we had the time. A must-see if you're in Recoleta.

Visit the dead. How strange to visit a cemetery but one must see where the saint is buried! Eva Peron is hidden here and is a must trip for any tourist not only former grave but to see all the highly valuable crypts that are here and indeed being sold for very high profits. Very worth the casual walk in the sun.

Lovely area. A historical and architecturally beautiful residential area and home to many mansions and embassies. Highlight is undoubtedly the Cemetery de la Recoleta, a visit to which I highly recommend.It's also home to the Buenos Aires Hard Rock cafe!

interesting place if you like this kind of attractions. very interesting and scary place, many interesting statues and stories(if you take guide). but some crypts are very old and ruined, so you can see broken coffins and some hmmm...some remains...you know what i mean....am very impressionable person so time to time i had to close my eyes and run away :)

Palermo & Recoleta - lovely green areas. My partner & I took the subway to the Botanical Gardens and then walked down thru the Palermo area and then the Recoleta area (to the cemetery). If you have the time both are lovely and have lots of park/garden areas. There are many interesting sculptures - some are quirky and some are huge and many show a great sense of fun/humour (for example the oversized "park bench"). It also felt very safe and relatively crowd-free.

Recoleta. During our visit to Buenos Aires, we stayed in Recoleta. The hotel was very close to the cemetary, restaurants, bus and taxis. This area is so historic and beautiful that we enjoyed just walking around and looking at the architecture. Would stay in this area again!

Interesting Area. Area interesting with cemetry as highlight - tip: take a guide. Very good micro brewery close to centre of Recoleta - sport shown on TV, so make a session of it. Area is safe and walking distance to other sites of interest such as Malvinas War memorial - keep mouth shut if British, but no hassle otherwise.

If you go to Buenos Aires, you must visit Recoleta. A trip to Buenos Aires is not complete without a visit to Recoleta. It has great bars and restaurants, Plaza Recoleta is beoutiful and on the weekends you can go to La Feria de Recoleta, great place to go with the Family during the day and with friends at night

Beautiful!. Beautiful and peaceful right in the middle of the busy city. We went on one of the Recoleta market days and took a break from browsing the stalls to visit the cemetary. It's not to be missed.
Don't stay anywhere else. If you are not in a budget, don't stay at anywhere else. Best high end hotels in BA and best restaurants as well. Quick trip to Puerto madero and Palermo.
a safe area. My hotel is close to Recoleta cemetary and museum. It is quite nice to walk around and stop in the cafe. It is a quite safe area.

Always in the top ten. The Recoleta is always in the top ten list for Buenos Aires. It is a great back drop for the culture, history, politics and religion. You have some of the most significant people of Argentina's history buried in the heart of the city. You really should hire a tour guide so you can hear the legends, myths and significance of the tombs. If you do not hire a guide you will definitely miss out.

nice neibourhood astounding cemetary. This is one of the most well kept area in Buenos Aires.The university of BA is located there and streets and coffee shops are very clean and inviting.A lot of ambessies are there .The most famous attraction is the cemetary,which is certaily worth a visit,not just to see Evitta's grave,but to see a burial style that has almost vanished from the world.The cemetary is still active today.
Very Upmarket. Very beautiful, upmarket area of the city. Fabulous houses, embassies, parks, etc. Fabulous shops and restaurants.
...Lovely!. The cemetary is creepy, but nice. Beautiful statuets all around. Go to Design Mall for some awkward shopping and the Bullrich Mall for high end shopping...

Veneration of the dead. Walking around this cemetary is understanding the past and how different nations honor and treat their dead. This is a great cemetary to visit along other "modern" cemetaries in Paris, Washington, DC, Vienna and London. Besides Argentine history you learn about human tragedies and suffering as well as the transience of worldy fortunes. It is a place to contemplate the A and O of our lives.

Well worth hiring our guide!. We stayed in the Etoile Hotel in Recoleta and our guide Marcelo Mansilla, met us there at breakfast to begin our walking tour. We had been introduced to Marcello on tripadvisor by another traveller and from our first contact he was wonderful. We had frequent correspondence before our arrival and Marcelo helped us with many other details regarding our stay. On our 7 hour walking tour, Marcelo shared with us his love of Bs As as well as his knowledge. It was not a memorized-blurb-at-each-attraction tour; Marcelo taught us about the city, it's history, politics, economics and social life in pleasant conversation, welcoming our questions and our opinions. He even put together a file for us of restaurants, attractions, shopping, entertainment and traveller's info to plan our other days in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is central to many attractions. I recommend you stay there and hire Marcello; best $160 we spent!

Great monuments. Lots of monuments and parks, which are great to view, but as a tourist, it might not really be what you are looking for. The cemetery is a good stop, but I'm not sure this area is really worth a special trip

In my opinion - the best area in BA!. The Recoleta is a wonderful place to stay while visiting BA. The location is quiet and centrally located. The hotels in this area are great and you are close to great shopping.
astonishing monuments. we enjoyed the idea of " living " in a " house " after passing away. also a lot to learn about human desires and curiosities.

Argies do good Crypt.. Had a better than expected Sunday after a shortwalk to this suburb from Central BsAs. The cemetery is full of wonderful crypts, just follow the tours to find Evita's. Outside the cemetery is a Sunday market which was excellent. Plenty of quality buskers. Walking to the other side of the park, is a large outdoor cafe with Tango demonstrations. Fantastic. Glimpse the Fernet drinking locals done up enjoying an aperitif or afternoon tea. Walk back into town via Carlos Pelligrini. You wont be disappointed.
Our home away from home.. Have taken an apartment here, billed as the most exclusive part of Buenos Aires. Beautiful shops, parks and restaurants. Pleasant.

Great location for wandering, food and cemetery. You can choose between peace and quiet or crowds in the Recoleta. The area around the cemetery is really mobbed but fun and there are actually some great restaurants. Also, don't miss going to La Biela...we experienced some amazing tango right out front. The street fair was average....San Telmo is MUCH better!
A part of BA not to be missed. Everyone wants to see the tomb of Elvita. On Sunday there is a great artisans market at the garden near the cemetery .
Historic Neighborhood. Beautiful area to walk and browse the the tastes of the city. This is a must for anyone with a free afternoon.
Love the Angels. I am always ready for a good cemetary and Recoleta did not disappoint. Could have spend a day there wondering the aisles. Don't miss it1

Okay.... Was told and read many things about visiting Recoleta. It is supposed to be where tourists find things to do. So me and my travel mate wandered around Recoleta on the extra day we had in Buenos Aires after missing our flight. We found it just average, but a nice walk. The neighborhood was better than most of Buenos Aires. The Metal Floral is nice to see though, but nothing else to do.

Nice little walk. La Recoleta is a nice little area to go and visit and walk around. From the cemetery where Evita is buried in her family plot, to the french style apartment housing, to the great Art Museum, it is a nice area to walk around. The only thing that we found really out of place, and also left to nature was the National Library that looked runned down from outside.

Fascinating. Very interesting, like nothing we've seen before. So much history. A good guide is essential to explain the history, the personalities and the storiez surrounding these ornate and interesting graves.

A nice air of luxury and nostalgia!. We enjoyed the cemetery and a lot of walks in the Saturday flea market that is full of local artists and crafts! Please do not forget the trees that are especially grown only in Recoleta.

Excellent neighborhood to stay. This area has good hotels, traditional cafés,and many of the sights in town: the Plazia Francia, Basilica Nossa senhora del Pilar, Floralis Genérica, Avenida Alvear( fancy avenue),excellent restaurants, Recoleta Cemetery, the Design museum etc. I stayed at Etoile hotel, which was pretty ok and is right at Plazia Francia

French buildings with beautiful cupulas!. The french architecture, and the european atmosphere, but in south america! You can also visit the Recoleta Cemetery, which is amazing, and which holds Evita s grave.

Turning back the clock. If you like walking and appreciating wonderful architecture this is the place to wander. A lovely safe part of the city full of grand buildings, street cafes, good restaurants and garden squares to sit in have a take-a-way lunch and soak in the grandeur.
Foof,Shopping and History. My favorite area in Buenos Aires--many fine restaurants and shops, upscale enviornment and Eva Peron's gravesie in the cemetery and a craft market on Sundays.

Fun area. Great neighborhood, shops, the famous cemetery, cafes, architecture, great fun. Walk everywhere, if you can, and ask to see one of the rooms at Mio Buenos Aires Hotel...amazing bathtubs , carved out of indigenous wood!!!
My favorite neighborhood in BA. I walked for hours in Recoleta and didn't get tired of looking at beautiful architecture! It's my favorite neighborhood in BA.

Nice area in Buenos Aires center. This is one of the must see areas in Buenos Aires. You would enjoy walking around Recoleta with so many nice cafes, restaurants and shops. The area is full of life and is safe to walk around for tourists.

one of the nice district in BA. for me , Recoleta is nice, clean, free of beggars, houses and building which are restored and a stroll through the streets is just fun - one can see a lot and gives an impression of the city, it could be - the other parts i would recommend are palermo and the marina - the rest of buenos aires is just disappointing.

Even if cemeteries are not you thing - this one will impress you!. If you go to Recoleta on your own keep in mind, that there is a free English speaking tour offered every Tuesday and Thursday at 11 am. Come early, since the tour fills up and if you are not standing close to the guide, it is hard to them him/her. Overall it is a historical landmark, with lots of famous people and some impressive masoleum architecture. I really loved the square in the front as well, which had some impressive Ficus trees, there were massive, and were 300-400 years old.

Best Upscale Shopping in Buenos Aires. This is the area to fine the best fine leather in the city that we could find and many other upscales shops. Find Cardon, Rossi Caruso, Peter Kent and Casa Lopez for jackets, belts, shoes and purses in addition to clothing. It is a safe area to walk around and shop!

Beautiful in every way. By far the prettiest place in Buenos Aires.Street tango and fabulous food from street vendors.Laze about in thepark whilst listening to bands strumming away. A little bit of heaven!

Evita's Grave. If you want to see the grave of the person who destroyed Argentina and made it into the Socialist country it is today, then go to Recoleta. We did, it was alight. A huge place with tons of graves. Basically, it's the place where the richest of the rich in Buenos Aires are buried.

Beautiful Ricoletta. The most charming well located area! We were right across from the famous cemetary, where we had a guide who told us so many interesting stories, a great craft market on the weekend, and the most delightful walks to lovely dining and ice cream in the evenings. A perfect place to stay, and not far from anything!!

Well worth a stroll around. Very nice nod exclusive part of BA. Smart shops and desirable apartments. Your stroll should ear you to the church and cemetery but Los have a coffee in one of the cafes overlooking the green.

So good I went twice!. Never having seen the appeal in visiting cemeteries I was reluctant, but it was so lovely I went twice! Once I went alone before closing time and it was a great place to wander. The second time with a guide who pointed out all types of symbols and ancient clues to things that I missed on my own. If you don't have a guide, go with a guide book so you don't miss out.
Pleasant. Visit this neighborhood on the weekend when the street fair is happening. Nice place to stroll around and grab lunch at one of the cafes.

Go if you have time. We went to see the church, it was beautiful inside, but simple and the cemitery hasn t anything so diferent from others cemiteries. The neirgbhood has some beautiful squares, nothing special that you can t look in a few minutes.

Nice place for a picnic. It's a pretty and wealthy neighborhood. You see lots of parks and people running. It's a nice area to go for a picnic or enjoy of a hot summer day. You can also check out the flower, recoleta cemetery, museum etc..
Recoleta's Pleasant Atmosphere. A truly delightfull area to sit and sip and watch the passing parade in the shade. This also has the famous Cemetery next door.

Recoleta. Someone, we always ended up back in Recoleta. We probably should have paid more for the hotel to stay in Recoleta than to take a taxi to get there. Wonderful lovely area with lots to do and eat.

Interesting Cemetery Visit. We did not get a chance to really experience the whole neighborhood, just spent a bit of time at the cemetery to look at all the mausoleums for rich and famous of BA. Eva Peron's is the most popular site but there are more elaborate ones with ornate statues and decor. The place is in much better shape than the ones in New Orleans and safer to walk around as well. It is an unique experience and worth a visit.

beautiful. They were beautiful. We travelled from New orleans, LA,USA so we understand and respect why one would visit cemeteries as a tourist. We loved the trip, and that makes me feel like I should go to the cemeteries in New Orleans too!

Great neighborhood. Pleasand plkace to walk, shop and eat. the beautiful people of BA are there and there is always something to do. The cemetery is beautifuk and full of history and the icecream places are very nice.Try eating at the Recova - great restaurants.

Lovely area. It is the rich people area in Buenos Aires. It is very safe during the day and at night. You have many bars with great options and also a mall. Very recomendable to have a beer at night or to shop along Alvear avenue if you have some extra dollars

Beautiful.... Visit the famous cemetery where Evita is buried, walk amongst the cobblestone and take in high tea, or some world famous ice cream. This is a beautiful part of town, and it is definitely worth spending a significant amount of time in. Get lost in the beauty of Recoleta, but remember to bring your wallet because this area is pricey, not ideal for budget accommodation, but hey...walking is free.

don't miss. The architecture and history of the cemetery are something to see. My wife and I did not get a guide and we probably should have. I am sure that we missed a lot but we had a good time anyway just strolling around.
Essential for BA. Every person will have a different reaction to this remarkable monument, but you won't have seen Buenos Aries without having seen and felt Recoleta.

Recoleta. Very nice trendy area to stay in. We were right across from the cemetery where Eva Peron was buried--that could be a whole day exploration in itself. (Her maiden name Duarate is used so don't look for Peron!)
A must for shopping!. This is the nicest shopping area of Buenas Aires. Safe and very pretty you feel like you are in Paris. Especially good values in leather and polo attire.

Great shopping and lots of cafes.... Lots of little shops and cafes to choose from.
Vibrant nightlife for all people.
Can get very hot in the summer so make sure to eat ice cream at one of the many parlours along the street.
The market is fun but normal touristy stuff.
Try to find the local designers for special finds.
Can be expensive.
Walking in Recolata. Elegant neighbouthood with nice buildings, very good hotels, smart boutiques, good restaurants. There is also a park where a flea market operates in w/e
Must see!. Surpasses New Orleans cemeteries! Plan on at least 1.5 hours to truly enjoy the variety. Finding Evita's grave is a fun activity if you miss the map on the left side of the entrance.

Amazing place. Amazing neighbourhood- an "open air museum cemetery"- go their when some events( such as outside market ). You can go there day and also late at night, as there are numerous restaurants and bars. Nice boutiques, French consulate and chic houses...Brilliant- a feel of Europe

Interesting. Like a New Orleans cemetery on steroids. The mausoleums were stunning and interesting. You can spend as little or as much time here as you wish. Eva Peron's site is listed under Duarte and seems like its always busy.

i love recoletta. i have been to BA twice - and both times i would say my favourite area to go was recolettathere is something beautiful about this place... it had the cemetery, church next door, beautiful parks, the crazy monster flower, boutique shops, volta icecream (which in my opinion is so much better than freddo) and on the weekends there is a market... now im a guy that doesnt usually like wondering through massive markets on a hot day but these were soooo interesting. My wife and i couldnt resist but buying a whole lot of souvenirs from here... its a richer area so might be tough to find affordable accommodation there - so maybe stay close by and taxi it to the famous recoletta - u wont be dissapointed

Make Sure You Have a Map. Walking around Recoleta Cemetery was for me an amazing experience. My mistake was not having taken a map, the area is huge and it is very easy to get overwhelmed. The sheer beauty of the artwork that is all around you and the different styles makes this a photographic must. A pity I was unable to spend more time, and get more information on the sculptures.

Excellent place to walk. This is a beautiful cemetery where Evita is buried, it is primarily Catholic, but there are some Jewish graves and other faiths represented. It is free of charge, and demonstrates a fascinating collection of architectural styles and design. The gardens and rooms inside each plot/grave are all very interesting. a must see.

Recoleta walk by a Local Guide is the best choice!. I enjoyed Recoleta a lot. I stayed at Intersur Hotel and did a walking by myself but later on I decided to hire a local guide that was recommended by my friends in town. Then we walked all the area including the beatiful Cementery and we did other things during the rest of the day.My memories are based on Recoleta. I really enjoyed the charming and the coffee La Biela where we stopped for a drink and watching people around. Liz is a good guide to do it. http://www.lizflor2.blogspot.comYou can do it by yourself but you will loose 50% of information.Just other option.

Unusual historical landmark. Well worth doing a walking tour or on your own. Bring your camera. Plenty of great shops and on the weekends, plenty of artisan stands set up for shopping. Many unusual Argentine handmade goods
Recolata walk. While we chose a hot day, the walk through the cemetery was very interesting and our guide proved to be very knowledgeable.
best part of town for hotel. quiet but central, close to attractions, shops and the local artisans market. We felt very safe, day and night. Not as many food choices as Palermo, but more quaint.

Take the tour. Recoleta Cemetery is probably one of the most famous in the world. It is the resting place of Evita but there are thousands of mausoleums there with incredible artwork and unique designs. I have visited Pere La Chez in Paris and it is magnificent. One item that most visitors never hear about is the Chacarita Cemetery. It is world class and may even best Recoleta. Among it's inhabitants are Juan Peron and the Argentine Tango Singer Carlos Gardella (sorry if I spelled his name incorrectly). It has a statue of him and locals and visitors place a lit cigarette in the hands of the statue. I also have a friend buried there with the surname Gastelu. Very much worth a visit to Chacarita Cemetery!

Mistake to travel to buenos aires over new year thank god for Recoleta. Found that buenos aires closes before, during and after new year. Faced by streets of shuttered premises and closed attractions. So we spent a lot of time walking around Recoleta. Wandered around the cemetery really over the top. We're photographed by Eva's mausoleum, enjoyed b-b-q, prices differ so shop around. We went to the bottom restaurant of the second block parallel to the cemetery.
Great place to walk around. This is the most charming neighborhood of Buenos Aires, a must-go for nice walks and pictures with beautiful buildings.

Recoleta. You have to go trough the big cementary. There are also a nice park and a littel street market. We just walked arround. The rest of Recoleta we didn't see. All stores were closed because of the 1st of January.
Nice part of town. This is just a safe nice part of town. Go to the cemetery. Totally cool. Much better than I expected

Great neighborhood - Quiet and Safe. We stayed here for 5 nights as our base during our Buenos Aires trip. Recoleta is one of the upscale neighborhoods in BA and it is very safe. The restaurants are a little more upscale but the safety factor is worth the extra cost. The area is very safe. We never worried about walking around late at night to get a drink or dinner.We would also recommend checking out the cemetery where Eva Peron (from the movie Evita) is buried. Additionally, there are lots of ice cream shops lining the streets (definitely indulge at least once!).

Big cemetery with giant tombstones. Visited this cemetery as part of a private guided your. You will be blown away by some of the graves and mausoleums. There's a lot of history there and there is no admission cost. Elvita's grave is definitely the most visited. Worth checking out.

A good place for a walk and a drink. Very nice neighboorhood for a walk, plenty of restaurant and bar with table on the sidewalk. We did enter the cemitery this time (beautiful but a bit morbid), but is still a place worth visiting.

Relax and enjoy!. Such a great neighborhood to laze away the day! The weekend is especially good because you can check out the craft stalls, people watch along the plaza, and then walk along Alvear street to look at the fancy buildings. Recoleta cemetery grounds this whole area, ofcourse. They've also just completed a nice modern indoor mall behind the cemetery with dining options on the top floor allowing for birds-eye views into the cemetery. It's got a clean slick theatre on the ground floor (village cines), too!

Must see!. The cemetery at Recoleta is a must see if you are in Buenos Aires. The tombs are so magnificent. I would recommend picking up the map they sell out front. We did not and it took quite some time to find Eva's tomb. It really is a remarkable cemetery. There are vendors in the park out front as well. No one is pushy and you can just stroll through the various tents looking at souvenirs.
loved it. Just go and see. Great shopping and eating. Fabulous shoes. A great place to wander around and see the mix of people, especially the large contingent of elderly ladies out for lunch.

Great place to take pictures. The cementery has a lot of places with gothic sculptures. Just be careful: avoid street sellers or proposal of guidance. keep cameras attached to your neck ;) It's a great experience in BsAs
Recoleta is a great place. I like the theater and the market place there. There is located hard rock cafe. In the market place you can find different things to do.
worth it. good place to hang out , lovely gardens, nice restaurants and bars around worth a view of the cemmetary
Don't Miss This. There are guides outside who will take you in for whatever you want to pay them. They are excellent and will enrich the experience for you and well worth it.

Nice neighborhood but not much to do at night. Although Recoleta is a nice neighborhood and the most touristy of BA, I would recommend to visit it during the day and stay in Palermo in the night, as there is not much to do and what you can find is very touristy.

You can take it with you!. It's amazing how elaborate ones final resting place can be.
That is the cemetary! On Sat, the market was so much fun.
The whole are is gorgeous...Do not miss this..

The center of barrio Norte.. With the Recoleta cemetery in the center, the area is great to walk around. Walk through the cemetery to find the famous Evita Peron's grave.
Then continue your Walk through the tree lined streets to see the great shops. Have a coffee at the famous La Viela coffee house.
If you are hungry there are many great restaurants.
Traditional place to walk around. Great place to wal around, the main park, the cemetery, the shops and artesans. Stop by "la Biela" for a coffee. Day and night is a great place to visit.

nice neighborhood. Lovely place to walk, cute open market on sundays, the recoleta cultural center is amazing. There are many restaurants in the surroundings, and a good movie theater in recoleta mall.

A very interesting experience...time well spent. If you come to Argentina, you must visit the cemetery....we came during a major rainstorm and basically had the entire cemetery to ourselves. We were able to get up close and personal to Eva Peron's grave....usually everyone congregates there. An enjoyable experience.

Iconic. This place is a must visit! I have been here twice on both trips to BA. Naturally everyone wants to see the final resting place of Eva Peron and there is always a queue around her tomb, but this place is more than that, it is wonderful and the monuments outstanding. There are many famous people resident here and we were told than that to buy a plot costs US90,000 followed by an up keep fee of US200 per month. No sure who is paying for the existing ones if that is the case as many are in a state of disrepair to the point that they are open and have weeds growing inside there broken glass encasements. Still can highly recommend visiting this iconic place and you could easily spend a couple of ours wandering, reading inscriptions and wondering about the history of its residents.Plenty of restaurants in the area which are good as well and there is a market surrounding Recoleta which is very popular with tourists and locals.

Very touristy. I was here 12 years ago. Many of the tombs are falling into disrepair, probably because of the economy. The main point of interest is that of Eva "EVITA" Peron, which has one tour group after another. It is the only one of any interest, I think, to anyone not versed in Argentine history. Worth a visit because of the art work surrounding the various above ground tombs.
Great neighborhood. We rented an apartment in wonderful area in Recoleta. It was clean, upscale and safe. We were able to walk everywhere. Perfect location.
Bands on the Grass. Stop here, street shopping and there were bands to listed to on a big grassy area! Loved this place!
Amazing. Pick up the map from the volunteer at the gate for 10 pesos ($2) and you will spend about two hours in the graveyard. The sculptures and architecture alone is worth it.
Nice Day Trip. This is a really good area to walk around. The outdoor market is a great way to spend the day. I agree with some of the other reviewers around the cleanliness of the area.

Traditional good time place. We liked the trees, outdoor seating, old-fashioned cafes with uniformed waiters. We disliked the high prices and a bit stand-offishness of waiters and other attendants. Plus, you see mostly other tourists.

Best part of Buenos Aires. Recoleta is one of the cleanest parts of Buenos Aires (yes, we had a difficult time dodging dog droppings, particularly in Palermo). The cemetary is noteable, the outdoor craft market was one of our favorites and the El Ateneo bookstore 'theater' is totally worth the trek.
more than Evita's tomb. wonderful area for walking, of course through the tombstone, but also through wonderful neighborhoods.

The most incredible thing I saw in BA.. It's a virtual city of the dead. The famous and the infamous live in mini-mansions with doors and windows. They say that "it is easier to get into heaven than to get into Recoleta". They have a tomb here that cost over a million dollars. They have Evita, They have sad stories of premature burial. See the best of it with a tour guide like Liz Flores, but see it by all means.
Older historic with a modern flavor. Parks, excel at shopping mall, restaurants in a very open fresh air atmosphere - many many choices. Very large outdoor park area, close to the Recoleta cemetery.
Great area. A great area with cemetery the main attraction. La Biela is the best cafe/restaurant outside under the century old rubber tree.
The best ride in town. Cementery / design mall Very safe área / nice boutiques / very good restaurants!!!!!!!!!!!!! Don't miss the open fair

Worth paying a bit more to stay here. We spent two weeks in an apartment on Posadas Av right in the heart of Recoleta and we're very pleased we chose that location. It's easy and cheap to take taxis right on the street, so not having the subway nearby was not an issue. Grocery shopping is not far, but a bit of a hassle - the locals seem to mostly send their maids and have the products delivered. It seems that there are more and perhaps interesting restaurants outside of Recoleta, but they are available although more expensive.

Awesome Neighborhood. Clean, safe, good shopping for everyday needs and special occasions, and full of beautiful people. This is a functioning community as well as a draw to visitors. The area is well-serviced by bus lines and loads of taxis.

Nice afternoon. Cemetery was awesome, there were people dancing tango in the streets all near a cute and affordable market. Also saw a fairly racist capoeira performance, but the audience seemed not to care.

Safe & chic. Loved this area. Plenty of nice shops, restaurants and sites. Walking everywhere was easy. Far from any subways, however and we never did figure out the bus system.
