Visited the cemetery several times for the architecture. BA Design Mall is a must see (though a bit confusing) Recoleta Mall also good. AV Pueyrredon has some great shops too.
cemetery was interesting. interesting, a lot like New Orleans. They are around it is nice to walk around and you can eat outside. or sit in the park to people watch

One of the nicest neighbourhoods in BA. Recoleta is a really lovely neighbourhood. It's clean and open with lots of bars and restaurants to try out and some grassy areas to relax in the sun if you like. Also, it's right where you can find the Recoleta cemetery where Evita is buried. Definitely an area to visit.

Beautiful, classic neighborhood. From the colonial church, to the traditional cafes, to the elegant streets with upscale shopping, this is a favorite place to walk around Buenos Aires, and take in its turn of the century history.
Delightful. Especially go to see the Cemitary and Evita Duarte's Tomb. Had dinner at Lola on first night. Wonderful area. Not to miss. Elegant. Great for walking around. Browsing.

Sweet Square. The Recoleta is a beautiful square in Beunos Aires. It is also home to El Gomero, the famous gum tree and the cemetery where Evita lies. It is a wonderful place to walk around, relax, think, and enjoy.

One of the must-see parts of Buenos Aires.... I stayed in the Recoleta neighbourhood during part of my stay in BA. It's safe (I was traveling by myself), there are lots of restaurants and shops, and of course interesting sights like the cemetery (kind of goes without saying). Definitely worth a day or two of wandering around. There's a market that goes on outside of the cemetery, but I much prefer San Telmo market.
Best neighborhood to stay in Buenos Aires. Nice restaurants, cafes. Also the City of the Dead is walking distance. Amazing cemetery where many famous Argentines are buried. Such as Evita Peron.
Upscale. Like to walk this area .. nice stores ..clean with GOOD SIDEWALKS... great architecture food market with everything...and close to my hotel....walk walk walk.

Interesting cemetary. We had a fascinating visit to the cemetary. I thought perhaps we'd been swindled by the fake guide outside who gave us a map to Evita's tomb and then asked for money but his map was most helpful as the cemetary is huge. It was amazing to see such mausoleums.
Beautiful area. Nice walking area. Close to museums and united nations plaza with large lotus flower. Ave Alvear really does put one in the mind of Paris.

Best neighbourhooud in BA.. Classy bit of BA, nice resturants, bars and clubs. Close to cemetry, which is like an open air museum. Must try the ice cream here. Food not too bad either. Comes alive at night, so that's the time to go.
A perfect Saturday morning!. A perfect place to go on saturday morning, to walk and to take a look at the local handicraft. Don't forget to go insie the cemiterium!

Residential area. Mainly a residential area, much cleaner than the rest of BA. Of course the most important part is the cemetery. Suggest you take a guided tour (we used Buenos Aires Historico) to tell you about not only Evita's grave but many of the important figures in Argentina's history.

Tourist trap. This is nothing more than a tourist trap. I understand that everyone is trying to make a living, but there is no reason to be jumping in top of you every two steps you take to try to sell you something or try to make you eat at their restaurant.

Weekend market. A lovely area, plan to stop at the cemetary, and walk through the market's stalls. perhaps sit down for a beer in the shade at a cafe and enjoy some music. Plenty of shopping in the area but we were limited on time and did not venture far from the cemetery.

Pretty place. Its good to walk on Recoleta. There are good places to stay and just watch the people, the birds, the life of Buenos Aires. There are malls and restaurants, there is the cemetary... Its pretty good.
Nice neighbourhood. This is one of the nicer neighbourhoods of the city. A must to visit the Recoleta Cemetery and Evita's tomb along with many other famous people who have ornate tombs there.

Upper East Side Feel. Recoleta feels like the upper east side in NYC. Lovely shops and buildings. A must when in BA. My favorite stores there are Rossi & Rossi for leather goods and Humawaka for bags. Loved the Park Hyatt.

Amazing piece of history. Quite a collection of monuments in the cemetary. Some of which dated back hundred of years. The area surrounding the cemetary was very nicely kept. Restaurant food was very good and prices were reasonable....

Beautifull area. Good shopping in Florida Street.
Visit the Museum of New Art / visit cafe Tortoni
Fur leather and handbags

Beautiful for Walking. We found Recoleta to be a very easy and beautiful place to walk around for high end shopping and dining. I found one of my favorites to be Smeterling Patisserie for deserts and treats. Also, we bought perfume from Fueguia which I loved because it's not a brand that I could shop for here in the U.S. The cemetery is a MUST-SEE! I was enthralled and appalled all at the same time. It's crazy the amount of money that is spent on burying the wealthy, but the grave-sites are so beautiful that you have no choice except to be enticed by the beauty of the architecture. I have never seen such a place in my travels. We would definitely stay in Recoleta again for the ease of getting around and peacefulness in the community.

Cemetery - Doesn't miss it. Had time to do a personal stroll early in the morning through the cemetery. Would suggest saving time for the free tour so you can leave with a few stories of the souls resting there.

A must do visit when in BA. I was doubtful that a cemetery was worth seeing but this is like nothing i have ever seen! It's like a small city with lavish homes! Extraordinary stories behind many of the crypts, Peron also here.quite beautiful architecture in amazing setting in centre of city.
intriguing locale. well kept parks and pathways. The cemetery is like nothing we've seen before with some mausoleums that I suspect cost more than a lot of housing nearby.
Love the neighborhood. Not much changed except the mall. Nice little mall by cemetery. I enjoy the neighborhood for it's beauty. So many streets to explore.

Classy & innovative: where contradictions meet. While Recoleta still retains part of its 19th century charm (such as the cemetery) it has also evolved to keep in with people new tastes. It is intersting to see how fancy ice creams shops, the always rebellious MALBA, an old Church and the Faculty of Laws live side by side without causing disruption to the visitors eyes. Definitely, it is worth a visit!

Beautiful part of BA. This was our second time to stay in Recoleta BA and we even enjoyed it more this time. If you do not stay in this area I would definitely recommend spending a day strolling through this area and enjoying the parks, the shops and the cafes. It feels like a quit less crowded version of Paris.

Great Walking Neighborhood. We heard plenty about how dangerous Buenos Aires can be, especially for tourists, but, forewarned, we had five delightful days strolling the city and the Recoleta neighborhood.
Cemetery. This is brilliant. Could spend half a day here. Did not dislike anything. This is the most I portent cemetery in Argentina.

Like an outdoor sculpture museum.... Upon entering Recoleta, you feel like you're in a city of sculptures rather than in a cemetary. Most of the monuments are truly stunning. You will visit the Duarte family mausoleum where Evita is buried because, well, you have to, but there are so many tombs that are much more beautiful and interesting. It pays to hire a guide who can tell you about some of the people who are buried here.If you go on Saturday, there is an excellent, high-quality craft fair outside the cemetary.

Overrated. Buenos Aires' historical center as a whole, Palermo and Recoleta, were a bit disappointing. For me who knows Europe quite well, the architecture was a cheaper version of Paris, without all the monuments and the culture. However, I reckon it is nicer than Santiago de Chile, Montevideo or Lima, to compare it with other capital cities. There are very nice places to eat, drink and shop, but I was expecting more in terms of architecture and culture.

Enjoyed the neighborhood and historic Cemetery. We spent most of our time walking through the cemetery. I wasn't that interested in this tour but it was very interesting to see once we arrived. We spent about two hours walking through and touring the sights.

Cute place to walk around!. Nice to walk around - the cemetery was very interesting. There are lots of market stalls outside, but I wasn't nearly as impressed as the Sunday San Telmo market. Great people watching on a nice day!

Tourist trap, but worth seeing. Definitely more expensive than other parts of Buenos Aires. However, if your a tourist, and only there for a couple of days, then you should go. Safe environment. Also go to Palermo.
Great neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. Good location, safe and beautiful. Within walking distance of restastaurants, shopping and site seeing.

Impressive Cemetary. Cemetaries are history books and the stories behind the people buried there are fascinating. Among the ostentatious mausoleums of generals and politicians of Argentina's turbulent history, the grave sites that moved me the most were the more modest and thoughtful ones of the Duarte (Eva Peron's) family and those of Rufina Cambareceres and Liliana Crociati.

Lovely area go on a saturday when the market is there. I went to Recoleta to visit the cemetary where Evita is buried. The area is very nice to walk around as have a local market on a saturday where you can buy lots of crafts and jewelry

Don't miss this neighborhood. This is the a wealthy area, and interesting to see how the upper class live. The architecture in this area is so beautiful. We visited the area on he weekend and browsed through the markets near he cometary, which had a lot of quality items ranging from leather items, jewelry, clothing, and quirky and unique gifts. The cemetery here is a must, it has to to be the most beautiful and ornate cemetery have ever seen. Don't miss seeing Eva Peron's grave. It's located in the Duarte family plot, located in the middle of the cemetery on your left.

The only arae to stay in BA. We stayed in Recoleta for 4 nights and used it as our base and literally walked the majority of the city as big as it is. This area is quiet, upscale, has less traffic and less crime. Good choice of restaurants and an amazing cemetery were the rich and famous are all buried including Eva Peron. The only choice for me
A must see. Very interesting areas from Evita's tomb to the surrounding area of high end shops. The cemetery is interesting and cannot be missed.
Depends on What You Like. A upwardly mobile suburb that could be anywhere, Recoleta is still worth a visit for the cemetery and the Sunday market. But don't expect to meet the locals.

Feria de Recoleta, Feria Artesanal Plaza Francia. I was here on a Saturday that started out a little rainy, there were some places set up from the beginning, and more and more as the day went on. I was impressed with array of products from local craftsmen, especially the jewelry, some was quit good and original. The prices that I check were ok in my estimation, and of course bargaining is a good idea. There were paintings, leather goods, clothing, jewelry, mate gourds of course, items made from wood, lots of knick knacks. On a good day there could be a larger variety, there was space available for at least a couple of hundred vendor, and they were only about half full the day I was there, presumably because of the weather.
Elegant neighborhood. Great place to walk around. Interesting architecture, nice shops, restaurants and bakeries. Plenty of parks, and of course the cemetery, which is ascinating.
A must see. This is an amazing place. The family crypts are architecturally beautiful and the inscriptions and sculptures worth exploring.
The Best part of town!. Excellent shopping, upscale neighborhood with many great restaurants. There are many designer boutiques and antiques stores in the area.

Recoleta Rocks!. Diverse area with anything for everyone! October weather in BA is grande mid month this year; very easy to walk the entire outside area and stope at watering holes all thru the 'hood.
A must see!. Take the free guided tour to learn about this fascinating place. Make sure to look into many crypts as they are different. Eva Peron's crypt is located here.

Beautiful part of the City. Visiting the cemetery and markets are a must in this beautiful neighbourhood! Managed to pick up some beautiful hand made handicrafts and souvenirs while walking round this peaceful area.

Beautiful neighborhood with many cool sites and restaurants. You MUST visit the cemetery and seek out Evita's family tomb. Lots of great photo ops there. A great eatery across from the cemetery is Clark's. Great service, good value and cool atmosphere. Also visit Buenos Aires Design - tons of trendy home decor and mod furniture galleries to browse. Also hit up the weekend market here, where a lot of vendors sell their goods on the weekends.

Finest area in the city. It is considered to be on of the finest and most expensive areas of the city. Places to visit: Recoleta Cementery and Nuestra Señora del Pilar Basilic. The famous Alvear Hotel takes place in Recoleta too

Loved Recoleta. We loved walking around Recoleta. We wandered there many days in our almost month-long time in BA. We especially enjoyed the cemetery and the outdoor craft market near there on weekends. Mostly, we just walked and popped into cafes when hunger required. The area felt safe and easy to explore even with kids (ages 9 and 12). Be sure to have coffee or a meal near the cemetery under the HUGE trees. Lovely.
Neat area, lots to do. We had a great apartment in a good location. So much to do. We even found a great street market. Safe neighborhood.

Great shopping!. Recoleta has a lot of high end stores that are great fun for window shopping. I would not recommend buying anything in the Bullrich Plaza mall because everything is overpriced. If you shop up and down the streets in the smaller stores, you can find beautiful things at much better prices. Don't miss Medialunas del Abuelo on Juncal. They have the best medialunas!

My favourite neiboughhood in Buenos Aires. A magnificent neiboughhood were the eye remains restless.Beautiful marble buildings, aristocratic block of flats with polished handdles and railings. Marble pavement. Upmarket cafes, exceptional restaurants (we tried one) We walked through & through and we enjoyed the surroundings. A lot of historical buildings and a few Architecturally magnificent Churches, the cemetary and the Evita's tumb are the main attractions of the area.
Interesting cemetary.. Had a great English speaking guide. Saw Evita's tomb. There are many beautiful statues and vaults. A wonderful final resting place.

Great place to stay in Buenos Aires. I especially loved the Recoleta cemetery when I visited BA over 12 years ago. Returning this Sept. 2012 was a treat, albeit the vibe overall in BA feels different. Perhaps it's the impact of inflation, government corruption, and the increase in crime. Nevertheless weI felt relatively safe walking around at night, and the elegant Recoleta area felt particularly secure. We stayed at the boutique hotel Mio Buenos Aires and had a great experience there. It's literally a two minute walk from Recoleta cemetery and the Basilica Nuestra Senora del Pilar, and Plaza Francia where all the cafes are situated. In the Plaza there's a lovely fair on the weekend with live music and art vendors selling their goods. There are great restaurants to consider; Fervor on Posadas and their sister restaurant for Spanish food, El Burladero on Pte. J.E. Uriburu. Try El SanJuanino for authentic locra...also on Posadas, right next to Fervor. For amazing, but expensive Italian food we dined at Piegari, near the Four Seasons hotel. Walk down Callao to visit the famous jazz club Notorious We had a fun evening there.....not spectacular (my novio is a jazz musician and coming from NYC the standard is hard to beat) but it's a good time out taking in good music. Nearby is the famed El Cuartito for amazing pizza. It's a 5 minute walk from Teatro Colon which is a must see! Overall a wonderful stay and Recoleta was a terrific home base.

Solo staying in Recoleta. As much as people say there is a lot of crime in BA, I stayed in Recoleta and didn't feel at risk. I walked home from Palermo a couple times in the middle of the night and was not bothered. Of course common sense and not wearing flashy items helps. The area is very pretty with a lot of European flare. I found it to be really central to everything from Palermo to Puerto Madera and so on.

Stepping back in time. Full of history and some quite substantial mausoleums, Recoleta is definitely worth a visit. Of course, most people go to see the final resting place of Eva Peron, but there is much more as well.

Must for all tourists. This very famous neighborhood is beautiful and resides in the heart of the city. You can visit the cemetery where Evita and many other famous names are. For a walk and coffee/lunch break.
Go and experience. Recoleta Cemetary is an eerie, unique and overwhelming experience. So much history in such a small space.
What a tourist trap!. The cemetery that houses renowned Madonna impersonator, Eva Peron, looked like the Haunted Mansion in Disneyland. All that’s missing is the carmel apples.
Window shopping. Great area for window shopping and sipping on lattes. People watching is also interesting in this area.

Great place with lots to do. Could not be in Buenos Aires and not go to Recoleta - the cemetery full of famous Argentinians including of course Evita - Eva Peron. Have been twice. Once on a Tuesday at 11am to hook up with the free tour in English (Also available on Thursday at the same time). The volunteer guide was excellent and passionate about her subject and gave us a fantastic overview of the diversity of the cemetery. Also a great insight into the practical day to day running of the place - including how to buy a plot for our mausoleum! Second time went on a Sunday when there are a lot of stalls on the paths in front of the cemetery selling the whole range of rubbish through to some very nice local arts and crafts. Whilst entrance to the cemetery is free, for 10 ARG pesos you can buy a map which includes a suggested walk through. This money goes to the friends of Recoleta and helps maintain the site. Exhausted by all of that we had a nice Sunday lunch in the cafe across the park. Lovely day out. Surprised at how small it is - tiny compared to other cemetery's. Surprised at how small the Eva Peron tomb is - expected more splendor. Surprised at how they ever get a coffin down into the underground chambers - a very tight squeeze. Look out for the cats who've made themselves at home

Mini Pere Lachaise. Visit this beautiful cemetery and see beautiful monuments - the cemetery is a small village unto itself with many interesting mausoleums. Visit Evita at the Duarte family tomb, then move along to the far grander and more interesting ones along the way, pausing to contemplate the beauty of being alive to witness it all.

Lots to see and eat in Recoleta. The cemetery is free to explore and very interesting. It is free to enter, so if a man out front stops you and is asking for a donation just know it's not for the cemetery admittance.Many good eateries in this area. Especially pizza and ice cream.The neighborhood looks like it is mainly comprised of wealthy, older citizens.Consult the tourist guides on-line for more sites to see in this part of town including the obelisk and the theatre.
Cemetary alone. The cemetary alone is worth the trip but this a beautiful part of the Buenos Aires old houses and a great place to walk

Nice area. Cemetary is the main attraction.. Very nice area. The cemetary was the main attraction for us. Beautiful monuments. Worth the trip to see. Of course the most famous is the Duarte Family which is where Evita is buried.
Another dimension of the city. Enjoyed walking around observing how the locals live.Food and shopping abound, with the infamous cemetery worth the visit with a Freddo ice cream shop across the road !

Safe clean great shopping!. The Park Hyatt is center to this area, just look for the doggie poo poo its not a law to pick up after they doo doo! Also where the Cemetery is located, and where Evita rests.

Safe, interesting and varied . . . that's my view.. I like the cafes, the supermarkets, the bread shops, the wine shops, the cinema, the greengrocer, the fish shop, the little cafes and bars and walking around the streets! The markets, the museums, the hairdressers, the dress shops, the jewellers . . . and there are cops everywhere and security guards as well. It's all very lovely, tree lined, buzzy and quite conservative actually. Of course it is . . . it's Recoleta! Everyone goes on about the cemetary which is amazing . . . well worth a trip or two...if you have time.

The best area in BA. You must definitely go to Recoleta if you are in BA and enjoy its architecture and Parisian buildings, nice restaurants and posh designers shops, cool bars, open craft market at weekends, the Hard Rock cafe, the Patio Bullrich Mall, etc

Beautiful parks. Libertador Ave. walk and visit the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes, is free, continuing walking to the Plaza Naciones Unidas and the go all the way to Avenida Sarmientos . Best area of Buenos Aires.

Snobish area with tourist attraction. Recoleta is the typical high middle and low high class neighberhood of Argentina, the place where clasically Argentines dress, eat and walk as around Europe. Has solid restaurants, international first class hotels and very nice shopping spots. It is worth a walk around but be ready to carry your bags!

Culture and cusine. You need to take your tennis shoes and walk around is a lot to see, the Recoleta Cemetery is one of the main tourist attractions in the neighborhood. Several cabarets in the neighborhood served as locales for tango music and dance. The Pabellón de las Rosas, on Libertador Avenue and Tagle Street, like the Café de Hansen in the Palermo neighborhood, maintained a Belle Époque atmosphere, where the so-called "atorrantes" (vagabonds) spent their evenings.

A worthwhile Saturday excursion. There is an art fair each Saturday but don't arrive before noon. Afterwards, there are many cafes surrounding the park next to the cemetery where Evita Peron was buried (though I prefer the cafes in Puerto Madero.)

Great neighborhood of Buenos Aires!. Recoleta area is quite nice! There are a lot of parks and squares all over with a huge market on Saturdays. The cemetary there is quite unique and worth a visit. We sat out at one of the cafes on day and had a beer enjoying the weather. Another day we had lunch at Tuscan in the shopping area behind the main square and had a great burger (the best we had in BA). I found the neighborhood to have a very european feel. We always felt very safe.

Very Parisian area. The Recoleta neighbourhood is one of the trendiest and more stylish in Buenos Aires. There are lovely buildings, parks and cafes. Also the most expensive shops with brands such as Armani, Hermes, Louis Buiton and Ermenegildo Segna.It is quite a safe area to walk around at night too. One of my favourites in BA.

Fascinating. The most interesting feature here is the cemetery and the size of the mausoleums of the wealthy deceased , and of course, Eva Peron's resting place (in the Duarte tomb). Very upmarket area, and well worth a visit

Great for present buying. Go on a saturday or sunday and visit the Plaza Francia for the markets - they are really great for picking up nic naks to take home for people. Also go inside the Pilar church - i only costs 1paso but seeing inside the old cloisters is really interesting.

Great Neighborhood. Fancy and beautiful. It's the chic area of town with lots of cultural things to do. The cemetery is gorgeous. The church is wonderful, too. On weekends, there's an outdoor fair that's probably the prettiest fair in the city. Find the artisan who makes tailored dog collars and leashes out of some of the most beautiful leather you've ever seen.

Great walking. For a taste of Europe in Latin America this is worth the trip. I just walked around to gaze at the architecture and walk through parks and streets. You will enjoy, and I have heard the restaurants are also very good.
Wow. I was blown away. BEAUTIFUL. Like a lesson in history, art, sculpture, architecture, and politics all at once. Highly recommended.

Different on day and night. Recoleta needs to be known during day and night.
You will enjoy different environment that includes restaurants, cinemas and discos! Don´t miss it!
My Favourite. This is my top 1 place to be in Buenos Aires, great restaurants, the cemetery is a must to see and so many great green areas, it's a win win place to go!

A must destination in Buenos Aires. The Recoleta area is a must if you visit Buenos Aires. Probably one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world and this is where you will find the final resting place of Evita. There is a nice cathedral to visit here as well. Restaurants abound around the Recoleta and don't miss the shopping mall on the northern end. There are some good places to eat in there at the food court you not think of. I was there over Labor Day and there were hundreds of arts and crafts vendors in the park adjacent to the Ricoleta. A great time for buying mementos of my trip.
Cemetery is a must see. Great neighborhood for shopping, dining, street fair on weekends. The cemetery is a must see- so ornate and beautiful!

Home away from Home. We lived there for a month and FELL IN LOVE with Buenos Aires. Recoleta is a beautiful, safe neighborhood and I could easily live there permantely. So much to see and do in the city of BA and Recoleta is a good central location with its own charm!
historic place. great area with a historic centre place, cemitery , museum and cafes , restaurants , shoppings, amzing
Charming Luxury Area. Recoleta is the most charming area of Buenos Aires with all beautiful buildings, best restaurants and stores

Pretty, with Great Attractions. This is a nice place to visit. It is a very pretty part of the city and has some wonderful attractions. Check out The Argentine Experience which is located in Recoleta, although they will be moving soon to their new location in Palermo Hollywood.
lovely area. Our hotel was in this district. The area had good shops, a vast selction of dining. It was home to the cemetery that has "Evita" in.It also had lovely open spaces for relaxing.

Great Area. The Recoleta as a neighborhood a a ritzy little number. There are some nice buildings. The main attraction for me is the weekend bazzar that sets up here. There are a lot of tacky touristy thing but also some very nice craftsmen will work the area. The church and graveyard are also nice to see.

Nice Neighbourhood. This is the review from a local and is a positive review. This is one of the most visited places for tourists in Buenos Aires. The streets and architecture are European style mostly and also it's pretty safe at night compared with another neighborhoods.
The rich and famous.... Nice place to see the richest part of B.A. All of the expensive shops are here, so windowshopping is a nice activity. Of course the cemetary is a must see!

Beautiful Area. This is one of our favorite areas of Buenos Aires. The cemetary is amazing to walk through. We visited on a Sunday when the out door market goes on and loved all of the food and crafts.

If I lived in Buenos Aires... i'd live in Recoleta. Recoleta has so much to offer: historic sites, open spaces, markets on the weekends, petite shopping malls, restaurants. It is a beautiful place to stay, I have stayed in two different hotels in the area and Recoleta always delivers.

Living in Ricoleta. We rented an apartment in this neighborhood for two weeks. It is not very far from the famous Ricoleta cemetery and you can walk to it easily. However, the sidewalks are all borken up and are in need of repare. Also there is dog poop all over the streets. The people in Buenas Aires are not obligated to pick up after their dogs so you have to constantly look down so you don't slip or step it it. This is a very elegant neighboorhood and can be quite expensive. But it is just a short walk to other parts of the city to eat in cheaper and better restaurants Avoid the restaurnats near the Ricoleta Cemetery- they are over priced and are tourist rip offs.

One of the top neighborhoods in BA.. I did quite a bit of walking around Recoleta due to its reputation as being one of the more upscale neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. And even though the reputations is well deserved there also is a very relaxed and quiet elegance to the neighborhood. It is also one of the more cleaner neighborhoods in BA.Recoleta also borders several large parks which include the museo de bellas artes and museo de artes decorativos. It also is home to the famous cemetary which is not just a must see in Buenos Aires, but all of Argentina!If you have time to kill, Recoleta is a great place just to take it easy and enjoy the best (and expensive) of Buenos Aires.

A must see in BA. This was an amazing experience to walk around the Recoleta cemetary and see the impressive and old mausoleums. There so many details to admire, so leave the tourist path that goes to Evita Perron's resting place and remember to bring your camera. It is highly recommended to visit the McDonalds restaurant in the Recoleta Mall at Vicente Lopez. From there you can enjoy Spectacular views of the cemetary from their balcony if you can get a table.
Nice neighbourhood. Very clean and elegant, but it's a bit expensive in some establishments, most of all are worth it, definetly a place to visit

Interesting. We had a lot of fun taking pictures, we missed the tour because of our timing and hoped we would be able to find someone to give us one. But it was not set up that way. But we took our tour book and looked around.

Very interesting. I took a city tour that stopped here and was so fascinated i came back the next day. No fee to enter. Guide said there are more statues in this cemetery than the entire country. Great place to wander around.
Recoleta. Very interesting and unique cemetery. Also the sorroundings are very pretty.

Architecture, Style and Dog Poo. We really like this area. It's expected for people to be a little snobby as you're with the crem della crem.My experience is mixed, just like a box of apples, you get your over ripe ones and some good ones. You can walk all you want and don't have to fear for your life. It's a luxury in Latin Americas and Western Society. But I have a dream that one day, no matter where we go, we'll be able to walk without any worries where ever we are. I recommend staying at an apartment, eating at the local restaurants, going to the many supermarkets, buying empanadas for breakkie (so many vendors), panaderias, etcLive like a local.
Art, music ,theatre. Lots of small shows based here in the community space. I also went to a free concert at the church which was stunning. The art space is rather experimental.

Use to be better. Sounds to me that Recoleta area loose the old glamour, in the past I use to see more people and activities.Recoleta cemitery is interesting just to see and try to discover where is Eva Peron tumble
Great Neighborhood. Nice place to stay beware of pickpocketing especially slinging "bird poop" on you and having napkins ready to help you and help themselves to your wallets

Recoleta. High priced real estate for the deceased including Evita Peron whose crypt is usually covered with flowers and momentos...lots of cats wandering about the crypts, very picturesque and varied areas within the cemetery.
Beautiful, comfortable area.. We loved staying in Recoleta. Their are many wonderful shops and great dining options.
Walking in a dead but beautiful mini city. It was spectacular! Absolutely a must-see if you are in town!

hi, EVITA!!. You should go this area on weekend. You can see a lot of weekend markets around the cemetary :)
this area is a little bit snob, but you can enjoy if you like shopping!

The 'posh area'. It is a lovely area to walk around and close to some of the big museums, and of course the cemetery.we stayed in Recoleta for our last 2 nights in this city, but we actually found staying the first 8 days in Esmeralda Avenida more convenient to everything we wanted to do.

Nice Walk - Nice Stores - Good Sight seeing. Nice place to walk around and explore!
Feel the city!
Recoleta. Nice place for shopping and day walking. You can reach Recoleta by subway, bus or taxi.

Recoleta with a Local Guide and transport to the luxury past of BA. Happy to hire a local guide to get all the information about Recoleta and Buenos Aires including Evita and the Cementery. The area is like going to Paris in 1940. Is like walking around 5th Av NYC. Elegant. French. I can recommend my private guide at www.lizflor2.blogspot.com to discover all and enjoy it!

Walk around then sit and relax.. Recoleta, one of the main enclaves of the argentinian wealthy,would be the local version of Central Park West. It was built close to a cloister and a church - Nuestra Senora delPilar next to the cemetery where Evita Peron is buried.Church and Cemetery still there, the Cloister long gone and thebuilding has been adapted to different art exhibits.Around Plaza Francia, which is the hub of this area, there is abusy artisans market on weekends and passing it, there is alarge terrace with a number of good restaurants. Beyond thisterrace there is the Buenos Aires Design Center, actually a sortof mall with well designed furniture and household goods, mostlyoverpriced and easy to find in the US or Europe at a fraction.If the visitor is not familiar with Catholic Cemeteries such as onefinds in New Orleans, then do not hesitate in visiting this one,final resting place of the Buenos Aires elite with quite imposingmausoleums.
Must See. One of the few free things for tourists in Buenos Aires. It was beautiful and wonderful! Definitely recommend it.
Excellent place you have to visit. A must in Buenos Aires.I have never seen anything like it. Beatuiful!

Excellent place to visit!!. It's a nice place to visit with many attractions, such as the Recoleta Cemetery, The Floralis, a veru beautiful andbig green area, very nice shops and old and elegant buidldings. It's the place to visit in Buenos Aires.

Beautiful and serene. In this bustling city there's a peaceful place you can spend an hour or so walking around. This resting place of the rich and famous of Argentina has some wonderful ornamental, art deco structures ; others decorated with sculptures, designs and stained glass. Each is different and unique. I'd definitely recommend a visit.

Like in France. This neighborhood has a lot of Paris, with elegant architecture, historic monuments and "The Cemetery of Recoleta"!His counterpart is the great nightlife, where restaurants, pubs and nightclubs make this night one of the best neighborhood of Buenos Aires. I love Recoleta for all this and more! I have stayed at Urban Suites Recoleta in my last stay and the truth which is located opposite the Recoleta Mall. All was perfect!Keep well!
Beautiful. Great place to walk. Recoleta's Cemetery a must ! Fantastic restaurants and bars. La Biela is one of them. Buildings with amazing architecture, great shopping.

Tourism Center, Interesting Craft Market. This area is old money apartments, cultural venues, Doctor Offices, shopping and places for renting sexual adventure. Take a walk thru the shopping malls and you will see how Portanio's live. The Design Center is OK for Interior decoration.
On list of things to see in BA. See the cemetary, go into the new upscale mall, have lunch in cafe. Very nice day excursion. Easy taxi from Palmero were we stayed.

Don't pay the guy at the entry. Beautiful cemetery! But, watch out for the guy at the entry. He tries to tell you there is an entry fee/or a 'donation'. Walk right past him!!After you visit the cemetery, there is a nice area to do some local shopping. At the main entrance of the cemetery take a left and continue walking. When I was there they had lots of booths from local vendors, crafts and food.
Fancy part of town.. Good people watching and outdoor cafes. Lots of big hotels. Near The Cemetery. The free walking tour starts near here - recommended.
Very nice neighbourghood. Love walking around, nice shops, coffee shops, parks and restaurants.
Must place to visit in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is a beautiful neighborhood in the city, very traditional. You should drink a coffee or get an ice cream there.

loved the local markets on the square. the markets on the square offered home made wears including the most awesome paintings... the quality of the flea market was remarkable...thank goodness there were no "made in china" stalls...
A big graveyard. I didn't find it exciting or particularly interesting. It is big, though, and something to tell people you saw.

Nice Place to Stroll. The recoleta really is a must-see neighborhood in Buenos Aires, especially on the weekend when the artesenal fair is going strong. Walk through, shop, buy some present for home, and just to the side is another must-see, the cemetery with tombs of presidents and Evita and more.

Love this neighborhood. We stayed at the Algondon Mansion and enjoyed daily walks in this neighborhood. We strolled to restaurants, parks, the cemetary and to arts and crafts exhibits. Pretty and safe with lots to see and do.
Majestic Cemetery. This cemetery is majestic with ancient graves and some houses of deaths which are national monuments. Eva Peron is probably the most visited of them!
Integral part of BA. Part of the history and culture of Argentina. Well worth a visit.

This is why Bs As passes for the Paris of the South. It would be tempting to spend most of one's visit here, given the nice buildings, the many good restaurants and cafes as well as all the museums and bookstores. Don't do THAT, but do make sure to walk around. I recommend going to the two bookstores, El Ateneo Gran Splendid and Clasica y Moderna. These are full of character, and feature good food and drinks (as well as good places to people watch). There is also a super cool museum dedicated to Xul Solar, a friend of Borges' and an interesting individual all his own.

I love it!. My mother was raised in Recoleta, and my grandmother still lives there, so I am a bit biased =) Although other parts of Buenos Aires are a bit dirty, Recoleta is a bit cleaner than most parts of Palermo and Barrio Norte. We really love the architecture and love sitting in Plaza Francia and drinking mate and watching all of the silly performers!

Another Must See. Everyone must visit Cemeterio Recoleta at least once to see the amazing family mausoleums and especially Evita's. There is an excellent craft market on the weekends, La Biela Cafe faces the cemeterio, the Design Centre and array of restaurants are worth visiting.

Fairly outrageous and memorable cemetery.. It was a gorgeous day and the stroll in the cemetery was a bit more like a stroll down a beautiful avenue of wonderful houses. If you're in the area, it's definitely worth the look and then some more time spent in the outdoor market outside.
Nice place on weekends. This is one of the most expensive area in BA. There are a lot of brands like Channel, Louis Vitton, etc and some regular restaurants in the area.

Historic and architecturally interesting place. Church of Nuestra Señora del Pilar and other architecturally interesting buildings built by affluent families still stand in the neighborhood. Recoleta terrain wise, sits on one of the highest points in the city. One of the few cemeteries I've visited was also there which was quite impressive with carved massive natural stone. We had an English-speaking guide who took us around and of course we were taken to the famous shrine of Eva Peron. There are also good restaurants in the area one of which was one of the only few open on Christmas day, Lola.
Lovely upscale neighbourhood. Great overpriced stores, yummy ice cream at Freddo, and a quiet walk through the cementery (last part can be avoided or reduce to two minutes).
Great place to walk around. It's a great idea to visit Recoleta on any given Sunday, there will be people with their own stands, food and a lot of others just sitting around and having a good time.
Beautiful architecture and great shopping. Recoleta has great shopping. It is also a beautiful place to walk around. The cemetery is a must-see for any tourist.

Unbelievable. Do not miss this. It is truly unique. If you go with a group, be sure to pick a time and place to meet as you will never be able to stay together. Let yourself go in the moment, and don't forget your camera.

Visited frequently. From the cafes to the cemetary, this is definitely a place to visit. The tour of the cemetary was very sombering yet interesting to hear the history of the families there. The architecture is amazing, you can see the European influence. We were able to visit while the market was going on, and made some nice purchases from local artists. Visited a few of the cafes for coffee and lunch, and had excellent service. Usually went with the wait staff recommendation and were not dissappointed. It is a must see area when you visit BsAs.
Great neighborhood to explore.. The Recoleta is one of the safest neighborhoods to explore..lots of restaurants,BA Design Center, shopping & outdoor cafes.
A must. This is a fascinating cemetery quite unlike anything I’ve seen below. I ‘s well worth the visit. I thought it might be mawkish to see but it is not at all.

Stepping into the streets, cafes of Paris, in South America-------. Upscale neighborhood, beuatiful well appointed Cafes, with outdoor seating for many...Parks, Pedestrian walkways meandering through bucolic hilly, terrain, Also, Cultural center, and Design Stores in charming malls w/higher end shopping.....Belle Artes, great museum nearby, as well as the Recoleta Cemetery when Eva Peron is buried...Took a visit to her grave and laid flowers there....If energized stroll about 20 min. down the Ave., to new Museum, opened a few years ago...Similar to MOMA in NYC..."The Malba",,,,,,Beautifully architecturally designed....,
Amazing cemetery. A cemetery may seem like an odd place to visit, however the Recoleta cemetery will amaze you! Also some nice little cafes in the vicinity.

Charming area. We stayed at Recoleta, a nice, expensive and absolutely charming neighborhood. There are nice restaurants and some are not expensive. Impossible to miss the Empanadas at Sanjuanito restaurant (calle Posadas).

Like New York City, upper east side.. This is the safest, nicest, most beautiful part of Beunos Aires. Very posh and easy. But it is also the most expensive. There are bargains, but you have to look for them.

The city of the dead. The part of town is great, but the cemetery is the best. Nothing as you have ever seen before. Try to get there on tues- or thursdays. Then they have free tours at 11, in english.

An Informative Cemetery?. Who knew? Death can be interesting?
This mauselem has the bodies of families going back generations. Eva Perone is buried there and there is always a crowd walking around. Trust me on this one: Go, and plan to spend two hours.
Very charming neighborhood. A rich neighborhood of Buenos Aires, nice to walk and watch the real people from Buenos Aires.

Inspiring. No trip to Buenos Aires is complete without a trip to Recoleta. We love the area of town with all of the shops, restaurants, weekend market, but most of all the cemetary.We have been to the cememtary twice and have enjoyed both visits. It is an quiet and inspiring place. Well worth having a guide to show you around so you don't miss anything. Note that it can take a long time in the cemetary as it is so interesting you may forget you have other things to see.

This is the part of BA you will want to visit. Recoleta is where you will find the cemetary where Eva Peron is buried. It has a beatiful park with a 200 year old rubber try that was featured on the Amazing Race in February 2012.

Worth to spend a full day if you have the time. This is where the whealthy people lives. Lots of cafes, great farmer's market on the weekend (you can not miss) I highly recommend go to hotel Alvear and have some tea with pastries, I think they offer a special deal in the afternoon which is a great experience.The cemetery is also very well know because Eva Peron (Evita) is buried there.
Very Ornate Cemetery. Spend an hour or so wondering around. Lots of very ornate vaults and burial chambers. Some beautiful architecture.
Beautiful and great for shopping. Good place for a daily walk and for having lunch. Also the shops are nice.

Check out the cemetary, small park with crafts & tango street show.. The cemetery here is really cool to see and it's free. Just outside is a small park and craft show - happening just about every day. On busy days you might catch a tango street performance. It's a fun place to hang out and walk around. If you walk down the main street, you can see the fancy hotels and stores too.
Recoleta visited. Interesting, somewhat depressing. Good to get out and walk around the cemetery.Easy to walk there from downtown.

Outstanding Time. I took a guided tour of Recoleta and had the opportunity to visit the cemetery and a number of the churches. The architecture is beautiful and the history is extremely rich. I recommend taking a tour so that you can get a better feel for what you are seeing. There is an outdoor market on Saturdays where you can get handmade arts and crafts. There is also usually live music and even a puppet show.

Cemetary. Definitely worth a visit if in Buenos Aires. My college aged daughter and I found it fascinating. We enjoyed looking at the intricate details of many of the monuments. There are English tours, though we did not have time to take one. On the weekends there is a market featuring locally crafted items in the park nearby.

cementario. This is a definite highlight of Buenos Aires. The monuments range from the magnificent to the bizarre to the sad. The Evita monument is a stop but definitely underwhelming compared to many others. You can look into many of the monuments and see personal pictures and momentos.
Grave Yard & All. Visit to the graveyard is very interesting. Did not care for Buenos Aires Design, high priced home accessories.

Amazing. Wow, what an experience, who would have thought a cemetary would be so interesting, like a visit to a small village. With a private tour guide, learned interesting stores about some of the residents. Don't miss. It has more than Evita.
The closest to Paris and 5th Avenue NY in Buenas Aires. I would seriously consider retiring here. Absolute the center of wealth, culture and civility.
Recoleta Cemetry. Recoleta Cemetry is stunning.Look into some of the "Monuments" - the stianed glass is fabulous. Of course, one wants to see were Eva Peron is now at rest
good night life. We had a great steak and barbecue there.The ambiance of neighborhood is very good .Also these area is famous because of table dance and hot night clubs.
Very nice district. Walk around the posh district. Shop a little. Go to the cemetary. Little to some live music in the park and chill.

City in a city!. It is peaceful, tranquil and gives great insight into how wealthy the city was. Amazing architecture and so many "streets" and lanes to wander aruound and all for free. Of course Evita's resting place is a must...a simple yet emotive place to go....

Unremarkable (except for the cemetery). Coming from Sydney, Recoleta is just like another Double Bay with overpriced pretentious designer clothing. I prefer wearing jeans and t-shirts but "horses for courses" as they say.
However, Recoleta Cemetery is worth a visit to see Evita's grave.
Never Get Tired of the Shops. Fabulous shopping, walking and dining; a must see area.
Evita's tomb. Loved the neighborhood at the cemetery. Grounds are beautiful and majestic. After hunting down Evita's tomb, head over to the Buller Brewery.

You must visit Recoleta. Recoleta is a beautiful neighborhood in Buenos Aires with great restaurants, shops and most importantly with great history with Cemetery La Recoleta where Evita Peron is buried...you can also find a great craft market on the weekends with great things to buy...I can spend hours walking in Recoleta and never get bored...

The "paris" part of BA. BA is called the "Paris of South America," and we were a bit disappointed when...well...it's really nothing like Paris nor looks like it! We understood what they really meant when we walked around Recoleta, which actually IS like Paris (in many senses). Very nice neighborhood, very safe, and lots of expensive clothing shops and little stores.
Old cemetery in Buenos Aires. Interesting visit, not my style, but it seems that most people enjopy it. Our hotel was in front of the cemetery, so I had to at least take a look at it.
Lots to see. Beware of pick pockets when walking around. Otherwise, there is lots to see. Feel free to walk to other areas and have lunch at a local restaurant.

charming upscale area. The cemetery is a must see, of course. The fine arts museum is close by and worth going to and free! Lunch at Mondona, the Ferrari themed restaurant next to the museum, is pleasant and not expensive.

Vibey, historical and not to be missed. The cemetery is the obvious tourist attraction but Recoleta is much more-a great , genuine flea market outside the cemetery, wonderfully attractive avenues to amble down, a fancy mall if that's your thing on holiday, museums and monuments and beautiful spacious parks.

Loacation, Location. You will have a few good options in regards to accommodation while travelling to Buenos Aires. Recoleta in my opinion is a great place. Good restaurants and hotels. Close to the main attractions Buenos Aires has to offer.

Only Place to Stay. Recoleta is the only decent place to stay in Buenos Aires. We had heard that Palermo was nice, but we cut that stay short and moved to Recoleta. In Recoleta, the sidewalks aren't busted up like many other areas, and there's a a better feeling of safety. There are some amazing restaurants, especially under the bridge next to the Four Seasons.

Worth a Visit. Visiting cemeteries is usually not at the top of my list of things to do when on holiday but this one is an exception to the rule. Many of Argentina's rich and powerful people are buried here reminding one of the fact that a person's status in life is also immortalized in death.Some of the marble mausoleums are well-maintained architectural gems while others are badly damaged which begs the question of why this contrast exists.The entrance is free but a persistent woman will try to sell you a map which doesn't really add much useful information. However you should buy one if you want to do your small part in the ongoing renovation of the cemetary.

A walk in the park. Recoleta is the rather well to do area of Buenos Aires. Very well kept, great shopping, the Recoleta cemetary (Eva Peron (nee Duarte) is buried here), wonderful feria on weekends and La Biela coffee shop and resto bar. What's not to like.

Parisian. This is one of the most beautiful areas of Buenos Aires, and reminds me of parts of Paris: tree-lined streets, lovely cafes and eateries, close to major museums and generally accessible to the rest of the city.
If you like to see God in a box. Fascinating cemetery with elaborate crypts, more havering stone angels than you can count, and many feral cats. Unique.

Historical, Romantic and nice restaurants. Very famous for its Grave Yard and Weekend outdoor fairs, which offer handcrafts, food and antiques... but it's a lot more than that. The restaurants are really nice and the night life also great. There's a Hard Rock Cafe and also a top notch shopping center, whcih I think it's a bit expensive, as most of the shopping in Buenos Aires.Try to visiti it on Saturdays or Sundays, if yu can!
Pash neighborhood. Cemetery visit a must! The best collection of architecture of obelisks and mausoleums I ever saw

Interesting but weird. I've never visited a place where famous people are buried while I'm on vacation. Evita P. is buried there. Also, the architecture is very interesting. I would budget 1/2 hour for this activity.
The Dead. Well worth walking around this amazing village of mausoleums and monuments to the various rich and famous, including Eva Peron.

Plenty to see and do in the fashionable part of Buenos Aires. Walk through the parks, browse the fairs for trinkets, window shop the more expensive part of town and sit outside in one of the cafes with the jet set of Argentina and let your gaze wander from the 100 year old rubber trees in the green parks to the Recoleta Cemetery beyond.

Amazing history.. We took the 11:00 English tour on Thursday's (it's free) and really enjoyed the in depth information provided by our guide. There is so much information about the history of the cemetery that you cannot get from a guide book.

If you like to visit cemetaries, this is the best!. Well known for the burial place for Eva Peron, this cemetery is an afternoon full of history, architecture and amazement. Originally only the rich could be buried here so you will see above-ground mausoleums are huge and an architectural delight. Well cared for grounds.
Amazing place. The cemetery provides an insight to Argentine history & society, and the architecture was amazing. Definately worth a visit.
nice place, with beautiful shops and people. walk around and visit also the cemetery where Evita was placed.

enjoy the barrio. walking through this nice area, take the sun, admire the trees, see the exhibition in Le Palais de Glaces, drink a cafecito in La Biela, buy a pair of leather shoe to Claudia on Saturdays, etc.
Visit the cemetery and art fair. Saturday there is an art fair worth a visit. You'll find some good buys along with tango dancers and the nearby cemetery containing Eva Peron's grave. Worth a day.
Beautiful, peaceful and historic!. Love all the family crypts and "streets" to stroll in. Lots of feral cats.

Very nice and relaxed place in a busy city. If you spend more than a day in Buenos Aires, you should definitely check out this area. There are lots of nice little shops and outdoor cafes. All buildings are in very good conditions, and the area is very clean and has a relaxed and young vibe. The surrounding suburbs are quite busy and dirty and full-on, so this is a very welcome area of calm.
Nothing special. It's a nice neighborhood but I didn't see anything special about it! the cemetery is pretty neat though!

Tks ! Recoleta . The best area by LIZ Private Tour Guide. Hi. Following the comment of Laura M here I contact the private guide to go to Recoleta. http://www.lizflor2.blogspot.comIn half a day we visited an old Palais Glace , Cementery and all the beatiful buildings. Nice walking. Stop for a coffee relax and got local culture. Tks both L!

Buenos Aires at its most elegant. Don't expect mansions in this upscale barrio. Instead there are very well appointed "apartments" and stores to equal Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills. Expensive shopping opportunity. Good place to stay if you want this kind of environment. Recoleta Cemetery is where Evita is buried.

Mi Barrio. The past two years I have rented an apartment for the month of March in Recoleta. For me it is the ideal location from which to explore the rest of the city, as well as for its own attractions and services. Each block is a vertical "village" with all necessary services contained. And the weekend fair in summer in Plaza Francia is an enjoyable diversion. Several excellent museums are well within walking distance, and the Botanical Garden and Zoo are a short cab ride away.

The up and coming tourist spot. this area is a must see, for those of you that are eva peron fans, this is her final resting place at the recoleta cemetary, the area is pretty much a tourist destination, it is full of shops and hotels, you can find every type of entertainment in this location. Use common sense when out at night.
The cemeterio. The Recoleta cemeterio is one not to miss with its unique tombs and Evita's tomb.

Interesting architecture, shopping, and don't miss the cemetery.. We went to the area twice, once on Saturday, to see the craft market and art museum, and on Monday to tour the cemetery and do some window shopping. Easily accessible on the public transit.

Cemetery is worth a visit but he rest of the neighborhood?. The cemetery is fun. Lots of great monuments and interesting stories. We bought a map outside and walked on our own while reading information from our tour guide. I really couldn't see anything too great about the rest of Recoleta. Like elsewhere in BA, there is dog poop everywhere and broken tiles in all the sidewalks. Not a good way to walk around since you need to look down all the time.

Beautiful section of town. Of course you have to see Evita's grave in Recoletta otherwise where would you get to stand in really silly lines! In any case, the stores and restaurants nearby are terrific and well worth the price of admission (which is free of course).
Very ornate cemetery. Allow plenty of time to explore this historic and lovely cemetery. Refrain from purchasing the map...it's all in your guide book.
lovely area. beautiful palaces that now belong to Embassies and government building.. What a shame.. people that build it no longer can afford an upkeep

So much to do. There were so many restaurants and cafe choices in Recoleta and value for money was good provided you shopped around. There was also lots of shopping options with little boutiques and a large shopping centre.A highlight of this area was the cemeteary, it's so old and fascinating. Eva Peron is also here in a very understated musulium but quite fitting at the same time.This area is a must for all travelers to Buenos Aires.

Paris of the south. Recoleta is where BA gets it's reputation as Paris of the South. Beautiful architecture, expensive boutiques and stylish locals certainly support that reputation. The cemetary is one of BAs 'must sees' and the area as a whole is well worth an afternoon walking around.

Recoleta with a Local Guide is elegant, historical and lovely!. I went to Recoleta as all the bookguides say but I wanted to visit the Cementery specially.I got a local guide in town so it was a good idea as I got the atmosphere of the golden ages of Argentina when she explained all the building history around. Visit the Cementery with a local guide !!!! or you will only watch the Evita place and loose the art of this unique place. I can recommend her if you need www.lizfor2.blogspot.com
pretty area. Nice walking area with pretty buildings and trees. Loved the dog walkers! Ate lunch by the cemetery at La Biela, good people watching. Check out the Park Hyatt Hotel.

Terrific location. We rented an apartment in this district. Being close to many museums,walking distance to markets,restaurants and boutiques was a plus. We were 3 blocks from the famous cemetario and recoleta park (weekend craft show) highly recommend

Art that seeks to trascend mortal coils.. One of the most interesting cemeteries outside Pere Lachaise in Paris. In Recoleta, the wealthy have built their own necropolis full of outrageous, outlandish, creepy, on-your-face mausoleums that say "great in life, greater in death" Except that, as opposed to the great poets and musicians and scientists and actors and the homages to the heroes of the Resistance and the victims of the Holocaust and the Commune that you see in the Pere Lachaise, few of the ones buried in in Recoleta were really great, most were just wealthy people that built their wealth on the back of the working classes. Definitely worth a visit. Oh! And then there is Evita.
old fashioned. Used to be trendy, nowadays no longer.Streets are dirty and good restaurants flew away towards palermo.
Upmarket area of Buenos Aires. A few nice bars and restaurants to watch the world go by, or spend a long afternoon.

The best neighborhood of Buenos Aires. Recoleta is where Buenos Aires is more imponent and recalls Argentine glory days, with its beautiful buildings, palaces, cafes and stores. The famous Cemetery where Eva Peron was buried and the best shopping malls are located in Recoleta.
Interesting area. Great shops and buildings. Felt like we were in Paris and part of the area instead of a visitor
very scenic, calm, serene, expensive. calm and secenic. great but very expensive shopping.

Cemetary is an unusual way to spend a few hours. Wandering through the cemetary is like seeing the who's who of the Buenos Aires departed. Some of the statues are a bit creepy, but that adds to the fun.

Nice to chill and watch the world go by. This is a nice, upmarket part of Buenos Aires which is well worth a visit (or two). Take time to sit in any of the outside cafes and people watch - fascinating! Also, visit the Cemetery - what an interesting piece of history. The splendour and opulence of some of the graves and monuments are worth the visit alone. I recommend you purchase the guide to the graves - it's amazing what you'll find!!!I can't comment on the shopping as I don't shop when I'm on holiday but they looked very upmarket!
Nice and elegant area, good shopping market sunday morning. Really close to Casa Rosada, nice shopping area, elegant streets, good art craft sunday market.

Recoleta Cemetary is a must see. Check out this cemetary where the creme de la creme of Buenos Aires are buried. Evita Peron is in her family crypt. Look for her under Duarte, her maiden name. On weekends, there is a great outdoor market across the way from the cemetary. You can purchase some beautiful and high quality handmade crafts.
cemetery. We went there for the cemetery and we really liked it. We did not like the surrounding specially. But we can really recommend a walk through the graves.

Cemetery in the city and many food options. The cemetery is awesome and spooky all at the same time. It is absolutely worth the trip, I've never seen anything quite like this. People are still being buried there, which is hard to conceptualize as they seemingly are running out of space. Dining options seem to also be vast in this area.
The best neighborhood in Buenos Aires!. Great restaurants, upscale buildings, very clean streets, super parks, a great mall, walking distance to museums...anything else you wish?
Interesting and Beautiful. A huge cemetery in the middle of a city where famous and not so famous are buried. Some of the graves are magnificent and full of detail. Eva Perron is buried here.

Nice. A really very nice part of Buenos Aires. Good restaurants and shops. They have just reopened a redone shopping complex. Recoleta Shopping. Worth visiting--nice,trendy
stores and good cafeterias.
Worth a visit. We walked the cemetery with our guide, Chance Miller. Good way to see the highlights and notables buried there. I'm glad we went, and I'm glad we had Chance to show us around!
Creepily awesome. One of our best day visits out. Like something out of a gothic horror novel.
A piece of history!. A place you MUST visit when you're in Buenos Aires!
shop till you drop. neighborhood with plenty to shop and local coffee hot spots.
Wonderful. I love photographing statues in cemeteries to add to me art and this place was great.

The 'posh' part of Buenos Aires. Definitely the place to go for the architecture. Cleaner than other parts of BA, we walked around most of the streets. Found a lovely little restaurant full of locals - even got a waiter to explain some of the menu in English. Great shops, but expensive - mainly label boutiques (you need an empty credit card for here)

This recalls Montmartre and the Via Veneto. Great place to stay, walk, and shop.. Every major city has that grand old neighborhood that's held its luster, and in Buenos Aires this is it. Find a description of the neighborhood - including photos and restaurant recommendation - here: http://antonio1028.wordpress.com/2009/12/12/buenos-aires-first-impressions/
Recoleta Cemetery. Do not miss this while in BA. It is rich in history, politics, art and architecture. Spend a day or spend an hour. Don't just rush through to see Evita's Tomb.
Fun area. fun place to visit. Lots of nice shops and we felt safe and comfortable walking days and evenings

Very pretty. Recoleta was a nice place to visit and grab a bite to eat (albeit a slightly more expensive bite to eat). I was there in November and they had a pretty cool free jazz festival as well. The cemetery is interesting but we didn't spend much more than 20 minutes there. Not a bad place to visit in the evening either, quite a lot happening in the bars and restaurants.

Charmy!. One of the most charmy neighborhoods i've been. Full of restaurants, good hostels, sculptures and gardens everywhere.... The best is the cemetery, and also the handcraft market in front of it. At night, the best clubs and the bigger concentration of beautiful people in Buenos Aires. Unfortunately, it is also dangerous. Some people discovered that it is full of tourists and rich people.
Historic neighborhood. Historic neighborhood, where you can enjoy many different things

beautiful!. gorgeous neighborhood with lots of great boutique clothing stores. as a woman...i fell in love! we had a great time seeing all the performers at plaza francia, as well as eating the food from the vendors...very tasty! definitely stay here or in palermo hollywood.

An interesting neighborhood. The mall across from the cemetery, the home decorating and design mall which starts just past the cemetery and is partly underground and the neighborhood in general are quite interest. It does not have the charm of Palermo Soho (like Greenwich Village). More like the upper East side in NYC.

Traditional area of Buenos Aires. A good neighborhood in Buenos Aires, filled with restaurants and cafes, as well as cool bars and shopping.No subway though, at least on its most chic area. Shopping-wise, Recoleta has serious opportunities for fashionistas

Very good to have and Argentinian Barbacue. There are many small barbacue houses in Recoleta to chose from. If one intends to eat an Argentinian Barbacue, there is no mistake in any of these houses. In most of them the restaurant is divided in 2 parts. One indoor and the one outdoor. I usually prefer the outdoor unless it is cold, for I can also walk the people go by.

You'll think you're on 5th or Madison Avenues in NY. Elegant shops, fancy hotels, and beautiful condo units and apartment houses make up much of this area. Some good restaurants also are available and the area is relatively safe for walking around. Many banks also dot the area.
A must see district.. Elegant shops and architecture. The cemetary is a must-see

A truly unique cemetery. The extraordinary architecture and the density of history, culture and politics. Go early to avoid the EVITA vultures. This is so much more than Eva Peron's resting place. Take your time to examine the tombs. We had a great local guide to tell us the fascinating stories.

Recoletta a nice neighborhood. They have a market on Saturday and Sundays outside the cemetery. It is best to have a guide inside the cemetery as one of the main reasons is to see Eva Peron's crypt. Unless you walk the rows you may miss it.

a must see though overrated. We already visited this cemetary yeras ago early in the morning when there were no other visitors, just cats walking around, we were with a group and our tour guide could tell us an awfull lot of creepy stories which made it fun. This time we basically took pictures from the adjacent Pilar church where you can visit for 5 pesos a small exhibition on the first floor and you have different views of toombs from above.The neighbourhood is indeed a bit more chic and clean then other parts of BA.

Recoleta. Recoleta is the wealthy area of Buenos Aires. The stores are pretty expensive but it is fun to walk around. The Recoleta market is fun to go to on Sunday (or maybe it was Saturday). The market is near the Recoleta cemetary where Evita was buried. That is an interesting place to go to and would recommend walking around the cemetary
stunning cemetery. this is such a lovely place to visit and do not miss Evita's tomb!
Where else would you visit a cemetary ? Do visit in Buenos Aires, you won't regret. Different ! You can easily spend hours if you want to see everything different here.
Loved it. We liked the area a lot. Never visited the graveyard, but my husband did and he was impressed. Nice strolls, Close to Marcelo T. Alvear Avenue, which reminded me of Paris
Creepy!. Something very unsettling about seeing people line up to take pictures with a grave site.(Referring to Evita)
very nice. a great way to spend an afternoon. very pretty and interesting

One of the few "clean" neighborhoods in BA. We explored a lot of BA in our 6 days there, and one of the lasting impressions of the city is how dirty and unkept many, if not most of the streets were. Recoleta and Palermo are the two exceptions, and have a definite "upscale" feel compared to most other neighborhoods. Be sure to try and hit the Recoleta open market on Saturdays outside the cemetery!

Dont miss it. Nice cafes to go during the day , with tables outside like Paris , and also good restaurants to go in the evening for dinner . Great ice cream places . Go to recoleta cementery ,very interesting
a must see. Take a tour, then spend as much time as you like roaming the grounds, peering into the mausoleums. and soaking up Argentine customs. An absolute (and somewhat creepy) must see.

Historic and interesting. The location was adjacent to a park and a street market, which was interesting. Some of the mausoleums were quite old and in disrepair, while the more recent ones were elaborate.

The right place to be in BA. My wife, after much research, settled on renting an apartment in Recoleta. In fact we had a view of the famous Recoleta Cemetery from our balcony.This is a lively part of town. Aside from the usual attractions that any guide book can tell you about ... we were entertained by a market and fair on the weekends, musical concerts during the week. And Portenios (BA residents) are not half hearted about participating ... they turn out in droves. They are fun loving people.While other parts of BA can feel a bit sketchy at night (I don't know that they are but they feel that way) Recoleta does not. BA is recovering from it's financial crisis of a decade ago; in Recoleta the evidence is that the recovery is well under way. New hotels and apartments plus the new Recoleta mall (BA doesn't do Walmart type malls ... they are all high end places).Recoleta is also well placed for getting around the rest of BA too. $10 or so will get you to San Telmo, or the weekend Gaucho Festival in Mataderos (well worth a visit ... it is really for locals ... doesn't run in the summer months ... its huge), La Boca, el centro etc.There are lots of nice places to eat from corner kiosks, family style carnavore's dreams, to finer dining. Recoleta is an upper middle class neighborhood and has all the niceties. My wife tells me the shopping is also very good (something I don't have the right chromosomes to understand).All in all one can not go far wrong basing their stay in BA from Recoleta. It is a very nice area, the prices are very good (but not bargain basement). We stayed 2 weeks the apartment was about $50 a night (by the week). There were many modern grocery stores (Carrafour sp?).Enjoy B
Lugar unico!!. Come and see this small place in this great city, fun history, good food, great disco dances club, simple, come

Strange place. This place is really bizarr, it is like a small city of the dead. It is fascinating but also a bit sad to see so much resources has been used making mausoleums for the dead.Personally i don´t like the concept, but it is certainly a must see in Buenos Aires.
Interesting. Cool pathways between towering crypts - well worth a couple of hours wandering

Cemetery and Church / Museum a must. The Basilica Nuestra Senora del Pillar is absolutely stunning inside - the simple white facade is deceiving. Take it all in though when you are there are pictures are not allowed and finding a post card of the inside is nearly impossible. If you time it right, you can hear Mass with beautiful Gregorian chants (just please remember to be respectful of those attending if you are not staying for the whole service).On the left, about half way down the church, there is a small entrance to the Cloister Museum (Claustros Historicos del Pillar). Admission is well worth the 5 pesos. The building is the original cloister of the monks and today holds various objects from the history of the church. If you're lucky, one of the attendants may be kind enough to give you an impromptu tour. You can overlook the cemetery.I never thought a cemetery would be a must see attraction, and this is one you have to see for yourself. Just to put it in perspective, we spent 2 hours and maybe covered 1/3 of it. Bring your camera!Lastly, if you visit on a Sunday or holiday, the fair has some interesting items for sale - from photographs and hand-painted shoes to pottery and other crafts.
Cemetery is a must see!. Great upscale shopping and a fantastic design center, but come here for the cemetery tour. English tours were Monday and Thursdays at 11am when I was there.
A must see in Buenos Aires. This a very nice area and we walked all around the neighborhood. The cemetery is of course the main attraction, specifically Evita Peron's mausoleum.

A big nice surprise. During2011 I travelled through South America. I started in Colombia (+/- ok), then Ecuador (not cool), Peru (machu pichu very nice, but Lima is not nice at all), Chile (++ very nice). Finally I got to Argentina. Travelled from Iguazu all the way to B.A.I must say that of all the places I have visited, this is bay far the best, just fantastic, and the Iguazu Falls, ohh!.Here I found everything I like and need. I went to a restaurant bar called Million wow!, very nice, nice people, nice music. The building remind me Prag. So I'm out all that long, love to walk. Have to say some buildings are so beautiful. Some times I feel that I am in Rome or Paris.The cafes look like European, some times I feel I'm not in Latin America if you know what i mean.Also Recoleta and all the city is so modern. There is free wife everywhere, even in the tube!. So about Recoleta, I've tried some nice restaurants and some bad ones. By far the best was the Argentinean cuisine. Stake my friends! the best and also the cheapest, can you believe that!So Recoleta has it all, Museums, Mall, art fairs and the beautiful cemetery. Finally I want to say that of all the places I have visited this is what I liked most. Honestly I'm thinking about quitting my job and move to Recoleta Argentina
The Best. Great architecture, cool feria in Plaza Francia, and super safe. Stay here if possible!

You can find everything walking some streets. I disliked the lies that the restaurants tell you at the entrance. normally they promisse prices that they won`t respect. Always have something more. But the neighborhood is wonderfull. You have good shopping onthe streets nearby and It has a brend new shopping mall just at the corner of junin and the cemitery. You can pick up a bus to anywhere you want and the taxi is expensive but Recoleta is not too far from some attractions. You can go walking to some of them.

Pleasant place. Nice buildings, nice plaza, wonderful trees! Very pleasant of seat outside the Freddo place in front of the handcraft fair - feria de artesanos - at Plaza Francia. It is a little more crowd than I would like, but it is real nice. Some people will dance tango on the plaza, some people will play accordion. the artisans expose their work and everything is very cheap.

Worthwhile. Like most tourists, I went to see Evita's grave. It was interesting to see how wealthy people lived in palaces while alive and then tried to build themselves elegant crypts for their corpses. It was a small city of crypts.
So Clean. So Clean and with wonderful happy people and great food and of couse the Malbec
Historical and A Must Visit Area. Simply stated in this title. You can't miss this are while in BA. Don't miss the famous cemetery...unbelievably a beautiful place to visit.

Perfect. We sat at the corner bar, La Biela, and had a tabla, wine and good conversation. It was a perfect Friday evening. We first walked around the cemetery and stores before relaxing with wine. Great people watching and a true sense of the relaxed pace of Argentina in the city.

A part of Buenos Aires history.. While in the Recoleta area, the Recoleta Cemetary is an interesting way to spend a couple of hours when visiting Buenos Aires. Free to the public (but watch out for people who will stop you at the bottom of the entrance step, giving you a map, telling you about the cemetary and then asking for money in exchange for thier information) this very old cemetary holds the mausoleums of many notible Argentinians such as Eva Peron and The Duarte family. The beautiful stone sculptures that adorn the crypts are very impressive, some are perfectly maintained, others are in various states of demise. The crypts line each side of the many streets that make up the cemetary, giving it a city within a city feel.
Fashionable Neighborhood. We liked the park-lined areas of Recoleta, obviously one of the nicest areas of Buenos Aires in which to live. Fine shops, nice housing, and just a wonderful feel.
The Cemetery. Opulence of the highest form. Worth the visit. Evita is here.
Recoleta. Mildly interesting tour of cemetery for the wealthy.

You will not believe this site!. I thought everyone went to see Evita's tomb but that is a minor attraction in this amazing cemetery. The architecture is wonderful;you will NOT have seen the like of this anywhere.
Don't miss Recoletta. Amazing monuments to the dead of BA. Quite mind boggling follies.
Fascinating. It may be the dead but it is the history of Buenos Aires. A guide is a distinct advantage, though expensive.

Historical Cemetery in Recoleta. Not to be missed.....this was not just a cemetery, but a museum with beautiful mausoleums. Each family quite prominent and displaying their own artistic looks. The La Recoleta Cemetery dates back to the 1800's. It is also where Eva Peron (Evita) is buried, but her's is just one of many to see.
London's Mayfair. Worth a visit if only to see the Mausoleum of Eva Peron. Lovely shops, interesting architecture and nice places to eat outside
Sounds morbid, but the cemetry is worth a visit. Take a local guide with you who can explain the history and politics as you wander through the cemetry. Really fascinating place.

A great area for a walk. This is the area with great restaurants, elegant shops, a large park with huge trees, the famous Recoleta Cemetary where Argentina's most famous are buried (Eva Peron, among them) and the adjacent early 18th century elegant church.
