I'm Bias, but Recoleta is terrific!. We have been staying in Recoleta for the past month of a two month stay and have been impressed with this neighborhood in Buenos Aires. The tree-lined streets and residential feel (many apartments) makes Recoleta a good choice for visitors. The attractions such as the Cemetary, Art Museums, and park spaces give it lots of appeal. You'll be safe in most parts of Recoleta, too.

Reminds me of Europe. This is the "richer" area of the city, and much was designed by architects and garden planners from Paris, and the similarities are obvious. If you go, be sure to visit the Cemetery and sit in one of the parks in the late afternoon.
a must. If you're on BA you need to see Caminito street in La Boca.Sure it's touristy, but chances are if you're in BA and reading tripadvisor you are a tourist.
Tea and Sympathy. We walked around the cemetary and then went to tea at the Alvear palace. A perfect afternoon!

Makes For a Relaxing Day. Take a break from heavy-duty touring and spend the afternoon strolling through the cemetary and nearby. There are many cafes and retaurants, some with outdoor dining optons Not sure how often the "art fair" type of market is going on but that makes it all the more pleasant.

The fancies neighborhood in Buenos Aires. This is a great neighborhood with nice shops ranging from reasonably priced to designer stores that are not so reasonably priced. There are some good restaurants but the ones across from the cemetery are questionable. The cemetery is a must see. I have never seen such a fancy cemetery.

Weekend artesian fair. This type of fairs are everywhere in Buenos Aires but this one really was fun because of the surroundings. We walked around and enjoyed the historical buildings and monuments , the fair was like dessert after a great meal.
It's ok. It's interesting to go there and see the cemetery. It's different from what we are use to.
Quite a Unique and Interesting Cemetary. Best to have a guide (live or written) so you can better understand what you are seeing, the history, and how it all works.

City of the Dead. It is like a little town with streets, instead of having buildings there are musoleums containing bodies and ashes of whole families/and or individuals. If you go to Recoleta by Subte you will have a nice long walk through the neighborhood, which is full of good restaurants and interesting stores, with tree-lined streets. Very nice!!!

A safe area inwhich to stay in BA. The cemetario is totally unique and not to be missed (includes the tomb of Argentinas beloved Eva Peron). Plenty of restaurants and park areas. We stayed nearby the cemetery which makes for a long walk (8 blocks) to the Subte (Metro).
Upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Recoleta is an upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires with expensive homes, shopping and restaurants.
Death by tourism. Very Latin Attitudes to death, combined with someone feeding the stray cats

Good central place to stay. Noisy but incredibly convenient central location in which to base yourself. Some nice boutiques and pretty French-style buildings in this neighbourhood. Hard to find outdoor cafés not on very busy streets. Nice park at the end of Quintana with amazing old and huge trees. Across from Recoleta cemetary. Spend a 1/2 looking around this neighbourhood.

Loved it - felt at home. Stayed for ten days, loved every minute … don’t say noisy: say vibrant! Nice people, from the “Havana” at Pueyrredon and French who served great breakfast (even at eight PM), to the staff of the nearby “Cotto” supermarket, to Marc (the Montreal snowbird) working at the gourmet store down the road, to Sr. Szmid maker of wonderful ceramics, Oksana Soroka who paints great Buenos Aires streetscapes and the skilled, intelligent, ironic jewelry designer Mazzaro … cannot forget Sasha the Ukrainian tango watercolor artist at the weekly arts and crafts fair down at Av. Libertador.Forget about ice cream from “Freddo”, the chain, go to the artisanal “El Fundador”: it is better, more natural and cheaper.When I go back, I know where I am staying!

Love the neighborhood. This lively tourist area is worth seeing. The vibrant colors and energy are engaging. Definitely buy a fresh juga de naranja from the local vendor. Nothing as good as a fresh glass of orange juice on a hot day.
A Great Place for a Stroll. Walking down the tree-lined streets of Recoleta is a favorite of mine. It is a great place to feel the vibe of BA.

Lovely place to hang out. This is one of my favorite spots in Buenos Aires. any day/time is nice to take a nice stroll through the park, get into the Iglesia del Pilar, one of the oldest in town (from 1700), have a cofee at La Biela under that ancient tree, have an icecream or just seat to watch the local market on Saturdays and Sundays. The cemetery needs a separate review but it's also worth it!
Worth the visit for sure. We loved Recoleta, it was our favourite part of BA. If you are there, you must go.
Good neigborhood. Interesting cementary and other sites like museums, shopping and lots of good restaurants

Beautiful neighbourhood. Recoleta is one of those upscale Buenos Aires neighbourhoods that lends itself for a nice stroll. The Recoleta Cemetery and all the buildings surrounding it are well worth a visit. Here are some photos from my visit to La Recoleta: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10150389630991091.349380.300778126090&type=3

Recoleta Cemetery. Fascinating cemetery in the Recoleta area. Easy to navigate and full of Argentine history. Beautiful sculpture abounds. Don't go if seeing caskets on shelves of crypts bothers you.....

Stay in Recoleta (believe me). I rented an apartment in this neighborhood and was very conveniently located, very centrical for tourism. I moved around the city very easily and it's a safe place at night. Lots of shops, restaurants, cafes, and not far from Corrientes. At night I could hop on a bus and go to Palermo in just 1o minutes.
Awesome. Even if you only go to Buenos Aires just to see Recoleta; it would be more than worthwhile. One day was simply not enough.

A nice, pretty neighborhood in the heart of a metropolis. Recoleta is a nice break from the bustling city. Several wide open spaces keep the neighborhood friendly and free from traffic. A stroll up embassy row, and into the opulent hotels and stores, is also a pleasant experience.
Excelent ride. beautiful and charming neighborhood with shops, great restaurants, the famous cemetery and a new Shopping Center to go.
Best Cemetary Ever!. Forget searching for Eva Paron's tomb, this cemetary is so much more interesting than just seeing her final resting place! This is the coolest cemetary I have ever seen!

Thiefs. Be prepared to be robbed in Buenos Aires. Do not respond if you think you have been hit by pigeon dirt or similar when walking as it is most likely a distraction to enable thiefs to steal your wallet or rob you of jewellery. We were robbed and would not have realised for hours after had the thiefs not throw the wallet back at us in the street, having taken it from my husband's backpack, when 'helping' us clean up after dirt fell on us from a tree.
2nd Trip and would go again. Beautiful cemetary with lots of history, architecture and ambiance

Beautiful neighborhood. Beautiful neighborhood with nice buildings, old palaces and wonderful branded and luxury stores. Don't miss an afternoon coffee/tea at Palacio Duhau (Park Hyatt) or at the Four Seasons - two beautiful properties. Do not miss Posada street, Patio Woolrich and Arroyo street just with Art Galleries.
Nice spotting. A nice place to stay in Buenos Aires. Easy for a walk, restaurants nearby, bars, history.
Upscale neighbourhood. Very nice and trendy. Reminds me a bit of some New York upscale areas

Very nice district. Recoleta means : beautiful buildings, well-dressed people and nice restaurants. Go there on the Sunday morning and visit the Recoleta Market in front of Recoleta Cemetery. You can find there handicrafts like leather bags, clothes, gifts, photo frames, jewellery etc. And for the cemetery: Go there and visit the graves of rich& famous people. It is really interesting.
Lovely afternoon. The cemetery while being noted for Evita being buried there is actually a marvelous collection of mausolins butted up to each other. Great narrow passageways, terriffic phot opts.

Interesting and beautiful. This cemetery is very interesting and has beautiful mausoleums. It includes a visit to the Evita's grave, but having a personal guide helps to maneuver this large place. Good visit.
Def good area to stay and spend time. Beautiful area with green squares, nice delis and grand buildings.
Love BA and feel save in Recoleta. Can walk or talke a short taxi ride to most places

BA's Best Area. This is where the museums are and some very nice cafe's.
Easy bus rides around too. Walking is pleasurable, especially ambling in and out of the Alvear Hotel. Or stay and have some tea.
Gorgeous and elegant. A cosmopolitan area with wonderful things to do, places to shop, eat, and stay. Do visit.
The best area in Buenos Aires. This is the nicest area in Buenos Aires, green, luxurious and with many restaurants.

Little Paris. Walk to the park where there are artists showing on Saturday. Watch the tango dancers, and they want many put in the hat to show your appreciation. Go toEl Sanjuanino on Posadas for empinadas, Go to Olivieras for fish Ferreros for dinner

Upmarket and fun!. Saturdays or Sundays are great in Recoleta- the markets are fantastic!
There are lots and lots of expensive shops and it is surprisingly very residential with lots of apartments towering over. nice restaurants, but be prepared to pay higher prices on everything!
Beautiful area and cemetary. I just loved the Recoleta neighborhood, and the cemetary is haunting and beautiful.....just wander around and absorb the history......

Out of Fashion. Recoleta has been one of the most exciting tourist and BA. With the emergence of Palermo, Puerto Madero and other locations, the Recoleta is now going through a restructuring. At the moment is still visited by the Cemetery and some traditional restaurants that remain in place.

Pleasant place to walk.... Recoleta is a charming district of Buenos Aires, you can go there walking (if you are a good walker) or by a fast taxi ride. There are a lot of bars, coffee shops, restaurants, fancy shops and so on. It is a nice place to walk and see the architecture of new buildings. There is too the Museu Nacional de Belas Artes, which is very good, with a big and good collection of art. Tip: be aware of opening times of museum, on week days it only opens after noon (we were there in the morning and could not go in...)
Nice neighborhood. Very safe neighborhood - good for wondering around

Truly Astonishing. The mausoleums, the statuary and the sculptures are breath -taking in their scope and variety. To really appreciate Recoleta would take more time than our group was given. We were there about an hour, at least half a day is needed to take it all in.
fun area to walk around. defintely a nice area to explore and we felt entirely safe. lots of shopping. and of course the cemetary.

best district in buenos aires. bohemian and rich.a beautiful place to stroll around and have a nice helado,ice cream,maybe in fredos in front of la recoleta cemetary. all the luxury boutiques (what s left of them:) and the best hotels are situated in this area. like a mixture of some parisian and berlin fin de siecle streets. definitely the place to be for upscale restaurants and safe hotels ! dont miss on having a look at the gorgeous french embassy and the patio bullrich shopping...the best in the country !
Well worth seeing.. Very interesting cemetery, worth your time. Fantastic location for photography, just be aware it closes just as the golden hour starts.

nice area to visit only in the day. Recoleta is a cute area where there are open market shops on saturdays and its where the famous cemetery is ... Eva Peron is buried here... our hotel concierge advised against visiting this area at night... street walkers at night... but very safe in the day!
Cosy area!. Just oposite the cementary you will find a lot of small outside cafes. When hot - take something cold to drink and relax. Outside the cementary there is also a big marked.

The best area in Buenos Aires. It's absolutely the best area in Buenos Aires. We feel very safe in Recoleta. It has so many beautiful buildings and it has a European feel and look when walking along the streets in this area. I would recommend anyone who is visiting Buenos Aires to stay or at least visit the area. It's also very green and very clean. It has so many nice restaurants in the area and also shopping places. We walked all the way from Recoleta Cemetery to Florida street and enjoyed it!

Priceless. The most exclusive and beautiful area in Buenos Aires not to be missed. If you cannot afford staying in beautiful and safe La Recoleta district, please take at least one or two days to stroll along its parisian style avenues, and enjoy all the attractions it offers: Plaza Francia, Terrazas del Design, the brand new Recoleta Mall, Junin and Vicente Lopez streets and their lively open air bars and restaurants The remodelled Emilio Mitre Square on Las Heras Av., boasts a picture-perfect gotic construction (actually a University). Just accross the street you will find Plaza Barrientos with many good and quite affordable options for inddoor or outdoor dining..
We visited 4 times, and still didn't see it all. What a wonderful place, so interesting. It would be good to take a tour. We visited 4 times, and still didn't see the entire site.
Wonderful neighbourhood. Better place to walk in B.A. Visit recoleta cemetery and do a little shop than just relax and drink a good wine at any resto or bar.

Fascinating Upscale neighborhood. Imagine every street being a mixture of upper 5th Avenue (NYC) and the shops from lower 5th or Madison, but with 1/10th the traffic of NYC. An absolutely charming neighborhood to walk around. All I could think about was that if Mrs. NJ-Eric had been on this trip she could have spent a month shopping here quite happily. Others have talked about this reminding them of Paris. It reminded me of the best part of New York.
Ricoleto. Definitely the place to stay. Close to everything by cab. Paris atmosphere. Good places to eat. Great place to stroll and safe at night.

If you live architecture, stay here. Close to all the great sight to see or a $5 cab ride. Clean streets, walk around. Stay off the big bulevards. Loved streets around algodon palace. Montevideo. Nice shops, loved tea connection. Colon theatre was outstanding too!

Have a walk around the neighbourhood. Whilst the cemetery is the prime attraction here, I would still recommend a walk around the neighbourhood, where you'll find some fairly well-heeled parks and streets with decent cafes and restaurants. We tried the Rodi Bar and indulged in the lunchtime specials, before sampling all the beers at Bullers. Yes, San Telmo and Palermo may be slightly better. But don't overlook Recoleta.

Too Much Fuss. Cemetary Good Though.. I don't really see why people like this as a neighborhood. I thought San Telmo and Palermo were much better as neighborhoods to walk through. Recoleta was overpriced and very touristy. They cemetary is unique, though, with huge ornate houses as tombs of what I assume to be rich dead people. So for that it's fine. But for strolling, finding great cafes, and people watching, stick to Palermo and San Telmo.

Check out La Biela Cafe/Cemetery Tour Worth it. One of the most famous and historic cafes is in Recoleta, LaBiela www.labiela.com It is on the historic register, and is across the street from the cemetery. R Duvall is known to go there. Also good is a heavenly cappucuino shake at Freddo Ice Cream, it has coffee, dulce de leche ice cream and milk in it and is divine, worth the 18 pesos! If you do the cemetery, get a tour, it's worth it to learn about the symbolism/history, and they will show you the best sculptures/graves. Love cats? Bring some cat food for the kitties there. If you go in just to see Evita, then leave you are missing out big time. Fredwww.silverstarcar.com
The South American Paris. This neighborhood can occupy for hours -- shopping, cafes, tree lined streets, old palacios. Always bustling. Great street fair outside Recoleta Cemetary on Saturday.

Recoleta: Walk it and find it--BA not Paris. We rented an apartment in Recoleta. In the three months spent in Argentina, other than at Llau Llau, it was the most comfortable area of our trip. I would recommend a Cafe and Resto called Syrop or something to that effect. There is the cafe and the full restaurant and both are charming and of very high quality. They both offer a nice break from parrilla. As for shopping in Recoleta, I would stay away from the tourist-driven places around the cemetery although there are some nice outdoor cafes for checking out the locals. Guido is a shoe store in the area that offers very high quality traditional shoes for men and women that are worth checking out. BA is not Paris. It is BA. Be careful of the criminals. I had my watch ripped off of my hand in broad daylight from a cafe in Palermo. However, it is an amazingly diverse country offering the traveler everything.

Most beautiful and safe neighborhood in Buenos Aires. We rented an apartment for a month in Recoleta, and we absolutely loved the experience. Recoleta is one of the safest zones in Buenos Aires. You can see policemen guarding all around this neighborhood, so you can feel safe walking around the area. It is filled with clothing stores, shoes stores, restaurants, cafes, pubs, and some clubs. The architectures is very colonial and antique, which makes it a beautiful zone. Everything is quite close within minutes of walking. The Recoleta cemmetery is located here, which makes it one of the best attractions of the zone. There is always something great to do in Recoleta! I definitely recommend visiting this neighborhood of Buenos Aires!

Wonderful!!!. Recoleta is a wonderful part of Buenos Aires...On weekends, there is an outdoor market filled with things to but...Aside form that, you'll find Cemeterio de la Recoleta and Iglesia del Pilar right there...They have wonderful restaurants in the area...For example, two of my favorites were Pane y Vino & Locos X el Fulbol...The best pasta I had in Buenos Aires was at Pane y Vino...And the best crepes were in Locos X el Futbol...Wonderful area...They also have nightclubs there...

Recoleta with children. We enjoyed Buenos Aires and Recoleta with our two boys aged 8 and 11 years in May 2006, staying at the Hotel Ulisses. Recoleta is a pretty and safe area of BA, with European-style architecture. The district has lots of parkside restaurants and cafes (even a McDonalds in the shopping mall) and many serve international cuisine if your digestion needs a break from beef, beef, and more beef! English was commonly spoken, so ordering was a breeze for those of us without Spanish. The Recoleta weekend markets were great fun, lots of talented street artists, buskers and mimes who really engaged the children and the adults. The markets are adjacent to the famous Recoleta cemetery, where Evita and many notable Argentinians are interred. We bought sme local handcrafts, ponchos, musical instruments and there were also t-shirts and the usual tourist items.The kids had a couple of sessions playing online computer games at an internet cafe, but mainly enjoyed the freedom to let off some steam playing football in the parks near the hotel, away from the bustling city centre, which is about a 20 minute stroll away. Taxis are cheap and plentiful, but beware the counterfeit currency scamsters and note the drivers' ID (hanging over the back of his seat, or be extra vigilant if it is not present.A few days in BA with children can be enjoyed with a trip to the opera house, a visit to the famous Teatro Colon, but we were glad to break our stay with travel outside the city.We loved our three days in Colonia del Sacramento - a 40 minute ferry ride to Uruguay across the River Plata. The highlight, though, was a toss up between a couple of days at aworking gaucho ranch, Estancia El Ombu an hour or two north of BA and the fabulous Iguazu Falls. If you're lucky, they'll be running the full moon tour of the falls, but dress warmly!A boat ride up the River Tigre delta was an OK diversion, but I wish we'd known about the huge amusement park nearby, as we would have interrupted the tour there for some theme-park exploration.We also visited the home of tango, La Bocca, whcih can apparently be a bit dangerous at night. Unfortunately, we found it pretty bland on a midweek daytime visit, though.There is very upmarket shopping in the Recoleta district, with a reasonable sizes shopping mall for essentials. Try the Palermo for more variety, including a shopping mall mini amusement area with video games and mini bumper cars for kids.All in all, a bustling city to visit with children for a few days, but definitely improved by the more tranquil surroundings of the Recoleta district.
